Nearly 20 years after a real estate tycoon was shot to death in front of his Upper East Side apartment by a hit man in a Hollywood-style contract killing, the woman who prosecutors said was behind the plot received her punishment on Friday. Barbara Kogan, who was going through a bitter divorce from the tycoon, George H. Kogan, at the time of the killing, was sentenced to 12 to 36 years in prison after a hearing in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. She had agreed to the sentence in April when she pleaded guilty to manslaughter.

While researching hotels for a recent trip to Italy, I found that several places offered discounts if you paid in cash. They were mostly smaller hotels, and they offered discounts of 6 to 10 percent, on average. The savings aren't enormous by any means -- but they can easily add up to the cost of a nice dinner. ''I find that anywhere in Europe small hotels, guest houses, and B&B's often prefer cash,'' said Rick Steves, the travel expert. ''Any tourist can ask if there's a cash discount, and often give their hotel an excuse to discount the rate.''

As BP continues to struggle to plug the leak at the bottom of the sea, the president tries to convince the country that he is on top of the crisis, and the first oil laps the coasts of previously untouched states, Americans far from the gulf are feeling touched by the disaster. A sampling: * Wyoming: An 'Oil City' Fears for Its Future * Washington: Grief After Another Kind of Oil Disaster * New England: Fishermen Watch From Far Away * Protest: Environmental Groups Call for Alternative Energy

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about two church groups in Afghanistan that were ordered suspended by the government over suspicions that they were proselytizing misidentified, in some editions, the group with an $8 million annual budget and misstated the affiliation of an official. The budget is for Norwegian Church Aid, not Church World Service, and Liv Snesrud is program coordinator for Norwegian Church Aid, not Church World Service.

For a few short moments, a breath of life pushed through the lungs of a steam whistle that once gave a loud presence to the Normandie, the French luxury liner that was known as the fastest, most fashionable way to get to Europe in the 1930s. In billows of creamy steam and a throaty honk, the ship's ghost rose audibly 75 years to the day of its first arrival in New York harbor, when tens of thousands of New Yorkers lined the waterfront of Lower Manhattan to see the 1,029-foot, 83,423 ton vessel glide toward the 48th Street pier. It was fresh from victory at sea, having traveled from France in a record-breaking 4 days, 11 hours and 33 minutes, earning it a blue pennant that waved from the topmast to signal to other ships that it was the fastest of them all.

MARIBOR, Slovenia -- Roam the mountains and vineyards of Slovenia, and its citizens and soccer players will regularly remind a foreign visitor of two verities. This is not Slovakia (a very touchy subject).

WALSH--Rosemary Hammill, of Bronx, NY. Passed away, on June 3, 2010, at age 84. Beloved daughter of the late Nicholas F. and Marguerite H. Walsh. Dear sister of Elizabeth F. Walsh, and Grail W. Kearney, and the late Thomas H., John H., Margaret Mary, Eugene A., Nicholas F. Jr., and Francis X. Walsh. Cherished Aunt, Grand Aunt, and Great-Grand Aunt. Reposing at Williams Funeral Home, Inc. 5628 Broadway, Bronx, NY, Friday June 4, 2010 from 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday June 5, 2010 at 10:45am, St. John's RC Church, Kingsbridge Ave., Bronx, NY. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

A picture caption this weekend with the article about five of the nine cities hosting the World Cup in South Africa misspells the given name of one of the residents reporting on their favorite haunts. She is Almi Simpson, as the article correctly notes, not Almie.

EMBLER--Edith (nee Smith), passed June 2, 2010 peacefully and surrounded by loved ones. Beloved husband of Tom, sister of Virginia, mother of Mike and Maura, mother-in-law of Maria and Rick, grandmother of Ricky, Ryan, Tara, Shay and Keira, sister-in-law of Richard, Maureen, Peggy, Bob, Ellie, Don and Debbie. Retired Executive Director of the Huntington Housing Authority, former president of Huntington League of Women Voters, director of Brookhaven and Suffolk County chapters of League of Women Voters. Former elected trustee of Northport-East Northport Library Board. Former active parishioner of St. Anthony of Padua of East Northport. Active parishioner of St. Francis Cabrini of Coram. Member of Society of St. Vincent de Paul. Avid reader, traveler, figure skating fan. Visitation Marinello Funeral Home, 493 Middle Country Road, Coram Saturday June 5, 7-9pm and Sunday June 6, 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass, 10:30am Monday June 7, St. Francis Cabrini Church, 134 Middle Country Road, Coram. Private cremation. Donations requested in lieu of flowers to Society of Saint Vincent de Paul, St. Francis Cabrini Conference, 134 Middle Country Rd., Coram, NY 11727. She cared deeply and is already sorely missed.

WEISHOFF--Dr. Henry "Hank", DDS. The loving husband of Bernice. Served his country as a Captain in the Air Corps, practiced on the West Side of Manhattan for over 55 years counting as his patients New York athletic teams and much of the Broadway community. He leaves his devoted sons and their wives, Robert and Carol, Steven and Marla, Daniel and Christine. Also his adoring grandchildren George, Bart, Andrea, Diana, Rachel, Danielle and Nicole, and the great-grandchildren. "He was always there." He will be sorely missed. It will be very quiet. Services at "The Riverside", Monday, June 7, 11am.
EBERT--Stanley. Stan's melodies will linger forever in our hearts and minds. Condolences to Marion and family. Gloria and Jerry Z.

In response to my colleague Tara Siegel Bernard's recent post on the best places to store down payment money for a home, a reader commented with a tip that we thought was worth sharing. Here is the suggestion from reader 3 Munchkins of New York: ''Ally Bank has had the best F.D.I.C.-insured product out there for months. Get a 60-month C.D. that pays just under 3 percent. Cancel anytime and pay penalty equal to 2 months of interest. Do the math; you're still better off than earning 1 percent in a 1-year C.D.''

9 P.M. (Starz) DISTRICT 9 (2009) After a giant spacecraft stalls over Johannesburg, its inhabitants are placed in a squalid refugee camp, where they live for the next 20 years. Despite evidence that they are members of an advanced civilization, they are looked down upon by South Africans of all races and subjected to a heinous agenda of corporate greed in a program overseen by an executive played by Sharlto Copley, above. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said of this ''smart, swift'' film from Neill Blomkamp: ''Not that the metaphorical resonances of 'District 9' aren't rich and thought provoking. But the filmmakers don't draw them out with a heavy, didactic hand. Instead, in the best B-movie tradition, they embed their ideas in an ingenious, propulsive and suspenseful genre entertainment, one that respects your intelligence even as it makes your eyes pop (and, once in a while, your stomach turn).'' The film was nominated for four Oscars, including best picture. 8 P.M. (CBS) THREE RIVERS In this series about Pittsburgh transplant surgeons, which is returning from hiatus, Dr. Andy Yablonski (Alex O'Loughlin) tells a woman that she needs a new heart to save her unborn child and herself. In the latest back-and-forth over the legality of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's layoffs of hundreds of subway station agents, a judge ruled Friday that the authority violated the law when it closed booths and laid off about 260 agents last month without holding public hearings. But the judge, Saliann Scarpulla of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, did not rule on whether the authority must reopen closed booths or rehire laid-off workers, and the authority itself would not comment on whether it would, saying only that it intended to appeal the ruling and to immediately start the public-hearing process.

THOMPSON--Rosemary, died on June 1 at home in Ithaca, New York, where she had moved a few years ago to be near her younger daughter and grandchildren. She had previously lived in Cambridge, Massachusetts, and Gstaad. She was the daughter of the composer Randall Thompson and Margaret Whitney Thompson, and was a graduate of St. Timothy's School in Stevenson, Maryland and Radcliffe College. She is survived by two daughters, Alexandra Franciscus of this city, and Monica Zanen of Ithaca, two grandchildren, Isabelle and Emma Zanen, and two brothers, Whitney Thompson of Hanover, New Hampshire and Randall Thompson, Jr. of Lincoln, Massachusetts.

SCHLEICHKORN--Jacob S. "Jay". Funeral services for Jay Schleichkorn, who passed away on Thursday, June 3, will be held at Congregation of Reform Judaism on Sunday, June 6, at 10am with Rabbi Steven W. Engel and Cantor Jacqueline Rawiszer officiating. A native of New York and a veteran of World War II, Jay is survived by his wife of 60 years, Marianne; his sons, Raymond (Deborah) of Apopka, FL, Peter (Ilene) of New York and Henry (Susan) of Chicago and seven grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions in Jay's memory to Congregation of Reform Judaism, 928 Malone Drive, Orlando, FL 32810. Services entrusted to Beth Shalom Memorial Chapel, 640 Lee Road, Orlando, FL 32810. 407-599-1180.

PARIS -- The chief executive of Carrefour is staking the future of the giant French retailer on a simple strategy: strengthen at home, then either dominate or withdraw abroad. The chief, Lars Olofsson, joined the company at the start of 2009, when it was going through a period of upheaval. Market share had slipped at home, shareholders were uneasy and the group had lost focus on core clients, while pursing a haphazard international expansion.

The Economic Scene column on Wednesday about the effect a federal jobs bill would have on the federal deficit misstated the year in which a jobs bill before the Senate would add about $50 billion to the deficit and the percent of the deficit it represents. The bill would affect the deficit next year, not 2015. If the jobs bill is not passed, the $50 billion would represent 7 percent of the savings needed to reduce next year's deficit to a level economists consider sustainable, not one-fourth of the savings.

An article last Saturday about a proposed tax increase on investment fund managers misstated the actions taken by a group of venture capitalists and chief executives. The group, which was led by Jeffrey Bussgang, a partner at the Boston venture capital firm Flybridge Capital Partners, met with Representative Barney Frank to discuss legislation on environmental regulations and financial reform, not to lobby for an exemption from the tax increase. The article also misstated the location of the meetings. They were in Washington, not Boston.

A goal by David Villa in the 61st minute proved to be the game-winner as Spain won its first World Cup title, defeating Brazil in the final of the 2010 tournament in South Africa. Before fans get caught up in any irrational exuberance, hear this -- the match was part of a sophisticated computer simulation using EA Sports's 2010 FIFA World Cup South Africa video game, which went on sale on April 27. The simulation, on an Xbox 360 system, played the entire 32-team, 64-game tournament that will not begin, for real, until June 11, when the hosts face Mexico in Johannesburg. The 90-minute match took the computer game only 15 minutes to play. (Games can also be played online.)

Donald Windham, a novelist and memoirist who left vivid pictures of literary life in New York, both fictional and factual, when he was an intimate of Tennessee Williams, Lincoln Kirstein and Truman Capote, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89. The death was confirmed by his lawyer, Eugene V. Kokot.

Through Saturday, every major league team has played at least 54 games -- one-third of the schedule. Player performances have taken indisputable shape. (The Toronto Blue Jays' Jose Bautista, for example, will post his career bests in the traditional Triple Crown categories even if he hits .250 with no homers and 19 runs batted in over the final four months.) Though almost nothing is foregone, it is no longer sensible to dismiss as flukes this season's pleasant surprises and striking disappointments.

LOS ANGELES - The N.B.A. Coaches Association awarded Tex Winter and Jack Ramsay, two longtime coaches who have made significant contributions to the game, with the Chuck Daly Lifetime Achievement Award before Game 2 of the N.B.A. finals Sunday.

The Labor Department's monthly jobs report released Friday was not good news. Though 431,000 jobs were created in May nationwide, the bulk of them were workers hired by the federal government to help with the Census -- jobs that will disappear in a few months. Only 41,000 private jobs were created, far short of expectations of 150,000 to 180,000 jobs, and unemployment rates remained steady. Economists estimate that the U.S. needs to add more than 100,000 jobs a month just to keep pace with new workers -- high school and college graduates -- entering the market.

Reliance Communications, India's second-largest mobile phone provider with 106 million subscribers, plans to sell 26 percent of the company in an effort to raise cash to cover costs that include $1.8 billion for licenses for high-speed data services, The New York Times's Heather Timmons reports from New Delhi.

Have you ever thought about whether to have a child? If so, what factors entered into your decision? Was it whether having children would be good for you, your partner and others close to the possible child, such as children you may already have, or perhaps your parents? For most people contemplating reproduction, those are the dominant questions. Some may also think about the desirability of adding to the strain that the nearly seven billion people already here are putting on our planet's environment. But very few ask whether coming into existence is a good thing for the child itself. Most of those who consider that question probably do so because they have some reason to fear that the child's life would be especially difficult - for example, if they have a family history of a devastating illness, physical or mental, that cannot yet be detected prenatally.All this suggests that we think it is wrong to bring into the world a child whose prospects for a happy, healthy life are poor, but we don't usually think the fact that a child is likely to have a happy, healthy life is a reason for bringing the child into existence. This has come to be known among philosophers as "the asymmetry" and it is not easy to justify. But rather than go into the explanations usually proffered - and why they fail - I want to raise a related problem. How good does life have to be, to make it reasonable to bring a child into the world? Is the standard of life experienced by most people in developed nations today good enough to make this decision unproblematic, in the absence of specific knowledge that the child will have a severe genetic disease or other problem?

Game 5 of the Stanley Cup finals is Sunday night in Chicago, and it's now a best-of-three series with the Flyers having won, 5-3, in Friday's Game 4 by playing the best sustained stretch of hockey either team has managed in this hard-to-define series.

PARIS - An American-born teenager recruited from Argentina by American tennis officials lost in the finals of the French Open junior boys championship to one of his best friends. The New York-born Andrea Collarini, 18, lost in straight sets, 6-4, 7-5, to Agustin Velotti, 18. The pair had played on the same Argentine Junior Davis Cup team. Both acknowledged their friendship in postmatch interviews.

PRETORIA, South Africa -- It was difficult to tell who was more excited to be out at Pilditch Stadium on Sunday for the United States team's open training session: the 365 South African youths invited by the American embassy and USAID-affiliated projects, or the buoyant 20-year-old forward with bright yellow boots.

Ron Lieber, who used his Your Money column last week to tell the story of a graduate of New York University struggling to pay off $100,000 in student loans, provides something of a sequel this weekend. He examines efforts underway to change a little-known aspect of bankruptcy law, one that makes it "nearly impossible" to get rid of student loan debt.
Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

Justly famous and frequently in the news - it has played home to the Madoff matter and, more recently, to the Times Square bomb scare case - the federal courthouse of the Southern District of New York is arguably the most important local courthouse in the country.

We all know that horse racing is in decline. Thoroughbred racing declined nationally in handle by 7.3% in 2008, by 9.8% in 2009, and by 8.4% in the first four months of 2010. In New York State, total handle on horse racing fell by more than 10 percent in 2009. When you consider the changes in the consumer price index, New York racing handle is approximately 20 percent of what it was in 1974. What happened here? This article represents a subjective attempt to review what happened both in the nation and in New York State to bring about the fall from grace of the racing industry.

Valentino Rossi broke his leg Saturday in practice for the Italian Grand Prix in MotoGP, the highest level of motorcycle racing, and doctors say he will need at least six weeks to recover before he can return to racing. At age 31, Rossi has won seven titles at the highest level of motorcycle racing - six in MotoGP and one in the previous top category of 500cc - and so he can be thought of a little as the Michael Schumacher of motorcycle racing.

To make visiting clubhouses feel a little less unfamiliar, some players bring along mementos from home. A. J. Burnett, for instance, keeps a four-faced Buddha statue in his locker wherever the Yankees go. Then there is Phil Hughes, who displays a hat and a hockey puck with the team logo of the Tampa Bay Lightning.
Once in awhile I'll be filing mini-posts adapted from Twitlonger:

Washington has its eyes on the slow progress in efforts to contain the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico today as engineers work to seal a cap placed over the gushing pipe. At the same time, politicos are gearing up for a busy election week with House, Senate and gubernatorial primaries in eleven states Tuesday.

With clouds looming over the French Open men's final, Rafael Nadal found a way to make the sun in his tennis world shine again. Nadal faced down Robin Soderling, the same opponent who knocked him out in the fourth round last year, a harbinger for a regressive year of sore knees and lackluster results. But healthy and confident once again, the Mallorcan King of Clay raced to a straight-set win over the giant-chopping Swede, 6-4, 6-2, 6-4.

In an article on Saturday in The Times, my colleague John Rudolf and I wrote about brown pelicans, a species that became extinct in Louisiana, bounced back in the 1990s and is now being threatened by the oil spill. John's reporting centered on heartbreaking scenes at a rescue center in Fort Jackson, La., where trained workers are struggling mightily to clean and rehabilitate birds.
The bright spots outnumbered the United States team's missteps Saturday, but they did not outshine the problems.

With 10 points of a possible 18, Melissa Hoppert set a new Rail blog record with her 2010 Triple Crown race predictions, and Alex Brown became the first blogger to be shut out. Our guest pickers, Jim Rome, David Simon and Sean Avery, combined for 2 points. The final standings follow, and you can also view our results from 2009 and 2008. (Explanation: We use a 3-2-1 point breakdown for win-place-show. A horse picked to win must win to earn points; however, a horse picked to place or show must merely finish in that position or better.)

Ramallah, in the West Bank, doesn’t have the holy mystique of Bethlehem, but visitors are drawn to the city’s cafe culture, thriving night life and liberal attitude.
One of Canada’s prime winemaking regions, the Okanagan Valley is a youthful area in search of its style.
The breathlessness about British Columbian wine comes from the glory of the Okanagan Valley landscape.
Salt Lake City is a bastion of creativity, full of intimate restaurants and retro design shops.
With Utah liquor laws normalized last year, a budding film scene and a fresh crop of indie galleries and boutiques, the city has taken on a more cosmopolitan feel.
James Taylor and Carole King are definitive boomer touchstones, and their “Troubadour Reunion” tour captures the collaborative apex of the singer-songwriters’ interwoven 40-year careers.
Bruce Cameron Clark’s shop sells suits to hedge fund presidents, Saudi princes and rock stars.
The extraordinary art collection of the Gap’s founders, Don and Doris Fisher, will go on view at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art in “Calder to Warhol: Introducing the Fisher Collection.”
Can the controversial former C.E.O. of Hewlett-Packard become the next Republican senator from California?
An East Side house struck by an I-beam in the collapse of a construction crane is listed for $4.75 million.
Jane Lynch, a star of “Glee,” and Lara Embry, a clinical psychologist, married. (Guess which one performed “Vogue” moves at the reception?)
This dessert is buoyant and absolute, with cream easing the tart sting of the fruits.
A recipe for mousse.
A recipe for honey-and-ricotta mouse with strawberry-rhubarb broth.
The essayist talks about atheism, Marxism and intellectual consistency.
The Carmelite Quarter has become one of the few places in the world where bohemians stroll alongside groups of Orthodox Jews.
Shops and cafes feature decidedly local ingredients from Lazio, whose products were long overshadowed by Tuscany’s.
Among the sins of “Sex and the City 2” is that the leads act like ugly Americans. Also, they’re women.
The Pathological Theater, founded by Dario D’Ambrosi, uses stagecraft to help those with mental disabilities.
One of the fastest rising new companies to emerge downtown in years, the Amoralists specialize in high-decibel verbal and physical combat.
In Europe, a cutting-edge talent factory trains elite soccer players — starting at age 7.
Hotels aren’t offering the deep discounts of last summer, but regular prices are still about as low.
What the oil spill and the financial crisis have in common.
A few quote-unquote literary novels are surviving the summer reading onslaught, including Brady Udall’s “Lonely Polygamist.”

The 36 Hours column on May 23, about Santa Fe, referred incompletely to transportation options to the Albuquerque airport, which most Santa Fe visitors fly into. While the Rail Runner from Santa Fe does not stop at the airport, there is a free shuttle connecting the rail line to the airport on weekdays.

Last week, Russ Buettner wrote an article about a bill passed by the State Senate that would require paid holidays, sick days and vacation days for domestic workers, along with overtime wages; the Assembly passed a similar measure last year. Lawmakers expect that the two versions will be reconciled and that Gov. David A. Paterson will sign what they say would be the nation's first such protections for domestic workers. Scores of people responded on the City Room blog. Excerpts follow:

GOULD--Laurence, Ph.D. The Institute for Psychoanalytic Training & Research (IPTAR) mourns the untimely loss of our esteemed colleague, Dr. Laurence Gould, psychoanalyst, internationally renowned expert in organizational theory and consultation, Board member, and Founder of our Socio-Analytic Training Program. His wit, joie de vivre, and resonance for analytic ideas and their application to organizational life enriched our community. We will miss him and are deeply saddened by his passing. The IPTAR Board of Directors

Loving mother of Shari (Denis) Dicks, Michael (Ellie) Futterman, Evan (Lonnie Moon) Futterman, Mimi (Jamie) Rosen and Joel (Tammy) Futterman. Cherished grandmother of Randi, Hallie, Jason, Meryl, Dana, Lisa, Robert, Jessica, Jamie and the late Rachel Futterman. Beloved sister of Carol (Irving) Eisenman, Ricki Schreiber, and Elliot (Renee) Schreiber. Stepmother of Barbara (Jack) Baron, grandmother to Bruce and Meryl. "Rocky" was most happy when surrounded by family and friends.

It's unfortunate that this assessment of the album makes it sound like the pop tunes have been cleaned up and dumbed down rather than done with attitude and flourish. I'm in the younger demographic and would love this CD if the songs were done in a new and funky way. I feel like the older demographic is either going to want to stick to its usual classical music or listen to the original songs, if it's just straightforward covers. I hope that's not the case, because I appreciate many of these bands, and it sounds as if Ms. Fleming has legitimate talent. SARA HETLAND of Evanston, Ill., responding to Jon Pareles's review of Renée Fleming's pop album, ''Dark Hope,'' and Anthony Tommasini's article about classical music crossovers.

His name and his talent forged a destiny for Ken Griffey Jr. He was going to be famous, whether he liked it or not. Yet in many ways, Griffey, who retired on Wednesday after 22 major league seasons, simply wanted to be normal. The inherent contradiction is part of what made him as fascinating a person as he was a ballplayer. And let's make no mistake: from 1989 through 1999, with the Seattle Mariners, Griffey was truly incandescent. He oozed potential and lived up to it. The choices his contemporaries made in the steroids era have saddened or angered so many fans, yet Griffey stands apart. He was the best of his day, no asterisks needed.

ROWE--Patricia A.,Ed.D., on June 3, 2010. Chaired New York University Department of Dance and Dance Education, 1970-1996. Educator, mentor and friend. Services Sunday, June 6, 2010 1-4pm, Leber Funeral Home, 2000 Kennedy Blvd, Union City, NJ. 201-970-3835 for details.

Ferrin for over 66 years, mother of Barbara Ann Ferrin and Allan Ferrin, grandmother of Leigh E. Ferrin, Ellen L. Ferrin and Christopher M. Lane. A Memorial Service will be held at the Royal Poinciana Chapel, 60 Cocoanut Row, Palm Beach, FL 33480 on Tuesday, June 22, 2010 at 11am. Contributions in her memory may be sent to any charitable institutions in the communities in which she lived, or to Hospice of Palm Beach County Foundation, 5300 East Ave, West Palm, FL 33407. Quattlebaum Funeral & Cremation Services, Family Owned and Operated (561) 832-5171.

''All of these rules come about as a result of complaints that we've heard from the flying public.'' --Ray LaHood, the transportation secretary, on proposed federal rules that would include raising compensation for passengers denied boarding on oversold flights and requiring reimbursement of baggage fees and expenses when luggage isn't delivered on time. ''The longer I'm in foreclosure, the better.'' --Wendy Pemberton of St. Petersburg, Fla., who is still living in her home even though she has stopped making payments on her mortgage. Experts say the number of borrowers in foreclosure who are taking this approach is on the rise.

SEGAL--Jerome M. (Jerry). Our dearest father, grandfather, father-in-law, uncle, died June 3, 2010, at age 94 after a long and well lived life. Member of the 45th Infantry Division in WWII, he was awarded the Purple Heart and the Bronze Star. Graduate of C.C.N.Y. and Brooklyn Law School; member of the V.F.W. and J.W.V. of Leisure Village West, Manchester, NJ. Devoted, loving husband to his late wife of 60 years, Elizabeth Kaufman Segal; survived by his daughters Jo-Ann Segal and Carol Kaplan; grandsons Laurence Berland and Noah Berland; sons-in-law Keith Crossley and Joel Kaplan; his nieces and nephews and the Nitzberg Family Circle. Beloved patriarch of our family. We will miss you more than can be expressed. Witty, brilliant and generous in both his wisdom and earthly belongings you are forever in our hearts as the hero you were and that we were blessed to have in our lives for so long.

NATHANS--Robert, died on April 27, 2010 in N. Bethesda, MD. He was born on May 27, 1927, the son of Samuel and Sarah Nathans. He is survived by his sister, Emma, his five children, Mark, Leah, Jessie, Sam and Amy, and his nine grandchildren, Reilly, Grace, Sarah-Jennie, Yonah, Sam, Zev, Max, Simon and Levi. Barbara Lange Nathans, his wife of 55 years, died in 2006. Nathans got his Ph.D. in Physics, University of Pennsylvania in 1954. He was a Fulbright Scholar at the University of Osaka, Japan in 1958. From 1959-1968, he was a Senior Scientist in Neutron Physics at Brookhaven National Laboratory. In 1970, he founded the W. Averill Harriman College at SUNY Stony Brook, where he was a professor of physics. Donations may be made to the Walnut Street YMCA c/o YMCA of Delaware Development Office, 100 W. 10th Street, Suite 1100, Wilmington, DE. 19801. A memorial service will be held in the fall.

San Jose, Calif. may get a Jetsons-like pod car system to whisk passengers to the airport and other transit hubs. The Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority is financing a $1.8 million feasibility study to develop a so-called personal rapid transit system that whisk residents in small, driverless shuttles shaped like Tylenol capsules. The shuttles, which seat up to six passengers, would travel at about 25 miles per hour along a narrow elevated electric track. Backers of the system say it is much cheaper and more energy efficient than traditional monorails or shuttle buses.

Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, is the host. Paper Cuts The Book Review's blog covers books and other forms of printed matter.

THE NEWSYukio Hatoyama abruptly resigned as prime minister of Japan, eight months after being swept into office by his Democratic Party's landslide victory at the polls and ousting the long-dominant Liberal Democrats. BEHIND THE NEWS Mr. Hatoyama, the fourth Japanese prime minister in four years to resign, took power vowing to remake the country's politics, revive its economy and loosen the grip of bureaucrats. But by wavering and then backtracking on a promise to remove an American military base on Okinawa, he made himself look indecisive and rapidly squandered his popularity.

A picture caption this weekend with the cover story about five of the nine cities hosting the World Cup in South Africa misspells the given name of one of the residents reporting on their favorite haunts. She is Almi Simpson, as the article correctly notes, not Almie.

Maneuvering through New York City as a person with cerebral palsy can be a constant irritation. Just making my way down subway stairs at rush hour, with people breathing down my neck, is holy terror. But it is not the physical strain of steps and crowds that is my main source of anxiety. It is the naive, inappropriate and sometimes downright mean comments that people make. Because the umbilical cord was wrapped around my neck at birth, I have an awkward gait and slurred speech. In the disability realm, mine are relatively minor. I don't use assistance devices. I have two master's degrees and have been a professor and poet for many years. I am married (to an able-bodied man) and have one child (also able-bodied). Other than my inability to spell, I'm a completely functioning, productive member of society.

Q.Our family (myself, husband, 12-year-old daughter and 11-year-old son) are planning a trip to the Seattle and Vancouver area in July. We are looking for suggestions on reasonable hotels in either city within walking distance of the must-see sites. We plan on trips to Olympic and Mount Rainier National Parks and wondered how easy it would be to rent camping gear (tents and sleeping bags) for a few nights in the great outdoors. Sue Berger, Huntington Woods, Mich. A.First, be sure to make hotel reservations before going to Seattle, as July is peak season. The Edgewater Hotel (edgewaterhotel.com; from $249, double occupancy) and the nearby Seattle Marriott Waterfront (www.marriott.com; $269, double occupancy) are on the waterfront and close to several must-see sights. Consult Matthew Preusch's ''36 Hours in Seattle'' (Nov. 23, 2008) for further sightseeing and dining suggestions (which you can find in our Seattle destination guide at nytimes.com/travel). Take a stroll on the waterfront; on a clear day, you can see the Olympic Mountains across Elliott Bay. Stroll to the Seattle Aquarium, which the children will enjoy, and the Olympic Sculpture Park, where you'll find Alexander Calder's spider-like sculpture, ''Eagle,'' above. Afterward, make your way to the Space Needle; the observation deck, at 520 feet, offers a stunning panorama of the city and its surrounding landscape.

ON THE UYUNI SALT FLAT IN BOLIVIA, MARCH 30, 2010 David Hanson, a 32-year-old freelance writer from Seattle. ''All the tours to the salt flats are really standard. It's this Lonely Planet circuit that everyone just signs on to, hops into the land cruiser with six other hippies, cruises with their guitars and doesn't even think about it. But if you look on the map, it's actually far better to go in reverse. And it's really cheap, like $150 extra to say 'Give us a car and a driver and let's do it ourselves.' The nothingness is what made it one of the most unique places I've ever been to. Your perceptions are just completely thrown off. Distance becomes obsolete. It's just white and blue and that's all there is. Our guide was used to normal groups staying in hostels, but we were determined to spend that night on the salt flat. It was really windy, and we kept telling him it would be warm with three people in the tent. But he ended up sleeping in the car. He even ate his dinner in there.'' As told to Seth Kugel

GRANT--Robert H.,71, of Fallbrook, CA, passed away Friday, May 28, 2010 from pancreatic cancer. He was born May 2, 1939 in Brewer, ME, raised in Monroe and South Portland, ME and graduated from South Portland High School in 1957. He was married to Jean (Chadbourne) MacConnell. Robert attended University of Maine, RPI and graduated from Boston University. In 1984, he married Kathleen (Reed) Johns. Robert's professional career began at New England Merchants Bank and Salem Five Cent Savings Bank. In 1968, he joined Booz Allen & Hamilton in New York City. In the early 1970s, Robert developed land and renovated homes in Roxbury, NY. After becoming Senior Partner of Booz Allen & Hamilton, he became Managing Director of Southeast Asia and opened offices in Singapore and Sydney, Australia. Since retiring in 1993, Robert had been designing and building custom homes in Southern California. Robert is survived by his wife, three children, two stepchildren, and 10 grandchildren. A private burial ceremony will follow at a later date.

After cooking at the White House state dinner in honor of Mexico last week, the chef Rick Bayless flew across the country for an encore to open Red O Restaurant (8155 Melrose Avenue; 323-655-5009; redorestaurant.com) on trendy Melrose Avenue in Los Angeles. Well known to television audiences on PBS and Bravo's ''Top Chef Masters,'' Mr. Bayless translates his flair for regional Mexican cuisine to meet California tastes. Playful appetizers include crispy taquitos stuffed with duck in a tomato-chili sauce, and chimichurri halibut ceviche. Entrees include an achiote-marinated suckling pig and chicken in mole poblano.

Also his adoring grandchildren George, Bart, Andrea, Diana, Rachel, Danielle and Nicole, and the great-grandchildren. "He was always there." He will be sorely missed. It will be very quiet. Services at "The Riverside", Monday, June 7, 11am.

Carrie Bradshaw and co. have spawned many contentious fashion trends over the years, including Uggs (ugh!). But the bold, gold mirrored aviators that SJP sports in Sex and the City 2 are pure eye candy. A collaboration between the Belgian fashion designer Bernhard Willhelm and the Berlin-based eyewear company MYKITA, the light, sleek, stainless frames were inspired by the Alpine ski racer Franz Klammer's downhill heroics during the 1976 Winter Olympics. They're $525 at Bergdorf Goodman, Barneys New York and patriciafield.com. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

3:49 p.m. | Updated After days of failing to persuade the struggling Oliver Perez to accept a demotion to the minor leagues, the Mets and Perez finally found a mutually agreeable, if somewhat dubious, solution Saturday. Within hours of the Mets' needing to make a roster move, Perez was put on the 15-day disabled list with knee tendinitis in time for the Mets to activate Jon Niese. Niese, who had a strained hamstring, was scheduled to start Saturday's game against the Florida Marlins at Citi Field.

If you're going to start a line of biographical comic books devoted to ''culturally relevant celebrities and pop-culture icons,'' Lady Gaga is probably a good choice to inaugurate the series. But the first issue of ''Fame,'' published by Bluewater Productions, is very strange. The story is told from the perspective of Lester Bangs, a homage to the rock critic depicted in ''Almost Famous.'' Bangs becomes a fan of Lady Gaga after a chance viewing of one of her videos on MTV and quickly evolves into a fanatic (a la Robert De Niro in ''The Fan'' or Jennifer Jason Leigh in ''Single White Female''). Bangs goes from seeing himself as the male lead in the ''Paparazzi'' video to being Gaga herself. In another scene, he dons a wig and performs ''Poker Face.'' The blonde locks do not do the dark-haired, chubby schmo any favors.

MONROVIA, Liberia -- How much money did Charles G. Taylor, the deposed president of Liberia, siphon out of his destitute, war-shattered country, and where is it? For almost seven years, since an international warrant was issued for his arrest, the search has stretched from the mangrove swamps and diamond fields of West Africa to Swiss banks and shell corporations -- a state-of-the-art version of the sweeping asset hunts that have accompanied the fall of autocrats since the shah of Iran's demise in the 1970s.

Arriving in Paris the other morning on assignment, I did what most of the bleary-eyed do: I immediately checked my Blackberry to see what I had missed over the Atlantic. According to a press release, VIP guests at the Marina Abramovic dinner-the subject of Eric Wilson's diverting dead snake thread-were dressed by Givenchy, the host, with the letters RTW or HC after each name to denote a ready to wear or haute couture wearer. What instead? An OBE after your name? No, perhaps not. I studied the list as my fellow passengers gathered their things from the overhead, the three young women in my row just gathering looks for their beauty and height-three lanky black girls with fades or honey-blonde curls and an air of here-we-come confidence-and I wondered at the expense, on top of the dinner, and if the publicity justified it. There were two dozen names on the list, including Bjork (RTW) and Courtney Love (HC).

BENHAM--James Armen, 93, of Norwalk, CT died at home surrounded by his family after a long, wonderful life. Born in New York City on March 14, 1917, he attended Riverdale Country School and graduated from Princeton University in 1939. He joined the Navy shortly after graduation. He was stationed aboard the USS Farragut in Pearl Harbor on December 7, 1941, receiving The Bronze Star for the heroic act of steering his ship to safety during the attack that day. After his service in the Navy, he joined Young & Rubicam as an advertising executive until 1995 at which time he went to work for Ted Bates Advertising Agency, where he held the position of Sr. Vice President and director until he retired in 1980. In the years following, he volunteered with Executive Service Corp., in AJGA and other philanthropic endeavors. Jim was an avid golfer and a long time member of the Wee Burn CC in Darien, CT. A devoted husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather, his daughters, Judi Benham of Darien, and Maher Benham of New York City, his grandchildren Angelo, Gina, Tina and Freddie, and six great-grandchildren survive him. A private military service will be held at Spring Grove Cemetery in Darien. A Great One has passed. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Vitas Hospice Care, 777 Commerce Drive, Suite 220, Fairland, CT 06825 or The Wee Burn Caddy Scholarship Fund, Hanson Rd, Darien, CT 06820.
Classical Steve Smith

To the untrained eye, the small ground-floor space in Brooklyn held a few largely unremarkable objects: what appeared to be a flat-screen television and a plexiglass light fixture hung on one side; a scramble of wires and a strip of what looked like Christmas lights adorned the other. But to the 30 or so guests at Devotion Gallery in Williamsburg on Wednesday night - most in town for the International Computer Music Conference this week - these were objets d'art. More than that, they were buzzing, blinking examples of artificial intelligence.

''ELEVEN friends, two grills, one tiny Brooklyn backyard -- even the food was happy!'' Bruria Markovitz wrote. Indeed, who could resist those watermelon eyes? (See the top photo at right.) Ms. Markovitz is one of scores of people who have sent in photographs of their backyard barbecues as part of Metropolitan's summerlong project ''Around the Grill.'' Readers are grilling ''Savoyard lake trout filled with the garden's first chervil,'' ''pizza with roasted pork shoulder, fresh mozzarella, oregano and garlic,'' lamb chops, even mashed potatoes.

An article on May 23 about the Rolling Stones' album ''Exile on Main St.'' misidentified the chord at the beginning of the first verse of the group's song ''Loving Cup.'' It is a D chord, not an A chord.

TRICHTER--Dr. Benjamin, of Kingston, PA and Boca Raton, FL, passed away May 29, 2010 at the age of 92. He is survived by his companion, Shirley Abelson, his sister Gertrude Shapiro, his children Marjorie Rossiter and Robert Trichter, his grandchildren Timothy and Evan Rossiter, his great-grandchildren Kate and Ella, David Abelson and family, and Michael Abelson and family. Dr. Trichter was an ophthalmologist and World War II Navy veteran who served in the Pacific Theatre. He was born in Brooklyn, graduated from CCNY and Georgetown Medical School, Magna Cum Laude. We honor his life and mourn his passing. We miss you and remember you each day with love.

BELTRAN--Karen (Kleinhaus) died May 31, 2010. Beloved by husband Carlos, daughter Jane, sister Saraletty, favorite aunt to Jill and her children Madeline and Griffin, Rod and his children Sam and Jamie.

MAZUR--Hon. Gerald, 84, of Somers (formerly New Rochelle), NY died on May 31, 2010. Gerry was a WWII Veteran and worked for 40 years in the New York State Supreme Court as Chief Supervising Special Referee before retiring in 1995. Born in 1925 in New York, Gerry graduated from the University of Wisconsin and earned his JD from Cornell Law School in 1950. He is remembered for his brilliance, kindness and for his completion of the New York Times crossword puzzle in pen by 9am daily. He is survived by his cherished family: wife, Toby, sister Beatrice Stoller, children, Kara and Mark Battinelli, Kim and Richard Hoffman, and grandchildren, Olivia, Benjamin, Madison and Ryan. Forever in our hearts.
'I didn't want my 15 minutes of fame to be this; I'd rather be known for a great call at the World Series.' JIM JOYCE,

LUTTRELL--John George, 81, died peacefully at his home in Darien, Connecticut, on Tuesday, May 25, 2010, surrounded by his family. Beloved husband of Thelma; devoted father of John, Denise and Steven; and loving grandfather of Angela, Robyn, Cameron, Jake and Ryan. Survived by all, he will be missed by all. Preceded in death by his parents, Frank and Elsie Luttrell; his siblings, Howard, Charles, Alfred, Herbert, Mildred, Florence, and Marian; he is survived by his sister Lorene. Amidst the hardship of the Great Depression, John was born into a poor family with nine children in rural Christian County, Missouri. Later, his family moved to the small town of Leon, Kansas, where John grew up. An accomplished student-athlete in high school, John accepted an unsolicited offer of financial assistance by the town doctor and his wife, Harry and Dorothy Last, so he could enroll at the University of Kansas. During college, John demonstrated a native facility for high mathematics, but also enjoyed collegiate life as president of his social fraternity, Lambda Chi Alpha. John had a long and distinguished career with Mobil Oil Corporation. He began as a rig worker in between his sophomore and junior years at KU, and joined the company's exploration and producing division in 1952 after completing a Bachelor of Science degree in petroleum engineering, where he earned high honors. Across 37 years with Mobil, beginning in Venezuela, he rose to become the youngest managing director in the history of the company, running Mobil operations first in Libya, then Nigeria, and then Mobil North Sea, based in London. At the time of his retirement, he was vice president of Mobil worldwide exploration and producing, based in New York. Known for his fairness and generosity, he was a private family man who nonetheless touched the lives of many in a positive way. During his later years, he developed an interest in theoretical physics and spent countless hours studying vanguard theories in quantum mechanics. Many mornings, he could be seen walking his rat terrier, Chelsea, and later Dunster, in Selleck's Woods in Darien. For more than 50 years, John loved his wife and family, his friends, and, of course, the KU Jayhawks basketball team. Rock, Chalk, Jayhawk! Donations may be made in memory of John Luttrell to the Dr. Harry Last Memorial Scholarship, KU Endowment Association, PO Box 928, Lawrence, Kansas, 66044. Established by John in 1985, each year the scholarship affords exceptional high school students from the counties surrounding Leon, Kansas, the opportunity to attend the University of Kansas.

Giuseppe Taddei, a distinguished Italian baritone who made his Metropolitan Opera debut to glowing notices in 1985 at the astonishing age of 69 (though he would gladly have sung there decades earlier, he said, if only the Met had asked him nicely), died on Wednesday at his home in Rome. He was 93 and had continued his operatic career until he was well into his 70s. Mr. Taddei's family confirmed the death to Italian news agencies. Information on survivors was not available.
WEISS--Jeanette. Our hearts are broken over the loss of our dear friend. She waged a valiant battle. We mourn with you dear Gene, Gary, Mark and Paul. Joyce and Ivan

The State Department has issued a Travel Alert for South Africa, pegged to the coming World Cup, which takes place June 11 to July 11. The May 25 alert is broad. It includes mentions of a heightened risk for terrorist activity (American citizens traveling in South Africa are encouraged to register with the United States mission to receive specific alerts), a general warning on crime and ''public disturbances,'' and even a note about a shortage of lodging, particularly in the smaller World Cup host cities.
A picture credit on May 23 with an article about the Con Dao islands off the coast of Vietnam misstated the photographer's surname. He is Kevin German, not Garman.

The cover article on May 30 about the Douro winemaking region of Portugal referred incorrectly to air service between New York City and Oporto. There is indeed nonstop service between the cities on TAP Portugal airlines three days a week; it is not the case that there are no regularly scheduled nonstop flights.

The temperature reached 90 degrees at Belmont Park on Saturday, but that did not keep Jeffrey Bernstein from the racetrack. Bernstein, 39, of Manhattan, has sat at a table near the 1/8 pole for the past 15 years. With each passing Belmont, more friends have joined in his annual ritual. About 15 of them, one from as far as San Francisco, came this year. They arrived at 7 a.m. to secure their table.

SCHOENFEIN--Sandy. The Board of Directors of Eisman Foundation for Children is deeply saddened by the loss of our President, Sandy Schoenfein, and extend our sincere condolences to her family. Sandy's enthusiasm and hard work did so much to ensure the success of our day care center and the families we serve. She will be greatly missed.

BROWN--Himan, 99, died peacefully at his home in Manhattan on Friday June 4th 2010 at 8:13pm. He was Father to Barry Kenneth Brown of California and Hilda Joan Brown of Arizona. Grandfather to Melina Celeste Brown and Barrie Kristen Brown. Beloved great-grandfather "Papa Hymie" to William Samuel Brown, Zoe Judith Mildred Sansted, Zachary Dakota Aloysius Sansted and Zia Eva Dora Sansted, all of Connecticut, he was also father-in-law to Judith Ann Brown of Manhattan. He was the Widow of Mildred Brown and Shirley Goodman. He was preceded in death by his parents Samuel Brown and Dora Arkis Brown who were immigrants from Odessa, Russia, His brothers Mende Brown and Nathan Brown. He also leaves behind his beloved caretaker Zulfiya Ziyakhodjaev, who gave structure, meaning, and love to his final years, his great friend and doctor Cameron Hernandez of Mt Sinai Visiting Doctors, who he admired as a doctor and loved as a friend, a neighborhood full of people who loved him, and a bustling building full of devoted staff who were more than just that to him; they looked out for him, listened to him and enabled him to remain the independent guy that he was until the very end. He was a member of the community of North Stamford, CT, where he spent every weekend and most summers for his entire life, and he leaves behind a group of friends there who have been a tremendous foundation, providing a retreat to a very intense and creative mind. He also leaves a wonderful, talented, and devoted group of actors who he has worked with for years and who have remained his loyal friends and creative inspiration throughout more years than any may want to admit. He surely joins those who left this earth before him at some heavenly table-reading, throwing a cue, joking with Zero, and listening to Mercy growl out a laugh. He grew up in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, fluent in Yiddish, and only learned English upon his entry into public school. Steeped in music and great classics, he played violin, and excelled intellectually, while attending Boy's High School with the likes of Bugsy Seigel and The Amboy Dukes. He attended Brooklyn College and Brooklyn Law School graduating as valedictorian with a law degree in 1931, but acting was his great passion, and he already was producing and performing in live theater, Catskills revues, and on the fast growing medium of radio. Legendary creator, producer, director of radio drama, beginning in 1927 with the Hi Brow Readings, he was a one man show, often seen riding a horse in Central Park or walking the country roads of his Stamford, CT retreat while editing scripts with a red pencil, he was a mysterious figure to many but a regular guy to those that knew him. Some of his notable series include The Rise of the Goldbergs, Dick Tracy, Adventures of the Thin Man, Inner Sanctum Mysteries, Grand central Station, and the Peabody Winning CBS Radio Mystery Theater. In the 1950s he bought Players Studios at 221 West 26th Street, now Chelsea Studios, to produce his shows. He was a Founding Member of the Director's Guild of America, proud AFTRA member, a philanthropist and founder of The Radio Drama Network to propagate the spoken word, and was devoted to health care causes and the issues facing people over 50. He was a proud liberal, intellectual, art collector, and legendarily frugal. A member of the Radio Hall of Fame, Brown is the recipient of the American Broadcast Pioneer and the Peabody Award. Brown has taught audio drama at Brooklyn College and the School of Visual Arts. He has lived at the same apartment on Central Park West since 1938. He was awarded a doctorate of Humane Letters by Brooklyn College in 2003. Services will be private, The family urges that in Lieu of flowers donations be sent to the Visiting Doctors of Mt Sinai, Attn: Dr Cameron Hernandez, 5 East 102nd Street, New York, NY 10029.

An article on May 23 about the Rolling Stones' album ''Exile on Main St.'' misidentified the chord at the beginning of the first verse of the group's song ''Loving Cup.'' It is a D chord, not an A chord.
Theater Ben Brantley

There is fate in the moldy, dog-eared paperbacks found on the shelves and bedside tables of summer guest rooms. When the masterpiece we've dutifully brought along stalls five pages in, the accidental bounty of other people's discarded reading beckons. Like conversations with strangers on a train, these random literaryencounters can be unsettling, distracting or life changing. Eight writers tell us what they have read on their summer vacations. In a small bed-and-breakfast in Mexico, I found a copy of ''Unreliable Memoirs'' -- the autobiography of the Australian critic, poet and novelist Clive James. I'd never heard of James before, but this battered, swollen, salt-stained, absolutely enchanting paperback sent me home with an assignment: to read everything he'd ever written. As it turned out, this was a huge task (it consumed pretty much all of 2008), especially considering that James's writings include the great tome ''Cultural Amnesia,'' the reading of which is something like getting a master's degree in 20th-century intellectual history.

A compilation of unique outings available across the city, including art, theater, shopping, views, surfing, grazing, gardening, praying, swinging on a trapeze and, of course, roller derby, compiled by Times reporters and editors.

The N.H.L. season is concluding with what is turning out to be a memorable clash between Chicago and Philadelphia for the Stanley Cup. It is a fine finish, but what did the league and the rest of the hockey world learn in the 12 months leading to this moment? Below, a brief examination of some of the major lessons. Increased InterestTelevision ratings, news media interest and revenue have grown steadily over the past three years, despite difficulties in the economy at large. Game 2 of the Blackhawks-Flyers series on NBC attracted 5.89 million viewers, the largest American audience for an N.H.L. game since records were first kept in 1975.

John Wooden, a staid Midwesterner who migrated to U.C.L.A. and became college basketball's most successful coach, earning the nickname the Wizard of Westwood and an enduring place in sports history, died Friday at Ronald Reagan U.C.L.A. Medical Center, where he had been hospitalized since May 26. He was 99. His death was announced by the university.

The Lion has been generating buzz for its crowd and its burger (fried pork belly and two cheeses never hurt), but has anyone checked out the art? Basquiats mix with black-and-white photographs from the Daily News archives; a 17th-century oil painting hangs above a line drawing of a lion. David LaChapelle's portrait of Andy Warhol is positioned next to thrift-store finds and a photograph by a bartender at the Waverly Inn. The walls are so packed, ''Someone might never notice the picture of the monk hitting the baseball,'' sighs chef and owner John DeLucie. DeLucie wanted his love for old New York to show in the space. With its dark paneled walls and stripped-to-the-bones plaster ceiling, the room, he says, tells ''a made-up story about what this place has been.'' (Decorator Meg Sharpe, who has worked with Kelly Wearstler, explained the look as ''a great-great-great-grandmother's townhouse passed down through the generations.'' Or, as Sharpe - an avid reader - envisioned it, ''a little Miss Havisham.'') The layers of images, from flea-market oil portraits and Greek studies to '40s crime-scene photos and an amazing shot of the Knicks at the airport, circa 1969, speak of an odd inheritance indeed.

Dance Roslyn Sulcas

PRUETT--Eddie, The Last of Sugar Babies' Gaiety Quartet. Edward (Eddie) Pruett passed from life suddenly on June 3, 2010, at home, with his life partner, Lawrence (Larry) Hooper desperately trying to save his life while awaiting medics. Eddie's was such a good life and deservedly so -- he was such a good person. Ask anyone who ever knew him. Eddie was born in Terre Haute, Indiana, on July 21, 1951, the son of Fred A. Pruett and Edna Cope Pruett. The family, including two sisters, Ruth Pruett Tate and Susan Pruett Richardson, later moved to East Ridge, Tennessee (adjacent to Chattanooga), where the remaining family reside today. He is survived by his life partner Lawrence (Larry) Hooper, his sister Ruth Pruett Tate, his life brother Ray Hooper, life sister Judy Hooper, life sister Carol Graziano, life brother Ron Graziano, many wonderful nieces and nephews, and so many fine friends and neighbors. Eddie attended schools in East Ridge and went on to Middle Tennessee State University in 1970, majoring in Music and Theatre. While there in 1971, he met his life partner, Larry Hooper (then at Austin Peay State University), and the two enjoyed both each other's company, love, and profound joys and fulfillment for almost 39 years. Eddie transferred to Austin Peay in 1972 and became a star on the Austin Peay Theatre stage, before going on to perform at Nashville's Opryland theme park. During his Opryland period, he performed in numerous park shows; was a regular on the TV show "Music Hall America" (which originated from Opryland); was a part of Tennessee Ernie Ford's 1974 detente-driven tour of the former Soviet Union; played the White House with the Ford troupe and danced with First Lady Betty Ford; and appeared in other Nashville productions, including a Children's Theatre production of Young Mozart, which eventually played the Kennedy Center in Washington DC. In December, 1976, Eddie and Larry moved to New York City (inspired by their dear friends, Ted and Rosemary Norris of Clarksville, Tennessee) and pursued their career dreams. Eddie's dreams landed him on Broadway in 1979, as a member of the Gaiety Quartet in Sugar Babies. During the show's 1979-1982 run on Broadway, he was also the dance captain and partner to co-star Ann Miller's Mr. Banjo Man. After the Broadway run, Eddie toured with Sugar Babies and then retired from show business in 1990. In 1993, he and Larry moved to the Green Pond lake community in Rockaway, New Jersey, where they built their dream home and over the years, hosted many dear family members, friends, and guests. It was there, on June 3, 2010, that Eddie suffered an immediately fatal heart attack that took him from Larry, leaving enormous grief but also endless fine memories. It was a life lived well and the Fates are to be thanked for their generosity toward a couple of guys lucky enough to find each other early and to be able to share so much. At Eddie's request, there will be no funeral, no formal memorial, and no requests for flowers or contributions. Friends and loved ones are asked only to remember him (and Larry) whenever gathered together -- in recognition that all we leave when we leave this life are the memories that exist in the minds of those met and loved.

When people first hear the name National Ballet of Spain, they usually assume that the distinguished company performs works like ''Swan Lake'' and ''Giselle.'' But to the Spanish, the term ballet simply means dance - in this instance, traditional Spanish dance. To discover its breadth, beauty and theatricality, one need only spend an evening at the grand Teatro de la Zarzuela (Calle de Jovellanos, 4; 34-91-524-54-00), where the company will perform from July 8 to 18. For its 30th anniversary season, the troupe (teatrodelazarzuela.mcu.es) will present an extensive program of works from the Bolero School, a type of elegant and exuberant dance popular in the 18th century. Eminent dance teachers of royalty began creating what became the Bolero School in the late 17th century, combining steps from court and regional dances. It gained so much popularity over the next 100 years that the 18th century became known as ''the century of dance teachers.'' (Goya's many paintings of dancers, in their sumptuous costumes, indicate how important it had become.) ''There's an elegance and refinement to the dances,'' said the artistic director Jose Antonio Ruiz, ''that captures the period. It's particularly refreshing now.''

For her show ''Too Good to Be True'' at the Collette Blanchard Gallery on the Lower East Side, artist Rachel Hovnanian deals with the power and burden of beauty. Her photographs of various beauty queens (literally female trophies tops set in plaster) pose in pristine all-white scenarios- holding a bouquet in front a cabinet of donuts, perched on a bed surrounded by shopping bags from Chanel, Gucci and YSL, and standing in front of a mirror that adds pounds to the waistline. Hovnanian uses dollhouse pieces to create her maquettes of what the Texas-born artist refers to as as ''fantasy of perfect domestic life.'' Indeed, in one of the last scenes, our perfect beauty queen is passed out on a bed with empty bottles of vodka and valium. ''We feel this pressure in the media to be these perfect people, to look and act a certain way. But at the same time, we want to see the imperfections, the harsh realities. Look at at all the gossip magazines where we get to to see people off camera. We want to know it's too good to be true.'' The show runs from today through June 30th.

The reinvention of Coney Island for the 21st century took a terrific first step when Luna Park opened on Memorial Day weekend after 50 years of decline. The first view of the new era is the impressive 2004 glass-canopied subway station, an hour's ride from Times Square. The landmark 1927 Cyclone is running at full speed. The boardwalk is a promenade for bikini wearers and minuscule dogs, and the piers are catnip for illegal divers. And as twilight arrives, impromptu dancing begins as musicians play on the boardwalk. At night the skyline twinkles with the colored lights of the new rides.

Q.Can you suggest some places to surf and dive? I'd love to visit Costa Rica. I'm not looking for any fancy places to stay. I just want to enjoy the ocean, the sights, the fresh fruit and enjoy being in the company of the locals! Sarah R. Adams, Spring Arbor, Mich.A.In Costa Rica, the beach communities on the Caribbean coast between the towns of Puerto Viejo and Manzanillo are an ideal surfing destination - and a cheaper alternative to the so-called Gold Coast on the Pacific side. This beautiful 11-mile stretch of coastline, south of Limon province, ''attracts disciples,'' Gisela Williams wrote in her article ''With the Surfers on Costa Rica's Untamed Coast'' (April 4, 2010). For those looking for a laid-back and untamed vibe, the Caribbean coast is a great alternative to the country's more populated and touristy Pacific coast. To get there, you can take a puddle-jumper flight from San Jose to Puerto Limon, or a shuttle bus. But the easiest way, Ms. Williams noted, is to rent a car (four-wheel-drive recommended) and drive (about four hours). She suggested Casa Viva Beach Houses (www.puntauva.net), where a one-bedroom bungalow on the beach starts at $100 a day.

So-called gentlemen's clubs in Britain have long been shielded from the masses, and some even continue to prohibit women of any class. Until last month, the Milroy (5 Hamilton Place, W1J) was no exception. But now the hand-carved staircase, the newly restored tapestries and the Venetian chandeliers leading to its restaurant's luxurious and extravagant dining rooms can be seen by the public -- at least at lunchtime. The building was erected in the early 19th century on the site of one of King Henry VIII's hunting lodges, and has enjoyed a certain notoriety ever since its inception. Originally a private residence for intimate ''friends'' of the Royal family, the edifice was converted into a club by a wealthy businessman (and rumored spy) during World War II - and has been reserved for London's elite ever since.

An article on Sunday about Democratic Party gains in Chicago suburban regions referred incorrectly to the Congressional district of Representative Melissa Bean. It includes parts of Lake, Cook and McHenry Counties. It does not include DuPage County.

Mondrian and vintage floral wallpaper are not the usual references that come to mind when one imagines women's surf wear. It took two fashion insiders, Jillian Demling, an editor at Vogue, and Karen Mulligan, Annie Leibovitz's longtime studio manager, to finally take the mall out of surf with their new line Pret-a Surf. Functional rash guards come in graphic Warhol era op-art, a 1950's cut gingham bikini is engineered to stay put in the worst wipeouts and board shorts are done in a vintage wallpaper pattern. Demling and Mulligan had the idea for Pret-a-Surf two summers ago while landlocked in Amagansett with a broken foot and lyme disease, respectively. Mulligan, a surf addict decided to cheer herself up by buying a board at a local shop and noticed that all the ladies surf wear looked like it was designed for an ''8 year old girl.'' Soon they were sourcing fabrics and enlisting friends to help with the look book, for which the girls modelled the suits themselves. Their stylish suits have found fans in Blake Lively and Rihanna and can be found at both Opening Ceremony and Jeffrey.

ST. LOUIS - Jaime Garcia was too old to play baseball for Sharyland High School in Mission, Tex., so he sat out the 2005 season even though he was still enrolled. The Baltimore Orioles held his professional rights, having chosen him in the 30th round of the 2004 draft, but Garcia did not want to sign with them. ''Back then, everyone they drafted had to take a test, and because he took the test and didn't do well on it, they didn't let me sign him,'' said Joe Almaraz, then an Orioles scout. ''But it wasn't that he didn't do well on the test. The problem was that when they translated the test into Spanish for him, it was misinterpreted. I read the whole thing myself.''
Film Neil Genzlinger

Every four years, young players use the platform of the World Cup to become household names. Billy Witz looks at a contender from each group to emerge in South Africa. Group A: Javier Hernández Mexico, 22, forward Eighteen months ago, Hernández was struggling to get on the field for Chivas de Guadalajara, questioning whether he should give up on his career. Now, after taking the Mexican league by storm, Hernández, 22, has joined the vanguard of promising young Mexicans who have many thinking the country could advance to the quarterfinals for the first time since 1986. Known as Chicharito, or Little Pea, Hernández has the type of game - athletic, strong in the air and decisive in front of the goal - that translates well on the international stage. At least that is the feeling of Manchester United Manager Alex Ferguson, who recently scooped up Hernández for next season.

SMITH--Dr. Norman O.,Professor of Physical Chemistry at Fordham University in the Bronx, New York died peacefully May 29, in Arlington Heights, Illinois. In addition to his many accomplishments as a teacher and researcher, he was also a Cathedral caliber organist and choir director. Born in Winnipeg, Manitoba in 1914, he earned both his Bachelor and Master of Science degrees at the University of Manitoba. He then journeyed to New York City where he earned his Doctorate in Physical Chemistry from New York University in the spring of 1939. He returned to Winnipeg to teach at the University of Manitoba until 1950. In 1944 he was married to Anna Marie O'Connor, whom he had met while studying in New York. Dr. Smith taught at Fordham University for 34 years, retiring in 1984. During that time he taught both undergraduate and graduate students, mentoring ten doctoral students. He authored three books and published over 50 professional articles, including an article in the Encyclopedia Britannica on the Phase Rule. He also served as the Chair of the Chemistry Department in the late 1960's. Throughout his 45 years of teaching, he earned the highest reputation from both his peers and students as a superb lecturer, researcher and mentor of students. In addition to his scientific achievements, he was also a highly trained organist and choir director. He was a member of the Royal Canadian College of Organists and the composer of several anthems. He was the organist of St. John's Anglican Cathedral in Winnipeg in the 1940's and served as organist and choirmaster of Union Church of Pocantico Hills, in Westchester County, New York for 29 years. Married to Anna Marie O'Connor for 65 years, he is survived by three sons, Richard in Rochester, New York, Graham in Chicago, Illinois and Stephen in Boston, Massachusetts, along with seven grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Funeral information 847-998-1020.

Almost two dozen players will represent the U.S. men's national soccer team at the World Cup starting this month in South Africa. But years before they reached this acme, most of them confirmed their promise by playing on one or more youth national teams. So it will be no surprise if some of the elite prospects on the following pages, all of whom are U.S. youth-team members, end up playing for the U.S. at the World Cup four, eight or even a dozen years from now. To capture a glimpse of the future of American soccer, the French photographer Charles Fréger shot players who, like many in the American talent pool these days, were born abroad or whose parents were. To make his portraits, he had to visit the Netherlands -- where a group of under-20s was gathered for a tournament -- as well as Salt Lake City, Dallas and Norway. It's an itinerary that hints at another truth about American soccer talent: it's not only coming from abroad; at ever younger ages, it's also going abroad. As the coach of the under-20s recently noted, more than 200 prospects now playing in other countries would be eligible for the team at next year's U-20 World Cup. Ability and American citizenship are the criteria. As the United States becomes more serious about taking on the world at the world's game, its players are bringing more and more of the world to the American team.

The event, a fund-raiser for amfAR, the AIDS research foundation, played with contradictions - the theme of the evening was Black Tie/Black Leather. In the unseasonable early June heat, some guests dripped as they entered the library's lobby in their leather tuxedo jackets, pants and, as in the case of a dreadlocked man named Haynes (''just Haynes, like Madonna,'' he said), a black leather kilt. Inside, male models reclined on lounge chairs as living centerpieces, while around them guests drank green tea and vodka cocktails. The models were dressed like sailors; that is, if sailors' nautical striped shirts were backless, covered with sequins and designed by Jean Paul Gaultier, who wandered among them intermittently. ''I wouldn't say I'm a decoration,'' said one model, Timo Rademann, 24, from Germany. He was recumbent on a chaise in the center of the marble room in a woman's tube top.''The flowers are. I'm entertainment.''

Joe Meagher writes from New Hampshire, hoping against hope that his beloved California Golden Bears will somehow make it to the Rose Bowl before he is forced to leave this mortal coil. They had better hurry up. The horse racing industry is dying because people like me are its biggest fans. I have been a racing fan since my father took our family to Santa Anita when I was 11. IT'S been nearly seven weeks since oil from BP's deep-ocean Macondo well began gushing into the Gulf of Mexico. Over that time, the public has, understandably, become increasingly frustrated with industry and government efforts to prevent damage to wildlife and wetlands. There is the growing sense -- reflected in last week's discussion of using nuclear weapons to stop the leak and a viral video about using hay to sop up the mess -- that somehow, somewhere there are more innovative and effective measures for containing and cleaning up the oil. But I can tell you, based on 21 years' experience analyzing and observing oil spills, that the best minds in the business are already doing all they can. No special techniques that would work well to clean up the oil in this situation aren't being tried or planned. There simply are no foolproof solutions.

The United States spends much more on health care than countries with similar kinds of economies. So costs are sure to be examined closely as federal officials shape regulations under the new health care law. Americans have abundant access to high-tech diagnostic tools like CT and M.R.I. scanners, and to life-saving surgical procedures like angioplasties. Yet Americans don't see doctors more often or live longer, healthier lives, according to data from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. And Americans' cancer survival rates are not markedly better. In fact, the population of the United States has about the same prevalence of disease as that of other developed countries.

A chart with an article on May 23 about fears in Europe that the economic crisis there could lead to more austerity, such as reduced benefits and an increased legal retirement age, reversed the labels for the United States and Italy in trend lines comparing American and European ratios of working-age people to retirement-age people, an indicator of looming pension problems. The chart should show the trend line for Italy ending at a lower ratio than that of the United States, not vice versa, meaning that Italy's pension problems are more severe, not less. (A corrected version of the chart can be found at nytimes.com/corrections.)

DULIT--Everett Paul, 81, died at home June 2, 2010. Married 55 years to Elinor Greenspun Dulit, also survived by his children, Rebecca, Kate and Alan Dulit; his grandchildren, Josh, Jake, and Sarah Feingold, Ezra and Naomi Dulit-Greenberg and his sons-in-law, Stephen Feingold and Joshua Greenberg. He was a noted psychiatrist, specializing in the psychotherapy of adolescents, who served as Director of the Division of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Director of Adolescent Psychiatry at New York Hospital, Cornell University Medical Center-Westchester Division. He was a man of vast energy and enthusiasm with many deep passions, notably jazz, his family and friends, the outdoors and the study of the human mind. He was a remarkable educator and mentor to generations of psychiatrists, psychologists and social workers. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Memorial donations may be made to: www.jazzfoundation.org. Services: Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, White Plains, NY, 1pm, Sunday, June 13th. Daniel Medwed, a law professor, calls it ''the Innocent Prisoner's Dilemma.'' To get paroled, convicts must express remorse for their crimes. To express remorse, they must acknowledge guilt. So what about those prisoners who maintain they were wrongfully convicted? ''You're in this terrible Catch-22, a classic Catch-22,'' explained Mr. Medwed, a former co-director of the Second Look Project at Brooklyn Law School, who now teaches at the University of Utah. ''You know that if you proclaim your innocence at the parole hearing and remain true to yourself and true to your case then the chances of being released on parole are remote. But you also know that if I put on a good show, show some remorse, I'll have a better chance.''

WALGREENS recently bought Duane Reade, the New York drugstore chain, for $1.1 billion. A 7,100-store company with headquarters in Deerfield, Ill., Walgreens said it would not immediately wipe away the Duane Reade brand, but it is exploring a switch to common bookkeeping and prescription systems, as well as the closing of some of Duane Reade's 258 stores. Naturally, many New Yorkers worry that this deal will eventually mean the disappearance of yet another born-in-New York business -- beset as those ventures have been by global brands like Starbucks and big-box stores like Home Depot.

Once again Friday night's episode of "Friday Night Lights,'' proved to be an evocative treatise on miserable parenting. Early on we see Vince scouring the empty fridge in his apartment right before the camera finds its way to the image of his mother sacked out on a bench outside. She didn't forget to pick up the milk because she is too harried; she is too strung out to remember to do it in the first place. The series checks off every category of bad mother or father: Vince's mom is an addict; Becky's mom is an obsessive too focused on the transgressions of Becky's dad to really be in the moment with her daughter. Did anybody else feel worse for Becky that her mom was screaming into the dad's voice mail during the pageant than they did over the fact that he didn't bother to show up?And how about that pageant? (I loved Becky's correcting of the M.C. -- "It's just 'Wicked.'") There is something so incongruous -- in a good way -- about Becky being on the beauty pageant circuit, since she is so not a Texas looker. The show hammered this home with its shots of her competitors. Her confidence -- her aggressiveness with Riggins -- is constantly at odds with her rebellious hair and unconventional prettiness, and I'm finding myself really riveted by the tension. Becky is also the first central female character to be ordinary looking. (Tyra, Julie and Lyla -- knockouts all.) And what's amazing is how self-assured she is in spite of her clearly bad family life. She knows how to perform: I like the way her confidence was contrasted with Vince's, when he is asked to deliver a speech at a pancake breakfast after a great turn in his football game. He is at a loss and further confused by J.D. McCoy's Dale Carnegie-like ease in front of an audience.

This compares with 20 such transactions announced for all of last year.

This may seem redundant to say about a character who is essentially unable to die, but Capt. Jack Harkness will live on. On Monday, the Starz cable channel announced that it will show a new season of "Torchwood," the science-fiction series on which John Barrowman portrays Captain Jack, the immortal leader of the Torchwood team. The series, about a clandestine organization that investigates (and often battles) extraterrestrial threats to this planet, has already had three hit seasons on BBC in Britain and BBC America in the United States, culminating in 2009 with the five-episode arc "Children of Earth," which knocked off major characters who didn't share Captain Jack's invulnerability.

Last week, we bid a fond farewell to Martin Gardner, who died on May 22. However, fond farewells have a habit of lingering on, and we will not take leave of the spirit of Mr. Gardner just yet. As a not-unknown poet once said, "Parting is such sweet sorrow, that I shall say good night till it be morrow." In our case, circumstances have conspired to prolong our farewell at least one week. And it is only fitting. After all, if puzzling were geometry, we have just lost our Euclid.
