Additional responses will be coming soon.In this week's Science Times, Jane Brody, the Personal Health columnist, writes about the challenge of pancreatic cancer, an illness that is detected and treated at a potentially curable stage in fewer than 20 percent of those who have it. The disease, which became more common in recent decades with the rise in cigarette smoking, has also been linked to obesity, diabetes, lack of exercise, certain pesticides and chemicals and other factors. Some patients also have a family history of the disease.

This cruise season Donna Karan focused her attention on what to wear after the sun goes down. She took the word Resort out of her program completely, choosing instead to show all evening looks for "Holiday." In a palette of black, white and navy, she moved from a man's tuxedo to long, languid Grecian gowns. The masculine influence was softened in sumptuous pajama-style palazzo pants and smoking jackets paired with light pleated skirts. These are just the type of easy pieces to make a woman to feel chic after dark whether she spends her holiday on the island of Manhattan or somewhere decidedly more exotic.

This is a brief followup look at holes, building out of coverage here of the extraordinary orifice that swallowed a building and street corner in Guatemala City after the region was struck by a raging tropical downpour. In today's Media Equation column, I made my own attempt to address the very tough math of re-making a version of Newsweek that would survive and thrive in a busy, wired news ecosystem. With the magazine up for sale, others have weighed in: Jeff Bercovici of Daily Finance suggests that Newsweek begin by paying attention to the magazine and little else,  and Lee Siegel argues in the New York Observer that its current leadership is to blame. But rather than do forensics on what went wrong -- at bottom, the world changed -- we asked a folks by e-mail and on Twitter for new answers.

Google's GOOG411 service popularized a way for people to get business phone numbers for free, instead of paying up to $2.00 to get a phone number from a wireless or landline carrier. You just dial 800-GOOG411, and voice prompts ask for the name and city of the business, and the business name. When found, the voice recites the number, and either dials it for you or sends you the number and address as a text message.

WEISS--Jeanette. On behalf of our entire organization, the Principles and Partners of Newmark Knight Frank wish to express our deepest sympathies and heartfelt condolences to our esteemed partner Mark and his entire family for the untimely loss of your beloved mother, Jeanette.

PASTON--Ashley, most recently of Maplewood and West Orange, NJ, died on June 5, 2010, after a long illness. Born August 25, 1921, he was a decorated WWII veteran (Silver and Bronze Stars and a Purple Heart), a business executive, a creative writer and an avid bridge player, but to his family he was mostly a loving father, husband and grandfather. He is survived by his children Susan (Ian Wise) and Donald (Farida) as well as his adored granddaughter, Melissa, all of whom will miss him very much. Funeral services will be held June 7 at 1:30pm at Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel in Livingston, NJ. Contributions in his memory may be sent to the William Maugulies Senior Center, Leon & Toby Cooperman JCC, 760 Northfield Avenue, West Orange, NJ 07052.

An article on Thursday about high earnings among some employees of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority misstated in one place the surname of a Long Island Rail Road conductor who made more than $200,000 last year. He is Thomas J. Redmond, not Raymond.

An article on May 27 about hospitalists, who are taking over the care of hospitalized patients, referred incompletely to the number of patients who are readmitted after a hospital stay. The one in five readmission rate that is widely considered the result of poor care is readmissions that occur within 30 days of discharge. Additionally, in one caption that accompanied the article, the surname of a hospitalist in the story was misspelled. She is Dr. Subha Airan-Javia, not Airan-Javier.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption with an article on Thursday about a new Internet music service incorrectly stated that two executives in the photo, Carter Adamson and Drew Larner, were the creators of Kazaa and Skype. As the article correctly noted, Niklas Zennstrom and Janus Friis were the founders of the two companies as well as the new music service, called Rdio.

Justly famous and frequently in the news - it has played home to the Madoff matter and, more recently, to the Times Square bomb scare case - the federal courthouse of the Southern District of New York is arguably the most important local courthouse in the country. Its judges, prosecutors and defense lawyers stand at the cutting edge of the legal world, working on celebrated cases involving terrorism, financial fraud, even Somali pirates.
A music review on Friday about a concert presented by the Mannes Beethoven Institute, at Mannes College the New School for Music, misstated the date of the performance. It was Wednesday, not Tuesday.

WEISS--Jeanette. Mark, our hearts ache for you and your family. May her memory be a blessing. Natasha and Billy

BANK--Daniel, of Oakland Gardens, NY, on June 5, 2010. Beloved brother and uncle. A life-long musician, best remembered for the baritone sax, clarinet and flute. He leaves behind a substantial musical legacy. Chess master and world traveler, his dry humor will be missed by family, friends and students world wide. Funeral service Tuesday, 12noon, at the Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills. Interment at Wellwood Cemetery, Pine Lawn, NY.

WADE--Peter Hutchinson, of New York City and Pawling, NY, died on June 6th at the Greenwich Woods Health Care Center in Greenwich, CT., in peace after a long illness, at age 81. He is predeceased by his parents, Stuart A. and Genevieve M. Wade, his sister Margaret Welch, and his wife Joan Kehoe Wade. He is survived by his children Kevin, David, Jennifer (Garrity), Tim, and Laura (Farley), his eighteen grandchildren, his second wife Helen (Milne) Wade, and countless old friends and colleagues. A native of Pelham, NY, he attended Georgetown University and earned his BS in Business Administration from New York University in 1952. While working for the American Broadcasting Company in New York City he met Joan Marie Kehoe, and they were married in 1953. They settled in Chappaqua, NY, where Peter began his career as a prominent local merchant as owner of the Village Bottle Shop in Chappaqua and of the Young & Halstead Company in neighboring Mt. Kisco. While serving as a Trustee and Treasurer for the Northern Westchester Hospital Center there, he led the campaign to enlarge and expand that facility. In recognition of his talents and contributions, he was elected President of the hospital in 1977 and embarked on a second career as a hospital administrator, which he conducted with wisdom, expertise, and tireless enthusiasm until his retirement in 1990. During this time, he also served on the Board of Blue Cross-Blue Shield of Greater New York. In retirement in Pawling, Peter took on leadership roles as a member of the Quaker Hill Country Club and the parish of St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church while enjoying golf, traveling, and the company of his grandchildren. We mourn his passing and rejoice in his life; we will always cherish our memories of him as a loving husband and father, a wise and tender counsel, a cheerful and doting "Popop", a fine and loyal friend, and as a man who valued service to his fellow man as the true measure of success. In this spirit, and in lieu of flowers, please make a contribution in his memory to the Alzheimer's Association. Viewing on June 9th from 6 to 8pm at the Horn and Thomes Funeral Home, 83 East Main St., Pawling NY. A funeral Mass will be held on June 10th at 11am at St. John's Church, 39 East Main St., Pawling, NY, with a reception to follow. Kevin and Sasha Wade David Wade Jennifer and Joseph Garrity Timothy and Janine Wade Laura and Tom Farley

A report in the feature ''The Place'' on May 23 in T: Travel about a selection of wineries and tasting rooms to try in Napa Valley referred incorrectly to Cade Winery's quest to be Napa's first certified Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) solar-powered winery. HALL St. Helena became LEED certified in 2009.

ORLINSKY--Philip Jack. Loving husband, father, saba, pompy, uncle, cousin, brother-in-law and friend did not wake up on June 3. He will be sorely missed by everyone who knew him. Services were held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 10am on June 6. Rina, David and Ethan will be sitting shiva.

On a very cold morning Jeff, Kyle, Larry and Mike meet on the practice range to warm up. Jeff is not sure how well the ball will carry that day, so he has brought two drivers to the range. Kyle and Larry each have the same weighted training club with a grip that is molded to their hands. Also unsure of the weather, Mike has brought 18 clubs to the range, wondering which will work best in the cold. After warming up, all four players head to the first tee. As Jeff has 15 clubs, he takes one of his drivers, disassembles it and places the parts in the pocket of his golf bag. Kyle and Larry each have 14 clubs, including the nonconforming training club. Mike decides that he will carry 10 clubs himself and asks his son to carry the other eight clubs, thinking that he will add four of those clubs during the round. His son takes the clubs and heads down the fairway to watch the tee shots.

The second annual Best of the City issue of Sactown, a young bimonthly magazine that covers Sacramento, includes about four dozen accolades, pointing out scenic hikes and skating rinks. It also highlights a mandarin orange festival, so the art director included an image of a mandarin slice on the cover. Then came the idea: What about giving that slice a scratch-and-sniff coating?

BROWN--Himan, 99, died peacefully at his home in Manhattan on Friday June 4th 2010 at 8:13pm. He was Father to Barry Kenneth Brown of California and Hilda Joan Brown of Arizona. Grandfather to Melina Celeste Brown and Barrie Kristen Brown. Beloved great-grandfather "Papa Hymie" to William Samuel Brown, Zoe Judith Mildred Sansted, Zachary Dakota Aloysius Sansted and Zia Eva Dora Sansted, all of Connecticut, he was also father-in-law to Judith Ann Brown of Manhattan. He was the Widow of Mildred Brown and Shirley Goodman. He was preceded in death by his parents Samuel Brown and Dora Arkis Brown who were immigrants from Odessa, Russia, His brothers Mende Brown and Nathan Brown. He also leaves behind his beloved caretaker Zulfiya Ziyakhodjaev, who gave structure, meaning, and love to his final years, his great friend and doctor Cameron Hernandez of Mt Sinai Visiting Doctors, who he admired as a doctor and loved as a friend, a neighborhood full of people who loved him, and a bustling building full of devoted staff who were more than just that to him; they looked out for him, listened to him and enabled him to remain the independent guy that he was until the very end. He was a member of the community of North Stamford, CT, where he spent every weekend and most summers for his entire life, and he leaves behind a group of friends there who have been a tremendous foundation, providing a retreat to a very intense and creative mind. He also leaves a wonderful, talented, and devoted group of actors who he has worked with for years and who have remained his loyal friends and creative inspiration throughout more years than any may want to admit. He surely joins those who left this earth before him at some heavenly table-reading, throwing a cue, joking with Zero, and listening to Mercy growl out a laugh. He grew up in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, fluent in Yiddish, and only learned English upon his entry into public school. Steeped in music and great classics, he played violin, and excelled intellectually, while attending Boy's High School with the likes of Bugsy Seigel and The Amboy Dukes. He attended Brooklyn College and Brooklyn Law School graduating as valedictorian with a law degree in 1931, but acting was his great passion, and he already was producing and performing in live theater, Catskills revues, and on the fast growing medium of radio. Legendary creator, producer, director of radio drama, beginning in 1927 with the Hi Brow Readings, he was a one man show, often seen riding a horse in Central Park or walking the country roads of his Stamford, CT retreat while editing scripts with a red pencil, he was a mysterious figure to many but a regular guy to those that knew him. Some of his notable series include The Rise of the Goldbergs, Dick Tracy, Adventures of the Thin Man, Inner Sanctum Mysteries, Grand central Station, and the Peabody Winning CBS Radio Mystery Theater. In the 1950s he bought Players Studios at 221 West 26th Street, now Chelsea Studios, to produce his shows. He was a Founding Member of the Director's Guild of America, proud AFTRA member, a philanthropist and founder of The Radio Drama Network to propagate the spoken word, and was devoted to health care causes and the issues facing people over 50. He was a proud liberal, intellectual, art collector, and legendarily frugal. A member of the Radio Hall of Fame, Brown is the recipient of the American Broadcast Pioneer and the Peabody Award. Brown has taught audio drama at Brooklyn College and the School of Visual Arts. He has lived at the same apartment on Central Park West since 1938. He was awarded a doctorate of Humane Letters by Brooklyn College in 2003. Services will be private, The family urges that in Lieu of flowers donations be sent to the Visiting Doctors of Mt Sinai, Attn: Dr Cameron Hernandez, 5 East 102nd Street, New York, NY 10029.

ORENSTEIN--Samuel, Saturday June 5. Loving husband of Edith, father of Joseph, May and Philip, grandfather of Nathan, Sonya, Daniel, Jeffrey, Patrick and Katherine. Service on Monday June 7, 11:30 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street.

DULIT--Everett Paul, 81, died at home June 2, 2010. Married 55 years to Elinor Greenspun Dulit, also survived by his children, Rebecca, Kate and Alan Dulit; his grandchildren, Josh, Jake, and Sarah Feingold, Ezra and Naomi Dulit-Greenberg and his sons-in-law, Stephen Feingold and Joshua Greenberg. He was a noted psychiatrist, specializing in the psychotherapy of adolescents, who served as Director of the Division of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Director of Adolescent Psychiatry at New York Hospital, Cornell University Medical Center-Westchester Division. He was a man of vast energy and enthusiasm with many deep passions, notably jazz, his family and friends, the outdoors and the study of the human mind. He was a remarkable educator and mentor to generations of psychiatrists, psychologists and social workers. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Memorial donations may be made to: www.jazzfoundation.org. Services: Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, White Plains, NY, 1pm, Sunday, June 13th. Family will be receiving guests in Scarsdale at 45 Popham Rd., June 13th 4-8pm and June 14th 1-4pm and at 14 Cohawney Rd. June 14th 5-8pm.

James Cameron did not get his chance to save the world from a rogue oil well, but it is beginning to look as though he rescued Hollywood's box office ecosystem from total disaster this year. Mr. Cameron's ''Avatar,'' the 3-D science fiction epic released by 20th Century Fox in December 2009, has remained the biggest event of 2010, having taken in more than $465 million of its $749 million domestic box office this year, according to Hollywood.com's box office service.

PEARLMAN--Elaine, New Rochelle, NY was, as her husband says "the best:" the best wife to Herbert Pearlman since 1952; loving mother to Beth, Steven, Randy, Amy, and their spouses Garry, Ali, Laurie, Joe; wonderful grandmother to Hillary, Mathew, Melissa, Ariella, Tanya, Jessica, Michayla, Skye and Remy. Though family was her passion, she was past President of Beth El Sisterhood, PTAs, a bookkeeper, traveler, reader, sister and friend. Donations to cure macular degeneration- AHAF. 800-437-2423. Funeral - Beth El, New Rochelle, Monday June 7 at 11:30am.

A year ago, the MLB Network carried its first amateur draft, in which Stephen Strasburg was the No. 1 overall pick by the Washington Nationals. For its second go-round with the draft Monday, the network has made a few changes. An hourlong pregame show will start at 6 p.m. Eastern, followed by the draft at 7, with the first pick at 7:15. The Nationals are expected to take Bryce Harper, a 17-year-old catcher from the College of Southern Nevada, with that pick.

Sales for new vehicles were up in May for all car manufacturers, led by Chrysler with a 32.7 percent increase over May 2009. Ford sales rose 22 percent and General Motors, 17.5 percent. Toyota had an increase of 6.7 percent. Autotrader.com and Edmunds.com are popular Web sites for research (according to Nielsen, Autotrader was fourth and Edmunds sixth among users in April). Their top searches diverge, with only the Honda Accord, above, in the top five of both.

President Obama, struggling for balance on a political oil slick, gave a speech last week that seemed to contradict itself. One part was ferociously partisan. He criticized Republicans for obstructionism, ascribing that stance to crass electoral strategy and a ''sincere and fundamental belief'' that every problem's solution involved tax cuts for the wealthy and less regulation for corporations.

Steven P. Jobs predicted earlier this week that the personal computer was going to go the way of the farm truck: It won't disappear but it will be relegated to a niche role by popular mobile devices like smartphones and tablets. On Thursday, Microsoft's chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, whose company's success still rides on the success of the personal computer, answered by saying, in essence, that pretty much every computing device is a PC.

An article on Thursday about accusations of extrajudicial killings committed by the police during several days of fighting in a district of Kingston, Jamaica, last month misstated the estimated number of people huddled for safety in a building where, according to witnesses, police shot and killed a 22-year-old barber named Errol Spence. It was 16 or 17, not ''more than two dozen.''

The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes Monday's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday. According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 0.12 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 0.21 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 0.10 percent.

MAIDAN SHAHR, Afghanistan -- For months, reports have abounded here that the Afghan mercenaries who escort American and other NATO convoys through the badlands have been bribing Taliban insurgents to let them pass. Then came a series of events last month that suggested all-out collusion with the insurgents.

Monday through Wednesday, Major League Baseball will hold its amateur draft. The N.F.L. and N.B.A. drafts have become big events in their own right, but the drafts for the N.H.L. and baseball have always been less compelling. The baseball draftees are often 17-year-old high school players or from places like Miami Dade College, which has had 324 draftees, three times as many as all but two Big Ten universities (Michigan has had 151 players drafted and Minnesota 130).

After gaining control of much of the world's copper supply, the 19th-century robber baron William A. Clark set out to buy a seat in the United States Senate. Openly, he went about bribing Montana legislators, $10,000 a vote, the cash paid in monogrammed envelopes. Mark Twain called Clark ''as rotten a human being as can be found anywhere under the flag,'' but the senator did not show any shame. ''I never bought a man who wasn't for sale,'' he said.
An article on Wednesday about a strike by workers at Co-op City misstated the year the housing development opened. It was 1968, not ''the 1970's.''

SAN FRANCISCO -- When one of the most important e-mail messages of his life landed in his in-box a few years ago, Kord Campbell overlooked it. Not just for a day or two, but 12 days. He finally saw it while sifting through old messages: a big company wanted to buy his Internet start-up.

The founders of Diapers.com managed to start a company selling a commonplace product and turn it into a darling of the tech world. Now its founders are trying to do it again, with Soap.com. Vinit Bharara and Marc Lore, the founders of Quidsi, which owns Diapers.com, introduced Soap.com on Thursday at a news conference in New York. In July, it will start selling 25,000 items typically found in a drugstore, like laundry detergent, shampoo and toilet paper.

There is no piece of golf equipment more personal, more like a relationship, than the association of putter and golfer. Most people go through dozens of putters in a lifetime. Some pros go through hundreds. Some players are a little more faithful. My colleague Dave Anderson, who is a very good putter, has used the same flat stick for decades. ''We've had our arguments, but we've never broken up,'' he once told me after rolling in another putt that dashed my hopes of winning the hole.

In your own home it's easy enough making a mess, but doing so accurately onstage can take hard work. Here, the set designers of four dysfunctional dramas describe what it took - and cost - to clutter things up. (All are still playing except ''Oliver Parker!,'' which closed last weekend.)

Six weeks after oil began gushing into the Gulf of Mexico, BP is letting the public see live pictures from all 12 of the underwater cameras that are trained on its damaged well. There it is, streaming at all times on a panoply of Web sites, hard to miss in the lower right corner on CNN and other cable news channels: the oil gusher cam, a remarkable view of an unfolding disaster.

About 20 minutes into his on-stage interview at the D8 conference, Mark Zuckerberg had to take off his hoodie, the black sweatshirt that has become his trademark and that he said he never took off. Mr. Zuckerberg was being grilled about Facebook's latest privacy flap, and he was visibly uncomfortable and sweating profusely. Mr. Zuckerberg was on the proverbial hot seat and he seemed to know it.

Benjamin Lees, an iconoclastic American composer who spurned modern musical trends in favor of work that was lyrical, tonal and widely described as approachable, died on May 31 in Glen Cove, on Long Island. He was 86 and had recently returned to the New York area after living in Palm Springs, Calif., for many years. The cause was heart failure, his daughter, Jan Rexon, said. Mr. Lees was previously a longtime resident of Great Neck, N.Y.

In 1884, a man called Francis Galton opened the doors of his "Anthropometric Laboratory." This was "for the use of those who desire to be accurately measured in many ways, either to obtain timely warning of remediable faults in development, or to learn their powers." The many ways included height, hand strength, acuity of sight and hearing, lung capacity and the power of a blow with the fist.

It is delightful news that The New York Times columnist Nicholas Kristof's kidney mass, detected by a CT scan performed for another reason, turned out to be benign rather than a cancer, as he recently wrote in "A Scare, a Scar, a Silver Lining." A malignancy was the runaway diagnosis, a concern that occasioned considerable anxiety and a painful operation yielding a six-inch scar. Mr. Kristof has performed a public service by sharing the intimate details of his personal medical situation with millions, and we can all appreciate a major lesson of his thoughtful and moving column: to enjoy every day and time with our loved ones.

In a Times article last year about hardships faced by the residents of Pikalevo, Russia, bubbling pots of nettle stew are conjured as illustrative evidence of the toughness of the times.

I was thrilled and slightly horrified last week to discover that our local drugstore was now selling Huggies in a faux-denim pattern, with trompe l'oeil seams, back pockets and signs of denim distress. The diapers had already caused some controversy when ABC refused to air its commercial - a toddler pictured as a man-about-town dressed in a button-down Oxford shirt and denim diapers getting ogled by the ladies and climbing into a convertible - because it aired the word "pooping" on screen. The hypocrisy here is frankly hilarious, considering that the ABC program "Grey's Anatomy" has used the word "douche" not in the medical sense, but as a pejorative put-down, and a character on the 1990's ABC program "NYPD Blue" routinely used the word with its popular pairing, "bag." Compared to that, what's wrong with a little poop?

Fans of the Italian dance star Roberto Bolle will be disappointed this spring ballet season. Mr. Bolle, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, has withdrawn from performances with the company because of an ankle injury, the company announced on Tuesday. Mr. Bolle was scheduled to appear in "Swan Lake" on June 21 and "Romeo and Juliet" on July 8. Marcelo Gomes, another principal, will replace Mr. Bolle in both "Swan Lake," dancing opposite Veronika Part as Odette/Odile, and  "Romeo and Juliet,"  with Paloma Herrera.  The company's spring season continues through July 10.

"[Helen Thomas's anti-Zionist comments] reflect an interesting, under-appreciated ... media phenomenon: The longer someone is submerged in what they and their organizations regard as traditional 'straight' reporting, the more gruesome the results are when the gloves come off. As Thomas herself reportedly said in a 2002 speech, 'I censored myself for 50 years.... Now I wake up and ask myself, Who do I hate today?' Straight reporters have been taught for six decades to submerge or even smother their political and philosophical views in the workplace. Like all varieties of censorship, this process creates resentment and distortion. Whatever it is that you feel prevented from saying, you will be more likely to scream once given the chance ... Degrading the quality of that discussion still further is the likelihood that the partisanship-averse journos haven't bothered to construct their own self-conscious political philosophy, beyond identifying Bad Guys and wanting to Fix Problems. Show me the world's most intractable problems-the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, the inability to produce mass amounts of energy without negatively impacting the environment, the search for a beer that tastes great and is less filling-and I'll show you reporters in bars having conversations worthy of the Alex Jones show."

There's something about the onset of summer that prompts even the most diehard urbanites to dress like sailors. But there's a fine line between indulging in a little naval gazing and looking like an extra on shore leave from "On the Town." AANDD, a new line of three unisex bags from the architect/industrial designer Adam Davidson, gets the seafaring tone just right, with waxed rope handles and a predominantly navy color scheme. "I wanted to get past the usual garment center sources for hardware," Davidson says. "So I looked at marine hardware and just fell in love with it." The roomy Sea Bag is Davidson's take on the weekender, with large exterior pockets and a detachable leather shoulder strap; the Sea Duffle is a cross between a shoulder bag and a sailor's duffle; and the Courier is a leather messenger bag with a two-tone reversible flap that zips on and off. "Women's bags tend to be bling-heavy, while men's bags shy away from any risk-taking when it comes to details," adds the designer. "The idea is to find the middle ground." Aandd bags are available at Maryam Nassir Zaddeh, 123 Norfolk Street, (212) 673-6405. Prices range from $425-$625.

A down-at-heels economy (not unheard of in this country, after all) seems to be no deterrent to Italy's hotel business. Among several new openings in the past year, two new luxury properties are making a splash, beginning with Palazzo Caracciolo, which opened last November in Naples. Before it was a hotel, this 13th-century building was a palace, a fortress, and a noble mansion. And what remains today is a legacy of regal monumentalism, from the immense cobbled courtyard where once horses and chariots were kept to the lemon trees growing up a giant pergola near the entrance. No doubt this is what caught the eye of the European hotel group, Accor, which restored and remodeled the property to include 144 rooms (from about $122 to $1,060), some of them split-level suites, decorated with rich red and white fabrics and Baroque- and Rococo-style furnishings.

More than once on Motherlode, grieving parents have written about the inadequacy of language in the face of their loss. There are no words to describe the pain of burying a child, and specifically there is no word to label their new, lifelong status. If you lose a spouse, you are a widow; if you lose a parent, you are an orphan. But what about when you lose a child? How do you name something you cannot comprehend?

The MTV Movie Awards - which, it has already been established, were not entirely successful at keeping Kristen Stewart entertained on Sunday night - were also unable to build on the viewership the event has enjoyed in recent years. The 2010 Movie Awards show averaged 4.6 million total viewers during the two-hour broadcast on MTV, MTV2 and VH1, Reuters reported. That's a decline of 13 percent from the 2009 show, which was watched by 5.3 million people and was the Movie Awards' best outing since 2004. In its own news release, MTV said that 16.4 million viewers had tuned in at any given time during the 2010 awards, a 2 percent gain from last year by that measure.

Is the altitude finally getting to everyone? The dizzying swings of fortune for Alan Fletcher, the president and chief executive of the Aspen Music Festival and School in Colorado, continue. Mr. Fletcher, who was fired by the executive committee of the festival's board of trustees last October, rehired by the full board in November and given a vote of no confidence by the festival corporation (including board members, faculty and others) in April, has now had his contract extended for two years, through September 2012. The decision was made at a special meeting of the board on Monday, at which Rob LeBuhn, its chairman for the last year, announced that he was stepping down, effective immediately, in response to a majority vote. Mike Murray, the vice chairman, has been named acting chairman. The board will elect a new chairman, possibly at its next scheduled meeting on June 29. The festival is also looking for a new music director to replace David Zinman, who resigned in April, strongly criticizing Mr. Fletcher. The festival season opens on July 1.

One would much rather laugh at the image of the industry, as people did so vigorously during the P. Diddy video, than witness another occasion for self-congratulation. And there were still a few of those moments.

In saying, in part, ''Now Sanrio's in trouble,'' Professor Shichijo says he was referring to an earlier period at Sanrio, after the end of a brief boom in sales spurred by Hollywood celebrities' wearing clothes and accessories featuring the Hello Kitty character, not to the company's current status. The article also misspelled the given name of the chief executive of Fanworks, a consulting firm. He is Akira Takayama, not Hikaru.

Staring day after day at images of oil billowing from an undersea well in the Gulf of Mexico, many Americans are struggling to make sense of the numbers. On Monday, BP said a cap was capturing 11,000 barrels of oil a day from the well. The official government estimate of the flow rate is 12,000 to 19,000 barrels a day, which means the new device should be capturing the bulk of the oil.

BENSLEY--Elizabeth (Baker), of Riverdale, New York on June 6, 2010. Wife of the late Charles J. Bensley and Robert C. Baker. Mother to Martin (Susan) Baker and Margery (Stephen) Riker. Grandmother to Melissa, Howard, Katherine and David. Great-grandmother to nine and adored Aunt Betty to many loving nieces and nephews. A woman of warmth, elegance, beauty, wisdom and kindness. Services Wednesday, June 9, 9:30am at Central Synagogue, New York City. Donations may be offered to The Hertzberg Palliative Care Institute, Mt. Sinai School of Medicine, One Gustave L. Levy Place, Box 1070, New York, New York 10029.

BANK--Daniel, of Oakland Gardens, NY, on June 5, 2010. Beloved brother and uncle. A life-long musician, best remembered for the baritone sax, clarinet and flute. He leaves behind a substantial musical legacy. Chess master and world traveler, his dry humor will be missed by family, friends and students world wide. Funeral service Tuesday, 12noon, at the Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills. Interment at Wellwood Cemetery, Pine Lawn, NY.

BROWN--Himan. As a radio pioneer and entertainment visionary, Himan Brown was a giant. He brought families together to enjoy the "spoken word" that came out of the box that talked. He contributed to the cultural fabric of this country by helping launch the careers of so many world-renowned actors. At CUNY TV we knew him as a friend: fluent in Yiddish, witty, wry, always the pro, always gracious. Lunches with Himan were a great joy, filled with stories of radio's golden age, not to mention the bagels and lox. We mourn his passing and offer our condolences to his devoted granddaughter Melina and his entire family. Robert Isaacson Executive Director CUNY TV

I walked into my patient's room, waving a copy of her lab work in the air. Her white blood cell counts were finally high enough for her to leave the hospital. It had taken her awhile, and this was her third try at chemo, but finally she'd reached the magic number that would get her a ticket home. I knew her from her repeated hospital stays. We had tried one chemo regimen after another, trying to kill off her disease - or at least kill enough of it so she could get a stem cell transplant. She was not only practical about her cancer, but also exceedingly kind. She had a dedicated husband. We all loved her.
International CAMERON WARNS BRITONS

SADLER--Lorraine Zona Edelberg, 82, June 6, 2010. Beloved wife to Jerome, mother to Carole and Andrew, grandmother to Sadie Mae, aunt, cousin and dear friend to many. Services will be held on June 8, 2010 at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, 7800 Myrtle Avenue, Glendale, NY. www.mountlebanoncemetery.com at 11am. Contributions in Lorraine's memory can be made to Human Development Services of Westchester, www.hdsw.org, 930 Mamaroneck Avenue, Mamaroneck, NY 10543, an organization she avidly supported during her lifetime.

BUCENEC--Susan Debra, of New York City passed away on June 6, 2010 after a short yet courageous battle with cancer. Always smiling, Susan was filled with integrity, beauty and grace. Her laughter and love of life was inspiring to all who knew her. She is survived by her fiancee Michael Curcio, his children Scott and Sara, her mother Irene, stepfather Bob, father Herman, stepmother Meryle, brother Myron and Steven, niece Shana, her beloved Leo, and many family and friends. She will be remembered as a loving, caring and faithful daughter, aunt and friend to all. Service Tuesday, 10am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

I walked into my patient's room, waving a copy of her lab work in the air. Her white blood cell counts were finally high enough for her to leave the hospital. It had taken her awhile, and this was her third try at chemo, but finally she'd reached the magic number that would get her a ticket home. I knew her from her repeated hospital stays. We had tried one chemo regimen after another, trying to kill off her disease - or at least kill enough of it so she could get a stem cell transplant. She was not only practical about her cancer, but also exceedingly kind. She had a dedicated husband. We all loved her.

PEARSON--Emily Feder Was born in Cluj, Transylvania/Hungary on July 4, 1914. She immigrated in 1928 with her family and was married to Samuel Pearson on December 31, 1936. In 1940 Emily lived in Brooklyn and was a neighbor of Estee Lauder, and became her first door to door makeup model. During WWII Emily sang for the USO entertaining with Rosemary Clooney and Billy Daniels. Emily supported Sam through his career in Wall Street and ultimately joined as founding partners with Jack Dreyfus in The Dreyfus Fund. In 1962 Emily dined with Eleanor Roosevelt at the request of Dr. David Gurewitsch, the Roosevelt's personal physician. Emily was asked to convince the ailing first lady to go to Switzerland to undergo cellular rejuvenation therapy (the precursor to stem cell research). Emily and Sam underwent this treatment by Dr. Paul Niehans of Vevey Switzerland and lived into their 90s. Emily and Sam contributed heavily to Robert F. Kennedy. The Senator personally wrote to thank them for helping to retire his 1964 campaign debt. With connections in the Kennedy and Nixon administrations, Emily labored to free relatives from behind the Iron Curtain, as well as fed and clothed Hungarian immigrants. Emily and Sam were Master Builders of The Albert Einstein College of Medicine, a division of Yeshiva University. Their first great-grandchild Tyler was delivered in Madison, WI by an obstetrician who was a graduate of the very same institution. They also, along with Jacob Fuchsberg (New York State Court of Appeals) were founders of the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, NY. Emily Pearson financed the start up of The MBP Company, LLC d/b/a Marron Foods, an ingredient manufacturing company headquartered in Harrison, NY with facilities in Durand and Oconomowoc, WI. The concern is the recipient of the Small Business Success Story Award from the Oshkosh College of Business, division of the University of Wisconsin. Emily's eldest son Michael passed away in 1987. She is survived by her two other sons Roger and his wife Jennifer, Matthew and his wife Ronnie. Emily is also survived by her grandchildren Daniel and his wife Billee, Ryan, Michael, Olivia, Adam and Ian. She is also survived by two great-granchildren Tyler and Jacob. Emily requested that in lieu of food and other offerings of condolence, donations be sent to The Young Israel of Harrison, New York at 207 Union Avenue, Harrison, NY 10528 to help their building program. She wanted to help erect two synagogues in her beloved home Town of Harrison, New York where she resided for 53 years. Emily Pearson's tenacity and determined perseverance insured the success of her husband and sons. She never forgot her roots and always taught her family to give back to the community and country she loved so dearly. Gravesite service will be held at Riversville Cemetery at 1pm Thursday. For further information please contact Riverside Chapel at 914-664-6800.

Just as the economy is searching for direction, the markets also seem to be groping for positive signs. But with little in the way of economic data on Monday, traders found little to ease their concerns about Friday's jobs report and the debt problems in Europe. As a result, stock indexes spent much of the day wandering before falling sharply in the last hour.

A dance review on Monday about ''Erasing Borders: Festival of Indian Dance,'' at the Asia Society, misidentified the geographic origins of a traditional Indian dance form and of two dancers who performed. Bharatanayam is a form of dance from southern India, not northern. Shipra Mehrotra is from Maryland, not northern India (her family is from there), and Navtej Johar is from northern India, not southern.

When D., a woman in her mid-30s, learned that she was dying from complications of AIDS, she fully expected that her life would end in much the same way it had been lived: homeless, alone and among strangers. If it hadn't been for Dr. Jason K. Alexander, a medical student at the time, she might have been right.

RECANT--Benjamin S.,beloved father of Jane, Donna and Robin, grandfather of Eric and Rebecca; A true renaissance man, his greatness measured by his uncompromising integrity and honor, his unwavering love for his children and grandchildren and his boundless generosity. In his lifetime, he did it all. He served his country as a Lieutenant in the U.S Navy at the end of WWII, he went on to become a leading Oral and Maxillo Facial Surgeon and professor, he traveled the world, played tennis, skied, and always maintained deep and loyal ties to his friends, and, until the last few years when his illness deprived him of his independence, he staunchly insisted on doing it all on his own. Ben Recant was known for never shying away from a vigorous political debate, or from putting himself on the line to defend his sense of justice and righteousness. He proudly served two tours of duty as a volunteer for the Israeli armed services during times of war, replacing and supporting soldiers who were in active combat. He was a hero in every way. We will forever cherish him in our hearts and minds. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapels on Wednesday at 11:15am, Shiva Wednesday evening and Thursday afternoon and evening at the home of Jane Recant 455 East 86th Street.

SELIGMANN--Arthur Walter, 97. Beloved husband of the late Elizabeth Simon Seligmann and for the past 12 years adored companion of Jane Mayer Field, father of Mary Ascheim and Jean Seligmann, father-in-law of Robert Ascheim, grandfather of Tom and Nicholas Ascheim and Jane Winston and their spouses, Deborah, Amy and Eric, brother of Jean Seligmann Levine and the late James and Robert Seligmann, brother-in-law of Ursula Seligmann, uncle of 14 nephews and nieces and great-grandfather of eight, died peacefully at home in Manhattan on June 6, 2010. Born on June 16, 1912, he graduated from Columbia University and Cornell University Medical College, where he was on the staff for many years as Associate Professor of Medicine; he also maintained a large private practice in internal medicine. During World War II he served in the U.S. Navy as a Lieutenant Commander in the South Pacific. He will be deeply missed by everyone who knew him.

College students who want to boost their grades can start by boosting their level of exercise, new research suggests. A report presented on Thursday at the American College of Sports Medicine's 57th annual meeting in Baltimore finds that college students who regularly engage in vigorous exercise get better grades. Although a link between physical activity and higher academic achievement has been shown in middle-school students, it hasn't been clear whether exercise is associated with better grades among older students.

BEESON--Jack. New York City Opera mourns the death of Jack Beeson, distinguished American opera composer and longtime friend of NYCO. In a career spanning some seven decades, he was a student of Bartok, teacher of important American composers, composer of eight operas (including "Lizzie Borden," premiered by NYCO in 1965), and seminal figure of 20th-century American opera. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family, friends, and colleagues. George Steel, General Mgr

Nudibranchs are fascinating because of what they tell us about the evolutionary process, but the story of how I became interested in them is a little less sophisticated. As a child growing up in the San Francisco Bay Area, I started visiting the California Academy of Sciences, and seeing the exhibits and aquarium are some of my earliest memories. Little did I know that I would end up working there for 28 years and counting. I was always raising tadpoles into frogs and caterpillars into butterflies, and finding scorpions on the hill behind our house. I would also go to the tide pools on the Marin coast. When I was in high school and took biology, my inspirational teacher, Gordon Chan, would take students on field trips, including to tide pool areas. I told him I had seen nudibranchs in a book about marine life, but I had never been able to find one. ''No problem,'' he said. ''I know exactly where to find them.'' He showed me two different nudibranchs and I was hooked.

JERUSALEM -- Four Palestinian militants suspected by Israel of planning an attack by sea were killed near the Gaza shoreline early on Monday, an illustration of Israel's continuing control and concerns for security after last week's deadly raid on a Turkish ship of activists bound for the Palestinian coastal enclave. The Israeli military said that an Israeli naval force spotted what it called a ''squad of terrorists wearing diving suits'' and fired on them.

BENHAM--James Armen, 93, of Norwalk, CT died at home surrounded by his family after a long, wonderful life. Born in New York City on March 14, 1917, he attended Riverdale Country School and graduated from Princeton University in 1939. He joined the Navy shortly after graduation. He was stationed aboard the USS Farragut in Pearl Harbor on December 7, 1941, receiving The Bronze Star for the heroic act of steering his ship to safety during the attack that day. After his service in the Navy, he joined Young & Rubicam as an advertising executive until 1955 at which time he went to work for Ted Bates Advertising Agency, where he held the position of Sr. Vice President and director until he retired in 1980. In the years following, he volunteered with Executive Service Corp., in AJGA and other philanthropic endeavors. Jim was an avid golfer and a long time member of the Wee Burn CC in Darien, CT. A devoted husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather, he was predeceased by his first wife, June. His wife, Kay Fabbri -Benham, his daughters, Judi Benham of Darien, and Maher Benham of New York City, his grandchildren Angelo, Gina, Tina and Freddie, and six great-grandchildren survive him. A private military service will be held at Spring Grove Cemetery in Darien. A Great One has passed. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Vitas Hospice Care, 777 Commerce Drive, Suite 220, Fairfield, CT 06825 or The Wee Burn Caddy Scholarship Fund, 410 Hollow Tree Ridge Rd., Darien, CT 06820.

BEESON--Jack. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague. His compositions--especially his operas--are music at its most vivid and winning. As composer and teacher, he had an enduring influence on American culture, and his warmth and wit will be sorely missed.

NEW DELHI -- More than 25 years after a plume of fatal toxic gas from an American-owned chemical plant wafted over the slumbering city of Bhopal, eight former executives of the company's Indian subsidiary -- including one who has since died -- were convicted Monday of negligence. The seven surviving defendants were sentenced to two years in prison and fined 100,000 rupees, or $2,100. They were the first criminal convictions from the leak at the Union Carbide chemical plant in Bhopal, a central Indian city. The leak killed 3,000 people almost instantly, and thousands more died later from the aftereffects of the toxic gas, an ingredient in pesticides the plant produced.

Patric dedicated himself to various community projects in the poorest areas of Nicaragua working to feed and educate children. Wake at McGrath's Funeral Home in Bronxville, NY, Tuesday June 8th from 4-7pm. Funeral Mass at St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, NY, Wednesday June 9th at 11am. Burial will be in Managua. Donations can be made in Patric's name to the Children's Tumor Fund.

DULIT--Everett Paul, 81, died at home June 2, 2010. Married 55 years to Elinor Greenspun Dulit, also survived by his children, Rebecca, Kate and Alan Dulit; his grandchildren, Josh, Jake, and Sarah Feingold, Ezra and Naomi Dulit-Greenberg and his sons-in-law, Stephen Feingold and Joshua Greenberg. He was a noted psychiatrist, specializing in the psychotherapy of adolescents, who served as Director of the Division of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Director of Adolescent Psychiatry at New York Hospital, Cornell University Medical Center-Westchester Division. He was a man of vast energy and enthusiasm with many deep passions, notably jazz, his family and friends, the outdoors and the study of the human mind. He was a remarkable educator and mentor to generations of psychiatrists, psychologists and social workers. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Memorial donations may be made to: www.jazzfoundation.org. Services: Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, White Plains, NY, 1pm, Sunday, June 13th. A report in the Reuters Breakingviews column on Friday about Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner's urging of other countries to conduct bank stress tests misstated the prospects for such tests in the financial regulatory overhaul under consideration in the United States Congress. Bills passed by both the House and Senate envisage future stress tests, though their scope and level of public disclosure is not specified; such tests are not ''absent from America's financial reforms.''

It seems unthinkable, even now, that the disastrous oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico could bring down the mighty BP. But investment bankers get paid to think the unthinkable -- and that is just what they are doing. The idea that BP might one day file for bankruptcy, particularly as part of a merger that would enable it to cordon off its liabilities from the spill, is starting to percolate on Wall Street. Bankers and lawyers are already sizing up potential deals (and counting their potential fees).

Alimentation Couche-Tard's hostile offer for Casey's General Stores, a rival convenience store operator, would appear at first glance to be a plain vanilla hostile offer. Casey's does not have a staggered board, so all of its directors are up for election this year. This provides Couche-Tard with a standard route for any hostile bid: it can begin a tender offer and combine it with the nomination of a slate of directors to bring the target to the table.

Lately I've had the Nineties on the brain, so when I discovered that Chloe Sevigny had tapped the footwear brand NaNa (one of my only style signifiers in the formative years of wearing a uniform) to create some styles with her for Opening Ceremony, my heart skipped a beat. To anchor the kitschy accessories and cool cropped knits, Sevigny offered a core collection of five dresses in five prints. It will be easy for a girl to buy a few and wear them as a uniform. And she'll have more opportunities to change up her footwear, which to me is what the Nineties were all about.

The current Broadway production of "Hair," which won the 2009 Tony Award for best musical revival, will close on June 27, its producers said on Wednesday. "Hair" began turning a profit in August, after recouping its capitalization costs of $5.76 million, but has performed unevenly at the box office this year. When it closes, it will have played 519 regular performances and 29 previews.

The latest proposal to deal with energy and climate change came on Wednesday from Senator Richard Lugar, a moderate Republican from Indiana. His plan seeks to cut energy usage and greenhouse gas emissions without creating a new market in carbon credits or taking a big bite out of the economy.

Showing at his Crosby Street store for the first time, Derek Lam described his collection for Resort as possessing a certain naiveté not to mention an affinity for children's craft paper. Indeed, he wanted his skirts and dresses - with their delicate laser cut-out patterns - to look like they were  made with paper and scissors. A white cropped sweater bearing the midriff and high-waisted fit and flared skirt looked positively fresh. As my mind drifted from children to women to women's abs, I wondered who will choose to bare all in these teeny new knits.
Shai Stern, the C.E.O. of Vintage Filings LLC, explains how he saved his company after the market collapsed.
ABC has become of the fourth of the five big English-language television broadcasters to finish the sale of commercial time before the start of the coming season.

Updated, 5:03 p.m. | Few scenes of New York City are as iconic the one depicted in Edward Hopper's painting "Nighthawks." Based, as The Times, among many others, has noted, on "a restaurant on Greenwich Avenue, a street that runs at a sharp Hopperesque angle to several Village streets," Hopper's long-demolished diner offered the painter, as it does the viewer, a noirish window onto the penetrating loneliness that lies at the heart of modern urban life.

In Wednesday's TimesCast video, my colleague Brian Stelter suggested that the photos of birds mired in oil had supercharged public interest in the coverage of the Gulf oil spill nearly seven weeks into the slow-moving disaster.

Insular by custom and geography, the fishermen of Delacroix Island in Louisiana have even less time now for outsiders - especially outsiders with Canons hanging from their shoulders - as they race to catch what blue crabs they can before the oil leaking from the Deepwater Horizon well closes their fishery entirely.

Joseph E. Stiglitz, the Nobel Prize-winning economist, wants the financial regulatory bill to bar financial firms that give up their government-backed bank charters from ever being able to seek government assistance again.

The New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, is suing the developer of a troubled downtown luxury building, saying he stole $7.4 million from its  reserve fund and demanding he compensate buyers of apartments there.

Militants attacked dozens of trucks ferrying vehicles for Western troops in Afghanistan early Wednesday near the Pakistani capital, The Associated Press reported, a bold assault that killed seven people and illustrated the vulnerability of a crucial United States supply line. Militants and ordinary criminals have often attacked NATO and American supply convoys over the past two years, but Wednesday's strike was the first so close to the well-protected capital, something likely to cause particular unease. Much of the fuel and supplies for Western troops in Afghanistan travels through Pakistan after arriving in the port city of Karachi.
The bargain lines widely known as the Chinatown buses are rolling out new routes beyond the Northeast corridor, to hubs like Atlanta, Orlando and Chicago.

Maybe Max Azria was getting excited about the World Cup when he decided to base his eponymous Resort collection on Peter Beard's portraits of Lauren Hutton in Africa. The collection uses airy fabrics and a neutral palette. I'm looking forward to wearing the simple long T-shirt dresses in half jersey/half silk walking down the beach on a far flung island. A girl can dream, right?

As CNN explains, BP has released high-quality video images of oil flowing from its damaged well, after pressure from Democratic Senators Barbara Boxer and Bill Nelson, who demanded "full access to all video" to allow independent experts to make a better estimate of just how much oil is flowing into the Gulf of Mexico.

Dozens of readers had questions about Tourette syndrome, the odd and poorly understood disorder that causes uncontrollable tics and vocalizations, after the disorder was profiled in a recent Patient Voices series. The latest laid-back album from Jack Johnson ran away with the top spot on the Billboard album chart this week. Justin Bieber's "My World 2.0" (Island) came in a distant second, with 52,000 in sales, while "Glee: The Music, Volume 3 - Showstoppers" (Columbia), came in third after two weeks as No. 1, with 45,000.

"Buddy Cop 2," a new play by the Brooklyn troupe Debate Society, takes place in the 1980s inside a temporary police station built on the basketball court of a small-town recreation center. Adjacent to the station is a racquetball court.

Diane Von Furstenberg used an Ara Gallant photo of herself circa 1983 to set the tone for her 2010/2011 Resort show. The feeling of the collection was a modern woman's boudoir, with models standing in front of a mirrored bedroom-like setup before they took to the runway in clothes that were graphic, simple and sporty. You can envision a modern sexy woman mixing the swimsuits with high-waisted shorts and men's silk shirts.

Gail Collins: David, I'm shocked by the lack of team spirit shown by Arkansas Democrats in their Senate primary. Here we had a perfectly good scenario going about angry voters and doomed incumbents and the end of political moderation. Then they go and renominate Blanche Lincoln. Who is not only an incumbent but an incumbent wishy-washy moderate. Whose re-election campaign has basically been: "I'm head of the Agriculture Committee. Let me stay in Washington and continue to get you stuff."

Caitlin Flanagan has an essay in the June Atlantic that returns to one of her recurring themes: The coarseness of contemporary sexual culture and its impact on the souls of teenage girls. Along the way, she portrays her own 1970s teenage-hood as a more idealistic time, and posits that her own mother and women like her - liberals and feminists who believed in doing away with sexual double standards and "helping their daughters incorporate sexual lives within a normal teenage girlhood" - would react to "the kinds of sexual experiences that so many American girls are now having ... [with] horror and indignation."
The public radio program Marketplace is hosting an all-day conference and webcast, "Moving by Degrees," examining various aspects of the interlaced climate and energy challenges.
The Karole Armitage dance company’s benefit gala and auction in Chelsea drew artists, dancers and Salman Rushdie.
The operator of a Twitter feed that exists to mock BP and its response to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico was asked by the oil company this week to specify that the feed was just a fake.

On today's TimesCast, Jeff Zeleny talks about the results of Tuesday night's primaries, which didn't turn out to to be as bad for sitting lawmakers as Washington had feared. But they can hardly be carefree. With the economy still sluggish and the chairman of the Federal Reserve saying today that debts are unsustainable, Graham Bowley looks at an alternative to stimulus.

You can learn a lot about Michael R. Bloomberg, it turns out, from what he says at graduation ceremonies. He claims to have never had a bad day. He hates legalese. And he tries to call his mother every day.

When the designer Anne Johnston Albert shut down her East Village label and shop, Martin, in 2005 to move to Great Barrington, Massachusetts, cult-like fans of her jeans were, to put it mildly, dismayed. Martin resurfaced online, but the experience wasn't quite the same. "In the store, you can tell what's going to work on someone the minute she walks in," she says. "But when you're answering questions via e-mail, you're working in the dark. I missed having the interaction with customers." You can now have that personal experience again, but you will have to travel to Great Barrington. Germain, the clothing and home décor shop Albert's opened with the interior designer Elena Litteron, features a carefully edited collection of jeans, tanks and easy dresses as well as mid-century furniture, pillows made from Swiss army blankets and other vintage fabrics, and pottery and photography by local artists. Though the new digs are decidedly more bucolic, Martin fans are essentially the same. "In the East Village, I had young rocker chicks," Albert says. "This is a wider clientele. But no matter their age, everyone wants cool clothes that look good." And the allure of perfectly fitting jeans remains as strong as ever. "I wasn't familiar with Anne's line before we opened the store," says Litteron. "But I'm a convert. They're the only jeans I wear now."

Les Paul, the father of the electric guitar, often used to say that the favorite of his many disciples was Jeff Beck, a two-time inductee into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame for his work as a member of the Yardbirds and as a solo artist. Mr. Beck, in turn, has always said that his interest in the instrument was born when he heard "How High the Moon" on the radio as a 6-year-old. So when Iridium, the New York City jazz club where Les Paul had a Monday-night residency until his death last year, was looking for someone to lead a tribute to Paul, Mr. Beck was the logical choice.

Reversing a lower court ruling, a panel of federal judges on Wednesday decided that the city can keep secret roughly 1,800 pages of records of police surveillance leading up to the 2004 Republican National Convention in New York.

Americans who have been unemployed for more than six months are much more likely to report having emotional distress than people who have been unemployed for a shorter period, according to new Gallup survey data.

The Puerto Rican Day Parade, set for Sunday, has had a rough go of late. The telenovela star Osvaldo Rios stepped down Tuesday as the parade's "international godfather" - or grand marshal - after revelations that he had served jail time for domestic violence. Parade organizers were already grappling with another loss - real estate.

I'll never forget the time that my parents returned from a trip to Paris, gushing over the Place des Vosges. They told me it was the most beautiful square they had ever seen. Square, shmare, thought the clueless teenage me. What's so great about an empty space? Some years later, I saw what I'd been dissing: a 17th-century square, framed by tall, elegant red-brick facades and slate roofs that seemed to make time stand still. I wanted to pitch a tent then and there, and never leave.

Recently, 10 healthy male college students filed into an exercise laboratory at Brigham Young University in Utah to drink pickle juice. Many people involved in sports are convinced that the briny fluid combats muscle cramping. In a 2008 survey, a quarter of the athletic trainers interviewed said that they regularly dispense pickle juice to cramp-stricken athletes. Many also report that, in their experiences, the stuff quickly brakes the cramping. The athletic trainers have told researchers that they believe the pickle juice must be replenishing the salt and fluids the athletes had lost to sweat. Richard Tabnik, a jazz alto saxophonist, practices at the south end of Riverside Park. "I was having fights with my neighbors upstairs," he explained. "I am a peacenik. So I decided to try it out here. If you want a lesson in counterpoint, it's here. I've got the earth and the sky. I often see a cluster of goslings pass by as I play. It doesn't get better." He talked about his career with Ozier Muhammad for the 10th installment of "Sounds From Uncommon Spaces." His remarks have been condensed and edited for brevity and clarity.

MASIN--Herman L. June 21, 1913 - June 8, 2010. Writer extraordinaire. Editor-in-chief of Scholastic Coach and Athletic Director for 72 years. Raconteur, athlete, lover of jazz and classic movies, favorite uncle, mentor and treasured friend. He was a great wit and words were his life. Herman was the adored son of the late Bessie and Solomon Masin. Brother of the late Frances Masin, Rose Schiff, Anne Seidman and Mary Nestanpower. Beloved uncle of Marjorie Claire Baines, Leni and Herbert Grossman, Louise and Nat Yohalem, Beth and Gerard Smetana, Peter and Bonnie Seidman and Stephen and Ruth Nestanpower. Cherished great-uncle and great-great- uncle. Family and friends will gather for a memorial remembrance on Wednesday, June 23rd at 9:45am at Riverside Memorial Chapels on Amsterdam Ave. and 76th Street. Contributions to a charity of the donor's choice.

BAKER--Harvey, 77, died in San Diego, CA June 5th. Beloved brother, father, fiancee, colleague and professor. Taught psychology at Queens College for 36 years and was greatly esteemed by faculty and students alike. Leading energy psychology researcher with numerous articles in scientific journals. Director of Research and a member of the Board of The Association for Comprehensive Energy Psychology (ACEP). Survived by his sister Roz, daughter Amy, son Jonah and his beloved fiance Adela Oliver. Harvey loved his family, research and teaching, and he loved to laugh. He is greatly missed. Burial 1pm, Thursday in Malden, MA (800-982-3717). Shiva in New York Sunday through Tuesday at Dr. Adela Oliver, 120 West 97th St., Apt 11-I (212-662-7968). Contributions may be made to ACEP Research Fund, 349 W. Lancaster Ave, Ste. 101, Haverford, PA 19041.

A TELLING moment came midway through the American fashion industry's big awards night at Lincoln Center on Monday when Sean Combs, the music and apparel mogul, appeared in a series of funny MTV-style video clips that spoofed scenes from popular films like ''Avatar'' (Mr. Combs landed on Pandora to open a Tom Ford store) and ''The Blind Side'' (he and some Rag & Bone models tackled Sandra Bullock's Leigh Anne Tuohy.) The best bit came from a scene remixed from ''Up in the Air,'' when Mr. Combs was shown as an employee in the process of being downsized.

More than 500 Co-op City employees agreed Tuesday to end their weeklong strike and return to work as union leaders and the development's managers pledged to resume stalled contract negotiations. The strike of groundskeepers, janitors and maintenance workers had left the sprawling Bronx housing development severely understaffed, leading residents and office workers to keep up the grounds. Trash sat uncollected for days and floors and stairwells gathered dirt.

CLOUD--John Moorhead, died June 6, 2010, in Norfolk, VA. Born in Englewood, NJ, he graduated from Phillips Academy at Andover, Princeton University, and University of Virginia Law School, and practiced law for many years. He is survived by daughters Julia Sandor and Rachel Joy, their husbands, and six grandchildren; by Betty Cloud Davis and loyal friend Terry Davis; and by brother Robert and nephew Jared. Diabetes made his last years difficult, but he bore his troubles with fortitude. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

BERNSTEIN--Dr. Robert. A gifted doctor who ushered cherished new lives into our world, a respected mentor who shared his passion for medicine with those he taught and worked with. To his children, and their many friends, a source of advice, unconditional support and enthusiasm. To Roz, his wife, best friend, and life-long partner, nothing less than her endless love. His friends will bear the sadness of his loss by remembering the immense joy we felt in sharing his life. Deepest condolences and love, the Sanders Family

On a recent Monday during the evening rush on a Brooklyn-bound L train, a dozen or so people boarding the train at Union Square shuffled into the rear of the carriage where I was seated. The train was typically crowded, and there was a soberness in peoples' faces that I took to be nothing more than usual rush-hour blankness. A man who got on, still with his iPod headphones in, began talking to those of us seated in front of him. ''This woman just died,'' he said. ''Just now. The train hit her. She fell in the tracks.'' We were aware he was talking, and talking to us, but we pretended not to notice, as one sometimes does on the subway, until it became apparent that everyone who got on the train at Union Square was looking at us as the man spoke, and they were looking directly and gravely.

BROWN--Himan. Brooklyn College mourns the passing of Himan Brown, '34. His generosity allowed the college to build a state-of-the-art radio station, upgrade television studios and support young writers pursuing M.F.A.s in creative writing. As an instructor in the Television and Radio department, he passed on to another generation his talent and experience as a legendary radio producer, inspiring many of them to follow in his footsteps. We are deeply grateful for his loyalty throughout the years. Karen L. Gould President

ROBERTSON--Josephine. The Board of Trustees, Women's Board, Alumni and Staff of The Boys' Club of New York express their deepest sympathy to the family of Josie Robertson. Elected to the BCNY Board of Trustees in 2000 and the Women's Board in 1978, Josie served as Women's Board President from 1983 to 1986. As founder and benefactor of the Josie Robertson School of Music and Art, home of The Boys' Club music program, Josie was honored at the 72nd Annual Spring Dance in 2007 at Jazz at Lincoln Center. She served on a great many Women's Board and Board of Trustees Committees. As friend, supporter and Trustee, Josie embodied The Boys' Club of New York's core principles of character, civility community, and citizenship. She will be remembered by us all with deep affection. The Boys' Club of New York

We send our deepest sympathies to Steve and the entire Safyer family. Pamela S. Brier Chair, GNYHA Kenneth E. Raske, President, GNYHA

ROBERTSON--Josephine T.,Classroom, Inc. mourns the passing of Josie Robertson, our beloved colleague and friend. A Texas pipeline tycoon who died two months ago may become the first American billionaire allowed to pass his fortune to his children and grandchildren tax-free. Dan L. Duncan, a soft-spoken farm boy who started with $10,000 and two propane trucks, and built a network of natural gas processing plants and pipelines that made him the richest person in Houston, died in late March of a brain hemorrhage at 77.

PEARSON--Emily Feder Was born in Cluj, Transylvania/Hungary on July 4, 1914. She immigrated in 1928 with her family and was married to Samuel Pearson on December 31, 1936. In 1940 Emily lived in Brooklyn and was a neighbor of Estee Lauder, and became her first door to door makeup model. During WWII Emily sang for the USO entertaining with Rosemary Clooney and Billy Daniels. Emily supported Sam through his career in Wall Street and ultimately joined as founding partners with Jack Dreyfus in The Dreyfus Fund. In 1962 Emily dined with Eleanor Roosevelt at the request of Dr. David Gurewitsch, the Roosevelt's personal physician. Emily was asked to convince the ailing first lady to go to Switzerland to undergo cellular rejuvenation therapy (the precursor to stem cell research). Emily and Sam underwent this treatment by Dr. Paul Niehans of Vevey Switzerland and lived into their 90s. Emily and Sam contributed heavily to Robert F. Kennedy. The Senator personally wrote to thank them for helping to retire his 1964 campaign debt. With connections in the Kennedy and Nixon administrations, Emily labored to free relatives from behind the Iron Curtain, as well as fed and clothed Hungarian immigrants. Emily and Sam were Master Builders of The Albert Einstein College of Medicine, a division of Yeshiva University. Their first great-grandchild Tyler was delivered in Madison, WI by an obstetrician who was a graduate of the very same institution. They also, along with Jacob Fuchsberg (New York State Court of Appeals) were founders of the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, NY. Emily Pearson financed the start up of The MBP Company, LLC d/b/a Marron Foods, an ingredient manufacturing company headquartered in Harrison, NY with facilities in Durand and Oconomowoc, WI. The concern is the recipient of the Small Business Success Story Award from the Oshkosh College of Business, division of the University of Wisconsin. Emily's eldest son Michael passed away in 1987. She is survived by her two other sons Roger and his wife Jennifer, Matthew and his wife Ronnie. Emily is also survived by her grandchildren Daniel and his wife Billee, Ryan, Michael, Olivia, Adam and Ian. She is also survived by two great-granchildren Tyler and Jacob. Emily requested that in lieu of food and other offerings of condolence, donations be sent to The Young Israel of Harrison, New York at 207 Union Avenue, Harrison, NY 10528 to help their building program. She wanted to help erect two synagogues in her beloved home Town of Harrison, New York where she resided for 53 years. Emily Pearson's tenacity and determined perseverance insured the success of her husband and sons. She never forgot her roots and always taught her family to give back to the community and country she loved so dearly. Gravesite service will be held at Riversville Cemetery at 1pm Thursday. For further information please contact Riverside Chapel at 914-664-6800.

Richard Tabnik, a jazz alto saxophonist, has been practicing at the south end of Riverside Park for five years or so. ''I was having fights with my neighbors upstairs,'' he said. ''I am a peacenik, so I decided to try it out here. If you want a lesson in counterpoint, it's here. I've got the earth and the sky. I often see a cluster of goslings pass by as I play.'' It is not always so peaceful.

RECANT--Benjamin S.,beloved father of Jane, Donna and Robin, grandfather of Eric and Rebecca; A true renaissance man, his greatness measured by his uncompromising integrity and honor, his unwavering love for his children and grandchildren and his boundless generosity. In his lifetime, he did it all. He served his country as a Lieutenant in the U.S Navy at the end of WWII, he went on to become a leading Oral and Maxillo Facial Surgeon and professor, he traveled the world, played tennis, skied, and always maintained deep and loyal ties to his friends, and, until the last few years when his illness deprived him of his independence, he staunchly insisted on doing it all on his own. Ben Recant was known for never shying away from a vigorous political debate, or from putting himself on the line to defend his sense of justice and righteousness. He proudly served two tours of duty as a volunteer for the Israeli armed services during times of war, replacing and supporting soldiers who were in active combat. He was a hero in every way. We will forever cherish him in our hearts and minds. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapels on Wednesday at 11:15am, Shiva Wednesday evening and Thursday afternoon and evening at the home of Jane Recant 455 East 86th Street.

BOSTON -- In a world where Nabisco sells ''artisan'' Wheat Thins, the designation of Samuel Adams as a craft beer seems perfectly fair. But the Boston Beer Company, the brewery that was founded in 1984 and makes Sam Adams, is on the verge of outgrowing its coveted craft status -- at least according to the Brewers Association, a national trade group that defines craft brewers in part as producing fewer than two million barrels a year.

The On Baseball column on Tuesday, contrasting the hopefulness of the Washington Nationals with the woe of their neighbors, the Baltimore Orioles, misidentified a county in Maryland whose residents could be attracted to a more appealing Nationals franchise. It is Prince George's County, not Prince William. (There is a Prince William County in the Washington metropolitan area, but it is in Virginia.)

In his latest salvo against immigration fraud, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Tuesday that he had filed lawsuits accusing several companies of preying on the Haitian population in New York by fraudulently offering immigration services following the earthquake that devastated Port-au-Prince. The lawsuits accuse three companies, all based in Brooklyn, of unlawfully providing legal advice and services to Haitian immigrants even though their owners and employees were not lawyers and were therefore forbidden from representing anyone before immigration authorities, Mr. Cuomo said in a news release (see also Creole version).

BARCELONA, Spain -- For years, almost nobody paid attention to the sky-is-falling alarms of Edward Hugh, a gregarious British blogger and self-taught economist who repeatedly predicted that the euro zone could not survive. Living a largely hand-to-mouth existence here on his part-time teacher's salary, he sent one post after another into the Internet wilderness. It was the height of policy folly, he warned, to think that aging, penny-pinching Germans could successfully coexist under one currency umbrella with the more youthful, credit-card-wielding Irish, Greeks and Spaniards who shared the euro with them.

A couple of weeks ago, at Bar Boulud in Manhattan, I ordered oysters. They came beautifully nestled on ice, punctuated with a scattering of pink peppercorns. Usually I enjoy my oysters plain, with no condiments. But I was curious about the peppercorns and put some on the oysters. It was a delicious combination. Earlier that day, I had tasted 20 rosés from Provence. As I began to think about food that would complement the wines, the fruity spiciness and the floral aroma of the peppercorns stuck in my mind. Not with oysters, but perhaps with translucent raw slices of fresh, seasonal, sweet fish like fluke. Along with the peppercorns, I added pink grapefruit for a modest note of bitter sweetness, and some high-toned radish slices.

ORENSTEIN--Reed, beloved husband of Arlene; devoted father of Jillian; dear father-in-law of Aidan; adored grandfather of Joel; dedicated brother of Jane.
