ROBERTSON--Josie. The Women's Board of The Boys' Club of New York acknowledges with great sorrow the passing of Josie Robertson, a dearly loved member and friend. Josie served on the Women's Board since 1978 and as its president from 1983 to 1986. We always sought her counsel, trusted her judgment and appreciated her wisdom and kind heart. We were pleased to honor her at our Spring Dance in 2007 for her dedication to the boys served by The Boys' Club. The event was the most successful ever held by The Boys' Club and Josie was surprised that evening by the naming of BCNY's music and art program as the Josie Robertson School of Music and Art in tribute to her passion for the arts, support of education, and devotion to helping children. Our condolences to her husband, Julian, and her loving family. Our lives were all made richer by knowing her. The Women's Board

EVART--Anna, 90, died peacefully on June 5. Mother of Siblings Day Founder. Wife of late Alfred Evart (Estonian). Mother of three siblings. She had three sisters - Alice, Katherine and Pauline whose powerful bond, all now deceased, inspired her only surviving child, Claudia Evart to start a national campaign in '98 for a National Siblings Day held on April 10, birth date of Lisette, to celebrate the sibling bond that is forever a special gift. Born Brooklyn, NY. Parents: Alex and Christina Machin, Russian. Alfred died with daughter Lisette (19) car accident Holland; son Alan deceased '86. Funeral June 9, 2010, Vladimir's Cemetery Jackson, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations to charity, Siblings Day Foundation: P.O. Box 85 NY, NY 10163 or paypal www.siblingsday.org

ROBERTSON--Josephine (Josie) Tucker, died at her home in New York City on June 8 after a long struggle with breast cancer. The daughter of Robert and Josephine (Pimmie) Spencer Tucker, she was born May 16, 1943, in San Antonio, and graduated from Saint Mary's Hall there in 1961. She later attended Briarcliff College and graduated from the University of Texas in 1965. Before her marriage to Julian Robertson in 1972, Josie and her sister-in-law started and managed Tuckertown which designed and produced Christmas-tree ornaments which sold to leading department stores throughout the nation. Known always for her artistic talents and creativity, she collaborated with Julian to build two golf-course resorts in New Zealand. Hers was the eye behind the impeccable style of the two award-winning lodges they built near the golf courses. An avid golfer, she was the 2006 women's champion at Sebonack Golf Club in Southampton, NY. She was gifted with flowers, and loved using them while entertaining friends and family. Always gracious, lighthearted, and fun, she masked a formidable set of organizational skills which she put to work as a mother of three sons and as a volunteer in New York City. Her civic accomplishments were many. She joined the Women's Board of The Boys' Club of New York in 1978, served as its president, and in 2000 was elected to the combined board of trustees. In 2007, when she was the honoree at its annual spring dance, a group of friends raised money in her honor for the Boys' Club's Josie Robertson School of Music and Art. She also was on the Board of Overseers of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center since 2004, a director of Classroom, Inc. from 1999 and a director of the Breast Cancer Research Foundation since 2002. In 1996, the Robertsons established the Robertson Foundation which supports education, medical research, spirituality, and environmental causes. In 1998, shortly after her breast-cancer surgery, Julian surprised Josie with a gift to Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts that named the plaza there in her honor. She and Julian were leading supporters of the Central Park Conservancy, where she joined the board of the Women's Committee in 1997. In 1998 they funded the restoration of the 59th Street Pond and its surrounding landscape. She is survived by her loving family: her husband of 38 years; son Spencer, his wife, Sarah, and their children Hollis, Hart, and Wyndham of Brooklyn; son Julian H. III (Jay) of Hawke's Bay, New Zealand; and son Alexander Tucker of Manhattan. Also surviving are two sisters, Mary Cassell of Albuquerque and Julia Rasmussen of Houston, and two brothers, Robert Tucker of San Antonio and George Tucker of Midland. She will be missed by everyone fortunate enough to have known her. Funeral will be at 11am Friday, June 11 at St. Bartholomew's Church at 325 Park Avenue, New York. Visitation will be at 11:30-2 and 5-7pm on Thursday, June 10 at Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Boys Club of New York, 287 East 10th Street, NYC 1009; Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital, Dept. of Development, 633 Third Avenue-28th Floor, NYC 10018; and PAVE Academy Charter School, 71 Sullivan Street, Brooklyn, NY 11231.

A heap of travel gadgets hitting the market brings the comfort of home -- and images from there, too -- to people on the road, Christine Negroni reports in The Times. Among the offerings: a personal video system that allows you to aim wireless cameras at say, your cat's food bowl and view it real time on the Web; a battery-run charger for mobile devices; and goggles with a built-in monitor that for the viewer is the equivalent of an 80-inch screen. Seriously. Our former Frugal Traveler compiled a list of gadgets last year, and so have Time and Travel and Leisure. But a narrow poll of In Transit editors -- who are partial to smartphones and travel guides -- indicates that we could still use some suggestions. Got any favorite devices that you just can't leave home without?

As anyone knows who has followed the photo documentation of the catastrophic Deepwater Horizon oil leak, aerial pictures tend by their nature to obscure the damage done at surface level and below. At the same time, however, there is no denying that high-altitude views exert an abstract attraction of their own. Sandor H. Szabo, a photographer for the MTI Hungarian News Agency, has been taking the long view of the flooding in his country that has displaced about 4,000 people. Far removed from the misery on the ground, he has created canvases that would not be out of place in a gallery of modern art. They are well worth examining in "Full Screen" mode.

The Senate this week takes up a tax extenders bill with provisions that are sure to please small businesses. The American Jobs and Closing Tax Loopholes Act of 2010 - which has already passed the House twice and the Senate once - resuscitates many business tax benefits that expired at the end of last year. It also revives provisions in the stimulus bill that have bolstered Small Business Administration lending by increasing loan guarantees and eliminating borrower fees. Several times those measures have expired before winning short-term extensions from Congress, but they have not yet been renewed after running out of money and legal authority at the end of May. This bill will extend them through the end of the year.

A spokesman for the Roman Catholic Church in Scotland told The Associated Press that Ms. Boyle, the homegrown singing sensation who was discovered last year on the reality competition "Britain's Got Talent," was likely to perform for Pope Benedict XVI during a papal tour this fall. While negotiations are still taking place, The A.P. said, Ms. Boyle is expected to sing during an open-air papal Mass at Bellahouston Park in Glasgow on Sept. 16. The event is part of a four-day trip by Benedict, during which he will also address Parliament and beatify John Henry Newman, a cardinal who converted to Catholicism in the 19th century. In a statement, a spokeswoman for Ms. Boyle told Reuters: "Susan's management are currently looking at the possibility of this happening."

ROBERTSON--Josephine. The Board of Directors and Management of the Hampshire House acknowledge with great sorrow the passing of our beloved neighbor and friend, Josephine Robertson. Josie served on the Board of Directors of the Hampshire House for more than 11 years. We were inspired by her grace, charm and kindness. Josie had a leadership role in motivating the Hampshire House to become a Green Energy model. Our heartfelt condolences to her husband Julian, their sons Spencer, Julian III and Alexander; grandchildren Hollis, Hart, and Wyndham and her sisters Mary and Julia and brothers Robert and George.

THE ARTS A dance review on Tuesday about ''One-Man Show'' at Joe's Pub, which in fact had four performers, misstated the surname of one at one point. As noted elsewhere in the review, he is Aaron Mattocks, not Moss.

MEGUMI EDA sailed into the party on June 3, so chicly assured you could have mistaken the ice pack held to her face for a fresh-minted ''it'' bag. In fact, she was nursing a shiner acquired that morning when a cabinet fell on her head. It would have taken more to keep Ms. Eda (far right), a principal dancer with the Karole Armitage dance company, from taking her place on stage at the Cedar Lake theater in Chelsea for a performance of ''Three Theories,'' the new physics-inspired ballet by Ms. Armitage (with blond hair at left), or from turning up later for the company's benefit gala and auction at Jack Studios in Chelsea.
The Crib Sheet column last Thursday referred incorrectly to Liv Ullmann in a comment about the popularity of the Swedish author Stieg Larsson. She is Norwegian, not Swedish.

A report last Thursday in the Currents column about a tree museum in Switzerland referred imprecisely to one of the plants there. A Taxus baccata is otherwise known as an English yew, not a conifer, which is a class of tree that includes the English yew.

Now that AT&T no longer offers a $30-a-month unlimited data plan, many smartphone owners may wonder how that affects them. For most, it's a chance to save money. But there is no need to guess. There are tools to help people determine their best plan. AT&T basically offers two plans, one allowing up to 200 megabytes of data for $15 a month and the other supplying two gigabytes of data for $25 a month.

INTERNATIONAL An article on May 8 about the debate within Russia over Stalin's legacy referred imprecisely to the Polish victims of a massacre carried out by Soviet forces in the Katyn forest near Smolensk, Russia, at the start of World War II, an event that came to symbolize Stalinist atrocities. The victims, who numbered more than 20,000, included captured Polish military officers, soldiers and civilians -- not just ''Polish troops.'' This correction was delayed because a reader's e-mail message last month about the error went astray at The Times.

SCIENCE TIMES An article on May 11 about the debate over payments to women who provide eggs for fertility treatments and stem cell research referred imprecisely to the surgery for extracting eggs. Donors are usually given an intravenous sedative, not a local anesthetic.

BROWN--Himan. The CUNY Graduate School of Journalism offers its sincere condolences to the family and friends of Himan Brown. His generosity, friendship, and advice were instrumental in helping us establish a first-rate graduate school of journalism. The Himan Brown Scholarship Fund benefits students interested in broadcast journalism, particularly radio journalism. We are grateful to have had an opportunity to benefit from his knowledge of the journalism profession, shared always with his wry sense of humor, love of the industry, and concern for public education. Stephen B. Shepard, Founding Dean

JAROWSKI--Charles I.,on June 4, 2010 at the age of 92. Beloved husband of Winifred. Devoted father of Charles Jr. (Joan), Ana Paula Black (Leland), and Stephen. Cherished grandfather of two and great-grandfather of one. Reposing at The Massapequa Funeral Inc, 4980 Merrick Road (corner of Whitewood) Massapequa Park on Thursday 7-9pm and Friday 7-9pm. ROBERTSON--Josephine (Josie) Tucker. Died at her home in New York City on June 8 after a long struggle with breast cancer. The daughter of Robert and Josephine (Pimmie) Spencer Tucker, she was born May 16, 1943, in San Antonio, and graduated from Saint Mary's Hall there in 1961. She later attended Briarcliff College and graduated from the University of Texas in 1965. Before her marriage to Julian Robertson in 1972, Josie and her sister-in-law started and managed Tuckertown which designed and produced Christmas-tree ornaments which sold to leading department stores throughout the nation. Known always for her artistic talents and creativity, she collaborated with Julian to build two golf-course resorts in New Zealand. Hers was the eye behind the impeccable style of the two award-winning lodges they built near the golf courses. An avid golfer, she was the 2006 women's champion at Sebonack Golf Club in Southampton, NY. She was gifted with flowers, and loved using them while entertaining friends and family. Always gracious, lighthearted, and fun, she masked a formidable set of organizational skills which she put to work as a mother of three sons and as a volunteer in New York City. Her civic accomplishments were many. She joined the Women's Board of The Boys' Club of New York in 1978, served as its president, and in 2000 was elected to the combined board of trustees. In 2007, when she was the honoree at its annual spring dance, a group of friends raised money in her honor for the Boys' Club's Josie Robertson School of Music and Art. She also was on the Board of Overseers of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center since 2004, a director of Classroom, Inc. from 1999 and a director of the Breast Cancer Research Foundation since 2002. In 1996, the Robertsons established the Robertson Foundation which supports education, medical research, spirituality, and environmental causes. In 1998, shortly after her breast-cancer surgery, Julian surprised Josie with a gift to Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts that named the plaza there in her honor. She and Julian were leading supporters of the Central Park Conservancy, where she joined the board of the Women's Committee in 1997. In 1998 they funded the restoration of the 59th Street Pond and its surrounding landscape. She is survived by her loving family: her husband of 38 years; son Spencer, his wife, Sarah, and their children Hollis, Hart, and Wyndham of Brooklyn; son Julian H. III (Jay) of Hawke's Bay, New Zealand; and son Alexander Tucker of Manhattan. Also surviving are two sisters, Mary Cassell of Albuquerque and Julia Rasmussen of Houston, and two brothers, Robert Tucker of San Antonio and George Tucker of Midland. She will be missed by everyone fortunate enough to have known her. Funeral will be at 11am Friday, June 11 at St. Bartholomew's Church at 325 Park Avenue, New York. Visitation will be at 11:30-2 and 5-7pm on Thursday, June 10 at Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Boys Club of New York, 287 East 10th Street, NYC 1009; Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital, Dept. of Development, 633 Third Avenue-28th Floor, NYC 10018; and PAVE Academy Charter School, 71 Sullivan Street, Brooklyn, NY 11231.

If you snap a lot of photos in low-lighting conditions, you probably know that point-and-shoot cameras deliver pretty poor image quality once the sun goes down. Of course, you can use flash to get crisper photos, but that kills the ambience of soft natural lighting. Canon addresses this conundrum with its $350 PowerShot SD4000 IS, a newcomer to its ELPH line that delivers low-light images without the whitening blaze of flash.

Funeral Sunday, noon at Washington Cemetery, Brooklyn.

TEPPER--Albert, age 89, on June 8, 2010. Professor Emeritus of Music, Hofstra University. Devoted husband of the late Judith. Loving father of Marsha (Marc) Jordan and Marian (Robert) Stern. Adoring grandpa of Elisabeth and Marguerite. Cremation private.

SAMPLING some of the essential oils that go into natural perfumes couldn't be easier: just look for an herb or a blossom in the garden. ''If you take a leaf and fold it up in your hand and smell your palm, it's a wonderful aroma,'' said Mandy Aftel, an author and leader in the natural perfume movement. Preserving those scents is trickier -- like capturing the sublimity of a sunset with a cellphone photo. Yet it's possible to make fragrant tinctures at home with a minimum of gear.

BLUME--Clinton W. Jr. ABS Partners Real Estate mourns the passing of our long time friend and colleague Clinton W. Blume Jr. Clint was a well respected member of the New York real estate community, graduate of Colgate University, served honorably in the United States Marine Corps., former Chairman of the YMWREA and recipient of the REBNY Lawrence Memorial award in recognition of his outstanding work. Clint was a great raconteur and could hold a room effortlessly. He was fiercely loyal to his family, friends and country. His wit, style and character will be sorely missed by those who loved him. Earle Altman, Gregg Schenker, Steven Hornstock, Jay Kreisberg and the entire ABS team.

Air guitarists can take one small step toward reality with PaperJamz, a set of musical instruments that look as if they've been run over by a steamroller. The toys, aimed at ages 5 and up, come from WowWee, and will be available next month. The collection consists of six differently decorated guitars ($25 each), a drum pad ($25) and a shoebox-sized amp ($15). Each requires AAA batteries, and when seen from a side angle, is just a bit thicker than a slab of cardboard.

MINERVA--Phyllis, (Mondshein), June 4, 2010. We mourn the loss of our beloved mother and the devoted wife of the late Dan Minerva. Young at heart and always curious, her passion for helping others understand and face their most difficult challenges suited her life long practice as a clinical social worker. She grew up in the Bronx and lived, as a sought-after therapist and community volunteer, in Minnesota, Pennsylvania, Ohio and New York. She moved last year to the Cedar Crest retirement community in New Jersey, her "college campus for seniors." She is survived by three children: Mara Melum of St. Paul, MN, Franklin Minerva of New York and Ellen Minerva of Silver Spring, MD, as well as seven grandchildren, Daniel, Arielle, Annie, Jessica, Adelaide, Theodore and Benjamin. A memorial service will be held June 21 at 3pm at the Unitarian Universalist Congregation of York ("UUCY"), 925 South George St, York, PA 17403. Donations to the UUCY. Phyllis: Everyone's Mom, Counselor, Confidant, Mentor, Friend--she will be sorely missed.

Franklin Street in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, a sweet compact strip of creative indie shops and bars pouring microbrews, is also a hotbed of collaborative neighborhood events, like a prom-themed Matchmaking Mixer (disaster stories, anyone?) to be given by the bookstore Word (No. 126) at the Diamond Bar (No. 43) on June 17. All the more reason for Manhattanites, the new bridge-and-tunnel crowd, to make the pilgrimage.

The Puerto Rican Day Parade, set for Sunday, has had a rough go of late. The telenovela star Osvaldo Rios stepped down Tuesday as the parade's ''international godfather'' - or grand marshal - after revelations that he had served jail time for domestic violence. Parade organizers were already grappling with another loss - real estate. In February the Police Department announced that all city parades had to be cut by 25 percent in length and limited in duration to five hours. Shorter parades would mean less police overtime, saving an estimated $3.1 million, the department said.

WEINTRAUB--Abraham, 100 years, died June 8, 2010. Our father Abraham was born in Brooklyn in 1920 and lived all his life in that borough. He was married for 57 years to Ruth Donenfeld Weintraub (1915-1993), to whom he was passionately devoted. Abe held a variety of jobs during his lifetime, which included chipper and caulker at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, shoe salesman, window trimmer, toy company salesman and production manager, and mail handler for the US Post Office. He retained a special interest and pride in the growth of American Business as he watched its development during the almost full century of his life. Abe is survived by his daughter Florence, sons Irwin, Joel, and Robert, six grandchildren, five great-grandchildren, his brother Sidney and sister Joyce. Always enthusiastic about life's possibilities, Abe began a pastime of running at age 80. After training with the NY Roadrunners Club, he competed in 10 New York and three London Marathons, as well as many one - 10 mile races in New York City, Falmouth, MA and Martha's Vineyard, MA. Soon after beginning to run, he expressed his goal to be the first runner over 90 to compete in the NYC Marathon, which he accomplished in 2000. Between the ages of 80 and 94 he participated in over 500 races. Through his drive and vigor, he became an inspiration and role model for both runners and non-runners alike, illustrating what could be accomplished in later years. Memorial services will be held Friday, June 11 at 11:30am at IJ Morris Funeral Home at 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY.

ROBERTSON--Josephine. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc. are deeply saddened by the untimely passing of Josephine "Josie" Tucker Robertson, a longtime friend and supporter of Lincoln Center, of New York City through the Central Park Conservancy and the Boys Club of New York, and of the arts in general. She and her husband Julian H. Robertson, Jr., a member of our Board since 1998, opened their home for Lincoln Center events, and also have been generous contributors to Lincoln Center Institute's arts and education activities through the Robertson Foundation. Her warm and gracious spirit lives on in the iconic symbol of Lincoln Center that was named in her honor in 1998, Josie Robertson Plaza. We extend our sincerest condolences to her husband Julian; their sons Spencer, Julian H. III (Jay), and Alexander; and the extended family. Katherine Farley, Chair Reynold Levy, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc.

ROBERTSON--Josie. The Breast Cancer Research Foundation mourns the passing of Josie Robertson, our beloved Board of Directors member since 2002. Her grace, generosity, and dedication informed us, made us stronger, and will be greatly missed. We send our heartfelt condolences to her loving husband Julian, and her entire family. Evelyn H. Lauder, Chairman Myra J. Biblowit, President Jeanette S. Wagner, Vice President Deborah Krulewitch, Secretary and Treasurer Larry Norton, M.D., Scientific Director

HONG KONG -- Chinese exports in May jumped 48.5 percent from the same period last year, the country's customs agency reported Thursday, showing that the European debt crisis has not yet significantly dented international trade or crimped the pace of growth in one of the world's fastest-growing major economies. Imports rose 48.3 percent from a year earlier, as domestic demand for raw materials and other goods was buoyed by a massive government spending program and a flood of easy credit from state-owned lenders.

Up to the end of May, most of the oil making landfall from the Deepwater Horizon disaster was in Louisiana. But in June, tar balls and oil mousse began to reach the shores of Mississippi, Alabama and Florida.

The Kno is a new twist on the tablet and e-reader concept, aimed at the college market; it allows students to view textbooks on two digital screens much as they would view them in their analog versions, with text, color images and graphics. The Kno was first shown in public last Wednesday at The Wall Street Journal's D8 technology conference in California. It is made by Kno, founded by Osman Rashid.

An article on Tuesday about candidates' making last-minute pitches to voters before primary elections in several states misidentified the office sought by Chuck DeVore, a state assemblyman in California. He was running for United States senator, not governor. (He finished third in the Republican primary, won by Carly Fiorina.)

OBITUARIES An obituary on Tuesday about Marvin Isley, the bassist for the Isley Brothers, misstated his relationship to Chris Jasper, the band's keyboardist. Mr. Jasper was Mr. Isley's brother-in-law, not his cousin.

KNAUER--Elfriede R. (Kezia), died at age 83, in Philadelphia on June 7, 2010 after a long illness. She was a passionate scholar whose expertise began with the art and culture of classical antiquity and ranged from Europe through Central Asia to the Far East. She published widely and shared knowledge unstintingly. The learning and accomplishments of a bygone era have departed with her.

THE Israeli raid on the Free Gaza flotilla has generated an outpouring of clichés from the usual suspects. It is almost impossible to discuss the Middle East without resorting to tired accusations and ritual defenses: perhaps a little house cleaning is in order. No. 1: Israel is being/should be delegitimized

HALL--Peter J. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Peter J. Hall, who designed costumes for 13 of our productions, including such renowned stagings as Aida, La Boheme, Boris Godunov, Don Carlo, Die Fledermaus, Lohengrin, Otello (two productions), and Tosca. He was Resident Costume Designer at the Met from 1979 to 1988 (excepting the 1983-84 season). He is fondly remembered by those who worked with him not only for his extraordinary talent, but for his genuine kindness and collaborative spirit. We extend our sincere condolences to his many friends. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

NATIONAL An article on Tuesday about the retirement of Helen Thomas, a Hearst columnist who was the unofficial dean of the White House press corps for many years, misstated her place of birth. She was born in Kentucky; she was not ''a native'' of Detroit, though she moved there as a child.

KLEINMAN--Esther. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with profound sadness the passing of Esther Kleinman, beloved sister of Leah Susskind, whose generosity and commitment to social and humanitarian causes enrich the lives of millions in need in New York, in Israel, and around the world. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President; Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

An article on Wednesday about Samuel Adams, which is on the verge of outgrowing its status as a craft beer, misstated the number of years ago that Boston Beer introduced it. As the article noted, the beer was introduced in 1984, so it was 26 years ago -- not 16.

FRONT PAGE An article on Monday about corruption among the private security companies in Afghanistan hired to protect supply convoys to American and NATO bases there misspelled the middle name of the Wardak provincial governor, who had unsuccessfully sought a permanent ban on two of the biggest security companies as escors for NATO convoys on the Kabul-Kandahar highway. He is Mohammed Halim Fedai, not Mohammed Hakim Fedai.
To find a shoe has always been my dream. DIANA ZARDARYAN, an Armenian doctoral student who found the world's oldest shoe. [A3]

BUSINESS DAY An article on Friday about Google's decision to surrender to European governments the personal data it improperly collected over unsecured wireless networks erroneously included one country among those to receive the data. Google will share the data with regulators in Germany, Spain and France -- but not with regulators in Italy.

ROBERTSON--Josephine Tucker. The Boards of Overseers and Managers of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center note with sorrow the death of their colleague Josephine Robertson. Mrs. Robertson joined the Board of Overseers in 2004 and served as a valued member of the Joint Operational Policy Committee and the Patient Care Committee. We extend our sincere condolences to her husband, Julian; their sons, Spencer, Julian, and Alexander, and all of her family. James D. Robinson III Honorary Chairman Douglas A. Warner III Chairman Richard I. Beattie Vice Chairman Louis V. Gerstner, Jr. Vice Chairman Harold Varmus, MD President Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center
An article last Thursday about the effect of the oil spill on the fishing industry referred incorrectly to oysters. They are bivalve mollusks, not crustaceans.

ROBERTSON--Josephine. The Board of Directors, Leadership Counsel and staff of The New York Stem Cell Foundation mourn the loss of Josie Robertson, cherished wife of our esteemed friend and benefactor, Julian Robertson. We send our deepest sympathies to Julian, Alex, Jay, Spencer, Wyndham and the entire Robertson family. Roy Geronemus, Chairman Susan L. Solomon, President

ORENSTEIN--Reed. My voice, for thee, my love, with languorous caresses Disturbs the solemn peace the midnight dark possesses. Besides this couch of mine a mournful candle glows. And, welling up, my verse in rippling murmurs flows; It flows in streams of love, its music wholly thine, And in the dark thine eyes are sparkling over mine. They look at me and smile - and oh, the sounds I hear: "My sweet and tender friend...I'm yours, my love...my dear". Your one and only Irina. Your son Leon, friends Natalia, Alla, Natasha W., Irina F., Inna.
BERNSTEIN--Robert M. Rob, you were a prince of a man. We will always remember your heartwarming smile and we will cherish your friendship and love forever. Barry, Laurie and Romy

IRVING--Steingart. We deeply mourn the loss of one of our earliest graduates and a most beloved and esteemed teacher. Irv represented what is best as a person and as a psychoanalyst: the deepest intellectual and emotional integrity, commitment to the highest ideals of personal practice, loyalty to a large and loving circle of friends, and abiding love for his family. Our love to Joyce, David, and Amy, Chris, and Julia. Lewis Aron, Ph.D. Director, New York University Postdoctoral Program in Psychotherapy & Psychoanalysis

Darfur seems to have been forgotten, but the killings continue. After a lull, the pace of killings has increased lately, with some 600 people killed violently last month alone. As Newsweek notes, that's more than in any month since U.N. peacekeepers arrived.

No one epitomizes the pursuit of barbecue like my father-in-law. John's DVR is half-full of barbecue-related cooking shows, and he spends hours reading online commentary on proper smoking techniques. He uses natural gas when he's in a hurry, and charcoal when he's got all day, and can discuss the benefits of each. His esteem for the Weber brand is akin to another demographic's feelings for Apple -- that is, he believes it's not just the best, but that it has no credible competition.

The fate and scope of financial reform is now left to the Senate and House conference committee, which is putting together the final bill. It is an unsettling time as the struggle over derivatives reform, the Volcker Rule and untold nuances and seemingly minor provisions are left to jockeying among elected representatives. Yet, while there are many good things in the bill that should form the core of any financial reform and subsequent acts by Congress, there is one area - perhaps the key one - that this bill fails to address.

The layout and location of the Pebble Beach Golf Links, site of this week's United States Open, can bring about some unusual rules situations, specifically because the course has holes that abut what is arguably the largest lateral water hazard in the world (i.e., the Pacific Ocean). For example, this week players may choose to drop a ball in a dropping zone outside of a bunker instead of in a bunker when taking relief under the water hazard Rule (Rule 26). The long bunker to the left of the 18th fairway at Pebble Beach is immediately adjacent to the ocean.

In business competitions, as in business, the odds of winning are stacked against entrepreneurs. Of course, the chance to meet investors and partners and to get expert feedback -- along with the possibility of scoring prize money -- are chief among the reasons students tend to compete. But why would companies that are already up and running, and in some cases venture backed, risk it? And when they lose, is it worth it?

"Channeling His Inner Hound" (05:01)Robbie Brown, a Times correspondent, wants to teach his 5-year-old basset hound, Elvis, a new trick: to hunt. You'd think that the hunting instinct would come naturally to Elvis. Alas. This entertaining video, produced by Kassie Bracken, takes us to Atlanta, where Mr. Brown and Elvis attend hunting school. There, along with other hounds and the bipeds who love them, Elvis is encouraged to find his inner hunter. The shots bring out Elvis's somnolent personality and Mr. Brown's straightforward, sometimes awkward narrative is a delight. [A fuller account can be read on NYTimes.com: "Putting the Pounce Back in Your Pup."]

Sigmar Polke, an artist of infinite, often ravishing pictorial jest, whose sarcastic and vibrant layering of found images and maverick, chaos-provoking painting processes left an indelible mark on the last four decades of contemporary painting, died yesterday in Cologne, Germany. He was 69; the cause was complications of cancer, according to Gordon Veneklasen, a partner at the Michael Werner Gallery New York, the artist's chief American representative.

Even as Reuters reported "heavier concentrations" of oil washing up on the shores of western Florida, one new $50 million hotel is still planning to open its doors this month. The 162-unit Margaritaville Beach Hotel (165 Fort Pickens Road), from Jimmy Buffett, is on track to open in late June along the  Pensacola Beach. The hotel says its décor goes for a "barefoot elegance" - fresh orange juice upon arrival, teak furnishings, beach bar out back - inspired by the music and laid-back lifestyle of its proprietor. There's even access to the nearby public beach.

One of my favorite guilty pleasures in traveling to a distant land for the first time, is that I suspend my no-sugary-soda policy and try whatever regional soft drink the local crowd favors. Sometimes, they're terrible (I'm looking at you, Peru, with your neon-yellow Inca Kola that tastes like melted circus peanuts) and sometimes they're fantastic. (Uruguay's Paso de los Toros grapefruit soda rocks. Fresca, pffft!)

Even if you've never read a "Twilight" book in your whole undead life, you're probably aware that "Breaking Dawn," the fourth and final entry in Stephenie Meyer's novels about a young vampire and the human woman who loves him, is possibly the strangest in that series. (Among other plot twists, the human Bella gives birth to the vampire Edward's baby, and the werewolf Jacob becomes romantically bonded to that baby.) So what's the best way to handle the cinematic adaptation of such a weird work? Break it into two movies, of course.

A group of New York lawyers are up in arms over the mayor's plan to change the way lawyers are provided for indigent defendants. The mayor is overstepping his authority by creating a plan that is contrary to county law, the lawyers say, and the move would significantly hurt the quality of legal services provided to those who cannot afford a lawyer.

The party will go on. A week after the Bklyn Yard, the popular performance space on the banks of the Gowanus Canal, announced that it was closing, Justin Carter, a D.J. and promoter who has produced weekly events there, said his party, Sunday Best, will continue. "We've worked it out so we're going to be able to have a shot at it," Mr. Carter said in an interview. Tabletops are the daily canvases upon which we sketch. A glance at someone's coffee table, kitchen island or even computer desktop offers a revealing self-portrait: bookworm, neat freak, train wreck, mom. (My own tabletops tell short stories of collection and compulsion.) What gets randomly, or precisely, set down can be read like tea leaves; our surfaces are anything but shallow.

The service of World War I Veteran George Baldwin McCoy will be recognized in a ceremony tomorrow at 9:30 a.m., at the South Orange World War I Memorial Flagpole at South Orange Avenue and Irvington Avenue. South Orange Village President Douglas Newman provided details about the recent discovery that Mr. McCoy was a South Orange resident whose father served as a Village Trustee three times between 1893 and 1910 and was eventually elected to the 62nd U.S. Congress. According to Mr. Newman, "United States Congressman Bill Pascrell's office helped verify George Baldwin (McCoy's) military history, and Congressman Pascrell plans on joining us on Saturday, touched when he learned that McCoy's father held his Congressional seat a century ago." Mr. Newman tells the full story here, in an account that was slightly edited.

Recently, someone asked me why women don't support each other in business. The question threw me because it presumed a fact that seemed dubious at best -- and completely contrary to the reality I've experienced, both personally and through the stories I've written about women who own businesses. The "cat fight" narrative might draw viewers to reality TV shows and romantic comedies, but it's not helpful to the female business owner eager to learn from and share with her peers.

"The Tea Parties are a grassroots movement, and as a result, they have a lot of volunteers and a modest, but not insignificant amount of money. They'll be able to punch above their weight in states where voters expect to interact with campaigns and candidates outside of their television sets and where old-fashioned door-knocking makes a difference - I'm thinking Iowa and New Hampshire. But in the states with expensive media markets (think New York, Illinois, New Jersey, Connecticut, Maryland, and surprisingly Texas with high-cost Houston, Dallas, and San Antonio) the candidates of the Tea Parties, usually little-known newcomers to politics, will have a much harder time breaking through. The two recent West Coast primaries illustrate this distinction well: Nevada has two big cities, Las Vegas and Reno, and vast swaths of rural territory. California is famously the most expensive state in the country to campaign in; it has a huge population, is spread out all over, has some of the most expensive media markets in the country, and has an electorate whose interest in politics varies greatly. In Nevada, the Tea Party Express spent $500,000 on ads touting [Shannon] Angle, an astonishing amount of money in that state; in California, it is an exaggeration to say that a half million can be found in the petty-cash drawer of the Meg Whitman campaign, but not by that much on a campaign that spent $81 million to win the primary."

An article today reports on an increase in teachers caught tampering with their students' standardized tests and scores. Because those scores now often determine which teachers get bonuses and tenure, some say the higher the stakes are, the more teachers will cheat. Do you agree? Do you think this shows that changes in education, including the testing required under No Child Left Behind, are putting too much pressure on your teachers? Or do you think there are just a few "bad apples" who cheat, and that public school teachers are no more pressured than they ever were? Do you think it's fair to judge teacher performance on student scores in general?

FREEMAN--Clinton Spencer. Died May 30, 2010, age 47, of heart failure, suddenly, at his mother's home in Philadelphia. Son of Kay Olson Freeman and the late Stewart A. Freeman. Brother of Tanner M. Freeman. Valedictorian graduate The Browning School, 1981. Attended Georgetown University and graduated NYU 1986. Many saw his New York City Public Access TV shows, "Four Horsemen," "Love Cats," "Weather Report," 1981-2007. Loved walking Madison Ave, SoHo and Easthampton Beach. Happy and optimistic Sagittarius. Could converse with anyone in an amiable and original way. Knew everything about contemporary music, art and fashion, about which he wrote cogently. Welcomed at Don Hill's, Misshapes, Pacha and other clubs, where ever Derrick Carter appeared. Interests included playing tennis, New York Yankees and New York Giants, pro wrestling, Andy Kaufman and Andy Warhol. Committed tea-drinker and vegetarian. Very responsible, good-natured and polite, as Morrissey sings "used to be a sweet boy."

Sanderson, President and CEO Wildlife Conservation Society

An article in some editions on Thursday about the Chicago Blackhawks' victory on Wednesday over the Philadelphia Flyers to win the N.H.L.'s Stanley Cup misstated the time of the winning goal. It came 4 minutes 6 seconds into overtime, not 4:10. (Because the goal judge did not immediately indicate a goal, the scoreboard clock was not stopped until four seconds later.)

SIEGEL--Daniel, 84, of Westport, CT died June 9, 2010 quietly at home. Born March 1926 in New York, NY to Jesse and Dorothy Siegel, Dan lived in Westport, since 1953 with his devoted wife Alice. In addition to Alice, he is survived by his brother, Dr. Richard Siegel of Santa Rosa, CA, his sons Jeffrey of Trumbull, CT and Andrew of Newtown, CT along with their wives Mindy Siegel and Tracy Nashel, and grandchildren Jaclyn, Rebecca, Leah and Elliot. Dan was the founder and chairman of Mica Corporation, a leading supplier of primers, coating and adhesives to the flexible packaging industry. His innovations in water-based adhesive technology were industry changing in their time and continue to be the standard for world-wide manufacturers of flexible packaging materials. In recognition of a lifetime of technical achievement, he was the 1986 recipient of the TAPPI PLC (now TAPPI PLACE) Division Technical Award and Sam Zwieg Prize. Siegel started his career in the adhesives industry with Polymer Industries in Stamford, CT and later became Marketing Manager of Metro Adhesives in New Brunswick, NJ before starting Mica Corporation in 1971. He was a member of Cedar Point Yacht Club in Westport, CT since 1966 and served as Commodore in 1993 and 1994. Siegel was a member of the board of directors of Planned Parenthood of Connecticut and also served as its treasurer. Funeral service will take place Sunday June 13 at 10:00 am at Congregation B'nai Israel, 2710 Park Avenue, Bridgeport, CT. Memorial contributions in his memory can be made to Planned Parenthood of Southern New England.

WEISS--Martin, passed away on June 9, 2010, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Eleanor. Devoted and loving father of Sabrina and Sophia and son-in-law Jay Lapat. Also survived by his dear brother Carl and wife Ray, his loving nephew Peter and wife Roberta, brother-in-law Arthur and many other dear family members and friends. Martin had a long career as an attorney and was also a talented artist and writer. He will be remembered for his great humor and intellect. He will be deeply missed by all whose lives he touched. Services Monday 11:45am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

BROWN--Himan. The Brooklyn Law School community mourns the loss of Himan Brown, valedictorian of the Class of 1931 and a special friend to the Law School. He began his career in radio work at 17, and was the creator of iconic radio dramas that shaped the nation's "radio days." In his later life, Brown founded the Radio Drama Network, a not-for-profit educational foundation devoted to preserving the spoken word. His passion for this cause was evident in the interactive workshop he led with our students. Brooklyn Law School was proud to honor him as Alumnus of the Year in 2004 and is grateful for his extraordinary generosity to the Law School. Although he will be missed, the legacy of his remarkable work will last for generations to come. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Stuart Subotnick, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Joan G. Wexler, Dean

We extend our sincerest condolences to his widow, Lillian Mittman, his children, Sima (Allan) Greenberg, Steven (Roberta) Mittman, Judy (Barry) Goldstein and Michael (Malka) Mittman and his entire family. He will be long remembered and deeply missed by his family and friends.

KOHL--Leonard "Rollo", 84, of Fair Lawn, NJ, on June 10th. Survived by his wife Laurel, daughter Jodi, son Glen and his wife Julie, and grandchildren Becky, Ben, Molly, and Zoe. Service today, 1pm at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel W150 Rt. 4, Paramus, NJ.

HOUSTON -- For 16 years, a showdown has been brewing between Texas and federal environmental officials over the state's unique way of regulating industrial air pollution, which many critics complain is lax and has led to some of the dirtiest air in the country. Now, President Obama's new regional director of the Environmental Protection Agency in Dallas has forced the issue. The new environmental sheriff is Al Armendariz, a 40-year-old chemical engineer from El Paso, and two weeks ago, he took the unprecedented step of barring Texas from issuing an operating permit to a refinery in Corpus Christi.

JOHNSTON--Neal W. With great sadness, we mourn the loss of our father who died on May 24, 2010. Born in Illinois, December 30th, 1939, he graduated from the University of Chicago - where he edited the Chicago Maroon and appeared in US English-language premiere of Spring Awakening - and Harvard Law School. A practicing attorney until the end, he never put gaining a fee ahead of arguing a good case, and was known throughout the legal community for the literary quality of his letters and briefs. An associate at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison before starting his own practice, he was also Deputy Chief of Litigation for the New York State Attorney General; Chief of Staff to the President of the New York City Council; a fellow of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and the founder and first Executive Secretary of the Council of New York Law Associates (NKA the Lawyers Alliance for New York). A Midwesterner by birth but a New Yorker by soul, he celebrated and lived the life of the mind - and the arts. We will miss his wit, wisdom and great generosity of spirit. His wife Eden Ross Lipson predeceased him. He is survived by his four children, two brothers Warner and Scott and ex-wife Judy Johnston. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Lawyers Alliance for New York. Lawyers Alliance will host a memorial service on October 1st at the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. Delari, Tara, Margo and Garth.

SANSONE--Zachary, was born in Brooklyn, New York. Then at the age of twelve his family moved back to Italy. During that time, he studied at the University of Naples and obtained a degree in jurisprudence. Unfortunately, when World War II broke out he was forced to serve in the military. The horrors of war had a profound effect on him and colored his views on warfare. Zachary returned to his hometown of Sant' Antonio Abate and became extremely involved in rebuilding his town which had been ravaged by the war. Despite his hard work, the political climate at the time was not favorable to the needs of the people. Disillusioned in 1949 he left for New York where he met and married his soul mate Mary Crisalli. His wife Mary was always very active in social service work. With Zack at her side, they went on to create Congress of Italian Organizations (CIAO) in the early 60's. Their success of more than 40 years included the opening of day care, senior and social service centers throughout the city. Zack always insisted that Mary take the spotlight, he was more comfortable being the man behind the scene. Zack was her greatest advisor. Mary was the heart and Zack was the soul. In 2010 his work in Sant' Antonio finally obtained its due recognition when a committee from this town came to New York to honor his accomplishments as the first democratically elected mayor after the war. Zack was an avid reader who loved learning, however his greatest love was his wife Mary who he leaves after 61 years of marriage, his daughter Carmela, his son Ralph who predeceased him in 1986, and his two grandsons Gene-Paul and Zachary. He is survived by his sisters Giulia, Nina and Dora. Private ceremony for family only will take place tomorrow, Friday, June 11th. Zachary's wife Mary asks that you respect her privacy at this time. Please refrain from calling or visiting. Visitiation will be on Saturday, Sunday and Monday June 12, 13, and 14 from 12noon-4pm at the Sansone home at 1451-59th Street, Brooklyn, NY 11219. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that you give donations to the Ralph J. Sansone Foundation.

KONECKY--Ronald S. The Board, Staff, and Playwrights of New Dramatists mourn the passing of Ronald S. Konecky. We offer our loving support to Isobel, our president, and to Jennifer and the entire family. Ron will be remembered and grievously missed by many, though few of us will find language that will adequately express his profound impact. Ron was a brilliant professional, a powerful and fiercely ethical advocate, and a deeply loving husband, father, grandfather and friend. His presence in any room was at once commanding and reassuring. Ron calmly furthered consensus by offering the most thoughtful solutions with eloquence and elegance. By example, he inspired everyone else to be a better version of themselves. Through his legendary philanthropy and personal generosity, Ron also proved to be a partner and mentor to a generation of lawyers and entertainment executives. We will all miss Ron with a stubborn ache, and in place of his commanding presence, there will be a void beyond our ability to fill. We are certain he would want us to populate the empty space with those best versions of ourselves and share our lasting memories of his humor, wisdom, and great capacity for love. Our thoughts and our hearts reach out to Isobel, who is the soul of New Dramatists.

An article in some editions on Monday about the Chicago Blackhawks' victory in Game 5 of the N.H.L. Stanley Cup finals on Sunday erroneously attributed a distinction to the Philadelphia Flyers. They were one defeat from becoming the third team -- not the second -- to lose in six consecutive franchise Stanley Cup finals appearances. Besides the Toronto Maple Leafs, who appeared in six finals without winning from 1933 to 1940, the Detroit Red Wings also did it, from 1956 to 1995. (The Flyers joined them with a loss in Game 6 on Wednesday.)

It did not take long for declarations of greatness to start after Stephen Strasburg's debut for the Washington Nationals on Tuesday. He had some impressive numbers in his 5-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates: 7 innings, 14 strikeouts, 4 hits, 2 earned runs and no walks. He became the first pitcher since J. R. Richard in 1971 to record at least 14 strikeouts in his debut.

In a scene out of Hollywood, a wise coachlike figure in a neatly pressed polo sat in a darkened classroom surrounded by young, sweaty men watching football tapes. When a lineman tackled the quarterback, a chorus of ''ohs'' echoed through the room. But this was no movie; it was the opening session in a first-of-its-kind football officiating academy (pdf) for 17- to 24-year-olds sponsored by the National Football League and the New York City Housing Authority.
An article last Friday about big-ticket real estate in San Francisco misstated the given name of a resident who has three mansions for sale. The seller is Peter V. Sperling, not John.

A picture caption last Friday with an article about Jerry West, the retired Los Angeles Lakers player and executive who was 0-6 against the Boston Celtics in N.B.A. finals from 1962 to 1969, carried incorrect information from Getty Images about the time it was taken. The picture, which showed John Havlicek of the Celtics driving past West, was taken in the 1960s, not in 1970. (In some copies, the photograph also showed Bill Russell of the Celtics, who retired after the 1968-69 season.)

An article on May 25 about an inspector general's report that detailed inappropriate behavior by federal regulators responsible for oversight of drilling in the Gulf of Mexico referred incompletely to one finding. The report said the staff at the Minerals Management Service allowed industry officials several years ago to fill in their own inspection reports in pencil -- and then turn them over to the regulators, who traced over them in pen before submitting the reports to the agency. However, in laying out that scenario, the inspector general's report also went on to say that federal investigators ''could not discern if any fraudulent alterations were present on these forms.''

The Federal Bureau of Investigation said Thursday that it was investigating a security breach on AT&T's Web site that allowed a security group to obtain the e-mail addresses of 114,000 iPad 3G owners. The group also obtained the identification numbers known as ICC-IDs that those iPads use to communicate over AT&T's network.

Needing a break from the omnipresent BP oil cam, I went back and watched the spirit-resuscitating ''Apollo 13.''Oh, to revel in the days when we could fix anything with duct tape and American self-confidence! Sad to say, it looks like a time capsule. This is the film about the crippled lunar flight of 1970 that gave us two of the most iconic lines of our culture: ''Houston, we have a problem'' and ''failure is not an option.'' Turns out, the first line is a slight variation of the actual spoken words, and the second sentence was not part of the historical transcript. But it is part of our self-image.

The United States team is tired. It's not a question of fitness -- the strength and conditioning coach Pierre Barrieu has been praised by the coach and players all week. But there is a sort of fatigue setting in. ''We get tired of kicking each other, we get tired of training, we get tired,'' goalkeeper Tim Howard said Thursday. ''We're together for like forever.''

It is one of the most stunning moments in ''Enemies of the People,'' a documentary that revisits the Cambodian killing fields of the late 1970s, and a high point of the Human Rights Watch Film Festival opening on Friday at Lincoln Center. Thet Sambath, a Cambodian journalist whose father and older brother were among the two million slaughtered by the Khmer Rouge, coaxes a Cambodian farmer who carried out its lethal orders to describe his method of execution. The farmer recalls in a dispassionate tone how a fellow soldier would grab the bowed head of a kneeling prisoner and wrench it back so he could slit the victim's throat. After a while, he notes, his arm would tire, and instead of slitting throats, he would simply jab in the knife.

The TV Sports column on Tuesday, about ESPN's and Univision's World Cup broadcast plans for a growing soccer audience in the United States, described incorrectly the nationalities of ESPN's studio analysts for the tournament. None of them, except for Alexi Lalas, are Americans; it is not the case that all of them are Americans, except Lalas.

Arthur Herzog III, a prolific author who wrote about nuclear disarmament and the fugitive financier Robert Vesco but who was probably best known for his science-fiction thriller ''The Swarm,'' about killer bees, died on May 26. He was 83 and had homes in Manhattan and Wainscott, on Long Island. His death, at a hospital in Southampton, N.Y., was caused by complications of a stroke, his wife, Leslie Mandel-Herzog, said.

Julian is a cherished member of the Rockefeller University community, and we are deeply saddened that he has lost his dearest life companion. Julian's love for Josie was evident in everything he did. Their marriage was a true partnership that included a passionate commitment to philanthropy. At Rockefeller, we are grateful for Julian and Josie's extraordinary generosity, which enabled the University to make tremendous investments and progress in cancer research. We extend our deepest condolences to Julian; to their sons Spencer, Julian H. III (Jay), and Alexander; to their daughter-in-law Sarah; to their grandchildren; and to the many other relatives and friends whose lives Josie touched. Paul Nurse, President Russell Carson, Chair David Rockefeller, Honorary Chair

Lancaster Ave, Ste. 101, Haverford, PA 19041.
An Op-Ed essay on Thursday, on clichés about Israel, incorrectly included an item in listing that country's democratic attributes. Israel does not have a written constitution.

LEE--Patrick A.,a resident of Larchmont, NY, Patrick died unexpectedly of a heart attack on Tuesday, June 8. He was 47. He was predeceased by his father John (Jack) Lee. Patrick is survived by his mother, Catherine V. Boyle Lee; his sisters, Maureen LoRe and family and Grace Ann Arnold and family; and his dear friends, Ed and Jennifer Brout and family. Patrick was a life-long theater fan and one of the most passionate theater bloggers on the World Wide Web. He saw about 250 shows a year, wrote about them and helped shape the structure of the theatrical blogosphere. He was a member of the Outer Critics Circle, served as Awards Director of the Independent Theater Bloggers Association and was a regular contributor to Theatermania, as well as Theatre Development Fund and TDF Stages. He was a GLAAD Media Award juror, and co-writer and co-founder of the Show Showdown blog. Visitation 2-4 and 7-9pm on Friday at the Robert Spearing Funeral Home, Inc., 155 Kinderkamack Road, Park Ridge, NJ. Cremation is private. Donations in memory of partick may be made to TDF at tdf.org.

COLLINS--Deborah Perluck Woodward, born June 11, 1947, died unexpectedly on June 6, 2010 at the Westerly Hospital. She was the beloved wife of William A. Collins of Westerly, and the daughter of Dr. Herbert Perluck and the late Gertrude Perluck of NY and Westerly, RI. Deborah attended Washington University and was a graduate of the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York. Upon her mother's retirement, Deborah proudly ran the Mayan Shop in Watch Hill for a great many years. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Breast Cancer Research Foundation, 60 East 56th Street, 8th floor, New York, NY 10022. Visitation will be Sunday from 1-4pm at the Buckler-Johnston Funeral Home, 121 Main St., Westerly, RI. Immediately following the visitation, everyone is invited to the family's home at 12 Meadow Ridge Road in Westerly.

ROBERTSON--Josie. The trustees, staff and students of The TEAK Fellowship mourn the loss of Josie Robertson, a devoted friend to our community. We extend our deepest condolences to Julian, Spencer, Sarah, Alex and Jay.

ROBERTSON--Josephine. The Board of Directors, Leadership Counsel and staff of The New York Stem Cell Foundation mourn the loss of Josie Robertson, cherished wife of our esteemed friend and benefactor, Julian Robertson. We send our deepest sympathies to Julian, Alex, Jay, Spencer, Wyndham and the entire Robertson family. Roy Geronemus, Chairman Susan L. Solomon, President
SLIDE SHOW A feature about spending 36 Hours in Brussels. While Brussels gets its share of commuters pouring off the Eurostar, the ties there still come off after work. nytimes.com/travel

SCHIFF--Lillian. Beloved wife of the late Louis, devoted mother of Dr. Carl and the late Dr. Jack, loving mother-in-law of Sara, adored grandmother of Jessica and Stephanie. Services Friday 10am at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, New York.

BROWN--Himan. As a radio pioneer and entertainment visionary, Himan Brown was a giant. He brought families together to enjoy the "spoken word" that came out of the box that talked. He contributed to the cultural fabric of this country by helping launch the careers of so many world-renowned actors. At CUNY TV we knew him as a friend: fluent in Yiddish, witty, wry, always the pro, always gracious. Lunches with Himan were a great joy, filled with stories of radio's golden age, not to mention the bagels and lox. We mourn his passing and offer our condolences to his devoted granddaughter Melina and his entire family. Robert Isaacson Executive Director CUNY TV

GOULD--Laurence. The Doctoral Program in Clinical Psychology of the Graduate Center of CUNY mourns the death of our colleague, Laurence (Larry) Gould. Professor Gould taught in the program for over 30 years, serving as Director of the Clinic and Director of the Program. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. A memorial service will be held in his honor in the Fall.
ZELUCK--Barbara. North Star Fund sends its heartfelt condolences to the family and friends of Barbara Zeluck. Throughout her life, she was a passionate champion for human rights and social justice.

OGDEN--Robert M. III, age 88, beloved husband of Maureen, died peacefully at home on June 5 after a short illness. Loving father of Thomas, Los Angeles, CA; Henry, Summit, NJ; Peter, Durango, CO; father-in-law of Mary and Lena and devoted grandfather of Katherine, James and Benjamin. He served in the US Army Air Corps in World War II and graduated from the University of Denver and the NYU School of Business. Prior to his retirement he was an account executive with H. G. Wellington & Co. Inc. Past treasurer of the British Schools and Universities Foundation; treasurer of the Washington Association of Morristown, NJ; member of the University Glee Club of New York City; usher at Christ Church, Short Hills and member of Baltusrol Golf Club, Short Hills Club and Yeamans Hall Club, Charleston, SC. A memorial service will be held at 11am at Christ Church, Short Hills on Tuesday, June 15. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Christ Church, 66 Highland Ave., Short Hills, NJ 07078 or the Washington Association, 3 Washington Ave., Morristown, NJ 07960. Services by Dangler Funeral Home of Summit, NJ.

10 P.M. (Discovery) DUAL SURVIVAL Shelter, food, water and finding help: those are the basic tenets of surviving the wilderness. But after that? It's anyone's guess. This new series pairs up two survival experts -- Dave Canterbury, above, a former Special Reaction Team instructor and sniper for the Army, and Cody Lundin, a naturalist who teaches a course in aboriginal living and has gone barefoot for 20 years -- and plops them into some of the planet's most unforgiving terrain, where they'll demonstrate how the proper skills and some creative use of everyday objects like a 35-millimeter camera, cigarettes, car batteries and even condoms can keep marooned boaters, lost hikers and stranded mountain climbers alive. Their first challenge: to survive on a deserted island off the coast of Nova Scotia in the dead of winter using only items they can salvage from a life raft. 8 P.M. (NBC) FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS Coach Taylor (Kyle Chandler) tries to figure out how to defend against a rival team's ''juggernaut offense.'' Tim (Taylor Kitsch) and Lyla (Minka Kelly) reconnect.

The former Cincinnati Reds outfielder Ken Griffey Sr. learned he had prostate cancer in 2006. He has since become involved in educating other men, including his two sons, about the disease through the Depend Campaign to End Prostate Cancer, a partner with Zero, the Project to End Prostate Cancer. Griffey, 60, has 14 grandchildren and said, "I want to be around as long as possible to watch them grow up." He still works for the Reds, whom he helped win back-to-back World Series titles in 1975 and 1976, as the hitting coach for their Class A affiliate, the Dayton Dragons.

It's good to see Rajan put his cards on the table -- but what he says only further confirms my sense that we're talking about some kind of psychological desire to be tough, rather than the kind of analysis one would expect from a highly trained economist.

For a second straight game, Alex Rodriguez was not in the Yankees' lineup because of tendinitis in his right hip flexor. His availability to pinch hit against the Houston Astros was not known. Rodriguez is considered day to day with the tendinitis, which is not believed to be related to the hip surgery he had in 2009. Manager Joe Girardi did not know if Rodriguez would be available as a pinch-hitter Saturday because Rodriguez did not meet with the training staff before Girardi briefed reporters. "He's not ready to go and we'll continue to evaluate him every day and see what availability we have of him every day," Girardi said before the game. "He's not a starter for us. I came to the ballpark not planning on starting him. I'll keep talking to our doctors." Rodriguez was not available to reporters before the game. Rodriguez did not play on Friday. He had complained of tightness in his groin area and exited after the first inning of Thursday's loss at Baltimore. Rodriguez also exited early in a Yankees win over Toronto last Sunday, a day after a 14-inning loss to the Blue Jays. Asked if Rodriguez's workout regimen to warm up his surgically repaired hip might have caused the tendinitis, Girarid said: "He didn't have a problem until we played that 14-inning game on the turf. So is it more of his workload or was it more the 14 innings on the turf, a day game after night game? If I was a guessing man, I'd guess it was the latter." Girardi said he did not know whether Rodriguez might be used as a designated hitter when he returns. Kevin Russo was listed as the Yankees' starting third baseman on Saturday. Ramiro Pena started at third base Friday and went 0 for 3.

Brett Gardner, who has been relegated to pinch-running situations because of a mild sprain in his left thumb, took about 30 swings in batting practice Saturday and said he hoped to return to the Yankees' lineup on Sunday. Gardner said after batting practice his thumb felt good and that he would be available to play Saturday against the Houston Astros. "I feel like I could hit today or play the field today or whatever they need me to do," Gardner said before the game. Gardner said he would continue to heavily tape the thumb, which he did before taking batting practice. Gardner felt discomfort in the thumb Tuesday after a check-swing groundout in the sixth inning against Baltimore and then he jammed it during an at-bat in the eighth. He missed 40 games last year with a fracture in the same thumb.

The big party that is Bonnaroo teetered on an uncharacteristic mood on Friday: introspection. The headliner, Kings of Leon, has taken some of Southern rock's basic tensions--between faith and hell-raising, gospel and blues, pride and guilt, lust and repentance--into songs that wrestle private demons but ring like arena-rock. And the more pensive side of Kings of Leon rippled down through the rest of the day's bill. The National brooded cryptically over smoldering crescendos and U2 guitar chords. Dr. Dog pondered mortality, even as its songs bounded forward with cascading guitars and casual vocal harmonies.

MANCHESTER, Tenn. -- It's not a Bonnaroo set without a wild-card cover version. The Flaming Lips and an allied group, Stardeath and White Dwarfs, played the entirety of Pink Floyd's "Dark Side of the Moon" with no deference at all. With fuzztone bass and wah-wah guitars, a garage-rock kick and non-portentous vocals, it went lurching toward Flaming Lips'disheveled version of madness rather than Pink Floyd's majestic one.

Alex Rodriguez learned Friday that tendinitis in his right hip flexor had been the source of the tightness near his groin area. Rodriguez, who left after the first inning of Thursday's loss in Baltimore, did not play in the Yankees' win over the Houston Astros on Friday and is considered day to day. The following is a transcript of Rodriguez's meeting with reporters after Friday's game.

MANCHESTER, Tenn. -- Who are the real communal utopians at Bonnaroo? Sometimes it seemed to be the rappers. Wale, late on Thursday night, and Jay Electronica, on Friday afternoon, both invited the audience to dance onstage during their sets and were soon surrounded by flailing arms and grinning faces--so many that Jay Electronica's security ended up clearing the stage again during the set. Meanwhile, the proudly disorganized neo-hippie band Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros--who play an amiably ramshackle blend of 1960's skittle rock and soul, with singalong lyrics about sunshine, love and other, as one song puts it, "sentimental lies"--rambled loosely around the stage themselves, but left the audience offstage.

As predicted, the 24 Hours of Le Mans is turning into anyone's race. Sebastien Bourdais's pole sitting Peugeot is out of the race, the Peugeot of the winners from last year - Marc Gene and Alexander Wurz - has had problems and dropped down the pack. There are still two Peugeot cars in the lead, one a factory team car and the other the ORECA private team car. But that puts the Audis up in third, fourth and fifth. It is anyone's race still.

Maybe it's the color drawings that look like regular golfers I have known. Maybe it's the thick paper that reminds me of my old grade school projects. Maybe it's the simplicity of the tasks and the guidance offered, but I have always loved the Private Lessons section at the back of Golf Magazine. Four years ago, a collection of the most insightful lessons culled from the magazine through the decades was published. This year, new material has been added in the revised edition, "Private Lessons: The Best of the Best Instruction." (Abrams Books)

The nightmarish flash floods in southwestern Arkansas early Friday morning that swept away dozens of campers -- with some 18 confirmed dead and many more still missing -- resulted from a horrible confluence of a late-night burst of extreme rains over a region of steep-sided, isolated river valleys long popular with folks eager for a taste of nature.

South Korea dismantled Greece on Saturday in Port Elizabeth, South Africa, 2-0. Goals by Lee Jung-soo and Park Ji-sung on either side of halftime left the Greeks reeling. He said he preferred a government that looks beyond sect.

KONECKY--Ronald. Ron was our model of decency, compassion and humility. We send our love to Isobel, Jennifer and the family, with our profound gratitude for sharing him with us. Seth and Orren

KONECKY--Ronald. It seems like yesterday---but it was September of 1951. I sat next to this guy in Civil Procedure--our first year at the Harvard Law School (we were not yet 22)--taught by the bombastic Professor Richard Field and our knees knocked in unison. He became my instant friend and classmate throughout law school and thereafter, and in 1962 we started the firm then called Barovick and Konecky which became perhaps one of the foremost entertainment and sports law firms in this country and abroad. He was my partner and my friend. We would meet at the end of the day, sometimes with a drink but often not, and discuss the details of our clients' problems, potential strategies for resolving knotty issues and ....laughing. Not at or about our clients, but about the industry's foibles and absurdities, finding humor in situations others might not--laughing riotously so that even after long and trying client negotiations or problems, we could go home to our loving wives with a smile. He was a fine lawyer and a special person. I loved him and will miss him. Dick Barovick

KONECKY--Ronald S. Cherished husband of Isobel. Adored father of Jennifer (Bob Wheelock) and doting grandfather of Tim and Matthew Wheelock. Ron was born in Brooklyn, NY, the youngest of four boys to Philip and Lillian Konecky. His loving brothers William, Gerald (Mildred) and Murray (Adele) also survive him. He was a proud graduate of Midwood High School, where he scored the first ever touchdown for the school. He attended the University of Arizona. After serving in the Army, he attended Harvard Law School which prepared him for his 50 year law career in which he represented many TV news, sports, publishing and theater personalities; Roone Arledge, Walter Cronkite, Frank Gifford, and Morley Safer among the many. He was married to performer/theater producer Isobel Robins Konecky for 49 years. He was a mentor, confidant, advisor to many. A man who made the lives of all who knew him better. In addition to his love of the law, he also loved the theater and served on the board of the American Theatre Wing. He was the best husband, father, grandfather, brother and uncle ever. Gone but never forgotten . . . what a fella. Isobel and Jennifer

''Ask an Expert'' is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs. This week, our attention is on Social Security, specifically, the optimal time to start collecting. Determining that is difficult given the many complicated rules that govern the system. So it's not surprising that ever since we wrote about the topic last summer, readers have not stopped sending us their questions. That's why we've called in Lesley J. Brey, a financial planner with expertise in Social Security, to answer them.

My husband and I recently got back from a nearly cashless vacation. We flew to Cabo San Lucas from San Francisco on United Airlines, which didn't accept cash in the cabin and required customers to use credit or debit cards to pay for snacks and alcoholic drinks. Then, the hotel we stayed at, Hacienda Encantada Resort & Spa, also had signs up around the resort about its ''no cash for purchases on the premises'' policy. (No one stopped us from giving out tips in cash.)

OBITUARIES An obituary on June 1 about the sculptor Louise Bourgeois erroneously attributed a distinction to her. The first woman to be the subject of a retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art was the painter Georgia O'Keeffe, in 1946 -- not Ms. Bourgeois. (She had one there in 1982.) The obituary also referred incorrectly to a picture of Ms. Bourgeois by Robert Mapplethorpe. While it did appear in the catalog of the 1982 Modern retrospective, the photograph was not taken specifically for that catalog.

We recently came across a Facebook status update from a friend of Bucks who had trouble spending a $100 bill. Here's what she wrote: ''I think it wld be easier to spend hungarian florints than pay with a $100 bill in nyc. people act like you're a con artist for even trying.'' In a Bucks post on Tuesday, ''The Merchants That Don't Take Cash,'' we wrote that a growing number of businesses are no longer taking cash and that those no-cash policies are legal. We also noted how it's perfectly legal for businesses to decide not to accept a certain denomination like a $100 bill.

Since the Texas Rangers agreed to a sale to a group led by Chuck Greenberg and Nolan Ryan for $575 million earlier this year, creditors of the team's parent company have insisted that other bidders would have paid more. In a brief filed Friday in United States bankruptcy court in Fort Worth, Tex., the creditors cited correspondence from a lawyer for the Hicks Sports Group, which is selling the team, saying that a Houston businessman named Jim Crane offered a much better deal than Ryan and Greenberg.

JIDDA -- Roughly two years ago, Rowdha Yousef began to notice a disturbing trend: Saudi women like herself were beginning to organize campaigns for greater personal freedoms. Suddenly, there were women asking for the right to drive, to choose whether to wear a veil, and to take a job without a male relative's permission, all using the Internet to collect signatures and organize meetings and all becoming, she felt, more voluble by the month. The final straw came last summer, when she read reports that a female activist in Saudi Arabia's eastern province, Wajeha al-Huwaider, had been to the border with Bahrain, demanding to cross using only her passport, without a male chaperon or a male guardian's written permission.

NATIONAL An article on Friday about an Army report citing dozens of deficiencies in the day-to-day management of Arlington National Cemetery omitted the news organization that first reported the problems, including more than 200 mismarked graves. The Army's inquiry followed a year-long investigative series by salon.com, part of the Salon Media Group.

The executive who oversaw Major League Baseball's umpires for the past five years has been reassigned in a clear indication of Commissioner Bud Selig's unhappiness with the quality of umpiring in recent years. The executive, Jimmie Lee Solomon, has overseen on-the-field operations, which includes umpiring and security, since his appointment as executive vice president for baseball operations in 2005. He will now oversee baseball's academies in the United States and Puerto Rico, minor league operations and the annual Civil Rights Game.

9 P.M. (Showtime) ADVENTURELAND (2009) It's the summer of 1987, and James Brennan (Jesse Eisenberg) is dreaming of a post-college trek across Europe, followed by graduate school at Columbia. But his father has been demoted, so James will have to settle for working at a run-down amusement park in western Pennsylvania, the only job for which his degree in comparative literature qualifies him. Kristen Stewart, above with Mr. Eisenberg, plays James's crush, Em, a moody N.Y.U. student secretly involved with Connell (Ryan Reynolds), a married maintenance man who likes to weave bogus tales about all the famous musicians he's jammed with, most notably Lou Reed. Although Greg Mottola, who wrote and directed this comedy, is ''careful not to fetishize or lampoon the 1980s with silly hairdos or too-obvious topical references,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, he does at times lay on ''the suburban adolescent malaise with too heavy a hand.'' Still, ''the smart, slightly depressive vibe feels just right -- for James's era and for our own as well,'' he added. ''The path to adulthood is lined with disappointment, but for a young man with an open heart and a measure of self-confidence, to say nothing of a degree in comp lit, things will most likely be O.K.'' 10 A.M. (Fox Business Network) FREEDOM WATCH Judge Andrew Napolitano and guests debate the expanding role of government and consumer rights as outlined by the United States Constitution. The series begins with Sarah Palin; Rand Paul, the Republican Senate nominee from Kentucky; and Senator Jim DeMint, Republican of South Carolina.

MUYSKENS--John, Jr. died peacefully on June 8th. He was 88. WWII veteran and former Dean of Admissions at Yale University, he loved serving prestigious educational institutions and did so for more than 50 years. He is survived by a loving family. A celebration of his life will be held this summer.

In the Steinway section of Astoria, Queens, there is a little park in the middle of a residential block with a pair of narrow concrete handball courts. On weekend mornings for the last 35 years, these courts unofficially belonged to a dozen or so retirees who lived nearby and played paddle ball year round. The ringleader - who kept the matchup lists, adjudicated the games and ribbed the losers - was a jovial man known throughout Astoria as Buddy.
