BAKER--Harvey, 77, died in San Diego, CA June 5th. Beloved brother, father, fiancee, colleague and professor. Taught psychology at Queens College for 36 years and was greatly esteemed by faculty and students alike. Leading energy psychology researcher with numerous articles in scientific journals. Director of Research and a member of the Board of The Association for Comprehensive Energy Psychology (ACEP). Survived by his sister Roz, daughter Amy, son Jonah and his beloved fiance Adela Oliver. Harvey loved his family, research and teaching, and he loved to laugh. He is greatly missed. Burial 1pm, Thursday in Malden, MA (800-982-3717). Shiva in New York Sunday through Tuesday at Dr. Adela Oliver, 120 West 97th St., Apt 11-I, 2pm-10pm. (212-662-7968). Contributions may be made to ACEP Research Fund, 349 W. Lancaster Ave, Ste. 101, Haverford, PA 19041.

The Globespotters column last Sunday, about the National Ballet of Spain, gave incorrect dates for the ballet's scheduled performances at Teatro de la Zarzuela in Madrid. The ballet company will perform July 8 to 18; performances did not begin on Monday, June 7, nor are any scheduled through June 18.

EVART--Anna, 90, died peacefully on June 5. Mother of Siblings Day Founder. Wife of late Alfred Evart (Estonian). Mother of three siblings. She had three sisters - Alice, Catherine and Pauline whose powerful bond, all now deceased, inspired her only surviving child, Claudia Evart to start a national campaign in '98 for a National Siblings Day held on April 10, birth date of Lisette, to celebrate the sibling bond that is forever a special gift. Born Brooklyn, NY. Parents: Alex and Christina Machin, Russian. Alfred died with daughter Lisette (19) car accident Holland; son Alan deceased '86. Funeral June 9, 2010, Vladimir's Cemetery Jackson, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations to charity, Siblings Day Foundation: P.O. Box 85 NY, NY 10163 or paypal www.siblingsday.org

JELIN--Sima K.,age 89, mother of six, grandmother of fifteen, and great-grandmother of two, died at her home on June 12, 2010. Throughout her life, Sima was active as a real estate broker, corporate CEO, philanthropist and most importantly as a participant in the daily lives of her family and countless friends. We all celebrate her many accomplishments and relish the knowledge that she was proud of ours. She is married to Sidney Weinstein and predeceased by husbands, Martin Jelin, Cecil Lichtman and son William Jelin. Funeral services will be held at Temple Sharey Tefilo-Israel, 432 Scotland Road, South Orange, NJ at 10am on Tuesday, June 15, 2010. Contributions may be made to Sima Jelin Fund for Inter-Cultural Tolerance at the American Jewish Committee 225 Milburn Ave. Milburn, NJ 07041. For information, call Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel (800) 938-6372.

OSTER--Dr. Zvi H.,prominent physician and Holocaust Survivor, passed away June 10th in his home. Born March 2, 1933 in Romania, son of Yoel and Shifra Oster, he immigrated to Israel in 1947. After attending the Hebrew University-Hadassah Medical School he worked at Hadassah, Tel Hashomer, and finally, Stony Brook Medical Center. Zvi was a passionate physician and generous teacher. He is loved and missed by his wife and children. Survived by his older brother Gad, he also leaves behind his wife, Levana, daughter, Michal, sons Ady and Shai, and three grandchildren. His funeral will be held in Kibbutz Einat on Tuesday, June 15. Donations can be made to the U.S. Holocaust Museum in Washington, D.C.

It was the usual morning drill: Sit at the computer, sip coffee, scan e-mail. Outside, on a very sunny June day, the school bus rumbled to a halt and the neighborhood children scrambled on. My finger poised on the delete button, I took a second look at an e-mail message from Abercrombie & Fitch. The company was offering me a sneak peek at its back-to-school line. For years now, retailers have been quietly upping the shopping ante. Christmas decorations edge out Halloween costumes even before trick-or-treaters ring the bell. But thoughts of back-to-school buying before the present semester has ended are enough to give even the most dedicated and organized consumer a bit of a jolt.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Saturday, May 29th 2010, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount and department stores; and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics; and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

MILTON--Hon. Dennis E.,United States Bankruptcy Judge in the Eastern District of New York passed away on May 31, 2010, after a long illness. Judge Milton was born in 1951 in Staten Island, NY. He attended Regis High School, Columbia University, and Fordham University School of Law. Judge Milton was appointed to his position as a United States Bankruptcy Judge in 2001. Judge Milton is survived by his wife, Karen Greve Milton. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to Regis High School in New York, NY. A wake will be held at M.A. Connell Funeral Home in Huntington Station, NY on June 17 and 18. A funeral mass will be held on Saturday, June 19, at 10am at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Huntington, NY.

RADNITZ--Robert B.,who entertained a generation as producer of the films Sounder, Cross Creek, Island of the Blue Dolphins and many others died June 6 at his home in Malibu, California, from complications of a stroke suffered years earlier. He was 85 years old. Radnitz's passion was stimulating the imagination of both children and adults. Parents and teachers came to recognize that his name on a motion picture ensured a creative experience that could be shared between generations. He was awarded many accolades, from eight Academy Award nominations for his films to a joint resolution honoring his work from the U.S. Congress. Born August 9, 1924, in Great Neck, Long Island, Radnitz was the only child of Fred and Lilyn Radnitz. Afflicted with asthma as a child, he was a voracious reader. A love of movies was nurtured by Saturday visits with his father to Manhattan, for at least one double feature per trip. He dreamed of bringing great literature to the screen. He enrolled at the University of Virginia due to the school's renowned curricula in English literature and drama. He became editor of the school's literary magazine, managed the drama society and founded an off-campus playhouse. After graduating, he initially stayed at the University teaching English, but ultimately decided to pursue a career in stage and film. He served an apprenticeship with legendary theatrical director Harold Clurman. Afterward, he became a stage manager at the West Hampton Playhouse and then a producer on Broadway. Noted critic Walter Kerr called his 1955 The Young and the Beautiful "...a perfect production." It went on to play successfully on London's West End. Feeling that his ultimate contributions would be in motion pictures, Radnitz moved to Hollywood. After a stint at United Artists, he became a story consultant for production chief Buddy Adler at 20th Century Fox. This led to the opportunity to produce his first movie, A Dog of Flanders, released in 1960. A Dog of Flanders established the pattern for most future Robert Radnitz films: a family film, based on an acclaimed novel, featuring a young person who must overcome adversity. All of his films were shot entirely on location, many using local non-actors in secondary roles. The soundtracks were often filled with indigenous music. "No other art can match motion pictures' potential for conveying place," said Radnitz. "The exposure to a new geography can be one of the great joys of movie-going." Despite making films about and for young people, Radnitz avoided the sweet and sentimental. Critic Judith Crist of New York magazine said that Radnitz "restores respectability to the oft abused genre of family films." A Dog of Flanders established another pattern for Radnitz's films: awards and accolades. It won the Grand Prix Gold Lion Award at the Venice Film Festival (the first American film so honored). Over the next thirty years Radnitz produced another dozen popular motion pictures, including Misty, My Side of the Mountain, Where the Lilies Bloom, plus two television films, Mary White and Never Forget, all of which received awards and critical praise. His most honored film was Sounder, in 1972. It was nominated for a Best Picture Oscar and three other Academy Awards. It received a Special Humanitarian Award from the California State Assembly and four NAACP Image Awards, including one for Radnitz. It was also his biggest commercial success. The year Sounder was released Radnitz received his greatest tribute: becoming the first filmmaker ever honored by a joint resolution of the U.S. Congress for his body of work. Radnitz overcame his childhood asthma to become a robust adult. He swam every morning year-round in the Pacific Ocean, just steps from his Malibu home. Known as one of the best non-pro tennis players in Southern California, he held his own against members of the Pepperdine University tennis team half his age, playing nearly every day. Only wearing long pants or a tie when absolutely necessary, he was well known in the restaurants of Malibu and Hollywood in his trademark white FILA tennis outfit, arriving behind the wheel of his white convertible with the license plates "CALM." Asked about the plates, he would explain, "It is a state I hope one day to achieve." Driving that car along Pacific Cost Highway to Pepperdine one day, he spotted an attractive woman jogging. Seeing her again the next day, he pulled over to talk to her. Thus he met Pearl, who became his wife of over 20 years. Radnitz had several new projects in the works when he suffered a massive stroke in 1996 that effectively ended his career and started a long deterioration of his health. Although confined to a wheelchair, he still attended movies regularly (and expressed his opinions loudly) and still got out onto the tennis court twice weekly to return balls. He passed away Sunday night, June 6, at his Malibu home, surrounded by his devoted wife Pearl and his beloved dogs, Coco, Junior and Rosebud, finally achieving a state of calm. Radnitz had no children, but leaves behind an impressive legacy. When Radnitz received the joint resolution of Congress, Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas paid him tribute with the words, "The films Robert Radnitz has produced touch the common thread of humanity and that's why he's made such a great and glorious contribution to the thing that makes our society a viable, living, vibrant whole." He will be laid to rest next to his parents in New York in a private ceremony. Plans for a memorial service in Los Angeles are pending. In lieu of flowers, Pearl Radnitz suggests friends make donations to their favorite charities in Robert Radnitz's name.

On the Screen Do not visit Scanwiches on an empty stomach. The blog, which Jon Chonko created in February 2009 for the dual purpose of ''education and delight,'' is like a restaurant menu on steroids. Viewed before lunch, a BLT Perfecto from Papa Lima in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on toasted rye coated with basil mayonnaise, is enough to induce drooling on your keyboard followed by gustatory frustration.

Since being a founder of Jazz at Lincoln Center in 1991, Wynton Marsalis has made it his mission to introduce jazz to people the world over, offering classes at American high schools and performing at international music festivals. Now he is establishing a permanent base in London, as the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra begins its first residency at the Barbican Center on Silk Street from June 17 to 20. In addition to live performances by Mr. Marsalis and his orchestra, the wide-ranging program will include classes and workshops in local schools, and community events throughout East London - including swing dancing at Stoke Newington Town Hall, jam sessions at the Vortex in Dalston, and a family concert at Hackney Empire.

ROBERTSON--Josephine. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Wildlife Conservation Society mourn the loss of our friend and compatriot Josie Robertson, who inspired us all with her devotion to children, lifetime learning, cultural life and the parks of New York City. As long-standing friends and benefactors, Josie and Julian have left a lasting imprint on educational opportunities for all New York City schoolchildren. Our deepest sympathies go to Julian, Spencer, Jay, Alex and the entire Robertson and Tucker families. Ward W. Woods, Chair, Board of Trustees Steven E. Sanderson, President and CEO Wildlife Conservation Society

She was 87. The cause was pneumonia, said her daughter, Claire. Her mother had Alzheimer's disease, she said.

LIKE most fashion editors turned accessories designers, Khirma Eliazov, a former freelancer for Vogue and Harper's Bazaar, had a keen understanding of what was missing from the marketplace. And as she saw it, ''there were a lot of beautiful things, and a lot of functional things, but rarely were they both.'' Her new handbag line successfully fills that niche, with little numbers like the Mignonne (above): a chic '70s-style python and stingray pouch with an adjustable braided cord, an Italian calf leather strap, a side pocket to stash your cellphone and room enough inside for all of your day-to-evening essentials. Not sure how we ever did without it. Khirma Eliazov Mignonne pouch, $720 at Henri Bendel and khirmaeliazov.com.

Stephen Starr, who owns a string of high-profile restaurants in Philadelphia including Buddakan and Morimoto, has gone south-of-the-border- opening El Rey, a moderately priced Mexican restaurant in the city's fancy Midtown neighborhood, last month. The kitchen, which is headed by Dionicio Jimenez, the former chef at Xochitl, focuses on affordable home-style Mexican fare like braised goat, roasted whole fish with chili mayo, lamb tacos and short rib enchiladas.

KONECKY--Ronald S. Cherished husband of Isobel. Adored father of Jennifer (Bob Wheelock) and doting grandfather of Tim and Matthew Wheelock. Ron was born in Brooklyn, NY, the youngest of four boys to Philip and Lillian Konecky. His loving brothers William, Gerald (Mildred) and Murray (Adele) also survive him. He was a proud graduate of Midwood High School, where he scored the first ever touchdown for the school. He attended the University of Arizona. After serving in the Army, he attended Harvard Law School which prepared him for his 50 year law career in which he represented many TV news, sports, publishing and theater personalities; Roone Arledge, Walter Cronkite, Frank Gifford, and Morley Safer among the many. He was married to performer/theater producer Isobel Robins Konecky for 49 years. He was a mentor, confidant, advisor to many. A man who made the lives of all who knew him better. In addition to his love of the law, he also loved the theater and served on the board of the American Theatre Wing. He was the best husband, father, grandfather, brother and uncle ever. Gone but never forgotten . . . what a fella. Isobel and Jennifer

FREEMAN--Clinton Spencer. Died May 30, 2010, age 47, of heart failure, suddenly, at his mother's home in Philadelphia. Son of Kay Olson Freeman and the late Stewart A. Freeman. Brother of Tanner M. Freeman. Valedictorian graduate The Browning School, 1981. Attended Georgetown University and graduated NYU 1986. Many saw his New York City Public Access TV shows, "Four Horsemen," "Love Cats," "Weather Report," 1981-2007. Loved walking Madison Ave, SoHo and Easthampton Beach. Happy and optimistic Sagittarius. Could converse with anyone in an amiable and original way. Knew everything about contemporary music, art and fashion, about which he wrote cogently. Welcomed at Don Hill's, Misshapes, Pacha and other clubs, where ever Derrick Carter appeared. Interests included playing tennis, New York Yankees and New York Giants, pro wrestling, Andy Kaufman and Andy Warhol. Committed tea-drinker and vegetarian. Very responsible, good-natured and polite, as Morrissey sings "used to be a sweet boy."

Promising the presidential suite for the price of a budget motel room, a hotel auction site called Off & Away recently began operating online. Two nights in the Tata Suite at the Pierre in New York - list price: $40,000 - was the first to go up for auction at the Web site, which deals the best room in the house at each participating hotel. The room ultimately went for $938.25.

WEISS--Martin, passed away on June 9, 2010, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Eleanor. Devoted and loving father of Sabrina and Sophia and son-in-law Jay Lapat. Also survived by his dear brother Carl and wife Ray, his loving nephew Peter and wife Roberta, brother-in-law Arthur and many other dear family members and friends. Martin had a long career as an attorney and was also a talented artist and writer. He will be remembered for his great humor and intellect. He will be deeply missed by all whose lives he touched. Services Monday 11:45am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

HARD--Hildegarde Stevenson, a resident of Edgehill in Stamford, CT died peacefully at age 97 on June 6, 2010. Mrs. Hard was born in Pasadena, California, the daughter of Joseph H. Stevenson and Hildegarde Kobbe Stevenson. Following the divorce of the Stevensons, her mother married Francis B. Thorne and she and her older sister Carol were welcomed into the Thorne family's first home on Awixa Avenue in Bay Shore, NY. Later, the Thorne family moved into "Brookwood" in Islip, NY where Mrs. Hard, known as "Lolly" or "Babs" to many, spent most of her early life. In 1933, she married Frederick B. Hard and they built a house in Bay Shore where they lived for twenty years and raised three sons, Frederick, Jr., Michael and David, who survive her. After moving to Islip, NY, where they lived for about fifteen years, the Hards moved to Stamford, Connecticut in the mid-1960s. Mr. Hard passed away in Stamford on July 1, 2007. In addition to her three sons, seven grandchildren and five great-grandchildren, Mrs. Hard is survived by two half-brothers, Francis B. Thorne, Jr. and Oakleigh Thorne, II. She was predeceased by her older sister, Carol, two half-sisters, Phebe and Julia and one grand-daughter, Hildegarde Kobbe Hard Douglas. She is fondly remembered by all for her love of music, her indomitable spirit and her joyful attitude towards life. Services will be private, but relatives and friends are urged to set aside five minutes, beginning at 2:30pm EDT on Sunday, June 20, 2010 to remember her as each person feels appropriate. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Habitat for Humanity.

SKYDEL--Barbara. The family of Barbara Skydel regrets to announce her passing on June 10th after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Most recently, Barbara was a Senior Talent Representative with William Morris Endeavor Entertainment, following a pioneering career as a Principal and Partner with Premier Talent Associates. At Premier, she represented a large number of legendary rock 'n roll acts, including many of the bands of the British invasion. She was the first female Principal of a major talent agency, and Barbara was honored in 2000 by "Women In Music" with the Touchstone Award. She was also a five-time recipient of Performance Magazine's "Agent Of The Year" Award and twice named Billboard's "Agent Of The Year". Barbara was a long-time resident of Sagaponack, LI and Manhattan. She is the beloved sister and sister-in-law of Frances and Leon Hyman of Westport, CT, and cherished aunt of Scott (Phoebe) Hyman of Lynchburg, VA and William (Sarah) Hyman of Manhattan, and great-aunt of Alexandra, Samuel, Chloe and Jonathan. She was also predeceased by her parents Samuel and Sonia and her sister Eleanor. Services Monday, June 14th, 10am at "The Riverside" 76th St., and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be made to any Ovarian Cancer Research organization.

Recently, I was walking with a friend along a busy street in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, when she stopped suddenly outside a medical office and pointed to the bottom of a hedge. ''Do you see that?'' my friend asked, as a bus drove by. In truth, I saw only the hedge, along with a dandelion rosette and a few short weeds growing amid some crushed tissues and candy wrappers. My friend has been foraging for decades and is sort of a mentor - years ago she taught me how to differentiate Queen Anne's lace, or wild carrots, from poison hemlock - so I just assumed this was some choice edible that I had somehow overlooked in my foraging education.

RAND--Harold. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Friar Harold Rand. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Services will be held Sunday June 13 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 9:30am. The Friars Club

BERNSTEIN--Sheila. With great sadness, we mourn the loss of our beautiful mother who died June 11, a day after her 73rd birthday, following a year-long battle with cancer. Born in New York, she attended the University of Wisconsin and graduated from New York University. She worked for over four decades, in the fashion industry, including AMC, Adrienne Vittadini, and the last fifteen years as Manager of Textile Reproductions at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She was supportive and generous with her knowledge--she loved what she did and she loved all who knew her. No matter what she wore, she always had style--even casually, she was elegant. And as busy as she was, she always had enough time to help a friend find the right outfit, the right sofa, the right apartment. The quintessential New Yorker, she walked the city, knew every bus route, loved theatre, movies, museums, books, tennis in Central Park, bike riding in Europe. For business and pleasure, she traveled all over the world, including Chicago which she even grew to love when visiting her daughter and son-in-law and grandchildren. We will miss her wit, her perception and wisdom--and how much she loved a good laugh. Her love of life is exceeded only by her love of family: Beloved son Kenneth and his wife Janet Bernstein, beloved daughter Felicia and son-in-law Rafe Lerner, cherished grandchildren Jessica and Alex Bernstein, Daniel, Harris, Hannah, and Rebecca Lerner.

Performers and theatrical stars are often permitted their share of eccentric or diva-esque behavior. On Wednesday night at a performance in East Rutherford, N.J., some upped the ante, nipping their co-stars or aiming kicks at their heads. One even used the stage as a restroom. The raucous stars were the more than 60 horses of ''Cavalia,'' an equine version of Cirque du Soleil, which was celebrating opening night under its peaked white tent in a lot near the Izod Center. While there were scads of human performers, who tumbled across the white sand stage, scampered like monkeys up poles or yo-yoed from bungee cords suspended from the eaves of the tent, nearly 10 stories high, they seemed merely extras in the presence of the equine actors.

A family's life has been completely changed. And they don't even know it yet. FIRST LT. MATTHEW E. STEWART, an Army medevac pilot, referring to the relatives of a Marine his crew had tried in vain to save. [A14]

MILLER--David Wendell, Professor Emeritus of Columbia University's Uris Graduate School of Business, died peacefully in his home in New York City on June 10th. He was 86. During his 36-year tenure at Columbia Professor Miller taught statistics and many courses in quantitative methods. He served as a consultant to major firms including IBM and Morgan Guaranty Trust and served as the Director of Graduate Studies at the Uris Business School. He was totally devoted to his students earning him the status as "legend." Professor Miller, along with his colleague Martin Starr, wrote the seminal textbook, Executive Decisions and Operations Research, which was translated into sixteen languages for use around the world. In addition, he was the author and co-author with his wife of technical and historical works in quantitative methods. His latest two-volume work, Everyday Arguments and the Theory of Argumentation, was published last year. Professor Miller was a visiting professor in many countries including Argentina, Chile, South Africa, Tunisia, Namibia, Zimbabwe and England. During the Second World War he served as a code-breaker with the United States Army at Arlington Farms. Professor Miller is survived by his wife, Lisa Evered Miller, his two children, Rachael and Jason, from a previous marriage to Renee Rubin and a granddaughter, Vivian. Friends may call at the Riverside Memorial Chapel at 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. from 2-5pm on Sunday, June 13th. A memorial service will be held on a future date at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Visiting Nurse Association of NY Hospice Care.

There are so many black and white lines, set off by street-crossing grids, one can forget about counting sheep and fall asleep by counting lines on everything from the everyday T-shirt to the more complex zigzags, swirls and bull's-eyes on simple dresses. It's an uncomplicated way to dress for maximum impact.

An obituary last Sunday and in late editions on Saturday, June 5, about the U.C.L.A. basketball coach John Wooden omitted the last entry in a seven-point creed that his father suggested that Mr. Wooden live by, and it also omitted the final three words of the fourth point in the creed. According to Mr. Wooden's autobiography, ''They Call Me Coach,'' the creed was: ''1. Be true to yourself. 2. Make each day your masterpiece. 3. Help others. 4. Drink deeply from good books, especially the Bible. 5. Make friendship a fine art. 6. Build a shelter against a rainy day. 7. Pray for guidance, count and give thanks for your blessings every day.'' The obituary also referred imprecisely to the defense for which Mr. Wooden's teams were known. It was a full-court zone press, not merely a ''zone defense.''

Q.My husband and I will be taking our 4-year-old daughter to New York City for her first visit. We only have one day in late July, and we want to give her the most memorable day possible. What would you recommend that a child (and her parents) would enjoy? - Kerstin Rowe, DenverA.A day isn't much time to explore a city as rich in offerings as New York. So instead of running around trying to hit all the spots, keep it simple. Here are a couple of options that should make your daughter's visit a memorable one.

AS the seat of the European Union, Brussels gets its share of gray suits pouring off the Eurostar. Luckily, the ties come off after work. Beneath the buttoned-down facade is a lively capital that follows its own sartorial trends, indulges in decadent flavors (especially when it involves beer) and exhibits a witty, even wacky sense of humor. What other city would erect an entire museum to a single comic book series? Or to an artist famous for painting faceless men in gray suits? Friday

A report last Sunday about the marriage of Carolina Ventura and Dr. Zoë Rosenbaum misspelled part of the Ms. Ventura's middle name. She is Carolina De Los Angeles Ventura, not Be Los Angeles.

In this often hot and crowded city, it can be difficult to escape the blaring horns and careening rickshaws, not to mention the hordes of fellow pedestrians. Luckily, the ever-popular Marine Drive promenade and the Hanging Gardens are not the only green spots in town. For a short morning stroll, check out the leafy neighborhood of Five Gardens, just a five-minute drive from the teeming Dadar train station. While the gardens are a bit rundown, the sidewalks are wide and well shaded, particularly around the stately bungalows of the Dadar Parsi Colony. At sunset, head to Bandra's seaside promenade, which runs from the 17th-century Bandra Fort up to the fishing village of Khar. Take a few laps around the assiduously maintained Jogger's Park - entrance fee of 2 rupees, about 4 cents - then follow the parade of families and couples up the Carter Road Promenade, which has broad views of the Arabian Sea.

An answer in the F.Y.I. column on May 9 about the number of water-inspection stations in New York City misidentified the agency that manages the city's water supply. It is the Department of Environmental Protection, a city agency -- not the state's Department of Environmental Conservation. This correction was delayed because an e-mail message last month from the city department's spokesman pointing out the error went astray at The Times.
Because of an editing error, a report last Sunday about the marriage of Holly Weiss and Michael Schechter misstated the wedding date. It was Sunday, June 6, not Saturday, June 5.

KONECKY--Ronald. It seems like yesterday---but it was September of 1951. I sat next to this guy in Civil Procedure--our first year at the Harvard Law School (we were not yet 22)--taught by the bombastic Professor Richard Field and our knees knocked in unison. He became my instant friend and classmate throughout law school and thereafter, and in 1962 we started the firm then called Barovick and Konecky which became perhaps one of the foremost entertainment and sports law firms in this country and abroad. He was my partner and my friend. We would meet at the end of the day, sometimes with a drink but often not, and discuss the details of our clients' problems, potential strategies for resolving knotty issues and ....laughing. Not at or about our clients, but about the industry's foibles and absurdities, finding humor in situations others might not--laughing riotously so that even after long and trying client negotiations or problems, we could go home to our loving wives with a smile. He was a fine lawyer and a special person. I loved him and will miss him. Dick Barovick

ORENSTEIN--Reed. My voice, for thee, my love, with languorous caresses Disturbs the solemn peace the midnight dark possesses. Besides this couch of mine a mournful candle glows. And, welling up, my verse in rippling murmurs flows; It flows in streams of love, its music wholly thine, And in the dark thine eyes are sparkling over mine. They look at me and smile - and oh, the sounds I hear: "My sweet and tender friend...I'm yours, my love...my dear". Your one and only Irina. Your son Leon, friends Natalia, Alla, Natasha W., Irina F., Inna.

PRESUMABLY among the millions of YouTube views of Lady Gaga's new ''Alejandro'' video there are people who enjoyed the music and the gear (great underwear -- thanks, Calvin Klein), and then resumed their regular activities, not shocked but maybe bemused. My appreciation for Lady Gaga's act is simple: I like her insistent awkwardness. She is an ugly duckling with great spook appeal, in a long tradition of such women. (For the best of them, consult Cecil Beaton's ''Glass of Fashion.'') I like that she not only appreciates hats but also understands the boundaries a hat and veil impose on others, a point she discussed recently on showstudio.com. As many know, she wore a veil last week to her sister's high school graduation from the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Manhattan. Was it a ''slap in the face'' to the school, as some columns said, or a way to say, ''You can't touch me''?

PLUM--Fred, on June 11, 2010, age 86. He is survived by his wife, Susan Butler Plum and his children Michael, Christopher and Carol, the children of the late Jean Houston Plum. He was preceded in death by his parents, Fred and Frances Alexander Plum and his sisters, Christine and Marlette Petze Sawyer and his daughter-in-law Maureen Cavanaugh. He was a noted neurologist and professor who was Chairman of the Neurology Department at Weill Cornell Medical School/ New York Hospital for 35 years. He took great pride in his graduates who provide the foundation of the Neurology Department at many medical schools. An expert on the states of consciousness and coma, he was the co-author of many books and articles on the subject. His passionate belief in the right of an individual to define his own quality of life and to die with dignity allowed him to see the treatment sources from the view of the patient, rather than as simply a challenge for the physician. A member of the Institute of Medicine and the American Academy of Arts and Science, he was also the founding editor of the Annals of Neurology. A teacher, a healer, a lover of art and music, there will never be another like him. In lieu of flowers, the family hopes that contributions will be made in his memory to the Department of Neurology for studies of consciousness at Weill Cornell Medical Center, 1300 York Ave., New York City, NY 10021. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

BORTNER--Bernard, died on June 6, 2010. Beloved brother of Dr. Seymour Bortner, father of Jill Sue Bortner. For many years an assistant principal in the New York City School system, where he was respected and admired by his colleagues, and adored by successive generations of students. The former Cincinnati Reds outfielder Ken Griffey Sr. learned he had prostate cancer in 2006. He has since become involved in educating other men, including his two sons, about the disease through the Depend Campaign to End Prostate Cancer, a partner with Zero, the Project to End Prostate Cancer. Griffey, 60, has 14 grandchildren and said, ''I want to be around as long as possible to watch them grow up.'' He still works for the Reds, whom he helped win back-to-back World Series titles in 1975 and 1976, as the hitting coach for their Class A affiliate, the Dayton Dragons. VINCENT M. MALLOZZI Q.When you were being treated for cancer, did any former teammates reach out to you?

VIKTOR & ROLF, practical? It happens. As a follow-up to their capsule collection of little black dresses last winter, Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren, the Dutch design duo known for creating wildly elaborate garments, are releasing a series of five white shirts. Though inspired by the classic men's dress shirt, basic blouses these are not. Festooned with a bib of blossoms and multiples of oversize bows, the white poplin shirts with satin and georgette detailing are as wonderfully unusual as would be expected. ''Every woman owns at least one white shirt,'' Messrs. Horsting and Snoeren note in a prepared statement. ''However, in our vision, the Viktor & Rolf woman will want to distinguish herself from the crowd.''

An article last Sunday about Francesca Schiavone's victory on Saturday, June 5, for the French Open women's title referred incorrectly to the achievement. With the win, Schiavone, who will turn 30 on June 23, became the oldest first-time Grand Slam women's singles champion in the Open era of tennis -- not the oldest since 1969. (Three men, including Andrés Gimeno, who was 34 at the 1972 French Open, were older when they won their first.). And in relating Schiavone's victory to one by Ann Jones, the article also referred incorrectly to Jones's achievement. When she won Wimbledon in 1969 at age 30, it was her third Grand Slam win -- not her first. (It was her first in the Open era.)

AS the refined Russian-born wife of a Milanese textile magnate, Tilda Swinton's character in the new film ''I Am Love'' is a woman with a wardrobe as well ordered as her staff: tailored coats, monochromatic sheaths, a geometric gown lifted from a Sonia Delaunay painting (right). ''In a setting dripping with luxury, she represents the supreme essence of it,'' said the film's costume designer, Antonella Cannarozzi. ''She is iconic, like Russian art.'' And, reminiscent of the collaboration between Yves Saint Laurent and Catherine Deneuve in ''Belle de Jour,'' Ms. Swinton's clothing was designed by Raf Simons of Jil Sander. ''We tried to achieve something realistic -- a bourgeois, yet modern look,'' Mr. Simons said. ''Her look is a clear expression of understated luxury.'' And, it ought to be added, rather on trend. Case in point: Ms. Swinton's striking red cocktail dress (left), which proved so popular that it was produced in a small edition, and promptly sold out.

GREENSPAN--Melvin "Mel," of Ft. Lauderdale, FL. Born April 24, 1919 in the Bronx, NY. Died peacefully in his sleep on June 11 at Pine Manor Nursing Home. He is survived by his good friends in Ft. He lived in New York City and Fire Island Pines for many years before retiring to Ft. Lauderdale ten years ago. His many friends remember his sharp wit and many stories and will miss him. Services to be held at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, Del Ray Beach, FL on Monday June 14, at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to a charity of your choice.

Vera Beaudin was newly divorced and a recent arrival in Harlem when a stranger knocked on her door one night carrying flowers and coffee cake. When he died five years later, Ms. Beaudin, who had taken her new husband's name, Saeedpour, responded by starting the first library and museum in the United States dedicated to Kurds, an ancient, stateless people straddling three nations in southwest Asia.

Travelers may not have to actually buy an iPad to use one on the road. The device has already gained a foothold in various hotels, and the latest to adopt the iPad is Jetstar Airways, a subsidiary of the Australian airline Qantas, which recently announced plans to roll out iPads as part of its in-flight entertainment options. The pilot project, first reported by Tnooz.com, a technology and travel Web site, will make iPads available for a small fee ($8.40) on certain flights, allowing passengers to read e-books and browse pre-selected movies. Because of security concerns, passengers will not be able to browse the Internet or peruse their own content, at least for the first phase of the project.

The upcoming judiciary committee hearings on the nomination of Elena Kagan to be an associate justice of the Supreme Court will likely unfold under the shadow of Chief Justice John G. Last weekend, the eighth annual Big Apple Barbecue Block Party was held in and around Madison Square Park. Rain that fell for at least half of Sunday did not tame the flames. This year's event included food from 18 of the country's best pit masters, 5 of them from New York City. Barbecue lovers were able to get their hands dirty with food from as far away as Las Vegas and Driftwood, Tex.

Back on June 9, an African easterly wave exited the western coast of Africa and has gradually gotten better organized as it trekked westward. It's presently located near 10N 41W, or about 1400 miles east of the Windward Islands. It's moving WNW at 12-13kts and that motion is expected to continue for the next several days. There is a 1010mb surface Low associated with the disturbance.

In a story in The Times on Sunday, our colleague Sheryl Gay Stolberg wrote of growing displeasure in Britain over the use of the name "British Petroleum" by top federal officials in the United States in referring to the party responsible for the gulf spill. The company officially changed its name to BP several years ago, and to some on the other side of the pond, invoking the old name is a backhanded slap at Britain and even a threat to the "special relationship" our two nations share.

At around 2 p.m. on Thursday, I arrived in Atins via slow boat from Barreirinhas. But my destination was still about 90 minutes away: the home and restaurant of Luzia Diniz Santos and family in Canto de Atins, a little settlement of 30-odd people on a strip of sandy prairie between the ocean and the dunes of Lençóis Maranhenses National Park in northeastern Brazil. Luzia's grilled shrimp is famous, at least locally, and her place receives a steady stream of  lunchtime guests. Her four simple guest rooms (for 20 reais, about  $11, a night) are far less known. I  found out only from a fellow boat passenger heading home to Atins, and changed my lodging plans accordingly.

"Many Israelis believe - as many American Jews believe - that the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, and his prime minister, Salam Fayyad, are very different sorts of leaders than Yasser Arafat ... But Israelis tend to see them as semi-powerless; they see Hamas as the rising power (especially after Hamas's victory in the Turkish flotilla war), and they understand, in ways that many Americans don't seem to understand, that Hamas poses an existential threat - you should pardon the expression - to the Palestinian Authority led by Abbas and Fayyad. ... For the typical Israeli, two events in particular have soured them on the chance for compromise. In 2000, the Israeli army pulled out of Lebanon. It was hoped that this pull-out would lead to peace on the northern border, but instead it led to rocket attacks by the Iranian-sponsored Hezbollah. In 2005, Israel unilaterally pulled its soldiers and settlers out of Gaza. Again, rockets followed ... Now, of course, the peace process, such as it is, hinges in part on an Israeli willingness to withdraw from the West Bank, including the hills of the West Bank that overlook Tel Aviv, the airport, and the entire thickly-populated central region of the country. This withdrawal will not be happening anytime soon, because there is a high degree of certainty among Israelis that a withdrawal from the West Bank hills would be followed not by peaceful reconciliation, but, again, by rockets. No Israeli wants to be a freier, a sucker, and right now the Israelis feel like suckers."

This is the week the design world heads to Basel, Switzerland for Design Miami/Basel which opens to the public on Tuesday, a day ahead of Art Basel. But if you can't go to the design fair, the design fair will come to you: This year marks the debut of its blog, the aptly-titled Design Miami/Basel Blog (http://designmiamibaselblog.com/). It will afford journalists and design fans access to breaking news, quotes, images, and updates from participants in the fair like designers and gallery owners, as well as the option to sign up for an RSS feed that sends alerts in real time - in case you can't wait until your first cup of morning coffee in New York to find out which celebrities bought what before dashing off to lunch at Chez Donati.

While Marc Ambinder and Blake Hounshell, among others, wonder if the weekend's big news about Afghanistan's enormous lithium deposits is really all that new, I wonder how long it will take some inventive Afghani politician to come up with a lithium-appropriate equivalent to "the devil's excrement," which is how a farsighted Venezuelan oil minister described his country's enormous - and eventually enormously destructive - petroleum resources 30 years ago. It's possible, I suppose, that lithium could be a "game changer" that redounds to the benefit of Afghanis and their American occupiers alike, but the history of these kind of things suggests otherwise, and strongly. It's very hard to imagine that a country as misgoverned as Afghanistan will be an exception to the rule that whom the gods destroy, they first make rich in natural resources.

Men tend to be bottom-liners and women seem to enjoy talking about their experiences more.

Health problems have taken yet another toll on the schedule of the conductor James Levine. He has pulled out of all appearances at the Tanglewood Music Festival this summer because he needs more time to recover from the back surgery he underwent in April, the Boston Symphony Orchestra, which runs the festival, announced on Monday. Mr. Levine was to have conducted six Boston Symphony Concerts and three by the Tanglewood Music Center orchestra, which is made up of young musicians. Michael Tilson Thomas, Christoph von Dohnanyi, Hans Graf and Johannes Debus, music director of the Canadian Opera Company, will substitute for Mr. Levine, the Boston Symphony said.

James N. Wood, who served as director of the Art Institute of Chicago for 25 years and took over as president and chief executive of the Getty Trust in Los Angeles in 2006, helping to steer the institution through a turbulent period in its history, died Friday at his home in the Brentwood neighborhood of Los Angeles, the trust announced. Mr. Wood was 69. A statement by the trust said that Mr. Wood had died unexpectedly, of natural causes, but that no exact cause of death was announced.

Spirit Airlines has announced on its Web site that it is canceling flights through Wednesday in the wake of a strike by its pilots late last week. Spirit is offering stranded travelers credit for the full amount of the unflown portion of the trip and a $100 credit. Though the carrier had pledged last week that service would continue in the event of a strike, Spirit started canceling flights on Saturday, disrupting plans for thousands of travelers, the Associated Press reported. Spirit, according to the A.P., operates 150 flights daily and is Fort Lauderdale's sole carrier to 14 international and five domestic destinations. Whether the strike will be resolved soon remains unclear. Spirit and its pilots have been in talks for more than three years. The pilots had been seeking pay raises and the airline said it had offered to raise pay by 29 percent over five years.9:53 a.m. | Updated An earlier version of this post inaccurately described the amount of compensation that Spirit is offering its stranded passengers.

Our sports section ran a chart yesterday showing that, in relative terms, shortstops and second basemen are better hitters than they used to be and outfielders and designated hitters are worse. From Stacey Higginbotham at GigaOm:

It always seems to be the case that whatever gets hyped in the press will be undermined by reality in the coming days. Anytime the Dutch play, there is talk of Cruyff and Total Football and the sheer ecstatic beauty of the game. Talk of angels, Picasso and improbable genius shortly follow. And then there was today's effort: a pedestrian affair by any account. The Netherlands clearly miss the creativity and dynamism created by winger Robben who is a one man whirling dervish out there. Without his fervor the midfield did not have the options up front. Van Persie had maybe one stellar chance all game? It wasn't until late in the second half with the substitutions of the youngsters Afellay and, in particular, Elia on the left flank, that things started to open up and traces of the Dutch flair could be spotted. So let's hold off on any more talk of Total Football until we actually see it from the starting lineup.

JERUSALEM -- In an effort to dampen international criticism and stave off calls for an international inquiry, Israel announced the composition late Sunday of a government-appointed commission with foreign participation to investigate the circumstances surrounding its deadly commando raid on a flotilla bound for Gaza in late May. Earlier Sunday, the secretary general of the Arab League toured Gaza for the first time since the Islamist group Hamas took control of the Palestinian territory, underlining an urge for more Arab involvement in the issues raised by the raid on the flotilla, which was trying to breach Israel's naval blockade.

CUCINOTTA--Salvatore, on June 11, 2010, wonderful and loving husband of dearest Else-Mary, passed away peacefully with his wife by his side. He was known for his fabulous restaurants in New York City, especially Teddy's on West Broadway, where so many celebrities have dined. Among the many restaurants, he opened up the first Japanese steak house in New York City. He was also part of building up Tribeca downtown, after buying several of the buildings in the area, they were later made into lofts. Soon the artists started to move in, and shortly thereafter he was called "Mr. Tribeca." He was kind and very helpful to everyone, when someone needed help, he was there. He will be missed so much by everyone, especially by his wife, Else-Mary. They had a wonderful marriage for 40 years and she always said that she has the most wonderful husband in the world. He was the love of her life and she also said that they will be together one day forever in a beautiful place, and that God will take care of him until they meet again. He is survived by his wife, his two daughters, Arlene Posner of New Jersey and Joanna Minshall and son-in-law, Robert Minshall of California, four grandchildren, five great-grandchildren, and other loving relatives. A memorial service will take place on Tuesday at 7pm at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St.

GREENSPAN--Melvin "Mel," of Ft. Lauderdale, FL. Born April 24, 1919 in the Bronx, NY. Died peacefully in his sleep on June 11 at Pine Manor Nursing Home. He is survived by his good friends in Ft. Lauderdale and New York. A tireless collector of "things," he spent many years as a traveling store supervisor for Diana Stores in the Pacific Northwest. He lived in New York City and Fire Island Pines for many years before retiring to Ft. Lauderdale ten years ago. His many friends remember his sharp wit and many stories and will miss him. Services to be held at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, Del Ray Beach, FL on Monday June 14, at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to a charity of your choice.

ROMEO--Lilla Maria, aged 63, died on June 9, 2010, after a long and courageous battle with breast cancer. Lilla lived life to the fullest. She was an inspiring teacher, a powerful salesperson and a tireless entrepreneur. She became a forceful and influential advocate for the cause of fighting breast cancer, serving on numerous advisory committees and speaking widely. But most of all, she was a loving wife, mother, grandmother, sister and friend. She inspired all she knew with her positive attitude, empathetic manner, and endearing grace, and delighted her guests with her wonderful cooking. She will be sorely missed. She is survived by her husband of 41 years, Anthony, of New York City; by her son, John Romeo, and his wife, Antonia, of London, UK; by her son, Jeffrey Romeo, and his partner, Romanee, of London, UK; by her daughter, Carly Gibbons, and her husband, Andrew, of Philadelphia, PA; by her sister, Sarina Infranco, of Vineland, New Jersey; and by seven beautiful grandchildren. Contributions in her honor can be made to SHARE Cancer Support in New York.

SMUKLER--Victor E.,died June 10, 2010, age of 78, of metastatic melanoma. Amazing husband, father and grandfather, beloved patriarch of a large extended family, he was a friend and mentor to countless others. He will be greatly missed. A lifetime fellow of the American Bar Association and attorney at the New York City firm of Herzfeld & Rubin, PC since 1999. He specialized in commercial real estate, construction, finance and intellectual properties. He was involved in ultimate energy initiatives, an outgrowth of his real estate development expertise, and in solar plant placement in the US and Israel. Before becoming an attorney, he owned and ran Lake Erie Asfalt Products and Trucking (LEAP) in Cleveland, OH. He earned a BS in chemistry in 1953 and his JD in 1978, both from Case Western Reserve University. Serving on many not-for-profit boards, he was a president of the Elaine Kaufman Cultural Center, the Cleveland Orchestra and the Cleveland Chamber Music Society. Survived by his beloved wife, Barbara, brother, Mark, children Laurie Smukler and her husband Ira Weller, Amy Sprecher and husband Ben Sprecher, and Sam Ace. Grandchildren Anna and Julian Weller, and Emma and Luke Sprecher. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be made in Victor's name to the Melanoma Research Foundation 170 Township Line Rd, Hillsborough, NJ 08844-3867.

Oil has gushed into the Gulf of Mexico for eight weeks now - and sent a bipartisan wave of criticism crashing into the White House. Allies and adversaries have accused President Obama of reacting too slowly, deferring too much to BP, displaying too little emotion and demonstrating incompetent management. Fans of historical analogy compare his performance to ineffectual responses by President Jimmy Carter during the Iran hostage crisis, and President George W. Bush during Hurricane Katrina.

AUSTIN, Tex. -- The thing looks fearsome enough on the ground, 40 feet from teeth to tail, spikes raised and claws extended, rearing its head as though to give some lacertilian battle call. New Yorkers of a certain age, and a certain musical persuasion, may remember it well. Blessed with eyes of devil red, a protruding dewlap and a bared rack of incisors to complete the vision, this beast of bright green cut the sky over a major Texas city last week, suspended from the undercarriage of a helicopter, dipping toward board members of the Fort Worth Zoo.

About a year ago, the Sebonack Golf Club in Southampton, N.Y., retrofitted its golf carts with solar cell roof panels. Sebonack said it was the first American golf course with a solar-powered cart fleet. The roof panels convert daylight into power and charge the cart as it is being driven. It cost Sebonack, which will host the 2013 United States Women's Open, about $3,000 per cart to make the switch. The club has been recouping the cost in energy savings because the 39-cart fleet no longer spends the night in a barn recharging. And the batteries rarely run down and last longer.

Microsoft will release its new version of its office suite, Office 2010, on Tuesday. Microsoft Office, which encompasses the workplace staples Word, Excel and Outlook, has dominated sales this year, along with iWork, the Apple productivity application that is compatible with Word and Excel documents. Office 2010 tweaks its core products and introduces Web Apps, online versions of Word, Excel (above), OneNote and PowerPoint. These will compete with an application that is not on the top sellers list because it is free: Google Docs, the so-called cloud computing productivity programs that users can reach from any computer. Office 2010 users will be able to store documents online, giving them universal access, too. SHELLY FREIERMAN

DURBAN, South Africa - A World Cup Sunday that began at the soaring new arch of Durban Stadium ended in smoke and shrieks as police officers fired tear gas and what witnesses said were rubber bullets to break up a large group of protesting security guards. The altercation started shortly before 1 a.m. Monday, a few hours after the match between Germany and Australia ended. It began in the parking area underneath the stadium, where some administrative offices are located. It soon spilled into the streets outside as several hundred panicked protesters sprinted away as about 40 police officers advanced toward them on foot.

Harvey loved his family, research and teaching, and he loved to laugh. He is greatly missed. Burial 1pm, Thursday in Malden, MA (800-982-3717). Lancaster Ave, Ste. 101, Haverford, PA 19041.

An article on Wednesday about Dan L. Duncan, who may become the first American billionaire to pass his fortune to his heirs tax-free, misidentified the institution to which he gave more than $250 million during his lifetime. It is the Baylor College of Medicine, not Baylor University. (The two have been distinct entities for several decades.)

An article on Tuesday about the role of testosterone in gauging trustworthiness misstated the university affiliation of two scientists who recently wrote a commentary about research on the subject. The scientists, Ryan T. Johnson and S. Marc Breedlove, are from Michigan State University, not the University of Michigan.

Not content with selling handbags and home décor on television 24 hours a day, HSN now wants to sell for 48 hours a day. The company, formerly called the Home Shopping Network, will announce on Monday that it is starting a second full-time network in August, essentially expanding its retail space through a deal with the Dish Network. Called HSN2, the second network will run repeats of the first network's shows, giving pitchmen like Wolfgang Puck and Todd English a second chance to persuade viewers to pick up the phone (or reach for the mouse). It will initially reach 14 million subscribers.

An article in the special Personal Tech section on Thursday about competition among e-readers overstated the number of volumes available for the iPad through the iBook app. Tens of thousands of books are available, not 1.5 million.

On Thursday, we begin the equivalent of a four-day national holiday of golf. And although every United States Open is good theater, this year's stage is the Pebble Beach Golf Links, which will make the drama seem tinged with history even in real time. Laird Small, the director of the Pebble Beach Golf Academy since 1996, is a top-100 golf instructor who grew up on the Monterey Peninsula and caddied at Pebble Beach as a teenager. In an interview last week, Small offered some distinct perspectives, acquired through the decades, on championship competition at one of the world's most familiar golf landscapes:

The layout and location of the Pebble Beach Golf Links, site of this week's United States Open, can bring about some unusual rules situations, specifically because the course has holes that abut what is arguably the largest lateral water hazard in the world (i.e., the Pacific Ocean). For example, this week players may choose to drop a ball in a dropping zone outside of a bunker instead of in a bunker when taking relief under the water hazard Rule (Rule 26). The long bunker to the left of the 18th fairway at Pebble Beach is immediately adjacent to the ocean. If a player's ball last crossed the margin of the lateral water hazard adjacent to this long bunker, the player may play the ball as it lies in the lateral water hazard, play a ball from where he played his previous shot, drop a ball in the bunker within two club lengths of the point where his ball last crossed the margin of the hazard or drop a ball in the nearest dropping zone that is not nearer the hole than the point where the ball last crossed the margin of the hazard.

Well, now: it seems our dear ally across the pond feels that a row has broken out over the intemperance of the American president toward mighty BP. ''Anglophobic spite,'' was the charge leveled atPresident Obama by a columnist for The Daily Mail, implausibly attributing the animus to Obama's Kenyan father. London's mayor,Boris Johnson, demanded an end to ''anti-British rhetoric.'' He demanded it! Or else. And a leading Tory by name of Lord Tebbit branded Obama's conduct ''despicable.''

MOGADISHU, Somalia -- Awil Salah Osman prowls the streets of this shattered city, looking like so many other boys, with ripped-up clothes, thin limbs and eyes eager for attention and affection. But Awil is different in two notable ways: he is shouldering a fully automatic, fully loaded Kalashnikov assault rifle; and he is working for a military that is substantially armed and financed by the United States.

JELIN--Sima K.,age 89, died at her home on June 12, 2010. Throughout her life, Sima was active as a real estate broker, corporate CEO, philanthropist and most importantly as a participant in the daily lives of her family and countless friends. We all celebrate her many accomplishments and relish the knowledge that she was proud of ours. She is married to Sidney Weinstein and predeceased by husbands, Martin Jelin, Cecil Lichtman and son William Jelin. She is the beloved mother of Dr. Abraham Jelin and his wife Margie, Fred Jelin, Anne Jelin, Sarah Jane Jelin and her husband Ed Schwarz, and Deborah Jelin Newmyer, sister to Jay Kislak, David Kislak and the late Naomi Fisher Bartnoff. Mrs. Jelin is also adored by fifteen grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at Temple Sharey Tefilo-Israel, 432 Scotland Road, South Orange, NJ at 10am on Tuesday, June 15, 2010. Contributions may be made to Sima Jelin Fund for Inter-Cultural Tolerance at the American Jewish Committee 225 Milburn Ave. Milburn, NJ 07041. For information, call Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel (800) 938-6372.

DUPONG--Jessie M. (nee MacLeman), of Babylon, NY formerly of Park Slope Brooklyn on June 11, 2010 at age 99. Beloved wife of the late William Gregg Dupong M.D. Also survived by her many nieces and nephews. Jessie was a member of the American Medical Alliance and Grace United Methodist Church Valley Stream. Jessie graduated from Maxwell Teachers School and then attended Brooklyn College for her graduate study. She was employed by Con Edison where her tenure included lecturing and demonstrating how to cook on the first electric range. In spite of much success with Con Edison Jessie began her teaching career at P.S. 47 in Brooklyn. She enjoyed many years in the school system. Family will receive friends this evening Monday June 14 from 7-9pm at The Moore Funeral Home 54 West Jamaica Avenue Valley Stream, NY. Funeral Tuesday 11am. Interment Greenfield Cemetery Hempstead with Pastor John Cole Officiating.

Maybe it's the color drawings that look like regular golfers I have known. Maybe it's the thick paper that reminds me of my old grade school projects. Maybe it's the simplicity of the tasks and the guidance offered, but I have always loved the Private Lessons section at the back of Golf Magazine. Four years ago, a collection of the most insightful lessons culled from the magazine through the decades was published. This year, new material has been added in the revised edition, ''Private Lessons: The Best of the Best Instruction.'' (Abrams Books) It's a hefty tome, more than 300 pages and shaped like a textbook, but inside are the handy, digestible tips with the accurate, familiar illustrations. The lessons are separated into chapters with titles like course management, the mental game and specialty short game shots. If searching for a golf-related Father's Day gift, ''Private Lessons'' will be more helpful than a dozen golf balls - and last considerably longer as well.

LEVY--Lois K, 80, following a brief illness on June 12. Devoted mother of Diane Baxter and Nancy Lobell and their husbands Robert and Marc. Adoring grandmother to Andrew, Marshall and Marian and loving step-sister to Tony Wimpfheimer. Lois, who grew up in New York City, spent most of her adult life at the place she loved most, the Jersey Shore, where she raised her family and devoted herself to its communities. The daughter of Donald Klopfer, co-founder of Random House, Lois was keenly interested in the arts, especially dance, which she studied at Bennington College, literature, and the theater. Lois was a life-long fan of tennis and won many club titles at Ocean Beach Club, where she summered, a member of Hollywood Golf Club, a great friend of the Deal Jewish Community Center and Jewish Family and Children's Services. Lois was deeply committed to CPC Behavioral Healthcare, which she helped to create, and served on the Board of Trustees for over 42 years. Her efforts helped the Agency to grow and to change people's understanding of mental health. Lois will likely be best remembered for her complete devotion to her daughters and their families, and for her many, many friendships. Memorial Service on Monday June 14 at Temple Beth Miriam, Elberon, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to the CPC Foundation.

KONECKY--Ronald S. Cherished husband of Isobel. Adored father of Jennifer (Bob Wheelock) and doting grandfather of Tim and Matthew Wheelock. Ron was born in Brooklyn, NY, the youngest of four boys to Philip and Lillian Konecky. His loving brothers William, Gerald (Mildred) and Murray (Adele) also survive him. He was a proud graduate of Midwood High School, where he scored the first ever touchdown for the school. He attended the University of Arizona. After serving in the Army, he attended Harvard Law School which prepared him for his 50 year law career in which he represented many TV news, sports, publishing and theater personalities; Roone Arledge, Walter Cronkite, Frank Gifford, and Morley Safer among the many. He was married to performer/theater producer Isobel Robins Konecky for 49 years. He was a mentor, confidant, advisor to many. A man who made the lives of all who knew him better. In addition to his love of the law, he also loved the theater and served on the board of the American Theatre Wing. He was the best husband, father, grandfather, brother and uncle ever. Gone but never forgotten . . . what a fella. Isobel and Jennifer

9 P.M. (HBO) FOR NEDA In the hours after the death of Neda Agha-Soltan -- who was shot on June 20, 2009, during the turmoil surrounding the Iranian presidential contest -- the image of her final moments, captured by cellphone, ricocheted around the world and became a symbol of the struggle in Iran. This documentary from Antony Thomas, with reporting by the Iranian journalist Saeed Kamali Dehghan, presents a fuller profile of Ms. Agha-Soltan, and the place of women in Iran, through interviews with her parents, her siblings and the doctor who held her as she died, as well as her private videos, photographs, letters and diaries. Above, a protest after her death. The actress Shohreh Aghdashloo (''House of Sand and Fog'') narrates. 8 P.M. (ABC) THE BACHELORETTE Ali Fedotowsky flies to New York, where she has a makeover and photo shoot for InStyle magazine before meeting the 11 remaining bachelors. Seven of the men will audition to perform in ''The Lion King.'' One will take Ms. Fedotowsky on a helicopter tour of Manhattan and an exploration of the American Museum of Natural History by flashlight. Another will join her for a private rooftop concert by Joshua Radin and the Harlem Boys Choir. Still another will sneak out of the men's suite in the dead of night -- and return with a bandaged wrist.

The war of words between Google and Apple over mobile ads sharpened on Wednesday. AdMob, the mobile advertising start-up that Google recently acquired, said Apple's new terms of service for the iPhone 4 and iPad, if enforced, would prevent it from putting ads inside mobile apps. That could be crippling for AdMob, which is the No. 1 seller of ads in iPhone apps. Omar Hamoui, the chief executive of AdMob, said the policy could hurt developers too.

Murphy, who served for more than 20 years as Staten Island's district attorney, prosecuting a notorious child kidnapper, a corrupt city official and the killer of two New York detectives, died on Friday at his home in the New Brighton neighborhood of the borough. He was 65. The cause was complications of diabetes, his wife, Kathleen B. Murphy, said.

Imagine you're the hero in one of those old movies, desperately lost in a windswept desert, undulating dunes stretching to the horizon. Out of water, tongue parched and skin blistered, you drop to your knees. Vultures circle overhead. (O.K., maybe you're in a comic strip, not a movie.) Yet there, in the distance, is a crystal blue pool - no, wait, dozens of them - and you push forward, fantasizing about diving in, slaking your thirst, soothing your miserably sunburned skin. It's a mirage, of course. Dozens of perfect blue pools don't just magically appear in the desert.

In 1969, Gov. Ronald Reagan of California signed the nation's first no-fault divorce law. He later called it the worst mistake of his life. But other states eventually followed California's lead, and no-fault -- under which one spouse can end a marriage, with no proof required of wrongdoing by either party -- more or less became law of the land. New York State was the longtime holdout, since South Dakota passed its law in 1985.

I had early doubts about "Mad Men," but eventually I gave myself over to its charms, and after three excellent seasons I took it for granted that the saga of Don Draper was the best show on TV - the rightful heir, insofar as one could possibly exist, to "The Sopranos" and "The Wire." But after working my way through AMC's other drama, "Breaking Bad," which had its season finale Sunday night, I find that I've changed my mind. And not only because "Breaking Bad" is brilliant - though it is, it is - but because its dramatic strengths expose some of the weaknesses of "Mad Men," and puncture, ever-so-gently, the mystique that's built up around Matthew Weiner's show.

Imagine. You are lying in the grass in the east African savannah, watching wildebeest fording a shallow river. You can hear the funny grunting noises they make, and as they pass by, you can feel the impact of their hooves on the ground and smell their rich animal smell. You see their kicking heels, their beautiful sleek bodies. Then you look up, and you realize that the herd stretches as far as you can see, that the plain is dark with wildebeest. If you were to wait for them all to pass, you would be there for days.

The Dining section of The Times has an article this week on shaved ice. Diner's Journal is asking readers to post their ideas for a new shaved-ice recipe. Fany Gerson, a pastry chef in New York and the author of the forthcoming "My Sweet Mexico: Recipes for Authentic Pastries, Breads, Candies, Beverages, and Frozen Treats" (to be published by Ten Speed Press in September) will pick a suggestion from the comments and create a recipe for it. Write your ideas in the comments below. Be creative and have fun.

Takashi, a wondrous, strange new restaurant in the West Village that specializes in raw offal and Korean-style Japanese barbecue, is the subject of this week's review. The menu is a challenge to even the most committed carnivore. (Check out that raw liver!) But it is not a gimmicky restaurant so much as a celebratory one. It is a meat mecca, fun for adventurous eaters and anyone interested in the flavors of extremely high-end beef, uncooked or grilled. And it's very well run to boot, with good service in a pleasant setting. It is a marvel that the restaurant's owners, Takashi Inoue and Saheem Ali, who work as the chef and general manager respectively, have never run a restaurant before. (Indeed, Takashi is Mr. Ali's first-ever restaurant job.) Have you eaten here? Feel free, as always, to add your voice to the choir of citizen critics who have something to say about the restaurants in which they consume food. Click here, or on the "Reader Review" button attached to the published article and type away to your heart's content.

The bad news just keeps coming for BP -- this time from Bank of America. A high-level executive at the bank has ordered its traders not to enter into oil trades with BP that extend beyond a year from now, Reuters reports, citing an unidentified market source familiar with the order.

New York City's water supply got a little more protection Tuesday with the purchase of 1,124 additional acres scattered around the city's upstate reservoirs, for $4.75 million. That makes 155,000 acres that the city has bought or obtained easements on to create open-space buffers around its 19 drinking water reservoirs to guard against contamination. The new parcels are in Greene, Ulster and Delaware Counties. "This land acquisition is part of a $1.5 billion overall investment in watershed protection programs that allows New York City to continue supplying the majority of its drinking water from unfiltered sources - a status that only five large cities in the country share," Cas Holloway, commissioner of the city's Department of Environmental Protection, said in a statement.

A combination of marginal vertical shear and decreased low-mid-level relative humidity seems to have taken a toll on the developing vortex. Deep convection associated with the disturbance has diminished, and it's now an exposed swirl of clouds centered near 13N 46W and tracking WNW at 13kts. It is not expected to regenerate. See http://einstein.atmos.colostate.edu/~mcnoldy/tropics/atcf/latestATL.png for the current location and prior track.

At his recent resort presentation, Alber Elbaz explained that his collection was all about finding solutions. Most of these solutions were of the two-in-one variety. He interpreted fashion's current minimal mood in what he called a Lanvin way: sleeveless black T-shirt dresses, when turned inside out, transformed into feminine tulle confections. These were very charming (albeit a bit scratchy) when worn in the minimal way. The swimwear was divine; when each suit was paired with its appropriate cover-up, the combo took the shape of a cocktail dress or beach-appropriate gown.

If you are old enough to remember the 1990s, then you know that there was a sustained period of time in which the name David Hasselhoff was the punch line to every other joke about the lunacy of European pop cultural taste. (How this came to be is explained by his hit single following the fall of the Berlin Wall, "Looking for Freedom.") If you are of the right age and also German then you probably recall that between the years of 1975 and 1982 Mr. Hasselhoff inhabited the role of Dr. William "Snapper'' Foster, Jr. on the CBS soap opera "The Young and the Restless.'' On Tuesday, the Hoff returned to the show that made him a star, where he'll be playing Snapper all week. His daughter Taylor Ann (the one who recorded a drunken episode of her father's three years ago) will show up beginning Wednesday to play a nurse.

Last summer, Jennifer O'Keeffe, a photographer in San Francisco, was feeling stuck, "creatively and in my life," she says, and she wanted to get lost. So she bought a cargo van retrofitted with a bed and took to the road for a two-month solo road trip, photographing her way up the coast of California, to Oregon and the Olympic Peninsula of Washington, then through Idaho, Montana, Utah and Nevada. "I didn't have a definite plan and I didn't want one," O'Keeffe says. "I love maps and navigation, but I wanted this trip to have a different sort of pattern - one that came from directions scribbled on the back of napkins, questionable decisions and wrong turns." Besides her camera, her other constant companion was a copy of Steinbeck's "Travels With Charley," which helped O'Keeffe put her experiences of everyday American life in a larger context: a young woman in 2009 comparing her observations with those of a man at the end of his life in 1960. "He was witnessing a new era of modernity in full swing, and I was looking at a lot of the broken pieces." O'Keeffe made a selection of her images from the trip available to T; the full portfolio is on her Web site.

Soldiers, sailors and Marines experience the hardships of war firsthand, often serving in  countries where the culture and customs differ greatly from their own. International civilian aid workers, United Nations representatives and contractors are there, too, working tirelessly in harsh conditions and often without the resources -- money, equipment and personnel -- they need.At home in our armchairs, we learn about Afghanistan from network news and political pundits. Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal's counterinsurgency strategy and President Obama's security policies are debated over dinner and drinks, while combat statistics are recorded as numbers of civilian or military casualties. The highly personal nature of war and the impact it has on the people -- the victims -- are lost in those numbers.

Mr. Scott praises the performances in the film, including those of Charlton Heston, Janet Leigh, Marlene Dietrich and Welles himself, calling their turns "fleshy and real." And he appreciates how their complexities make it difficult to tell which side they are on. Have you seen "Touch of Evil?" Please share your thoughts on the movie.

BRITTON--John P.,beloved father, grandfather, husband, brother and distinguished scholar of Babylonian astronomy and the history of science, died of cardiac arrest on June 8th. He was 71. John was born in Hartford, CT. He attended St. Paul's School and spent ten years at Yale University where he received a B.A. and a Ph.D. in the History of Science and Medicine for his work studying ancient mathematics and astronomy. After school he moved to West Hartford, where he lived for more than 20 years with his first wife Kathryn Lines Britton, raising his family and working in a variety of roles in the investment management business. He joined Conning & Company in 1966, became partner and later left to found CF Management, an asset management firm. In his last two decades, John returned his focus to the study of ancient astronomy, and made a number of notable contributions to the field. His early study of the precision of the models in Ptolemy's Almagest was followed by numerous works that formed a comprehensive exploration of the origins of exact science. In 1995 he married Claudine Vincente Britton and in 1997 they moved to Wilson, WY. John charmed the lives of his friends and family with his mischievous, contrarian sense of humor, his deep intellect and his wide-ranging interests in politics, financial markets, science, arts, and history. He served on the Board of Trustees of the Wadsworth Atheneum and a number of corporate boards and worked with St. Paul's School to improve mathematics education. John also had a lifelong passion for the outdoors. He enjoyed rock climbing, skiing, and hiking for most of his 71 years and introduced both his sons and grandchildren to the outdoor life. He is survived by his wife, Claudine Britton of Wilson, WY; his sons John Britton of New York, NY and Sam Britton of San Francisco, CA; his brother Peter Britton of South Hamilton, MA; and four grandchildren.
