In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to SUNY Maritime College, 6 Pennyfield Avenue, Throggs Neck, NY 10465. In memory of Allen J. Flood for the Sailing Program.

WEST--Shirley Almeda, died peacefully at home in her Tribeca loft on June 8, 2010, after a long illness. Ms. West was born on October 24, 1928 in Breckenridge, Texas and was an artist. In 1949, she earned an Associate of Arts degree from Stephens College in Columbia, Missouri, where she was taught by Pierre Montminy and Worden Day. She then traveled to the University of Colorado, Boulder, to study with renowned German Expressionist Max Beckmann. She continued to study privately with Beckmann until his death in late 1950. Ms. West continued her education at Smith College, where she received a B.A. in English Literature, Art History, Painting and Sculpture in 1952, and at Columbia University, where she received an M.F.A. in 1958. She studied with numerous artists during the 1950's, including painter Mervin Jules, graphic artist George Swinton, sculptor Peter Srippi, and painters Ottis Dozier and Vaclav Vytlacil. Ms. West began exhibiting her work in New York in the 1950's at spaces such as Brata and Avant Garde Ltd. She had her first one-woman show of drawings and paintings at the Museum of Modern Art, Miami, in 1961. Throughout the 1960's and '70's, Ms. West was active in the Art Students League in New York, studying primarily with Robert Beverly Hale. She also studied privately for many years with Dr. A. Didier Graeffe, Humanities professor at the University of Florida in Gainesville. During this period, she began the large-scale sculptural work that came to define her career. From 1968 to 1970, she built three large, concrete sculptures that were constructed outdoors in Gainesville and Micanopy, Florida: The Prairie Woman (1968-69); Yin/Yang (1969) and The Embrace (1969-70). In 2009, Ms. West's work was exhibited at a one-woman show entitled "Discovery: A Retrospective" at the Chelsea Art Museum in New York City. Ms. West was the eldest daughter of Texas oil man Carey Keene West, the founder of the Chemical Process Company (now known as BJ Service Company), and Fredricka Almeda West. Ms. West was predeceased by her brother, Carey West, Jr. She is survived by her sister, Ms. Lorraine West of Dallas, Texas; her nieces, Ms. Roxane West of Dallas and New York, Ms. Carol Ann Presnell of Aledo, Texas and Ms. Catherine Oconnor of Tuscaloosa, Alabama; as well as her nephews, Mr. Robert Morris of Kennedale, Texas, Mr. Carey West III of Houston, Mr. Patrick West of Fort Worth and Mr. Frederick West, also of Fort Worth. In addition, she is survived by numerous great-nieces, great-nephews, great-great-nieces and great-great-nephews. Ms. West was an avid music lover and an accomplished musician, playing piano, cello and flute. She frequently hosted concerts in her Tribeca loft. Ms. West was also an ardent supporter of charities for the benefit of animals. She leaves behind many friends, who admired her sharp wit, extensive generosity, and kind and loving heart. Ms. West will be deeply missed by all who knew her. "To live in the hearts of those we leave behind is not to die..." She will live in our hearts forever.

A dance review on Monday about the Rosso Bastardo Evening at La MaMa in the East Village, using information from the program, omitted part of the name of the winery that sponsored the event. It is Signae Cesarini Sartori, not Signae.

CUCINOTTA--Salvatore, on June 11, 2010, wonderful and loving husband of dearest Else-Mary, passed away peacefully with his wife by his side. He was known for his fabulous restaurants in New York City, especially Teddy's on West Broadway, where so many celebrities have dined. Among the many restaurants, he opened up the first Japanese steak house in New York City. He was also part of building up Tribeca downtown, after buying several of the buildings in the area, they were later made into lofts. Soon the artists started to move in, and shortly thereafter he was called "Mr. Tribeca." He was kind and very helpful to everyone, when someone needed help, he was there. He will be missed so much by everyone, especially by his wife, Else-Mary. They had a wonderful marriage for 40 years and she always said that she has the most wonderful husband in the world. He was the love of her life and she also said that they will be together one day forever in a beautiful place, and that God will take care of him until they meet again. He is survived by his wife, his two daughters, Arlene Posner of New Jersey and Joanna Minshall and son-in-law, Robert Minshall of California, four grandchildren, five great-grandchildren, and other loving relatives. A memorial service will take place on Tuesday at 7pm at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St.

WOOD--James. The Association of Art Museum Directors is profoundly saddened by the loss of our colleague and friend James N. Wood. His 35 years of extraordinary leadership and role as a mentor set an unimpeachable standard for the field. His wisdom, guidance, and unfailing kindness will be deeply missed, but we know his visionary work will continue to inspire all those in the art museum community today and in future generations. We wish to send our most heartfelt condolences to his family. Kaywin Feldman, President, Association of Art Museum Directors

The Advertising column on Wednesday, about ''icing,'' in which men try to get their friends to drink Smirnoff Ice beverages, misstated the publication in which Kevin Wolkenfeld, a student at the University of Central Florida in Orlando, wrote about the phenomenon. He posted an article about it on a student news Web site called knightnews.com; he did not write about it ''for the school paper.'' (Mr. Wolkenfeld's university does not have an official school newspaper, although The Central Florida Future, a print publication owned by Gannett, is distributed on campus. Mr. Wolkenfeld does not write for that publication.)

Lots of people are talking about what is happening at Goldman Sachs. This is a column about what is not happening at Goldman. Despite all the bad headlines -- the accusations of fraud, the talk of a big settlement, the risk, however remote, of criminal charges -- there's an inconvenient truth that's been largely ignored: Most of Goldman's big customers are not bolting.

WOOD--James N. The Institute of Fine Arts community mourns the loss of our trustee and alumnus, James N. Wood. We will miss his good counsel, dedicated support and gracious presence. We extend our sympathy to his wife, IFA alumna Emese Forizs, daughters Lenke and Rebecca, and his entire family. Judy Steinhardt, Chairman Patricia Rubin, Director Institute of Fine Arts, NYU

ZWEIG--Dr. Jack I.,75, died at his home June 13 from pancreatic cancer. An oncologist, he is survived by his wife of 49 years, Elisabeth; children Karen, Kenneth, Richard and Monica; and eight grandchildren. Shiva will be at home in New Rochelle.

A Sports of The Times column in some editions on Sunday, contrasting the goalkeeping of the United States with that of England in their tie on Saturday in the World Cup, referred incorrectly to the match. While it was the teams' first match of the soccer tournament, it was not the first match of this World Cup. (The first was South Africa's 1-1 tie with Mexico on Friday.)

MARKS--Peter, 75, died peacefully at home on June 13, 2010, of complications from cancer. A lifetime New Yorker, Peter graduated from the High School of Music & Art in 1952 and from Amherst College in 1956. After a brief stint in publishing, Peter opened the Peter Marks Works of Art, Inc. in 1960, a private gallery specializing in Southeast Asian and Islamic antiquities. He made important contributions to the Asian art field both as a dealer and as an advocate for his profession. He also wrote and published three novels. Following his retirement in 2002, Peter began painting, a passion that had lain dormant for many years. Peter is survived by his wife Jean, his daughter Annie, his son Sam and his wife Lauren Pesso, his son Ben and his wife Elizabeth Morrison and their children Sophie and Eli, and by his brother Walter Marks and his wife Joan Brooker. The funeral will be private. Contributions may be made in his memory to the Art Angels Supplies Fund of the Friends of Fiorello H. LaGuardia High School of Music and Art and Performing Arts (www.alumniandfriends.org).

WOLKEN--Jonathan. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Joyce Theater mourn the passing of Jonathan Wolken, co-founder of Pilobolus. For 23 years, we applauded his creative spirit, indomitable personality and intellectual humor, and delighted in his artistry. We will miss him and extend condolences to his wife, daughters, and the entire Pilobolus family.

WEISS--Marie, a gift to the Little Red School House and Elisabeth Irwin High School for more than a half-century. Business manager, associate director, nurse, teacher, confidant and friend. A consistent force in the life of our school and the thousands who shared it with her through the decades. We miss her. She could never be forgotten. The LREI community extends its condolences to her daughter Andrea and her son Andrew and their families. In lieu of flowers, donations in Marie's memory may be sent to The Marie Weiss Memorial Fund, LREI, 272 Sixth Ave, NY, NY 10014.

LEVY--Lois. The CPC Behavioral Healthcare Board of Trustees offers its deep sympathy to the family and friends of Lois Levy. A dedicated Trustee for over 42 years and past Board President, Lois was a strong advocate for people with mental health issues. Her legacy lives on through the lives of many touched by her compassion and philanthropy. Kathy Goldstein, Chair John Mans, CEO

An article on Thursday about a Taliban campaign of assassinations against Afghans associated with local government misidentified the group working with Usaid that employed one of the victims. An 18-year-old Afghan woman named Hosay who was recently shot to death in Kandahar worked at DAI, or Development Alternatives Inc. -- not at Democracy International.
BANGSER--Hank. Dear brother-in-law and uncle. You were always there for us. We will always remember you as a caring and gentle man. Our love forever. Barbara, Ken, Gail and David

Is the Internet making teenagers do more dumb things than ever? Some child specialists worry that it is. Teenagers have always been prone to taking foolish risks (thanks partly to the brain's prefrontal cortex, which governs decision-making and is still developing in adolescence). But with the rise of sites like YouTube and Facebook, these experts say, teenagers now face virtual peer pressure to emulate all kinds of dangerous stunts and dares, and post them online.

SPOLAND, SWEDEN -- Mikael Karlsson owns a snowmobile, two hunting dogs and five guns. In his spare time, this soldier-turned-game warden shoots moose and trades potty-training tips with other fathers. Cradling 2-month-old Siri in his arms, he can't imagine not taking baby leave. ''Everyone does.'' From trendy central Stockholm to this village in the rugged forest south of the Arctic Circle, 85 percent of Swedish fathers take parental leave. Those who don't face questions from family, friends and colleagues. As other countries still tinker with maternity leave and women's rights, Sweden may be a glimpse of the future.
KATZ--Henrietta (Penny), on June 13. A treasure to friends, relatives, neighbors and her dog Lucy. She will be missed.
WEISS--Marie. Greatly loved and irreplaceable friend. Eve, Kara, Eddie, Amanda & Nina

SCHWARTZ--Jay E.,90, of New York City, on June 13. Predeceased by his wife Elaine. Survived by his sons George (Gail), and Steven, and grandson Joshua (Jana). Service: Wednesday, 10:30am, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W150 Rt. 4, Paramus, NJ.

OSTERER--Beatrice Ruth. June 30, 1920, died June 7, 2010. Beloved wife to Maurice (d.), mother to Merle Zabusky (Byron, d.), and Carole Osterer (Bob Bellman), cherished grandmother to Marcia Z. Harwitz (David), Jonathan Zabusky (Leora) and Miles and Leah Bellman, adored great-grandmother, treasured aunt and friend. Bea embraced life with purpose, verve and an abiding commitment to hard work, Jewish tradition, and love for family and friends. Donations can be made to Orchard Cove, Canton MA, or New City Hadassah.

OSH, Kyrgyzstan -- As four days of ethnic violence in southern Kyrgyzstan threatened to build into a major refugee crisis on Monday, both sides of the conflict were calling on Russia to step in, saying third-party peacekeepers were needed to defuse standoffs between Uzbeks and Kyrgyz. But an emergency meeting of the Collective Security Treaty Organization, a regional alliance dominated by Russia, ended Monday without a commitment to send in troops, though President Dmitri A. Medvedev called the situation ''intolerable'' and intimated that troops could be deployed if conditions worsened.

Adidas has heard much mockery of its latest, most troublesome child.  The Jabulani football has attracted all manner of critics, who decry its tendency to move mysteriously in midflight. Goalkeepers have complained in training that it is a difficult customer, a diva even. As far as all members of the anti-Jabulani crowd are concerned, footballs, like children, should be as unobtrusive as possible; they must be seen and not swerved.  That may be true. What's probable, though, is that the Jabulani just wants to be loved.

What makes a father? That is the question I asked in a post earlier today, and it is one that Douglas L., a management consultant in Pennsylvania, has been asking for several months now. He is a father. He became one last October when his daughter was born. The baby's mother was a woman with whom he had what he describes as a "casual" relationship.

Proposed legislation to revoke vendors' licenses of food-truck operators who rack up too many parking violations drew outcries from foodies and food-truckers alike at a City Council hearing Wednesday. There are an estimated 300 such trucks in the city -- both ice cream and hot dog purveyors and high-end vendors of waffles, schnitzel and the like. "It is clearly discriminatory that we get put out of business, while FedEx and U.P.S. pay millions in parking tickets as the cost of doing business," one vendor said. Read more on Diner's Journal.

Art Basel in Switzerland is not like Art Basel in Miami. For one thing, there are twice as many people in town for the fair (more than 60,000), and few of them are American. There is way too much art that looks like other art. And the Swiss maintain a level of decorum that would seem foreign at the beach.

If you're one of those passengers who hates waiting around until they call your seat zone number to board your flight, American Airlines has a solution for you: pay up. The carrier is offering its customers a chance to board earlier than everyone else (except priority customers) for an introductory rate of $10 each way.  The perk can be purchased alone but is also also part of a broader bundling of benefits that the carrier is calling its "Boarding and Flexibility" package. In addition to getting you on the plane a little earlier, the package offers a $75 discount off of flight changes and allows you to fly standby on an earlier flight on your day of departure at no extra charge. That package starts at an introductory rate of $9. The airline said in a release that this is the first of many customized perks that it plans to offer to travelers. Our vote for the perk we wouldn't mind paying for: flight attendants who can help land planes.

Flash floods caused by torrential rain killed 18 people and left about 10 missing near France's Mediterranean coast, Reuters reported on Wednesday, after the worst downpours the region has seen since 1827. Residents were surprised by the speed at which the waters rose, turning streets into torrents and carrying away cars as if they were toys. "It was dramatic," said Max Piselli, the mayor of Draguignan (pictured in Slide 1). "The town is in a terrible state, with rocks, stones, mud and cars blocking the roads."

The best came last. A relatively bland first week of the World Cup was salvaged on Wednesday by the last opening match, Switzerland's shocking 1-0 upset of Spain. It was the first time the Swiss had ever beaten the Spaniards (a streak covering 18 previous games over the course of 85 years); it was only the second loss in 46 games for Spain (whose previous defeat came last year, also in South Africa, to the Americans); and most important, it finally got people to stop talking about vuvuzelas.

The role of philosophers - and I take it, of The Stone - is to stimulate people to think about questions that they might not think about otherwise.  That so many people were roused to comment on my piece, "Should This Be the Last Generation?" - despite comments being closed at one point - suggests that it achieved this aim.  That said, it would have been good if some of those commenting had read the piece with a little more care, and all the way through.The comments show two common misunderstandings of what I was trying to do.  As an example of the first, Rob Cook of New York writes that "this piece frames overpopulation and environmental destruction in the wrong terms. It assumes that developed countries cannot cut down on consumption."  But "Last Generation?" isn't a piece about overpopulation or environmental destruction, and it makes no assumptions about whether developed countries can cut down on consumption.  It just isn't about that question at all.  It asks a deeper question, one not dependent on the environmental constraints on our planet, nor on the number of people now on Earth.  Even if there were only 1 million humans on this planet, all living at the level of an average citizen of, say, Switzerland, we could still ask whether it would be a good thing to have children in order to continue the species.

In my continuing quest for alternatives to wearing a necktie during the hazy days of summer, I recently rediscovered the neckerchief. I was going to a theater opening on a recent evening and just didn't feel like sporting my usual "tie slightly undone/white shirt open at the neck/sport jacket" combo. I rummaged through my bureau looking for who knows what, when I came across a stack of faded-print cotton bandannas (the nostalgic cowboy kind). Perfect! If the Parisians can pull off their origami-like mastery of the scarf, why can't I give it a try? I first folded it in half to make a triangle, then rolled it up tightly, à la Fruit Roll-Up. I wrapped it snugly around my neck and tied a small, tight knot in front, tucking the ends into my shirt. I instantly felt dressier, more suitable for the special evening I had in store. Any slight apprehension I had about winning a Charles Nelson Reilly look-alike contest was quickly assuaged when I received some very nice, unexpected compliments. Since then, I've been on the hunt for vintage bandannas so I can give my well-worn neckties a break.

What does exercisedo to your body? It may seem as if science, medicine and common sense answered that question long ago. But in fact, the precise mechanisms by which exercise alters your body - at a deep, molecular level - remain poorly understood. A number of analyses of the effect that exercise has on heart disease, for instance, have concluded that working out lessens a person's chances of developing heart problems far more than scientists can account for. They understand the physiological reasons for about 60 percent of the reduced risk. The rest is a mysterious if welcome bonus.

GRUHIN--Garson I.,89, died June 15, 2010. Beloved husband of Sylvia for 58 years, loving father of Ruth, Mark and Lee, cherished father-in law of Susan and Deirdre and devoted grandfather of Alex, Andrew, Samantha, Daniel and Jack. Born Jersey City, Garson lived most of his life in Carteret where he and his brother Max owned Gruhin's Pharmacy serving the community for 60 years. Garson graduated from Rutgers Pharmacy School at 19 and, as a Pharmacist served in WWII in the Pacific arena. He was a board member of the Congregation of Loving Justice and the JCC of Carteret. He was a kind and charitable man always reaching out to those less fortunate than he. Yiddishkite was at the center of his being. We will deeply miss his great generosity of spirit. Funeral services Thursday at 11:30 am Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Vauxhall, NJ.

Jerome Ware Jr. pressed his palm into a tray of orange paint. Then he found exactly the right spot for a handprint on the top of an upright piano he had just painted gold. ''Contrasts, that's what I'm going for,'' he said.

CLINARD--Marshall Barron, died at St. Vincent's Hospital in Santa Fe, NM on May 30, 2010, after having a heart attack at home two days before, at age 98. He was born in Boston, MA on November 12, 1911, the son of Gladys Barron and Andrew Marshall Clinard. Marshall was educated at Governor Dummer Academy, Stanford University (BA '32, MA '34), and the University of Chicago (Ph.D. '41, Sociology). Between 1941-1945 he worked as Chief Criminal Statistician for the US Census Bureau and in the enforcement department of the Office of Price Administration. He taught at the University of Iowa, Vanderbilt University, and for 34 years at the University of Wisconsin/Madison. At the University of Wisconsin he received many teaching awards and was a popular professor who attracted many students. He had 17 Ph.D. students. In 1957 he published Sociology of Deviant Behavior, a major text book now in its 14th edition and still widely used. He wrote 11 books and over 40 articles. He was widely recognized for his work on corporate crime; his book Corporate Crime was republished in 2005. He married Ruth Blackburn in 1937 and they had three children, Marsha Ruth, Lawrence Marshall, and Stephen Andrew. During his Wisconsin years he worked in Sweden for a year as a Fulbright Research Professor studying prisons; he spent three years working in India for the Ford Foundation in Urban Community Development; he taught a year at Makerere University in Uganda under a Rockefeller Foundation Grant; and he spent a year in Switzerland studying crime under a National Science Foundation Grant. He received numerous awards and was an active member of his professional organizations. He was a member of the American Sociological Society and was the President of the Society of Social Problems, among others. He served on several United Nations Congresses. He was awarded an Honorary LL.D. from the University of Lausanne, the Donald Cressey Award, the Edwin H. Sutherland Award for Distinguished Contributions to Criminology from the American Society of Criminology, and the Gilbert Geis Lifetime Achievement Award. After retiring in 1979, he and Ruth lived in Santa Fe for 10 years and then in Santa Barbara, CA. When Ruth died in 1999 Marshall returned to Santa Fe where he married and continued traveling, writing, and keeping engaged in the world. His zest for life, including a love of nature, the mountains, photography, hiking, family, and mankind contributed to his vigor right up to the moment of his death. He was a member of the Unitarian-Universalist Society. Marshall is survived by his second wife, Arlen Runzler Westbrook, whom he married January 15, 2002. She resides in Santa Fe and in Delmar, NY. He is also survived by two children, Marsha Clinard (spouse: Charlie Boast) and Stephen Clinard (spouse: Paula Giordano), by four grandchildren (Eric and Marshall Schacht and Amy and Andrew Clinard), and by five great-grandchildren (Madison, Kayley, Noelle, Wade, and Tanner). A son, Lawrence Clinard, preceded him in death. Private services are planned. The family requests no flowers. Marshall had a special interest in and supported Doctors Without Borders, Stanford University, the University of Chicago, and the University of Wisconsin/Madison. Services are under the direction of Berardinelli Family Funeral Service, 1399 Luisa Street Santa Fe, NM 87505 (505) 984-8600.

MARSILIUS--Newman M.,Jr., aged 92 years, died peacefully at home in Easton, CT. He was retired president of the PMT Group, a family-operated machine tool manufacturer in Bridgeport, CT. He received degrees from Cornell University and MIT. He was happily married to Marie Kuechle for 63 years. He served several terms in both the Connecticut House and Senate and worked tirelessly on many corporate and civic boards. He is survived by a brother, Phillip; children Newman III, Diane Nicholls, Barbara Link, and Kathy Bourque. In lieu of flowers, the family requests gifts be made to the Aspetuck Land Trust (POB 444, Westport CT 06881), Mid-Fairfield Hospice (POB 489 Wilton, CT).

An article on May 6 about people who donated hair and animal fur to be used to soak up oil from the spill in the Gulf of Mexico misstated the name of a town in Alabama where volunteers taught residents how to create booms with hair. (Officials later decided that using hair and fur was not feasible.) The town is Point Clear, not Clear Point. (A reader pointed out the error in a telephone call earlier this week.)

HARWIN--Martin, 92, of Naples, FL died June 13, 2010. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Dr. Harwin served during WWII as a medical officer in the US Navy during the invasions of Sicily, Salerno and Southern France. He was awarded the Bronze Star for his courageous efforts. Dr Harwin received his medical school degree from the Louisiana State University School of Medicine in 1942. He practiced as a pediatrician for 40 years in Westbury, NY. Martin Harwin moved to Naples 20 years ago with his wife of 61 years, Miriam, whom he lost in December, 2003. He is survived by his three sons Robert, Richard and William and their families. He is also survived by eight grandchildren and one great-grandchild. For online condolences, please visit www.fullerfuneralhome.com

LONDON -- Carl-Henric Svanberg, the chairman of BP and a former semiprofessional hockey player in Sweden, could use all the protective gear he can get when he meets President Obama on Wednesday to discuss the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Mr. Svanberg, who has been in the job since January, is unlikely to get a warm welcome in Washington, where BP is under assault over its efforts to stop the spill, clean up the oil and compensate local businesses and residents.

MUMBAI, India -- S. K. Sahai's firm ships containers 2,400 nautical miles from Singapore to a port here in four or five days. But it typically takes more than two weeks to make the next leg of the journey, 870 miles by rail to New Delhi. For most of that time the containers idle at the Jawaharlal Nehru Port near Mumbai because railway terminals, trains and tracks are severely backlogged all along the route. Counting storage and rail freight fees, Mr. Sahai estimates the cost of moving goods from Mumbai to Delhi at up to $840 per container -- or about three times as much as getting the containers to India from Singapore.

The DealBook column on Tuesday, about the loyalty of Goldman Sachs's clients, misstated, in some editions, part of the name of one client that did sever its ties with the bank. It is the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, not the Metropolitan Transit Authority.

BRITTON--John P.,beloved father, grandfather, husband, brother and distinguished scholar of Babylonian astronomy and the history of science, died of cardiac arrest on June 8th. He was 71. John was born in Hartford, CT. He attended St. Paul's School and spent ten years at Yale University where he received a B.A. and a Ph.D. in the History of Science and Medicine for his work studying ancient mathematics and astronomy. After school he moved to West Hartford, where he lived for more than 20 years with his first wife Kathryn Lines Britton, raising his family and working in a variety of roles in the investment management business. He joined Conning & Company in 1966, became partner and later left to found CF Management, an asset management firm. In his last two decades, John returned his focus to the study of ancient astronomy, and made a number of notable contributions to the field. His early study of the precision of the models in Ptolemy's Almagest was followed by numerous works that formed a comprehensive exploration of the origins of exact science. In 1995 he married Claudine Vincente Britton and in 1997 they moved to Wilson, WY. John charmed the lives of his friends and family with his mischievous, contrarian sense of humor, his deep intellect and his wide-ranging interests in politics, financial markets, science, arts, and history. He served on the Board of Trustees of the Wadsworth Atheneum and a number of corporate boards and worked with St. Paul's School to improve mathematics education. John also had a lifelong passion for the outdoors. He enjoyed rock climbing, skiing, and hiking for most of his 71 years and introduced both his sons and grandchildren to the outdoor life. He is survived by his wife, Claudine Britton of Wilson, WY; his sons John Britton of New York, NY and Sam Britton of San Francisco, CA; his brother Peter Britton of South Hamilton, MA; and four grandchildren.

9 P.M. (13) LA DANSE: LE BALLET DE L'OPÉRA DE PARIS In this ''Great Performances'' presentation, the director Frederick Wiseman observes the dancers of the Paris Opera Ballet -- among them Aurélie Dupont, Laetitia Pujol, Nicolas Le Riche, Marie-Agnès Gillot and Agnès Letestu -- as they perform seven works: ''Genus'' by Wayne McGregor, ''Paquita'' by Pierre Lacotte, Rudolf Nureyev's ''Nutcracker,'' ''Medea'' by Angelin Preljocaj, ''The House of Bernarda Alba'' by Mats Ek, Sasha Waltz's ''Romeo and Juliet'' and ''Orpheus and Eurydice'' by Pina Bausch. This documentary also offers glimpses of daily classes and rehearsals and ventures behind the scenes at the elegant Palais Garnier, with its scarlet velvet seats and Marc Chagall ceiling, to watch choreographers, ballet masters, musicians and production designers at work. ''To say that the film, sumptuous in its length and graceful in its rhythm, is a feast for ballet lovers is to state the obvious and also to sell Mr. Wiseman's achievement a bit short,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''Yes, this is one of the finest dance films ever made, but there's more to it than that.'' 8 P.M. (CBS) TV's GREATEST SURPRISES: A PALEY CENTER FOR MEDIA SPECIAL Jeff Probst counts down 30 moments that shook viewers to the core, from Bobby Ewing's shower scene in ''Dallas'' to Dr. George O'Malley's death on ''Grey's Anatomy.'' Tina Fey, Ellen DeGeneres, Howie Mandel, Whoopi Goldberg, Paul Shaffer, Regis Philbin, Patricia Heaton and David E. Kelley reveal their own favorite shocks.

MARKS--Peter, 75, died peacefully at home on June 13, 2010, of complications from cancer. A lifetime New Yorker, Peter graduated from the High School of Music & Art in 1952 and from Amherst College in 1956. After a brief stint in publishing, Peter opened the Peter Marks Works of Art, Inc. in 1960, a private gallery specializing in Southeast Asian and Islamic antiquities. He made important contributions to the Asian art field both as a dealer and as an advocate for his profession. He also wrote and published three novels. Following his retirement in 2002, Peter began painting, a passion that had lain dormant for many years. Peter is survived by his wife Jean, his daughter Annie, his son Sam and his wife Lauren Pesso, his son Ben and his wife Elizabeth Morrison and their children Sophie and Eli, and by his brother Walter Marks and his wife Joan Brooker. The funeral will be private. Contributions may be made in his memory to the Art Angels Supplies Fund of the Friends of Fiorello H. LaGuardia High School of Music and Art and Performing Arts (www.alumniandfriends.org).

WOOD--James Nowell. March 20, 1941 - June 11, 2010. The trustees and staff of the J. Paul Getty Trust express their sincere condolences to the family of James Nowell Wood on the occasion of his passing. An internationally recognized leader in the arts, Jim was appointed president and CEO of the J. Paul Getty Trust in 2006. Prior to that he served as the director and president of the Art Institute of Chicago (1980-2004), and director of the St. Louis Art Museum (1975-1980). He sat on the board of the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute, the Institute of Fine Arts at New York University, the Harvard University Art Museums, and the Museum of the Rhode Island School of Design. Jim was also president of the board of the Pulitzer Foundation for the Arts. He is survived by his wife Emese, his daughters Lenke and Rebecca, and their families. Arrangements will be private. Condolences can be sent to the President's Office of the J. Paul Getty Trust, 1200 Getty Center Drive, Los Angeles, CA 90049.

GREEN--William S.,passed away May 29, 2010, the same way he lived his life, surrounded by his loved ones. "Bill" was born in Hartford, CT, July 15, 1941, to Milton M. Green and Lillian R. Green. He loved language and the written word, graduating from Dartmouth University with a B.A. in English, and he was passionate about music. An accomplished pianist who was once invited to tour with Blood, Sweat and Tears, Bill rejoiced in the sound, the study, and the playing of cutting-edge jazz, so much so that he was once arrested at an underground Hartford jazz club that catered to mixed-race couples. He loved his job as a scientific writer and editor at the NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases, and he took great pride in it. He also loved New York City, the Mets, the latest computer technology, and humor, especially puns. He did what he loved, succeeded at it, and shared his passions with everyone around him. Most of all he loved his family. He is survived by his daughters, Betse Green and Nicole Green-Hilgen, sons-in-law Bill Cernansky and Sorin Hilgen; grandchildren Jason and Justin Ramirez, Jan and Grace Hilgen; and his closest friends, Sally Frenkel and Jack Ricci. A memorial service will be held in New York City on Friday, June 18. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the Caring Bridge (caringbridge.com) and/or the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (pancan.org). "Do good. Have fun. Make money." Bill's favorite quote.

Because of an editing error, an article on June 5 about a vessel carrying aid supplies that set out from Ireland and headed for Gaza in defiance of the Israeli blockade, days after a six-boat Gaza aid flotilla was stopped by Israeli forces in a deadly confrontation, referred incorrectly to the vessel's ownership. The vessel, the MV Rachel Corrie, is owned by the Free Gaza Movement, an activist group based in Cyprus that had helped to organize the earlier flotilla. It is not ''Irish-owned.''
MANN--William. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of William Mann, associated with The New York Times from May 1, 1964 until retiring on December 1, 1992.

We read this morning that certain states out in the middle of the country are withholding public financing for movies shot in their states that do not present the state in a favorable light. Here in New York, the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting assures us that its tax-credit program for filmmakers is ''content-neutral.'' But what if it wasn't? What if all movies shot or set in the city had to show the shiny side of the Big Apple? Turn back the clock and re-picture some of the city's iconic cinematic turns. Remember ''Midday Cowboy,'' where Joe Buck arrives penniless in Times Square on the Greyhound and within weeks has become an underwear-clad singer-songwriter sensation with his own reality show? Or ''Picnic In Needle Park,'' in which adventuresome crafters start a knitting circle near Lincoln Center? To say nothing of ''The Returning of Pelham 1-2-3 With New Brake Shoes and All the Graffiti Cleaned Off'' or ''The Godfather Part IV: Turns Out There's No Such Thing as the Mafia - Whew!''

WOOD--James Nowell. March 20, 1941 - June 11, 2010. The trustees and staff of the Art Institute of Chicago mourn the loss of James Wood, president and CEO of the J. Paul Getty Trust and former director of the Art Institute of Chicago. Everyone at the Art Institute extends their condolences to Jim's family. Jim led the Art Institute from 1980 to 2004, an era of tremendous growth. During his tenure, he oversaw two major building expansions, countless significant acquisitions, and many of the museum's best received and attended exhibitions. His legacy is present in every gallery of the museum, and he will be remembered as one of the most inspiring leaders in the 130-year history of the institution.

KABUL, Afghanistan -- A Pakistani-based militant group identified with attacks on Indian targets has expanded its operations in Afghanistan, inflicting casualties on Afghans and Indians alike, setting up training camps, and adding new volatility to relations between India and Pakistan. The group, Lashkar-e-Taiba, is believed to have planned or executed three major attacks against Indian government employees and private workers in Afghanistan in recent months, according to Afghan and international intelligence officers and diplomats here. It continues to track Indian development workers and others for possible attack, they said.

SKAARUP--Ole, of Greenwich, CT died Friday, June 11th, at home. Founder and Chairman of Skaarup Shipping Corp. He was the beloved father of Cathrine S. Parker, Christine A. Skaarup, and Stephanie L. Skaarup. Services will be private.

CANTOR--Daniel D. July 26, 1917 - June 14, 2010, passed away peacefully at his home in Tamarac, FL. He was Florida's most well-known and generous philanthropist, giving of his wealth to all who needed his help. There are numerous buildings that bear his name but he was most proud of the "Daniel D. Cantor Senior Center," which provide care to seniors and Alzheimer's patients. He was an attorney by training but spent most of his working years in the real estate business. Recognized as one of the nation's foremost authorities on mortgage financing and acquisitions, he was once called upon to negotiate the purchase of the entire DeBartolo Empire. Even in retirement he still owned numerous real estate holdings and nursing homes in New York. Cantor was honored in November, 1998, by both the United Sates Congress in conjunction with the Knesset in Israel as the founding father from Florida of the "American Promenade of States." The American Promenade was later named in his honor. He supported many charities which included The Jewish National Fund, The Reservoir Project of Israel, countless synagogues and organizations both here in the United States and Israel. The charities and individuals he helped and supported are too numerous to mention. He is survived by his wife Erhla Cantor. He was predeceased by his wife Lucille, daughter Leslie, twin sister Miriam, brothers Harry and Abe. The community and the country will never know another man like him. He will be greatly missed. Service to held Wednesday, June 16, 10am at Temple Beth Torah, 9101-15 NW, 57th St, Tamarac, FL 33351. Interment will be held in New York on Thursday, June 17, 11am at the Montefiore Cemetery, 121-83 Springfield Blvd, St. Albans, NY 11413. Donations can be made to the Daniel D. Cantor Senior Center, Sunrise, FL.

PLUM--Fred, M.D. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our colleague and friend Dr. Fred Plum, one of the preeminent neurologists of the 20th century. For 35 years, Dr. Plum served as neurologist-in-chief and chairman of the Department of Neurology and Neuroscience at Cornell University Medical College and New York Hospital -- today known as NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center. He was known nationally and internationally as a true pioneer in the study of the metabolism of the brain as it relates to traumatic head injury, stroke and coma. A renowned researcher, Dr. Plum was author and editor of more than 250 neurology publications and was founder and chief editor of the highly regarded Annals of Neurology from 197684. In collaboration with Dr. Bryan Jennett on a paper published in The Lancet in 1972, Dr. Plum originated the term "permanent vegetative state" to describe the type of unconsciousness that can follow serious brain injury or illness. Dr. Plum was a tireless advocate for the rights of terminally ill patients, promoting the use of living wills that ensured carrying out the end-of-life wishes for patients unable to communicate due to traumatic brain injury. Dr. Plum was a beloved teacher at Cornell University Medical College and trained a generation of neurologists who are today spread around the globe. A former student remarked, "Dr. Plum imparted a flash of insight to his students which represented a genius that placed him far beyond his peers. You quickly realized you were in the presence of a great mind." We offer our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Susan; his two sons Michael and Christopher; and his daughter, Carol. Antonio M. Gotto Jr., M.D. Dean Weill Cornell Medical College Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO NY-Presbyterian Hospital

BELSON--Mabel Phelan, 88, of Park Ridge, NJ on Tuesday, June 8, 2010. Beloved wife of the late John H. Belson. She is survived by John, Jane, Michael, Robert, William and James Belson. Mabel worked for the New York Times, New York City, NY from 1951 to 1987 retiring as Employee Relations Administration Director. She was a past president of the Park Ridge Golden Age Club and a past volunteer at Pascack Valley Hospital. She served as Treasurer for the Atlantic Collegiate Baseball League in the 1990's and was a member of the Bergen County Master Gardeners Association. Celebration of Life to be announced at a later date. Services by Robert Spearing Funeral Home, Inc., Park Ridge, NJ.

COCKRAM--Patricia A.,67, Jackson Heights, NY, died June 13, 2010, at Calvary Hospital. Beloved Assoc. Professor of English at Lehman College, she earned her Ph.D. at CUNY Graduate Center in 1999, and was a respected Ezra Pound scholar. Prior to entering academia, she had a distinguished career in fashion, working as an executive at Perry Ellis, Liz Claiborne, Saks, Macy's, and Barneys. Fluent in Italian and French, Pati traveled widely in Europe and was an avid lover of the arts. She is survived by her mother, Patricia Cockram, of Fayetteville, AR; siblings Kathleen, Peter, Chris, Tim, Michael, their significant others, a cousin Claire; nine nieces and nephews; a grandniece and grandnephew; and a host of other relatives, dear friends, and colleagues who cherish her memory. A memorial service will be announced. In the interim, memorial donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center's Patient Assistance Fund at: www.mskcc.org.

Mark Stewart -- guitar player, inventor of musical instruments and Paul Simon's musical director -- in the ''sonic salon'' he has created on Rivington Street on the Lower East Side. The space, he said, is in the tradition ''of the late-19th-century salons where folks would get together to make sounds, sing songs and play chamber music.'' Mr. Stewart, who is also a professor at the Manhattan School of Music and half of the duo Polygraph Lounge, said he liked ''to make instruments made from humble materials that have a very attractive sound'' and that are not intimidating to play. ''My motto,'' he said, ''is the word 'musician' is too often used to discourage people from participating in their birthright as sound makers.'' For decades, containers of milk sold in New York City have been stamped with two expiration dates: one carrying the dairy industry's recommended ''sell by'' date and an earlier one - sometimes nearly a week earlier - mandated by the city. The conflicting dates have caused much confusion - Is there something in the city's air that sours milk? Can I drink this or not? - and, milk sellers argued, resulted in the throwing away of rivers of perfectly drinkable milk.

LONDON -- As financial markets demand higher interest rates on its debt, Spain, like a number of economies in Europe, is battling to persuade skeptical investors that it can continue to service its mounting financial obligations. At a closely watched auction for 12- and 18-month bills on Tuesday, the Spanish government raised 5.2 billion, or $6.4 billion. The rate of 2.3 percent on the 12-month bills was a sharp rise of 0.7 percentage point from the rate it paid last month and a return significantly higher than in other major euro-zone economies. The result heightened longstanding fears that Spain's financing costs could soon become too high for the economy to bear.

With summer around the corner, the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene had some unpleasant news to impart Thursday: the number of city residents who caught Lyme disease jumped nearly 20 percent last year, to 643. The city's Lyme rate has been increasing steadily for years, and has nearly tripled since the dawn of the millennium. Most cases were actually contracted outside the city, in areas like the Hudson Valley, Long Island, New Jersey and Connecticut, where New Yorkers (and ticks) are known to travel. Wear insect repellent, light-colored long sleeves and socks, and check yourself and your friends after walking in the woods or tall grass. It's a jungle out there.

The Miami Art Museum has named Thomas Collins, currently the director of the Neuberger Museum of Art in Purchase, N.Y., as its new director, effective Aug. 16, the museum said on Thursday. The Miami museum has been without a permanent director since Terence Riley, the former chief curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, resigned abruptly in October after less than four years in the post. The museum is planning to break ground later this year on a new $131 million building designed by the firm Herzog & de Meuron, which is scheduled to open in 2013.

Like most English-speaking scribes, I've spent the last few weeks dipping in and out of Christopher Hitchens' memoir, "Hitch-22." Of all the reviews to date, David Runciman's essay in the London Review of Books seems to me to cut closest to the heart of Hitch. This part, in particular:

"As the euro continues to dance on the brink of calamity ... there are only two ways out of this bind: forward or back, more Europe or less ... It does not take a student of European politics to know which way Europe's political elites are likely to go. The plan being discussed is extraordinary. Like gamblers increasingly obsessed with the idea that their string of mounting losses will eventually pay off with an even bigger win, the European chiefs in Brussels are convinced that if they just double down one more time on their integration project, they will finally achieve victory ... Until a few months ago Jean-Claude Trichet was insisting, like the Duke of Wellington on the English constitution, that the euro was more or less perfect. Now, he is calling for a new 'budgetary federation' to keep the project afloat. ... In theory, the only way of ensuring stability within monetary union, as most economists will tell you, is to go for full-fledged fiscal union. In other words, to make the Greek budget a section of the budget for the whole eurozone. So Greece could nestle safely in the harbour of German taxpayers' vast funds. But in the case of the eurozone, such a fiscal union is likely to result only in deeper economic peril, social unrest and political disarray. And it would mark an almost complete repudiation of what the euro was supposed to stand for when it was hatched almost 20 years ago."

Sorry, Sting, but it sounds like Paul McCartney has just lapped you in the race to be the pop musician with the most classical bona fides. Mr. McCartney, the former Beatle and Wings man whose orchestral works include "Standing Stone" and "Ecce Cor Meum," told BBC News that he has agreed to write the music for a ballet and has already started work on the project. "I'm interested in doing things I haven't done before," Mr. McCartney said to the BBC. "That offer came up and I love writing music, the two went together and I said, 'Yeah,' so I just accept things before I even know what I'm doing." Mr. McCartney did not say who the music was being written for or when it might be performed, but he acknowledged that it was an unusual excursion, even for someone who has ridden shotgun in a yellow submarine, designed his own postage stamps and been recorded eating vegetables by both the Beach Boys and Super Furry Animals. "I don't really know that much about it yet," Mr. McCartney said. "I'm just writing music for it, but it's a switch."

Nat Hentoff hasn't retired yet and he probably never will. Mr. Hentoff, the columnist, preeminent jazz critic, prolific liner-notes writer, civil liberties activist and constitutional scholar who turned 85 last Thursday, recently published his 35th book, "At the Jazz Band Ball: Sixty Years on the Jazz Scene" (University of California Press), and has plans for several more. Having endured more masthead changes than United States presidents, Mr. Hentoff, a self-declared "Jewish atheist civil-libertarian pro-lifer," hasn't lost his sense of rage.

The controversial 38-story tower that New York University seeks to add to its University Village site in Greenwich Village would be made of concrete with floor-to-ceiling glass windows on the Bleecker Street side, according to plans made public Thursday by N.Y.U.

Wall Street strapped on its running shoes Wednesday night for the 34th annual JPMorgan Chase Corporate Challenge in New York. The two-day event, which continues on Thursday night, pits companies in a 3.5-mile dash around Central Park in order to claim bragging rights and prizes for fastest time and best company T-shirt.
Terrance Brennan's Artisanal Fromagerie, Bistro and Wine Bar is the latest restaurant to face a lawsuit over the way tips are appropriated.
Medical school rankings are part of our culture, but the criteria used to determine the “best” schools may not be serving the needs of patients.

James Chanos, the well-known short-seller, has never been timid about sharing his current stock bets. In an interview with Bloomberg Television, the hedge fund manager says that he's betting against several big oil producers.

The name Bill Blass is legendary in American fashion. The late designer was a champion of the tradition of American sportswear, creating clothes that were elegant but also extremely wearable. Jeffrey Monteiro is the latest young designer to be given a chance to interpret the house; resort marked his first collection. He kept it simple, channeling the spirit best with a sexy gray blazer dress.

Lawyers for about 10,000 ground zero rescue and cleanup workers met with their clients Wednesday evening in a town hall meeting at the Marriott Marquis hotel in Times Square to explain the terms of the new settlement of their lawsuits against New York City and its contractors.

Our sister blog The Choice is reporting that Cablevision has announced that it is offering a free SAT preparation course as an incentive for people to subscribe to its Optimum service. Cablevision has systems throughout the New York area, an epicenter of the highly selective college admissions chase. By dangling the prospect of higher test scores as a carrot for subscribers, the company has elevated SAT tutoring to a status previously occupied by such come-ons as the PBS tote bag, the Sports Illustrated fleece jacket and the Time magazine alarm clock.

Brian d'Arcy James and Anika Noni Rose will be among the stars of a reimagined -- or should we say reincarnated? -- version of "On a Clear Day You Can See Forever" that Michael Mayer will direct this summer at Powerhouse Theater, the Poughkeepsie collaboration between Vassar College and New York Stage and Film. The concert workshop of that Alan Jay Lerner/Burton Lane musical, whose cast will also include David Turner, Kerry O'Malley, Colin Hanlon and Sarah Stiles, will feature many changes from its stage and film versions. But what kind, exactly? Its director isn't ready to say yet.

Wanting a child makes no sense. It means signing up for sleepless nights, strained bank accounts and years of worry. Fortunately for the species, the wanting comes from a part of us that has nothing to do with common sense.

The Food Network is setting out to sea.  Starting in August, Celebrity Cruises and the Food Network are offering a "Food Network at Sea" trip, which will pair two of the Food Network's celebrity chefs with a seven-night Caribbean journey aboard the Celebrity Solstice.

In the latest sign of the premium that society places on an elite education, and the lengths some will go to get a leg up in securing it, Cablevision announced today that it was offering a free SAT preparation course as an incentive for people to subscribe to its Optimum service.

Short of a feel-good movie about young Scottish heroin addicts who aspire to become ballet dancers, the 2012 Summer Olympics have found a more constructive way to bring the filmmakers Danny Boyle and Stephen Daldry together. Mr. Boyle, the "Trainspotting" director (who also won an Academy Award for "Slumdog Millionaire"), and Mr. Daldry, whose films include "Billy Elliot," will be the creative heads of the London games, The Guardian reported. At an official announcement ceremony on Thursday, the 2012 Olympic Organizing Committee said that Mr. Daldry would serve as the overall creative director of ceremonies while Mr. Boyle would be the artistic director of the opening ceremony, which is scheduled for July 27. The Guardian said that the two directors would have a budget of £40 million (about $59 million) for a total of four ceremonies during the 2012 games, presumably a little more than Mr. Daldry had to play with as director of "Billy Elliot: The Musical." In addition to that hit production, Mr. Daldry is also developing a stage version of "Dumbo" for Disney Theatrical Productions, while Mr. Boyle is directing "Frankenstein" for Britain's National Theater.
AOL's $164 billion acquisition of Time Warner in 2000 is widely remembered as one of the most disastrous deals in corporate history.

Monologue | Wednesday night on "The Tonight Show With Jay Leno" on NBC: Last night, President Obama delivered a prime time address on the oil spill. He said his administration "has been on top of the situation since Day 51." I mean, "Day 1 ." I'm sorry.

Monologue | Wednesday night on "The Late Show With David Letterman" on CBS: Last night, President Barack Obama spoke from the Oval Office about his plan to clean up the oil spill. Did you folks get a chance to see it? Yeah. Well, I'm glad that problem's behind us.

Monologue | Wednesday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: Obama said we need a new energy strategy, one with more alternatives, like solar power. I agree. But let's not forget about lunar power. Remember, the moon is what gives power to werewolves.

Monologue | Wednesday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: A new poll found that Hillary Clinton is now more popular than President Obama. Hillary was like, "Look, I don't pay attention to the silly polls like that -- what were the numbers exactly?"
From Julia Werdigier, a DealBook colleague:

They say that bad news comes in threes, but it's really just a convenient trope that journalists use as a crutch to avoid writing an actual lead. Then again, it's a nice way to cluster all the bad news about one's profession so as not to dwell on it. Suffice to say that the in-box contained some signs this week that the long-running question of whether newspapers were suffering mostly from a cyclical (ads are down) or secular (ads have gone elsewhere) decline seems to have been settled. The answer is both.

The sight impressed even the most jaded of seen-it-all bloggers, from Gawker to Gothamist to Curbed to Daily Intel.

BEFORE the new vintage boutique Everybody's Going to Heaven (left) opened on the Lower East Side, the owner, Greg Armas, sat down with friends to come up what they deemed the 10 iconic pieces of the season. The list includes the usual suspects (a crisp white oxford button-down for spring) to the more esoteric (1900s French work wear). Staples like tanks, denim and hoodies are also in stock. ''The concept is to be a reliable go-to retailer for better everyday pieces at cost-effective price points,'' Mr. Armas said. The average price is $150, dipping down to $50 and up to $500. His first store, Assembly New York, is also on the Lower East Side and sells international and hard-to-find luxury labels alongside vintage. The new store's name is borrowed from a Todd Rundgren song. Everybody's Going to Heaven, 129 Rivington Street (Norfolk Street), daily noon to 9 p.m., everybodysgoingtoheaven.com.

A map on June 8 with a summary of developments about the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico erroneously included an area off Florida among those that were closed to fishing. Waters off Walton and Bay Counties reopened for fishing at 6 p.m. on June 7. (The error was repeated on maps that ran on June 9, 11, 13 and 14.)

William J. Mitchell, an architect and urban theorist who envisioned the modern city as an electronically interconnected network of systems and who, while serving as dean of the school of architecture and planning at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, enlisted top architects to carry out an ambitious expansion of the M.I.T. campus, died Friday in Boston. He was 65 and lived in Cambridge, Mass. The cause was complications of cancer, his wife, Jane Wolfson, said.

If you have ever played virtual tennis on a Nintendo Wii, you know the feeling of flailing your arms around in mid-air while trying to lob an invisible ball through space. You also most likely know that there is one important component missing from the game: the feeling of a real tennis racket. Electronic Arts hope to solve that problem, teaming with Sakar International to offer a new set of sporting equipment that will mesh with your Wii gaming console. The accessories include golf clubs, tennis rackets and baseball bats, and can be used with a standard Wii Remote control.

WHEN the designer Lisa Perry saw the Carl Fischer photograph of Andy Warhol drowning in a sea of soup, she immediately thought to herself, This would be a phenomenal dress. She modeled them after several paper dresses she owned, including a kooky one made by the Campbell Soup Company, a 1960s marketing gimmick that embodied the Pop Art motif of consumer culture. Ms. Perry's dresses, which are made of cotton twill, have the same clean shape and bold graphics ($1,295; later this summer, T-shirts, $100). Ms. Perry secured the rights to the photo, which appeared on the cover of Esquire, from Mr. Fischer himself. She also secured the rights to Nat Finkelstein's photographs of Andy Warhol and Edie Sedgwick for two other dresses. The collection will be available at the end of June and by order starting June 17 at the Lisa Perry stores at 976 Madison Avenue (at East 76th Street), (212) 334-1956; and 45 Main Street in Sag Harbor, N.Y., (631) 725-7467; and also online at lisaperrystyle.com.

I buy a lot of wood. Beautiful hardwoods, from domestic and foreign forests, that we use to make very fine furniture. But here's a weird thing: we throw a lot of it away. Not sawdust -- though we make lots of that, too -- but perfectly good chunks of cherry, walnut, mahogany, oak and maple. We toss several hundred dollars' worth in the Dumpster every week. There are many things we could be making with our scraps. The pieces range from 12 inches to 36 inches long, they are usually 4 to 14 inches wide, and 1 to 3 inches thick. Here's a few things we could easily make: cutting boards, toys, chess sets, jewelry boxes, expensive pens, chop sticks, backgammon boards, picture frames, baseball bats, forks and spoons, turned bowls, trophy bases, etc., etc. Beautiful, valuable things that people pay good money for every day. So why aren't we making any of them?

An article in some editions on Tuesday about licensed sports merchandise gave an incorrect estimate for the royalties that the 30 Major League Baseball teams shared last year for licensed goods. It was about $142.4 million, or $4.74 million a club -- not about $285 million, or $9.5 million a club. (The calculation should have been based on wholesale prices, not retail prices.)

Just how big is this oil spill, really? For BP shareholders, about $88 billion big -- and growing. That is roughly how much money investors have lost on paper as the oil giant's share price has plunged. And, in the grim calculus of the spill -- the lives and livelihoods lost, the barrels of oil spewing into the Gulf of Mexico -- the financial toll keeps mounting, too.

Because of an editing error, an article last Thursday about summer houses where alcohol is not allowed misidentified a restaurant in Montauk, N.Y., that serves ice cream. It is John's Drive-In, not John's Pancake House. And an accompanying picture caption misidentified a restaurant and an event on Fire Island, N.Y., at which people were shown dancing. It is Low Tea at the Blue Whale, not Middle Tea at the Pavilion.

The Gimlet Eye column last Thursday, about an auction at Albemarle House, the estate of Patricia Kluge in Charlottesville, Va., misstated the time sequence of the estate's construction and Ms. Kluge's divorce from her husband John Kluge in 1990. The house was built in 1985, not after the divorce.

They throw an interesting twist into the routine of the New York City day laborers, these World Cup games being played in South Africa, broadcast starting at 7:30 a.m. here. At 7:30 a.m. on a typical Wednesday, scores of Hispanic men stand along and around Roosevelt Avenue near the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, in the Jackson Heights section of Queens, waiting for contractors to drive up and hire them. At 7:30 a.m. on this Wednesday, Honduras faced Chile in the World Cup, and many of these Hispanic day labors/passionate soccer fans began the new morning dance of dashing in and out of delis and coffee shops to steal precious views of the action.

There are certain to be consequences if New York State introduces no-fault divorce, as now seems likely. The divorce rate might climb. Matrimonial battles will focus on bitter issues like support and child custody. The poor will be able to get divorced as easily as the rich. But there is something else. Those who are splitting up can just tell the truth. For decades, New York State's divorce system has been built on a foundation of winks and falsehoods. If you wanted to split quickly, you and your spouse had to give one of the limited number of allowable reasons -- including adultery, cruelty, imprisonment or abandonment -- so there was a tendency to pick one out of a hat.

In 1844, the first message delivered by Morse code declared, ''What hath God wrought.'' In 1969, ''one small step for man'' ricocheted from the moon. On Monday, in New York City, a brave new experiment began in less grandiose terms: ''Wats Shup.'' Those were the first words beamed via text message to City Councilman Fernando Cabrera's office as part of a new program called, rather thunderously, ''TEXT-UR-COUNCILMAN.''

Jonathan Wolken, a nondancer who four decades ago helped found a dance troupe, named it after a fungus and watched gleefully as that troupe -- Pilobolus Dance Theater -- became one of the most popular modern-dance companies in the world, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 60 and lived in Washington, Conn. The cause was complications of a stem cell transplant Mr. Wolken underwent in April, his wife, JoAnne Torti, said. He had been ill with myelofibrosis, a bone marrow disease, for some time.

WOOD--James Nowell. March 20, 1941 - June 11, 2010. The trustees and staff of the J. Paul Getty Trust express their sincere condolences to the family of James Nowell Wood on the occasion of his passing. An internationally recognized leader in the arts, Jim was appointed president and CEO of the J. Paul Getty Trust in 2006. Prior to that he served as the director and president of the Art Institute of Chicago (1980-2004), and director of the St. Louis Art Museum (1975-1980). He sat on the board of the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute, the Institute of Fine Arts at New York University, the Harvard University Art Museums, and the Museum of the Rhode Island School of Design. Jim was also president of the board of the Pulitzer Foundation for the Arts. He is survived by his wife Emese, his daughters Lenke and Rebecca, and their families. Arrangements will be private. Condolences can be sent to the President's Office of the J. Paul Getty Trust, 1200 Getty Center Drive, Los Angeles, CA 90049.
ROTHBERG--Claire. Nanny, we will miss you. We love you very, very much (x3). Love, your devoted grandchildren.

Recently, someone asked me why women don't support each other in business. The question threw me because it presumed a fact that seemed dubious at best -- and completely contrary to the reality I've experienced, both personally and through the stories I've written about women who own businesses. The ''cat fight'' narrative might draw viewers to reality TV shows and romantic comedies, but it's not helpful to the female business owner eager to learn from and share with her peers. Earlier this week, I visited the inaugural gathering of Sharp Skirts, an online and offline community of women who own a wide range of businesses -- or who aspire to become their own bosses. Sharp Skirts was founded by Carla Thompson, a former Silicon Valley marketing executive and Austin transplant. ''I got tired of reading articles that asked where the women entrepreneurs were,'' said Ms. Thompson. ''I was surrounded by them and knew they had an abundance of skills to share.''

An article on Tuesday about a new biography of Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson, the Chabad Lubavitch leader, omitted the last four words of the title of a book by Elliot R. Wolfson, who commented on the reaction to writings about Rabbi Schneerson. The full title of the book, which uses a slightly different transliteration of Rabbi Schneerson's given name, is ''Open Secret: Postmessianic Messianism and the Mystical Revision of Menahem Mendel Schneerson.''

Hoping to break a stubborn impasse over a major spending and tax package, Senate Democrats late Wednesday unveiled a trimmed-back measure they said was paid for except for emergency unemployment compensation and state aid money. Senator Max Baucus, the Montana Democrat and chairman of the Finance Committee, said Democrats hoped they could win approval of the new plan after a test vote earlier Wednesday on a costlier $140 billion version found Democrats 15 votes short of the 60 needed to forge ahead.

Ever since Viagra met blockbuster success in 1998, the drug industry has sought a similar pill for women. Now, a German drug giant says it has stumbled upon such a pill and is trying to persuade the Food and Drug Administration that its drug can help restore a depressed female sex drive. The effort has set off a debate over what constitutes a normal range of sexual desire among women, with critics saying the company is trying to turn a low libido into a medical pathology.

O.K., here's my deal with Twitter. Personally, I have a hard time doing anything in 140 characters or less. Maybe it's a difference of the sexes thing. Research tells us more men than women are on Twitter while the Facebook community (which offers free-flowing prose if you choose) is heavier in estrogen. No surprise there really. Men tend to be bottom-liners and women seem to enjoy talking about their experiences more. As a marketing person, I know Twitter works great as a traffic-driving tool for lots of restaurants and retail stores (online and off), including Birds Barbershop, which is one of the small businesses in Austin that clearly knows what it's doing on Twitter. Last week it was raining (a relative oddity here), and business was a little slow, so Ashley Cass, who manages Birds' social media, posted a three-hour, 25-percent rain discount at one of the Austin locations and got lots of takers immediately. Whole Foods, another Austin company, is great at engaging its customers (two million Twitter followers), listening to and answering their questions in 140 keystrokes.

You don't have to like bicycling to love Lance Armstrong, but you do have to like drama. And with one month until this year's Tour de France, you can follow Mr. Armstrong's story on your iPhone with a new, free Team RadioShack app. Let's recap: There was Mr. Armstrong's battle with cancer; his founding of one of the largest wellness organizations in the world; his seven consecutive Tour de France wins; retirement; his tabloid romances; his return to racing marked by a third-place finish in the tour despite open sparring with his teammate and the tour winner Alberto Contador. Then Mr. Armstrong formed Team RadioShack with members of his former team - but not with Mr. Contador. That's more drama than a season at the opera.

Gov. Tim Pawlenty of Minnesota has established political action committees in Iowa and New Hampshire, two states likely to play a large role in choosing the Republican nominee for president in 2012. The Iowa and New Hampshire versions of his Freedom First PAC will allow Mr. Pawlenty to more directly give financial boosts to candidates in those states. The governor has long been thought to be considering a bid for the Republican nomination in 2012, but a spokesman says the state committees were formed with an eye toward the midterm elections.

ZHONGSHAN, China -- It is labor revolt by text message and video upload, underwritten by the Chinese government. The 1,700 workers who went on strike at the Honda Lock auto parts factory here are mostly poor migrants with middle-school educations.

In my first post about Consolidated Printing, I described a family business that is long on family -- seven family members to be exact -- and short on infrastructure. My first meeting with the company's founder, Marilyn Jones, and her son-in-law, Shane, gave me a good picture of the inner workings of the company, and my observations during the meeting gave me enough insight to understand some of the problems. From running my own business and observing many others, I have learned that companies have their strengths and weaknesses and the strengths often feed the weaknesses. It is much easier to see this from the outside. People tend to do what they are good at doing and what they like doing. That does not necessarily mean they are doing what is best for the company.

IN the evolution of black barbering according to Kamal Nuru, the list of begats begins with the Fade (which some folks refer to as the Jersey). The era would have been around 1982. The Fade was a popular haircut dating to the golden age of hip-hop, one in which the sides were cropped close and the puffy hair on top was kept low, an effect achieved using clippers fitted with No. 1 and No. 2 blades.

WHEN it comes to removing back hair, ''each option has its own set of pros and cons,'' said Dr. Andrew Alexis, an assistant professor of dermatology at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. RAZORS They may be inexpensive, but in the absence of a specialty product like the Razorba, a razor requires a helper. The notion that shaving causes hair to be thicker or coarser when it returns is a myth, Dr. Alexis said, but men whose faces become irritated by shaving are apt to experience the same thing elsewhere.

MARK BRYCE, the operations manager at a semi-trailer dealership in Grand Rapids, Mich., has lost most of the hair on his head, but he is ''really good at growing it everywhere else,'' particularly on his back, said his wife, Anna, a publicist for Amway. ''My husband is blond, so he doesn't look like a big hairy ape, but he does look like a golden retriever,'' she said. For years, before the couple packed for the beach or a cruise, Ms. Bryce shaved her husband's back with a razor in the shower. Then one of her colleagues took a job with Remington, the shaver maker, and Ms. Bryce noticed on the company's Web site a new shaver with a telescoping handle for unaided trimming of back hair. She joked with her former colleague that her husband could use one.

An article on Tuesday about Tom Watson's golf game as he enters the United States Open at age 60 referred incorrectly to his performance in past tournaments. At the Skins Game in 1983 in Scottsdale, Ariz., he accused Gary Player of repositioning a rooted weed from behind his ball, not for tamping down the rough to give himself a clean lie. And the putt on No. 18 that cost him a victory at the 2009 British Open ended up short and to the right of the hole; he did not yank it, which suggests it was long and to the left.

This week, Leapfrog unveiled Leapster Explorer, a re-engineered, Flash-based edition of one of its most established educational gadgets. It will cost $70 and is aimed at ages 4 to 9. And when it arrives in stores on July 15, it will face stiff competition, far greater the original Leapster did in 2003, when the Game Boy Advance was state-of-the-art. Among the competitors these days are the Nintendo DSi XL, the Fisher-Price iXL and VTech's FLIP and MobiGo. Leapster Explorer must also face down the iPod Touch, iPhone and iPad, as well as other smartphones, each with swelling app libraries.

As if he did not already have enough on his plate coaching Argentina at the World Cup, Diego Maradona continued his running feud with his fellow South American soccer legend, Pelé, on Wednesday. ''Pelé should go back to the museum,'' Maradona told reporters at a news conference in Pretoria in response to a question about Pelé's recent criticism of Maradona's coaching.

IF your renovation budget does not permit you to send your contractor or architect to the Far East for exotic woods or stone, don't despair -- there are places closer to home that they go themselves. For homegrown exotic woods, Stephen Fanuka, a New York City contractor, recommends Timeless Timber, which sells North American wood that sank to the bottom of rivers during the logging booms over a century ago; (888) 653-5647 or timelesstimber.com.

I bought an iPad from Apple last week - Wi-Fi-only, the cheapest model, for $499. And it's awesome. This year's ''it'' gadget has many talents, and chief among them is its ability to share photos, face to face rather than online. Just like the old days when they had those photos printed on paper. The iPad's 9.7-inch LED screen displays images in gorgeous, vibrant color in your choice of horizontal or vertical orientation. As with most things ''i,'' you add photos to the iPad by synching with your iTunes library. You can do so using iPhoto 4.0.3 (or later) or Aperture 3.0.2 (or later) on a Mac; Windows fans can use Adobe Photoshop Elements 3.0 (or later).

Now that there's a Red Wing concept store in Berlin, you can buy Filson in Paris, and scarves from Brooklyn's Hill-Side have made it to Amsterdam and Trieste, it's clear that the fetishization of American "heritage" style is no longer just for American men. And few shops in Europe are more faithfully dedicated to heirloom denim and classic work wear than the new Stockholm shop Mr. Mudd and Mr. Gold. The name alone, taken from a Townes Van Zandt classic, is like Carhartts incarnate. The shop, in Södermalm, the city's answer to Brooklyn and the only party of town that could be called gritty, is outfitted almost entirely in unfinished knotty pine boards; they line the walls and form blocky benches and tables for merchandise that includes Mr. Freedom work shirts, Quoddy moccasins, Pendleton blankets and Wesco motorcycle boots. And true to the cult of craftsmanship, the narrative behind every company the store does business with is highlighted on its Web site. The expertly focused selection of brands includes plenty of international origin - canvas satchels from Brady Bags of England, founded in 1877; Grunden rain gear (Sweden, 1926); jeans by The Real McCoy's (Japan, 1990) - but the effect is nonetheless a mashup of styles that feels unmistakably American. Easy rider meets California gold miner meets New England stevedore, all crammed into your dad's tool shed, circa 1976.

Is there such a thing as a budget boutique hotel? Yes, at least in New York, where Stephen Heyman reports that such places have been cropping up over the past three years. A day after Tony Hayward, the chief executive of BP, was pummeled by members of a House committee over the company's role in the disastrous oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the chairman of the company said in an interview that Mr. Hayward would step away from daily involvement in BP's enormous response efforts in the gulf, The New York Times's Liz Robbins reports.

Even as some refugees who fled the brutal violence in Kyrgyzstan began returning home on Friday, tens of thousands remained in tent camps in neighboring Uzbekistan, Clifford J. Levy of The Times reported, and the United Nations said that one million people could be in need of food and other assistance. Although the bloodletting has ebbed, Kyrgyzstan, an obscure central Asian country that houses American and Russian military bases, remains in serious danger of fragmenting. The provisional Kyrgyz government has lost control of large areas in the southern part of the country because of its failure to quell attacks that have killed at least several hundred ethnic Uzbeks, and possibly many more. Uzbeks have set up de facto autonomous zones and are refusing to recognize the authorities in the Kyrgyz capital. The first two slides were shot for The Times by James Hill.

I am not a soccer fan, particularly. I hated playing the game as a kid, I'm easily exasperated by the ties and the low scoring and the penalty-kick finales, and I loathe what Jonathan Last calls "the ritual attack of the soccer scolds" every World Cup season. (Also, I had college roommates - and dear friends - who insisted on referring to the game as "football," even though they were Americans going to college in America, for crying out loud.) But today's United States-Slovenia match was a beautiful, remarkable, riveting thing to watch - and a game seemingly perfectly engineered, in its stakes and scoring and sudden reversals, to hoist me on my own soccer-hating petard.
