"In some ways, the Napoleonic Wars seem very alien to us. Americans are, mostly, used to short and simple wars. Our three greatest military conflicts - the Civil War, World War One and World War Two - were relatively short. After some initial setbacks, victory came relatively swiftly; we never suffered the shattering setbacks that drove the British out of Europe during the Napoleonic wars as coalition after coalition went down to defeat .... The Cold War was the longest and most complex international contest in which the United States has ever engaged as a leading protagonist, and that conflict was less intense and less complicated than the Anglo-French conflict of 1792-1815 ... But ever since the end of the Cold War, the world has been trending back toward the kind of kaleidoscopic politics of 18th and 19th century Europe and away from the more stable configurations of the late twentieth century. With no single great power threat to the world order currently on stage and a variety of issues agitating international politics, many countries are exploring new options and testing new partners. While the world hopefully is not on the road to another global conflict on a Napoleonic scale anytime soon, Americans need to prepare for an era of changing coalitions and individualistic and prickly great and middle powers seeking to elbow their way onto center stage."

One reason the public, and politicians, have been so focused on the unchecked environmental disaster unfolding in the Gulf of Mexico is the vivid nature of the assault from gushing oil. We have a much harder time with less visible, and more incremental, environmental disruptions. The carbon dioxide being added to the atmosphere at a rate of about 1,000 tons a second is invisible and will have impacts that are spread in time and space and often are a matter of shifted odds of adverse events, not direct harm. The same is true for changes in the oceans driven by human activity, including the CO2 buildup.

In addition to the legacy that is Michael Jackson's discography, the King of Pop also left behind a trove of collectibles - from his bedazzled gloves and rhinestone-covered military garb to the countless tacky tchotchkes that filled his Neverland compound. Though many of the clothes and objects have been sold at auction, the museum-worthy collection has been preserved by the Swiss-born photographer Henry Leutwyler in a new book, "Neverland Lost: A Portrait of Michael Jackson" (Steidl 2010; $45). Mr. Leutwyler photographed the items prior to Mr. Jackson's death in 2009, forgoing visual trickery and relying instead on a plain black background. Many of the images point to the otherwordly realm the star inhabited; others, such as an ordinary tube sock studded with rhinestones, bring him heartbreakingly down to earth.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

Having spent the better part of four years fighting for his right to travel to Britain, the hip-hop star Snoop Dogg now finds himself a rapper non grata in the Netherlands, where the authorities had him scratched from the lineup of a free concert planned for later this month, BBC News reported. Snoop Dogg was scheduled to perform at the Parkpop festival in The Hague on June 27, but the mayor and law enforcement officials there asked its organizers to find another artist to replace him to ensure the "open and friendly character" of the festival. Snoop Dogg is scheduled to perform at the Glastonbury and Wireless festivals in Britain this summer, after a ruling in March by a tribunal there that said the rapper should not have been denied a visa for entry in 2007 after a 2006 public disorder at Heathrow Airport involving members of his entourage resulted in Snoop Dogg's arrest.

In its second surprise executive shake-up in just over three months, the music company EMI announced on Friday that Roger Faxon, the head of its publishing division, would also oversee the company's recorded music.

Students in New York City will retain the discounted fares they pay to ride buses and subways, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said on Friday, ending a long political fight that had infuriated parents and public officials.
Fred Plotkin, author of "Italy for the Gourmet Traveler" is taking reader questions. Submit your question on how to eat in Italy in the comments below. He'll respond next week.

Lukoil, Russia's second-largest oil producer, said Friday that it was not interested in acquiring anything from the $10 billion asset sale with which BP hopes to help pay for its oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

"Justice League: Cry for Justice" lands at No. 6 on the hardcover list. The series follows a faction of angry heroes who have seen their comrades murdered (though it turned out Batman was merely lost in time and Martian Manhunter got better) and want to hunt down villains before they cause further calamities. Despite some often-beautiful artwork by Mauro Cascioli, the series, written by James Robinson, was almost universally derided.
Portland strives to cut driving and oil use by creating "20-minute neighborhoods."

Senate Democrats trying to pass a bill that extends many popular but expired tax breaks have softened two tax increases that had aroused concerns among some small-business supporters. But that was not enough to save the revised measure from a threatened Republican filibuster on Thursday night.
EMI, the music company owned by the private equity firm Terra Firma, said Friday that it would shake up its management, days after it staved off default on a $5 billion loan from Citigroup.

Can someone infected with herpes continue to have sex without giving it to their partner? Do cold sores, which are almost always caused by herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1), protect against genital herpes caused by herpes simplex virus type 2? Can someone be infected with both types of herpes viruses?
A second-half rally from a two-goal deficit gave the United States a nerve-racking 2-2 draw with Slovenia in their key Group C match Friday at Ellis Park in Johannesburg.

In a scene that plays out across many a high school gymnasium this time of year, a newly crowned prom king and queen self-consciously took to the dance floor in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, on Thursday night to dance awkwardly. Except this pair, who swayed to the plaintive chords of "I'll Make Love to You" by Boyz II Men, were well past prom age (the king by around a decade, his queen by two decades), and the setting was a bar, not a gym decked out in crepe paper.

José Saramago, the Portuguese writer who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1998 for novels that combine surrealist experimentation and a kind of sardonic peasant pragmatism, died at his home in Lanzarote in the Canary Islands, his publisher said on Friday. He was 87.
What we're reading this morning:

Upon hearing that David Mamet would be sitting down with Stephen Colbert on Thursday night we immediately thought of a line delivered by Kevin Spacey to Jack Lemmon in the film version of "Glengarry Glen Ross": "You've got a big mouth. Now I'm going to show you an even bigger one."
With a G-20 summit meeting right around the corner, President Obama has told other world leaders that a lack of cooperation could be threatening economic recovery worldwide.

It's the first time since 1986 that Germany has lost a match in the Group stage of the World Cup. Wow. And it goes to show you why we shouldn't get overly excited about the first games of the Group stage. Germany's 4-0 trouncing of Australia, Serbia's 1-0 loss to unheralded Ghana -- both mean little now. These two, expected to be leaders of the group, now each have 3 points.

Over the next 10 years, the new health care law will close the dreaded "doughnut hole" that about eight  million participants in Medicare Part D, the prescription drug program, fall into each year. Currently, the gap opens when a Medicare recipient and his plan have spent $2,830 on prescriptions; at that point, he must pay for medications himself until he's paid $4,500 out of pocket. Then Medicare coverage resumes.

Our Student Challenge will continue all summer long, and we'll regularly choose a "favorite" student comment to feature.

In our recent exchange about a soda tax, Greg Mankiw raised an important question: Do the estimates of the medical costs of obesity take into account the fact that obese people don't live as long on average?

Most operating systems include keyboard shortcuts that let you press a couple of keys instead of hunting around in menus to do common tasks. If you're new to Windows 7, Microsoft has a long list of shortcuts that help save time in the Taskbar area, in Windows Explorer and even in built-in Windows programs like Paint, Calculator and WordPad.

The New York Times has a slide show of the BP chief reciting his rather limited script between red-faced lawmakers and tar-smeared protesters. Good fun, of course, but neither Mr. Hayward's mealy-mouthed responses nor the Congressional bluster he faced have stopped the spill from moving further down the gulf coast, confirming with each landfall the oil company's inability to control a disaster it triggered.

A well-worn management mantra observes, "If you can't measure it, you can't manage it." A United Nations research effort known as The Economics of Ecosystems and Biodiversity, or TEEB, suggests that this maxim can also be applied to the earth's ecosystems -- habitats like forests, oceans and tropical mangroves.
People in Fremont, Neb., prepare to vote on an illegal immigration ordinance meant to drive undocumented workers from town.
Motorola is restructuring.

First there was General Motors, whose chief executive was summarily dismissed by the White House shortly before the government became the company's majority shareholder. Chrysler was forced into a merger. At the banks that received government bailouts, executive pay was curbed; at insurance companies seeking to jack up premiums, scathing criticism led to rollbacks, David E. Sanger writes in The New York Times.
An N.F.L. proposal to expand the season to 18 games generated discussion among readers.
Michael Scott Moore's book "Sweetness and Blood: How Surfing Spread From Hawaii and California to the Rest of the World, With Some Unexpected Results" is reviewed in this Sunday's Book Review.

California Public Employees' Retirement System is building up a reserve of executives who it can then nominate for board seats in underperforming companies in which the pension fund holds shares, The Wall Street Journal reported.

Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said Friday that it had agreed to buy the Intelligence job placement services unit of Usen, a Japanese media company, for 32.5 billion yen, or about $359 million, in the private equity firm's first major deal in Japan.
Jenson Button, in a Q&A posted on his official Web site, brought up the topic of how happy he is that he made the move from Brawn to McLaren Mercedes this year.

Twitter is a hit in Japan, succeeding where other social networking imports like Facebook have foundered as millions ''mumble'' -- the translation of tweet -- and give mini-blogging a distinctly Japanese flavor, The Associated Press reports.
Banco Santander confirmed Friday that it had made an offer for 300 Royal Bank of Scotland branches through its Santander British arm.

The Peeping Tom is no new concept, but an exhibition at the Tate Modern shows that if the camera didn't invent voyeurism, it certainly brought it to the fore. "Exposed: Voyeurism, Surveillance and the Camera," which runs at the Modern (tate.org.uk/modern) through Oct. 3, is full of covert glances and stolen intimacies. The 250 photographs on display are organized thematically rather than chronologically, beginning with the concept of the unseen photographer.

Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health-care field.The recently passed health care overhaul will affect many facets of our health system. But its truly revolutionary impact is confined to that segment of the private health-insurance market that serves individuals and employers with fewer than 100 employees, the small-group market.

Hedge fund managers left their annual get-together on Thursday with much to worry about, as volatile markets, looming regulation and tax changes block the industry's recovery from the global economic crisis, Reuters reported.

Dubai World's attempt to sell its Inchcape Shipping Services unit has run into trouble as potential buyers have reacted warily to reports of an investigation into the port and shipping agent by the United States. Department of Justice, The Financial Times reported.

A growing group of private equity firms are priming lukewarm investors to expect requests for new funds later this year, having run out of money -- and time -- to invest in new deals, Reuters reported.

Standard Chartered and Agricultural Bank of China said Thursday that they had signed a memo of understanding to establish a strategic partnership, a month before the Chinese lender's anticipated initial public offering.

Some educators and psychologists believe that having a best friend may actually not be wholly positive for kids. Do you have one best friend, or do you have a group of close friends? What do you observe about the "BFFs" you know?

Citigroup plans to raise more than $3 billion for its private-equity and hedge funds, even as United States lawmakers consider banning banks from owning and investing in so-called alternative funds, Bloomberg News said, citing people with direct knowledge of the plan.

Two initial public offerings rose in their Thursday debuts as the broader U.S. market fell, Reuters reported. A third offering was cut and delayed, a sign that the market for new issues is still uncertain.

Today's idea: Reality is already outpacing "Minority Report," the 2002 film that imagined technology in far-off 2054, an article says. Pre-crime systems, 3D video and gesture-based computing are already here, with e-paper and computer-guided cars not far behind.

A sweeping overhaul of financial regulations will include a controversial plan to insulate banks from risky swap dealing, aides said on Thursday as lawmakers hammered out a final bill, Reuters reported.
United Airlines and Continental Airlines need to merge to be profitable in competing with low-cost and foreign carriers, executives of the two U.S. major airlines said on Thursday, Reuters reported.

Man Group's $1.6 billion takeover of GLG is likely to signal the start of a wave of mergers in a fragmented hedge fund industry still struggling to rebuild asset levels after the crisis, executives told Reuters.

Facebook's financial performance is stronger than previously believed, as the Internet social network's explosive growth in users and advertisers boosted 2009 revenue to as much as $800 million, Reuters reported, citing two sources familiar with the situation.

Europe's fiscal problems are a risk that will have some effect on American growth during the rest of this year and 2011, the vice chairman of Federal Reserve, Donald Kohn, said in an interview with The Wall Street Journal, Reuters reported.

It's really amazing to see how quickly the notion that contractionary fiscal policy is actually expansionary is spreading. As I noted yesterday, the Panglossian view has now become official doctrine at the ECB.

The White House intervened to weaken a provision in the final financial regulation bill that aims to give shareholders more say on how companies are governed, Reuters reported, citing three people familiar with matter.

Christopher Bailey's accolades at Burberry are enough to make him blush - in five shades, to be precise. The designer's latest project, Burberry Beauty, is a comprehensive collection of foundations, powders, bronzers, lipsticks and eye shadows that were inspired by the label's classic trench coat and by the moody hues of the British climate. Two years in the making, the line pays homage to Mr. Bailey's vision of a modern English rose. "The Burberry girl wears just a trace of makeup - no crazy eyes or crazy lips," he says. "Makeup should enhance women, not just cover up what they perceive as flaws." Of the sexy reflective checked packaging, he adds, "The idea was for the products to look and feel like things you really want to have in your bag." The range will be available on Nordstrom.com starting Monday and on Burberry.com starting Friday.

Silverlake Partners, a Silicon Valley-based private equity and buyout firm, says that it's bought Intel's data center in Santa Clara, Calif., and has made it a part of Vantage Data Centers, a new company spearheaded by Jim Trout. Trout is a veteran of both the telecom and data center business, having founded CRG West, a telecom infrastructure company and TeraSpace Networks, a data center development company.

Debt-ridden companies are wooing bond investors with an appetite for risk in a frantic dash for cash, as the renewal of hundreds of billions of euros of bank borrowing looms in the coming few years, Reuters reported.

American citizens and residents with UBS accounts are racing the clock to disclose their secret holdings to the Internal Revenue Service after the Swiss Parliament ratified an agreement to surrender the names of 4,450 bank clients, tax lawyers told Bloomberg News.

An article on Thursday about BP shareholders' losses after the gulf oil spill misstated part of the name of the firm of Fadel Gheit, who commented on the stock's prospects. He is a managing director at Oppenheimer & Company, not Oppenheimer Funds.

NEWARK (AP) -- The fourth time apparently was the charm for John MacLean. A perennial candidate to lead the team he played for and coached as an assistant, MacLean was named the coach of the Devils on Thursday, replacing the retired Jacques Lemaire.

The State of the Art column on Thursday, about the Sprint Evo 4G phone, erroneously included one city on a list of major cities where the writer found no fourth-generation cellular Internet towers while traveling. While 4G is not available in New York, Boston and San Francisco, it is indeed available in Chicago.

When Ubaldo Jimenez allowed three earned runs in a rain-shortened, six-inning victory against the Blue Jays last Friday, it was by far his worst outing of the season. Once upon a time, a pitcher would have considered himself fortunate to escape Coors Field with a performance like that, but for Jimenez, the Rockies' 26-year-old ace, it was a blemish that raised his earned run average above 1.00 for the first time in nearly two months. Even in what's shaping up to be the year of the pitcher, Jimenez is standing out. In addition to the no-hitter he tossed on April 17, he leads the majors in wins (he now has 13 after his victory over the Twins on Thursday afternoon) and his 1.15 E.R.A., if it continues, would be the lowest since Bob Gibson posted a 1.12 mark during the notoriously offense-starved 1968 season.

An article on Wednesday about error messages on Apple and AT&T Web sites that prevented many customers from preordering the iPhone 4 misspelled the surname of an AT&T spokesman. He is Mark Siegel, not Siegal.

8 P.M. (ABC) MILEY CYRUS IN LONDON: LIVE AT THE O2 My, how she's grown. Following on the heels of the furor caused by her music video ''Can't Be Tamed'' -- Fetish gear! Suggestive dance moves! Hints of Lady Gaga! -- this network television special, Ms. Cyrus's first, is said to reveal what ABC called in a news release ''her natural progression and sophistication.'' Filmed during her recent Wonder World tour, the 17-year-old Ms. Cyrus, above, performs ''7 Things,'' ''Party in the U.S.A.'' and ''The Climb'' and promotes her new, more adult CD, ''Can't Be Tamed,'' which will be released on Tuesday. She will talk about the performance on ''Good Morning America,'' at 7 a.m., and ''Live With Regis and Kelly,'' at 9 a.m. 6 A.M. An article on Thursday about drug industry efforts to develop treatments for depressed sex drives in women referred incorrectly to the status of a testosterone spray tested by Vivus, a drug development company. The company has transferred rights to that spray back to Acrux, an Australian company; Vivus is not still testing it.

LATE one summer night 40 years ago this month, Yosef Mendelevich, a young Soviet Jew, camped with a group of friends outside the Smolny airport near Leningrad. The next morning, they planned to commandeer a 12-seat airplane, fly it to Sweden and, once there, declare their purpose: to move to Israel, a dream they had long been denied. Most in the group were pessimistic about their chances -- but none more than Mr. Mendelevich. He felt sure they would get caught, but to his mind, a group suicide was preferable to a life of waiting for an exit visa that would never arrive. Even a botched attempt, he figured, would at least attract the eyes of the world.

An article in the Personal Tech pages on Thursday about software that can help recover stolen laptops and other electronic devices misstated the number of laptops lost each week in American airports, according to a Ponemon Institute study. It is 12,000 -- not 17,000.

THE HAGUE -- Since the days after World War II when people accused as Nazi criminals awaited their fates in the grimness of Nuremberg Prison, reformers have dramatically reshaped the standards under which suspects accused of the vilest war crimes are being held. Beyond the brick towers of a Dutch prison just east of here is a compound where former Congolese warlords, Serbian militia leaders and a former Liberian president accused of instigating murder, rape and enslavement are confined in two detention centers with private cells stocked like college dormitories, with wooden bookcases, television sets and personal computers. Among the other amenities are a gym, a trainer, a spiritual room and a common kitchen where some former enemies trade recipes and dine on cevapi, or Balkan meatballs.

FANNING--David J.,died unexpectedly on June 14, 2010 on Bainbridge Island, Washington. The CEO of Theraclone Sciences, he is survived by his beloved wife Katie and adored daughter Caroline, his parents Joseph and Constance Fanning, a brother John and two sisters Fiona and Deirdre Fanning Quesada, as well as three nephews and a niece. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation, to support David's passion for finding a cure for Type I diabetes. A memorial service will be held in Boston at a time yet to be determined.

Robert Gesink of the Netherlands won the grueling sixth stage of the Tour of Switzerland and claimed the race leader's jersey, while Lance Armstrong showed he was returning to top form by finishing fifth.

Midtown is a grid and it's easy to figure out where you are, but Wall Street's a different story, and so is the West Village. It helps to have a sense of direction in the city. But are we born with that sense, or do enough visits to the corner of Stone and Broad Streets teach us? Now, some researchers in Norway have come across evidence that yes, indeed, humans do have an innate sense of direction. Of course, they were dealing with rats, but what goes for rats goes for humans. (Or so the Norwegians tell us.)

A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about the refugee crisis building on the Kyrgyzstan border with Uzbekistan, using information from The Associated Press, misidentified the nationality of the soldier shown directing members of Kyrgyzstan's Uzbek minority as they were fleeing into Uzbekistan after days of ethnic violence. The soldier is from Uzbekistan, not Kyrgyzstan.

An article on Monday about the Somali government's use of child soldiers referred incompletely to the American position on the Convention on the Rights of the Child and its provisions against the recruitment and use of child soldiers. While the United States and Somalia are the only countries not to have ratified the convention, the United States did ratify a later agreement, known as an optional protocol to the convention, aimed at preventing the recruitment and use of child soldiers.

This week brings questions about birthday dinners, a particular slice of Midtown and, as always, the perils of dining with vegetarians. I endeavored to answer as best I could. Send your food queries to dinejournal @nytimes.com.

Because of an editing error, an article on June 8 about the convictions of eight former executives of a Union Carbide subsidiary in the 1984 chemical leak that killed thousands of people in Bhopal, India, misidentified, in some editions, the source of pressure for a cleanup of the accident site by the Dow Chemical Company, which bought Union Carbide in 2001. Environmental activists -- not the Indian government -- are continuing to press for the cleanup of 425 tons of hazardous waste.

Mexico's 2-0 victory against France on Thursday went over extremely well at Foley's, an Irish pub on West 33rd Street in Manhattan. Foley's advertised an ''Anyone but France'' policy that included free shots of whiskey when the first goal of the tournament was scored against France. The policy was a response to the play by France's Thierry Henry against Ireland last November, when Henry admitted he used a hand to control the ball before the goal that sent France to the World Cup at the expense of Ireland.

SUMMER SOLSTICE CELEBRATION June 22, 1633, did not go well for Galileo Galilei. On that day, the summer solstice, the Inquisition forced him to renounce his theories of a Sun-centered planetary system.

An obituary on Wednesday about Ernest Fleischmann, who ran the Los Angeles Philharmonic from 1969 to 1998, misstated the given name of one of the conductors he hired. He was Carlo Maria Giulini, not Carl.

His wife, Jessica, has arranged for Seinfeld to take part in a broadcast of a Mets game, his longtime dream. On Wednesday, when the Mets play the Detroit Tigers at Citi Field, Seinfeld will spend at least three innings in the SNY broadcast booth with Gary Cohen and Keith Hernandez.

WOOD--James Nowell. March 20, 1941 - June 11, 2010. The trustees and staff of the J. Paul Getty Trust express their sincere condolences to the family of James Nowell Wood on the occasion of his passing. An internationally recognized leader in the arts, Jim was appointed president and CEO of the J. Paul Getty Trust in 2006. Prior to that he served as the director and president of the Art Institute of Chicago (1980-2004), and director of the St. Louis Art Museum (1975-1980). He sat on the board of the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute, the Institute of Fine Arts at New York University, the Harvard University Art Museums, and the Museum of the Rhode Island School of Design. Jim was also president of the board of the Pulitzer Foundation for the Arts. He is survived by his wife Emese, his daughters Lenke and Rebecca, and their families. Arrangements will be private. Condolences can be sent to the President's Office of the J. Paul Getty Trust, 1200 Getty Center Drive, Los Angeles, CA 90049.

An article on Wednesday about India's overcrowded railways misstated the country's freight tariffs. In 2005, the most recent data available, India charged 6.446 cents to move a ton of freight one kilometer -- not $395. (The error stemmed from a misreading of a chart that indexed freight charges, benchmarking fees in the United States at 100. The chart, which used World Bank figures from 2005 adjusted for purchasing power parity, listed India's charges as 395, or, as the article correctly said, nearly four times what American companies charge.)

The air over Sheepshead Bay in Brooklyn was so thick with fog on Wednesday evening that Capt. Bill Reddan steered his boat, the Jeanne II, by GPS, staring more intently at computer screens than at the monotonic mist that was starboard, port and everywhere between. Yet Captain Reddan, 70, a retired New York City police diver who now runs a commercial diving business, still set out with his cargo of 6 crew members and 10 passengers at 7:30 p.m. There would be no fog where this group was heading: the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean at a spot 45 minutes off Brooklyn. There, chunks of rebar and slabs of steel from a bridge demolished in the 1970s and disposed of at sea still lie.

BERGER--Gerry. Daughter of the late Max and Ida Friedlander. Beloved mother of David and Meryl Levin, mother-in-law of Alison Grant, grandmother of Gabriel Levin, and aunt of Matthew Friedlander and Robert Riveles, died surrounded by her family in Maplewood, NJ on June 16th. She was 82.

Whether to start the gaffe-prone goalkeeper Robert Green is only one of the questions facing Manager Fabio Capello ahead of England's match against Algeria in Cape Town on Friday. In his final day of preparations, Capello faced a storm of criticism at home, questions over an injury-depleted defense and even some crafty psychological warfare from the Algerians. Such is the nature of the England job, where a coach's reputation can go from genius to bumbler with a single result.

ROBINSON--Herbert, Esq. The Board of Directors, Medical Advisory Board and staff of The Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration mourn the loss of Herbert Robinson, who actively contributed to the organization as a dedicated member of its Board since 1982. His generous support and wise counsel throughout the years brought a constant quality of leadership that allowed The Eye-Bank to successfully advance its mission of restoring sight through cornea transplantation and medical research. Herb's boundless enthusiasm, philanthropic spirit and devotion to helping those in need in his beloved New York City community will be greatly missed. The Eye-Bank For Sight Restoration, Inc.

ROSSMOORE--William, a civil rights lawyer, passed away at his home in Provincetown on June 13, 2010. He leaves behind his wife of 35 years, Rhoda (Perlstein) Rossmoore. Mr. Rossmoore was a pilot with the Army Air Corps during World War II, and was awarded for his heroics in landing his airplane under fire in Italy. Mr. Rossmoore was an appellate lawyer for some of the prominent civil rights cases of the 1960's and 1970's, including the defense of the "Chicago Seven". He stood up to the McCarthy Committee in the 1950's, by refusing to plead the Fifth Amendment. He represented one of the Indians at Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in 1975 which resulted in a Justice Department investigation after his group of lawyers was ambushed. Mr. Rossmoore was formerly married to Anne Tracy and to Barbara (Gotleib) Rushmore. In addition to his Wife, Rhoda, Mr. Rossmoore is survived by his brother, Howard, and sister, Helen Moore, along with three daughters, Susan Stone, Laura Yingling, Katherine Rossmoore Shields, and his stepchildren Neal and Amy Germain and his grandchildren, Elise Boyce, Erik Yingling, Raphael Richter, Daniel Germain, Jacqui Stavis, Justin and Tyler Shields and Nikki, Alexis and Schuyler Germain. He was predeceased by his daughter Emily Rossmoore, and two stepsons, Andrew and David Germain.

SUNDAY'S PUZZLE - "Publishing Trade" is a clever title for today's theme, one involving book titles whose letters have traded places. Well, some of the letters. I'm not going to spill the beans as to the specifics, but I will say that Tarzan of the Apse* would be right at home in this grid.

Earlier this month, a front-page article in The New York Times looked at the Dartmouth Atlas of Health Care, a compendium of research on Medicare spending that has often been cited by the Obama administration in the debate over health care legislation. The article challenged a common interpretation of the atlas's findings: that the hospitals and geographic regions with the highest medical spending are often the ones delivering the worst medical care.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. - Thongchai Jaidee's hole in one Saturday at the 181-yard, par-3 fifth hole was the seventh hole in one in United States Opens held at the Pebble Beach Golf Links. According to the United States Golf Association, Jaidee's ace is the 41st hole in one in United States Open history, although the association referred to the feat as the 41st "known" hole in one at the national golf tournament. It is also the first hole in one at the event since 2006 when Peter Hedblom had one in the third round at the 238-yard third hole at the Winged Foot Golf Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

WIMBLEDON, England - The queen of England is scheduled to attend Wimbledon next Thursday for the first time since 1977. That put Andy Murray, Britain's greatest hope, in the line of journalistic fire Saturday.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. -- Ty Tryon was talking about his up-and-down third round at the United States Open on Saturday when Johnny Miller, whose two major championships included the 1973 United States Open, approached with an outstretched hand.

WIMBLEDON, England - Not sadder but a bit wiser, a struggling Maria Sharapova has returned Wimbledon, where she recorded a breakthrough victory in 2004 that launched a highly lucrative dual career of tennis and business endorsements.

Pregnant or sick and without health coverage? Well, you can always hold a fundraiser and get the strippers to work for no charge. Once again "Friday Night Lights" poignantly got at the hardships experienced by the more troubled sector of the two Americas. Mindy's early contractions signaled complications with her pregnancy and Billy does not have any insurance. To even keep her safely in the hospital for a night -- she's got to go on bed rest -- is going to be a huge struggle for him financially. But Mindy's stripper friends rally together to offer their services for free to raise money for her treatment. It is moments like these that give "Friday Night Lights'' the tempered levity that keeps it from being relentlessly melodramatic. Terrible things keep happening to people, but there are always displays of resilience and wherewithal.

WIMBLEDON, England - At his Saturday news conference, Andy Roddick presented his list of Wimbledon favorites: Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal and Andy Murray. Roddick did not name himself until prompted, despite his five-set loss to Federer in the final here last year.

For decades, the debate about balancing work and family has been framed as a woman's issue, focused on the struggle of women to balance career and family life. But now several studies show that fathers are struggling just as much -- or sometimes even more -- than mothers in balancing work and home responsibilities, an issue I explore in the Week in Review section.

SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE - The acrostics regularly include clues and answers that relate to their quotes. That's nice for two reasons. The first is artistic; it strengthens the theme of the puzzle. The second is helpful; it can provide a hint as to the author, the title or words in the quote.The Details:
Monologue | Friday night on "The Tonight Show With Jay Leno" on NBC: Let's see what's going on with B.P. C.E.O. Tony Hayward, otherwise known as "the lying king."

Monologue | Friday night on "The Late Show With David Letterman" on CBS: There are rumors now that the C.E.O. of British Petroleum is saying they could go out of business. And I thought, well, yeah, great. But if they go out of business, who will be in charge of not stopping the leak?

Monologue | Friday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: Did you know that NASA says there's 100 times more water on the moon than they first thought? In fact, there is so much water on the moon that B.P. is planning to go up there and ruin it.

Monologue | Friday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: Tonight, I'm not going to do any jokes about oil spill related news. I thought it might be nice to just pretend for a few minutes that the oil spill isn't happening. You know, kind of like B.P. does.

Monologue | Friday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: Sarah Palin was on the Fox Business Network and surprised a lot of people by calling marijuana quote, "a minimal problem in America." She said law enforcement has more important priorities than arresting people smoking pot in their homes and also admitted that she herself has tried pot, which could explain some of the things that she's said over the years. It's not Sarah, it's old baked Alaska talking.

Al Kaline, a Hall of Fame outfielder for the Detroit Tigers, retired in 1974 with a career batting average of .297, 3,007 hits, 399 home runs and 1,583 runs batted in. Kaline, 75, now a special assistant to the Tigers' president, Dave Dombrowski, was in Manhattan in May. He accepted the Vin Scully Lifetime Achievement Award in Sports Broadcasting on behalf of Ernie Harwell, the longtime Tigers broadcaster who died just before the presentation. The award is sponsored by WFUV, Fordham University's radio station.

Infielder Alex Cora pointed out that the Mets were losing a lot of road games in their last at-bat, meaning they were in games until the end. Manager Jerry Manuel saw a lot of hits and figured the Mets would start making them timely.

An article last Saturday about new books on Commentary magazine misspelled the given name of Commentary's founder. He was Elliot Cohen, not Eliot. The article, using information from the book ''Running Commentary: The Contentious Magazine That Transformed the Jewish Left Into the Neoconservative Right'' by Benjamin Balint, also erroneously attributed a distinction to the magazine. Chicago Review published a short story by Philip Roth in 1954, and Et Cetera, a literary journal at Bucknell University that Mr. Roth founded, also published some in the early 1950s; the story Commentary published in 1957 was not the first Mr. Roth had published.

In response to Wednesday's Bucks post, ''On Lying About Your Salary in Job Interviews,'' about whether it's ethical to inflate your current salary during a job interview, many readers recommended refusing to disclose your salary in the first place. After all, by disclosing your salary, you may be hurting your chances for a big pay increase. ''You don't have to reveal your salary information,'' said Ramit Sethi, author of ''I Will Teach You to Be Rich'' and the popular blog of the same name. ''You're under no obligation to reveal it at all.''

10:23 p.m. | Update An article in the Journal du Mali from two days before the match profiles Coulibaly and offers a brighter view of his performance in the African Nations Cup final last January than those of other observers: ''When Koman called his family to inquire about the news, his wife informed him that the house was swamped by neighbors who came out to show their joy and pride after the excellent performance of their compatriot in the final of the CAN.'' Koman Coulibaly, the Malian referee whose calls are dominating discussion of Friday's 2-2 draw between the United States and Slovenia, is no stranger to big-game controversy. But never has he had so large an audience for the controversial calls he has come to be known for.

WHITEHILL--Ronald M.,passed away peacefully in his sleep of cancer, on Wednesday, June 9, 2010 at his home in Darien, CT. Born in White Plains, NY, he was the son of the late Max and Emilie (Pasch) Whitehill of West Hartford, CT. Ron was 72. Until his retirement, Ron was President of the Money Fund Division of AllianceBernstein in New York City. He was a graduate of Brown University and attended Cornell Law School. While in school Ron was three times Concert Master of the Connecticut All-State Orchestra in Hartford. In retirement, he returned to the Violin, playing chamber music with friends on his beloved Cremona instrument. His estate will be endowing a Scholarship for Strings at Brown University. Ron was a long-standing member of the New York Athletic Club, where for many years he was reigning bridge champion. He is also well-known among his friends for his diehard love of the Boston Red Sox. He is survived by his wife of 37 years, Veronica Pierce Whitehill, formerly a featured dancer on Broadway, but more recently known as a writer of mystery novels and plays under a pen name. The Services and Interment will be private, and Mrs. Whitehill requests that no flowers be sent.

We extend our sincere condolence to her brothers, Seymour and Edward. Loved by all who knew her, we will miss her and cherish her memory forever.

In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation, to support David's passion for finding a cure for Type I diabetes. A memorial service will be held in Boston at a time yet to be determined.

JACOBS--Robert M.,June 17, 2010, of mesothelioma; 83, beloved husband of Mary for 60 years, devoted father of Miriam (Haran) Boral and Louis (Erica), loving grandfather of Tamar (Tony), Eitan (Michal), Noah (Brittany), Ben and Lily. 8 P.M. (HBO) HARRY POTTER AND THE HALF-BLOOD PRINCE (2009) In this sixth chapter in the eight-part film series, new dangers lurk for Dumbledore (Michael Gambon), above, and especially Harry (Daniel Radcliffe) after he is commissioned to destroy Voldemort, played in his youth by Hero Fiennes-Tiffin (a nephew of Ralph, who portrays the evildoer's adult incarnation) and Frank Dillane (the son of the actor Stephen). Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis called Mr. Gambon invaluable and Alan Rickman (as Prof. Severus Snape) sensational, but said that Mr. Radcliffe, Rupert Grint (Ron) and Emma Watson (Hermione) had ''grown up into three prettily manicured bores.'' This film series ''has begun to show signs of stress around the edges, a bit of fatigue, or maybe that's just my gnawing impatience,'' she wrote. ''Not that the director, David Yates, doesn't keep things moving and flying and soaring, his cameras slashing through the gloom that has settled onto this epic endeavor like a damp, enveloping fog and at times threatened to snuff out its joy as terminally as a soul-sucking Dementor.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Saul Gonzalez looks at the dozens of clergy members who offer pastoral care and confidential counseling to the inmates of the Twin Towers Correctional Facility in Los Angeles, including Dennis Gibbs, the senior chaplain and a former prisoner. Bob Faw examines the choices available to parents who have adopted children from abroad only to discover that they have behavioral issues.

The crash on May 8 of a Staten Island ferry that was previously involved in a deadly wreck may have been caused by defective parts in the boat's propulsion system, according to a report from federal investigators that was released on Friday. The National Transportation Safety Board said there had been a breakdown in the system that controlled the propulsion system of the ferry, the Andrew J. Barberi. Some parts of that system ''were identified as possibly defective and replaced,'' the report said. In preliminary tests after the repairs, the system appeared to working properly again, it said.

WASHINGTON -- The outburst by Representative Joe L. Barton of Texas in support of BP underscored the potential peril for lawmakers forced to respond to crises involving industries vital to their regions, and whose bountiful donations finance their political campaigns. Democrats continued to make use of Mr. Barton's apology to BP, using it to portray Republicans as beholden to big oil. Mr. Barton, the senior Republican on the Energy and Commerce Committee, worked as a consultant to Atlantic Richfield Oil and Gas Company before being elected to Congress. He has long been one of the top beneficiaries of campaign donations from big energy companies, cornerstones of the Texas economy.

Harwitz (David), Jonathan Zabusky (Leora) and Miles and Leah Bellman, adored great-grandmother, treasured aunt and friend. MAKRIS--George C.,charismatic, international, greek, shipping magnate, passed away on June 16, 2010. He was born in 1925. Makris fought in the Pacific in WWII; recipient of the Bronze Star and Purple Heart; graduate of University of Miami; resided in Brookville, NY with his wife, Patricia and family. A man of character and integrity. He is survived by his daughters Katina Makris and Barbara Makris, grandson Jacob Hollander and sister, Evangeline Makris. Calling hours, 3-5 and 7-9pm, Sunday, June 20, Fairchild Funeral Home, Manhasset, NY. Funeral service, 10am, Monday, June 21, St Paul's Greek Orthodox Cathedral, Garden City, NY.

SESKIS--John Y. The family of John Y. Seskis announces with great sadness the death of their beloved father and grandfather. Mr. Seskis died June 17, 2010, two days after his 99th birthday. The son of the late Solomon and Jenny Seskis, Mr. Seskis was predeceased by his sister Sarah Seskis Gusman, his brother Irving, and Eleanor Diamond Seskis, with whom he was married for sixty-two years until her death in 2004. His daughter, Jane Seskis Soudavar, and his granddaughter Annabelle Caufman Soudavar survive Mr. Seskis. A long time New York City resident, Mr. Seskis maintained homes in Woodmere, NY, and until recently, in Palm Beach, FL. Mr. Seskis became a member of the New York Stock Exchange on December 10, 1936, and was at the time the Exchange's youngest member; he was the Exchange's oldest member when the NYSE became a public company in 2005. Mr. Seskis was known for his personal elegance, his many acts of kindness, his interest in music, art, and sports, and for his fondness for the color yellow. He was devoted to his family and rejoiced in their many enthusiasms and accomplishments. Honorable in his dealings, loyal to his friends and many professional associates, Mr. Seskis carried himself with dignity and great personal charm. He will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved him. Funeral services to be held Sunday, June 20th, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 11:30am.

He was 46 and is survived by his father Jag, his mother Jaya and his brother Sanjay.

When the DailyWorth retracted its recent post about a woman who had inflated her current salary during a job interview, the site's editor wrote that a number of human resources personnel had said that ''even slight salary history inflations are illegal and could jeopardize your job application.'' The illegal part struck us -- and a number of readers -- as surprising. So I decided to investigate. I spoke with several employment lawyers around the country, and here's what I found.The lawyers I talked to weren't aware of any federal laws that specifically stated that lying about your salary when applying for a private-sector job is illegal. They also generally said the issue would probably come under state law jurisdiction but they weren't aware of any state laws making it a crime either.

Jose Saramago, the Portuguese writer who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1998 for novels that combine surrealist experimentation and a kind of sardonic peasant pragmatism, died at his home in Lanzarote in the Canary Islands, his publisher said on Friday. If you want to get a bead on the state of feminism these days, look no further than the ubiquitous pop star Lady Gaga. Last summer, after identifying herself as a representative for "sexual, strong women who speak their mind," the 23-year-old Gaga seemed to embrace the old canard that a feminist is by definition a man-hater when she told a Norwegian journalist, "I'm not a feminist.  I hail men!  I love men!"  But by December she was praising the journalist Ann Powers, in a profile in The Los Angeles Times, for being "a little bit of a feminist, like I am." She continued, "When I say to you, there is nobody like me, and there never was, that is a statement I want every woman to feel and make about themselves." Apparently, even though she loves men - she hails them! - she is a little bit of a feminist because she exemplifies what it looks like for a woman to say, and to believe, that there's nobody like her.

In the 17th century, Amsterdam was a growing city. Foreign adventures and the colonial wealth they brought with them enriched a merchant class eager to display its might with opulent new homes outside the city's inner core. The result was Amsterdam's Grachtengordel, or canal belt. Three canals -- the Herengracht, Keizersgracht and Prinsengracht -- saw a building frenzy that created what is now one of the city's most popular destinations.

BRESLIN--John Pershing, DSc formerly of Mt. Lakes and Montclair, NJ, died in Alicante, Spain on May 26, 2010. Born June 9, 1919, he graduated from Webb Institute of Naval Architecture and served as an analyst in the Navy in WWII. From 1958 to 1982 he was Director of the Davidson Laboratory at Stevens Institute of Technology where he was also founder and head of the Dept. of Ocean Engineering. Professional activities included SNAME, AIA, Technical University of Denmark, and ITTC. Breslin co-authored Hydrodynamics of Ship Propellers (Cambridge) and published over 100 technical papers. His awards included the Admiral E L Cochran Award, the Davidson Medal and the Ottens Research Award. John is survived by his wife, Randia, in Alicante. He also leaves Madeline Mitchell, W. Hartford, CT, the mother of his nine children to whom he was married for 30 years. He leaves six children, 13 grandchildren and one great-grandchild. An infant daughter and two sons preceded him in death. Memorial information: Breslin2010@gmail.com

GAZA--James L. Chicago entrepreneur James L. Gaza, 73, died May 25 at home after battling cancer for eight years. Born in 1936 to factory workers, Gaza grew up in a tiny apartment above a tavern. He graduated Steinmetz High and attended Colorado State on football scholarship, playing offensive center and defensive lineman. A Sigma Nu member, the athlete with an engineer's mind earned an electrical engineering B.S. in 1958. Less than a decade later, Gaza launched International Components Corp., with partner Alan H. Shure. ICC joined forces with Igarashi Electric Works, manufacturing motors for appliances for Black & Decker, General Electric, and others. ICC continued to evolve in the 1980s, expanding into the cellphone market with offices in Europe, Asia, South America, and a factory in Quingxi, China. In 1990, Gaza became CEO of ICC, serving as board chairman until his death. In 1995, he was inducted into the Entrepreneurship Hall of Fame. Gaza is survived by wife Lynnette; first wife Shirley Marcus; four children: Brian (Janet) Gaza, Cheryl (Garry) Shoda, Michelle Gaza, Jonathan (Kristy) Gaza; six grandchildren: Kira and James Gaza, Danielle and Brad Shoda, Malakai and Janaia Gaza.

Following is the third and final set of responses from Rebecca Forman, who has been working as a court reporter in the Manhattan federal courthouse since February 2003.You must come into proximity with a lot of violent criminals on a day-to-day basis. Do you ever fear for your personal safety? Also, would you fear for your safety if the 9/11 trials were held in your courthouse? - Posted by Jonathan SandbergCourthouse security is always a concern. In 2005, in an Atlanta courthouse, a defendant got ahold of a gun and killed a sheriff's deputy, a judge and a court reporter. In 2008, in the federal courthouse in Brooklyn, a defendant attacked a prosecutor in the courtroom, and the court reporter tackled the defendant.

Q.My fiance and I are thinking about honeymooning in Croatia in August. We'd like some time on the beaches and to do some exploring. Can you suggest a 10-day itinerary and luxurious (not exorbitant) hotels? Michelle Marcus, New YorkA.With its Roman ruins, medieval castles and gorgeous coastline, Croatia is an ideal honeymoon destination. Fly to Zagreb (above) and allow a couple of days to explore that lovely city before you head to the coast. Read Alex Crevar's ''36 Hours in Zagreb'' (Sept. 6, 2009), for sightseeing, dining and lodging suggestions. Walk or take the tram to the Upper Town neighborhoods, where historic buildings and churches are concentrated, and then walk to the Zagreb City Museum (mgz.hr), which offers a look at the city's political, architectural and artistic history. Next, walk around the pedestrian-only Tkalciceva Street, jammed with cafes and boutiques, and stop at Ivica i Marica, a restaurant and patisserie offering traditional desserts. On your second day, head to the Lower Town, which is dominated by a ''green horseshoe'' of parks and is home to the Academy of Sciences and Art, the National Theater and the Botanical Gardens. For lodging, Mr. Crevar suggested Hotel Dubrovnik (www.hotel-dubrovnik.hr; 130 euros, or $155 at $1.17 to the euro, for a double), with a great location: one of its buildings overlooks the cafe-packed Jelacic Square.

BLOOM--Irene T.,71, on June 16, peacefully after a long illness at home in Cambridge, MA. She was the Anne Whitney Olin Professor Emerita of Asian and Middle Eastern Cultures at Barnard College, and Chair of the Department until her retirement in 2002. A distinguished scholar, Irene Bloom was dedicated to translating the philosophical traditions of China to a new generation of students and scholars. She will be missed by her husband Barry of Cambridge, MA, daughter Inae of Honolulu, HI, brother Eric Tilenius of Hillsborough, CA and by all who knew her. A memorial service is planned for the fall in New York.

The Food Network is setting out to sea. Starting in August, Celebrity Cruises and the Food Network are offering a ''Food Network at Sea'' trip, which will pair two of the Food Network's celebrity chefs with a seven-night Caribbean journey aboard the Celebrity Solstice. While Food Network stars have previously appeared in episodes aboard cruise ships, the Food Network says this is the first time that its branded tours are available on cruise lines. The cruise will depart from Fort Lauderdale and stop in San Juan, St. Thomas and St. Maarten. Cat Cora of the show ''Iron Chef'' and Aaron Sanchez of the restaurants Paladar and Centrico in New York will be the inaugural hosts. They will be onboard for the whole cruise and will prepare some of their signature dishes. They will also engage in question-and-answer sessions, take part in a the Battle of the Celebrity Solstice Chefs, an Iron Chef-style competition, and a ''Dine-Around,'' during which guests sample Food Network recipes.

SESKIS--John Y. The family of John Y. Seskis announces with great sadness the death of their beloved father and grandfather. Mr. Seskis died June 17, 2010, two days after his 99th birthday. The son of the late Solomon and Jenny Seskis, Mr. Seskis was predeceased by his sister Sarah Seskis Gusman, his brother Irving, and Eleanor Diamond Seskis, with whom he was married for sixty-two years until her death in 2004. His daughter, Jane Seskis Soudavar, and his granddaughter Annabelle Caufman Soudavar survive Mr. Seskis. A long time New York City resident, Mr. Seskis maintained homes in Woodmere, NY, and until recently, in Palm Beach, FL. Mr. Seskis became a member of the New York Stock Exchange on December 10, 1936, and was at the time the Exchange's youngest member; he was the Exchange's oldest member when the NYSE became a public company in 2005. Mr. Seskis was known for his personal elegance, his many acts of kindness, his interest in music, art, and sports, and for his fondness for the color yellow. He was devoted to his family and rejoiced in their many enthusiasms and accomplishments. Honorable in his dealings, loyal to his friends and many professional associates, Mr. Seskis carried himself with dignity and great personal charm. He will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved him. Funeral services to be held Sunday, June 20th, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 11:30am.

REISMAN--Charles, 93, passed on June 19, 2010. Survived by wife, Gladys, three children, six grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Donations in lieu of flowers should be made to the Hadassah or the American Cancer Society.

WEST--Shirley Almeda, died peacefully at home in her Tribeca loft on June 8, 2010, after a long illness. Ms. West was born on October 24, 1928 in Breckenridge, Texas and was an artist. In 1949, she earned an Associate of Arts degree from Stephens College in Columbia, Missouri, where she was taught by Pierre Montminy and Worden Day. She then traveled to the University of Colorado, Boulder, to study with renowned German Expressionist Max Beckmann. She continued to study privately with Beckmann until his death in late 1950. Ms. West continued her education at Smith College, where she received a B.A. in English Literature, Art History, Painting and Sculpture in 1952, and at Columbia University, where she received an M.F.A. in 1958. She studied with numerous artists during the 1950's, including painter Mervin Jules, graphic artist George Swinton, sculptor Peter Srippi, and painters Ottis Dozier and Vaclav Vytlacil. Ms. West began exhibiting her work in New York in the 1950's at spaces such as Brata and Avant Garde Ltd. She had her first one-woman show of drawings and paintings at the Museum of Modern Art, Miami, in 1961. Throughout the 1960's and '70's, Ms. West was active in the Art Students League in New York, studying primarily with Robert Beverly Hale. She also studied privately for many years with Dr. A. Didier Graeffe, Humanities professor at the University of Florida in Gainesville. During this period, she began the large-scale sculptural work that came to define her career. From 1968 to 1970, she built three large, concrete sculptures that were constructed outdoors in Gainesville and Micanopy, Florida: The Prairie Woman (1968-69); Yin/Yang (1969) and The Embrace (1969-70). In 2009, Ms. West's work was exhibited at a one-woman show entitled "Discovery: A Retrospective" at the Chelsea Art Museum in New York City. Ms. West was the eldest daughter of Texas oil man Carey Keene West, the founder of the Chemical Process Company (now known as BJ Service Company), and Fredricka Almeda West. Ms. West was predeceased by her brother, Carey West, Jr. She is survived by her sister, Ms. Lorraine West of Dallas, Texas; her nieces, Ms. Roxane West of Dallas and New York, Ms. Carol Ann Presnell of Aledo, Texas and Ms. Catherine Oconnor of Tuscaloosa, Alabama; as well as her nephews, Mr. Robert Morris of Kennedale, Texas, Mr. Carey West III of Houston, Mr. Patrick West of Fort Worth and Mr. Frederick West, also of Fort Worth. In addition, she is survived by numerous great-nieces, great-nephews, great-great-nieces and great-great-nephews. Ms. West was an avid music lover and an accomplished musician, playing piano, cello and flute. She frequently hosted concerts in her Tribeca loft. Ms. West was also an ardent supporter of charities for the benefit of animals. She leaves behind many friends, who admired her sharp wit, extensive generosity, and kind and loving heart. Ms. West will be deeply missed by all who knew her. "To live in the hearts of those we leave behind is not to die..." She will live in our hearts forever.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about young adults' taking longer to become financially independent misspelled the surname of a sociologist who is researching parental spending on children. He is Sabino Kornrich, not Kornich.

THE NEWS In his first televised address to the nation from the Oval Office, President Obama promised a long-term plan to restore the Gulf Coast region, economically and environmentally, from the effects of the oil leaking from an offshore well. BEHIND THE NEWS The president used the occasion to summon Americans to a ''national mission'' to reduce reliance on oil and develop alternative energy, calling on Congress to act quickly to overcome ''a lack of political courage and candor.'' He was open to bipartisan ideas, he said, but ''the one approach I will not accept is inaction.''

In addition to the legacy that is Michael Jackson's discography, the King of Pop also left behind a trove of collectibles - from his bedazzled gloves and rhinestone-covered military garb to the countless tacky tchotchkes that filled his Neverland compound. Though many of the clothes and objects have been sold at auction, the museum-worthy collection has been preserved by the Swiss-born photographer Henry Leutwyler in a new book, ''Neverland Lost: A Portrait of Michael Jackson'' (Steidl 2010; $45). Mr. Leutwyler photographed the items prior to Mr. Jackson's death in 2009, forgoing visual trickery and relying instead on a plain black background. Many of the images point to the otherwordly realm the star inhabited; others, such as an ordinary tube sock studded with rhinestones, bring him heartbreakingly down to earth. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

WEISSMAN--George, M.D.,curriculum vitae, died Sunday, June 13, 2010 of natural causes at the age of 91, at his home in Dallas, Texas. Born in New York City, he retired from the Veterans Administration in Manhattan after 30 years as Chief Clinic Cardiologist in a storied career of saving and prolonging lives as an internist and cardiologist - his deft skills in reading cardiographs being remarkable. Dr. Weissman graduated from Manhattan's George Washington High School, New York University, and New York University Medical School in 1943. During WWII he served three years in the U.S. Army Medical Corp, where he was appointed Chief of Medical Services - 245 General Hospital, in the Philippines. Dr. Weissman's zest for life led to extensive travel adventures, particularly in Italy, where his fluent Italian won him entre to many rewarding experiences. He also excelled in 50 yrs of botany - particularly the art of growing Banzai trees, photography; his vast knowledge of opera and classical music brought him constant joy which he shared with others. He played piano. Dr Weissman, a keen scientific mind, was an avid reader on most subjects; he spoke and read several languages, Italian being his favorite. He loved to fish - particularly for blue fish and stripe bass. A true friend always; he lead an exemplary life, filling each day with meaningful accomplishments. Noted for his strong bond with his family and friends - he gave us much and he will be missed even more. Our salutes! Many salutes! George Weissman was preceded in death by his grand parents Chaim and Miriam Weinberg of Poland and NYC, parents Erwin and Paula Weinberg Weissman, of NYC, and brother Morton, of NYC and Boca Raton. He is survived by his friend and financial advisor of many years, Richard Ellison of NYC and Dallas, sister-in-law Eleanor Weissman, NYC and Boca Raton, niece Iris Weissman Kelsen (Chris), Cincinnati, Michael Weissman (Lisa), Jericho, NY, and their children: Matthew (Melania) and Jennifer Kelsen, and Andrew and Rachel Weissman. Special salutes to Eleanor Nyilas, Frank Lawrence, Joe and Dolly Richino families, of Long Island, NY, the extended Ellison families, and his other wonderful friends. Cremation by Restland Funeral Home, 13005 Greenville Ave.; Memorial Service will be in Wildwood Chapel, Restland, 10am, Saturday June 26th, followed by Internment, then Reception at Doubletree Hotel, 75 at Caruth Haven, 12:30-2pm.

JEDEIKIN--Edwin E.,of Somers, NY peacefully passed away on June 14th surrounded by his family. Besides his beloved wife Joan, he is survived by his loving daughters Beth Mesisco of Mount Vernon and Wendy Schleifer (Norman) of Briarcliff Manor. He was also the proud grandfather of four grandchildren, Melissa Mesisco-Chica (Jorge), Chad Mesisco, Justin Schleifer and Ross Schleifer, and his cherished great-granddaughter Ava Teresa Chica. Ed is survived by his sister Sylvia Rosen (Mel), as well as many nieces and nephews and is predeceased by his brother Robert Jedeikin (Harriet). Edwin had a great quality of life up until the onset of his brief illness. He had that special something that is hard to define but you know it when you see it. Ed loved his family, he loved his friends and he loved his food. A remarkable, gentle, man who was always great fun to be with; Ed was truly one of a kind and a gift to all who knew him.

JACOBS--Robert M.,June 17, 2010, of mesothelioma; 83, beloved husband of Mary for 60 years, devoted father of Miriam (Haran) Boral and Louis (Erica), loving grandfather of Tamar (Tony), Eitan (Michal), Noah (Brittany), Ben and Lily. What does exercise do to your body? It may seem as if science, medicine and common sense answered that question long ago. But in fact the precise mechanisms by which exercise alters your body -- at a deep, molecularlevel -- remain poorly understood. A number of analyses of the effect that exercise has on heart disease, for instance, have concluded that working out lessens a person's chances of developing heart problems far more than scientists can account for. They understand the physiological reasons for about 60 percent of the reduced risk. The rest is a mysterious if welcome bonus. But a new study that gauged the metabolic effects of exercise may significantly advance our understanding of what's going on inside a body in motion. During the experiment, scientists actually saw how much being fit changes your ability to incinerate fat, moderate blood sugar and otherwise function well. They also uncovered proof, at once inspiring and cautionary, of just how complicated and pervasive exercise's consequences are.

In the late 1990s, Cecilia Pagkalinawan had a business advising fashion labels about selling their stuff online. There were actually some people who knew what she was talking about, although there wasn't really a market. Then came the dot-com bust, and Ms. Pagkalinawan closed her business and went to work for Burberry in London and later Frette and La Perla, developing e-commerce. She learned a lot about the inside of the luxury-goods business at a time when those dyed-in-the-wool brands were coming to grips with digital technology. She also began to wonder about emerging talent and if an e-commerce model could be built around those people, one that took advantage of social media. She tucked away the idea and stayed in touch with her investor friends.

BREITBART--Yuri Professor. OBR Distinguished Professor Yuri Breitbart (69) passed away peacefully Sunday, June 13 at 1:06am. Yuri was a man of unstoppable spirit, passionately dedicated to work and family all his life, despite a two year battle with cancer. A highly accomplished member of the international computer science community, Dr. Breitbart will be remembered for significant contributions in areas including data base systems and network management. He received his MS degree at Moscow Pedagogical Inst; Ph.D. in Computer Science at Technion in Haifa. He taught at Technion, SUNY Albany, University of Wisconsin, University of Kentucky (where he was department chair) and at Kent State. He also worked in industry at ITT, Amoco Oil, ETH (Swiss Institute) and Bell Labs. He is survived by his wife, two children, five stepchildren, ten grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. He will be greatly missed. http://yuri-breitbart. forevermissed.com

An obituary last Sunday about the neurologist Fred Plum referred incorrectly to an experiment Dr. Plum and two associates conducted to study hyperventilation's effects on the brain. In the experiment, each man breathed rapidly for five hours, not five minutes. The obituary also misstated the given name of the doctor with whom he coined the term ''persistent vegetative state.'' He was Bryan Jennett, not Byron.

Christopher Bailey's accolades at Burberry are enough to make him blush - in five shades, to be precise. The designer's latest project, Burberry Beauty, is a comprehensive collection of foundations, powders, bronzers, lipsticks and eye shadows that were inspired by the label's classic trench coat and by the moody hues of the British climate. Two years in the making, the line pays homage to Mr. Bailey's vision of a modern English rose. ''The Burberry girl wears just a trace of makeup - no crazy eyes or crazy lips,'' he says. ''Makeup should enhance women, not just cover up what they perceive as flaws.'' Of the sexy reflective checked packaging, he adds, ''The idea was for the products to look and feel like things you really want to have in your bag.'' The range will be available on Nordstrom.com starting Monday and on Burberry.com starting Friday. On the eve of the launch of Burberry Beauty, we asked Mr. Bailey to tell us about his six favorite British beauties. Click on the slide show above to view.

MENKEN--Kenneth Andrews, June 11, 2010. He was born in Vienna in 1931, to an Austrian mother and American father who had sold his seat on the New York stock exchange in 1928. His schooling began in England. His family moved to the United States before World War II. He graduated from the Hotchkiss School, attended the Ashville School, and graduated from Duke University. He excelled in soccer at Duke, was on the All-South team, and was a candidate for the Olympics when the Korean War broke out. He served in the Navy during the war and when he returned obtained an MBA from Wharton. After Wharton, he worked for a time in advertising at Foote, Cone & Belding, then started a financial career first at Smith Barney and finally at his own firm, Managers Capital Development which specialized in alternative investments. He was a Past President of The New England Society, a Past President of First New York Continental Chapter of the Sons of the American Revolution; a member of the Sons of the Revolution at Fraunces Tavern and a member of Holland Lodge No. 8, F&AM. He was a member of the Union Club and the Maidstone Club. The son of the late N. Davis Menken, he is survived by his wife of 25 years, Joan, and his mother Emma J. Harvey. A memorial service will be held at 10:30am on Wednesday, June 23, at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Ave. and 90th St. In lieu of flowers, a donation to the charity of one's choice would be appreciated.

The bargain lines widely known as the Chinatown buses are rolling out new routes beyond the Northeast corridor, to hubs like Atlanta, Orlando and Chicago. Many of the bus routes have been in existence for several years, catering mostly to the Chinese immigrant clientele for whom the carriers were originally started in the 1990s. But several bus companies have begun publicizing the routes to the students, backpackers and other English-speaking bargain-hunters who have embraced the lines as a cheap mode of transportation through the Northeast.

With the World Cup games in South Africa just days away, soccer balls aren't the only things spinning out of control. The New York City artist Kehinde Wiley's ''Africa Lifestyle'' sneakers and sports apparel for Puma are creating their own brand of hysteria. Puma has been supplying African soccer teams with uniforms since 1997, when it signed on with Cameroon. Wiley's own partnership with the brand began two years ago with a commission to capture the spirit of the game through life-size paintings of Africana footballers like Samuel Eto'o of Cameroon, John Mensah of Ghana and Emmanuel Eboue of Ivory Coast. The paintings have been touring the globe with pit stops in Paris, London, New York, Beijing, Tokyo, Milan and Johannesburg, where they will land just in time for next week's kickoff. Wiley, 33, whose name means ''second born'' in Yoruba, was raised in Los Angeles by an African-American mother and a Nigerian father and says this project has been like ''a coming-out party.'' The spirited collection includes bomber jackets, T-shirts, leggings, laces and particularly eye-catching patterned kicks like ''Tekkies Heroic Sisters.'' Wiley calls this initiative his response to ''street branding,'' in which a fondness for abstraction, West African art and ''veritable wax'' fabrics from Dakar and Lagos merge onto lively footwear that echoes contemporary African tribal markings. According to Antonio Bertone, Puma's chief marketing officer, the raw canvas for each additional collection will be sourced directly from Africa. In the meantime, keep an eye out for more items debuting this fall, including the Kehinde Puffa and the unisex 4M Mix high-top sneakers.

On Tuesday, the Food Network star Sandra Lee's cooking -- specifically her lasagna -- took a public knock from her possible future mother-in-law, Matilda Cuomo, mother of the New York State attorney general and Democratic gubernatorial candidate Andrew Cuomo. Ms. Lee's lasagna recipe calls for two cans of condensed Campbell's tomato soup and a container of cottage cheese. When a reporter from the news channel NY1 asked Mrs. Cuomo whether her son might prefer the tomato-soup version to his mother's own, she dismissed the idea.

Manute Bol, a towering Dinka tribesman who left southern Sudan to become one of the best shot blockers in the history of American basketball, then returned to his homeland to try to heal the wounds of a long, bloody civil war, died Saturday at the University of Virginia Medical Center in Charlottesville, according to Sally Jones, a spokeswoman for the hospital. He was 47 and lived in Olathe, Kan. The cause was severe kidney trouble and complications of a rare skin disorder known as Stevens-Johnson syndrome, said Tom Prichard, who runs Sudan Sunrise, a foundation that is building a school near Bol's birthplace in Turalei. Bol had been hospitalized since late May when he fell ill during a layover on a trip home from Sudan, Mr. Prichard said.

ZAPANTIS--Michael B.,P. E., Esq., 62, of Princeton Junction, NJ passed away Wednesday at his home. Born and raised in Brooklyn Heights and Long Island City, NY, Mr. Zapantis had also resided in Holliswood (Queens), NY for sixteen years before moving to Princeton Junction in 1998. Michael received his Bachelor of Engineering (Civil) from City University of New York, School of Engineering in 1969, Master of Science Transportation Planning from The Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn in 1971 and Juris Doctor from New York Law School in 1978. Michael was also admitted to practice before the United States Patent and Trademark Office in Patent Cases in 1978, Attorney and Counselor of the Supreme Court of the United States in 1982, as well as admitted as Attorney and Counselor of the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals. He was a licensed Engineer in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. As a licensed attorney, he served on the New York Patent Bar and was currently serving as the Deputy Director, Procurement Department, Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Mr. Zapantis began his career at the Port Authority in the Engineering Department where he quickly rose to the position of Manager of the Construction Contracts Awards Unit. In 1996, he moved to the Procurement Department as the Manager of its newly created Construction Contracts Awards Division. In this role, Mr. Zapantis was responsible for the award of millions of dollars of construction contracts as well as the general oversight of the agency's consultant programs. In 2008, he was promoted to Assistant Director, and at the time of his death he held the position of Deputy Director, Procurement Department. In this position he was working closely with both state and federal agencies on the new development leading to the restoration of the World Trade Center property. He was highly regarded and respected by his staff, colleagues and senior executives at the Port Authority. He was a varsity wrestler while attending City College and in later years, was highly respected as a fun and loving soccer and baseball coach for his children as they grew up in both Holliswood, NY and Princeton Junction, NJ. Michael also found deep joy as a Sunday school teacher for many years at St. George Greek Orthodox Church, in Hamilton, NJ. He will be profoundly missed by his wife and children, family and friends and all those who were fortunate to have known him. Son of the late Michael and Emily "Millie" Zapantis, he is survived by his beloved wife of 31 years, Victoria Zapantis; his daughter, Melanie N. Zapantis; two sons, Michael J. and Kristofer A. Zapantis; his sister, Genevieve Zirman and her husband David, of Flushing, NY; and his nephew, Jamie Zirman, of Philadelphia, PA. Friends will be received at A.S. Cole Son & Company Funeral Home, 22 North Main Street, Cranbury, NJ on Monday, June 21 from 2:00pm to 4:00pm and 7:00pm to 9:00pm. Trisaghion services will be held at 3:30pm, during the visitation. The funeral will begin 8:30am Tuesday, June 22 at the A.S. Cole Funeral Home. The Funeral Service will be held at 10am at St. George Greek Orthodox Church, 1200 Klockner Rd., Hamilton, NJ. A Trisaghion service at interment will follow in Brainerd Cemetery, Cranbury, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested memorial contributions be made to the American Heart Association, 1 Union St, Suite 301, Robbinsville, NJ 08691 or St. George Greek Orthodox Church, 1200 Klockner Rd, Hamilton, NJ 08619.
