Hammering out legislation that could be the biggest change in financial regulation since the Great Depression is a monumental task -- and it's commanding the full firepower of lawmakers on all sides of the issues. This month, House staff members have been trying to chisel out details that will satisfy their Senate counterparts. And Democrats and Republicans continue to disagree on key components of the bill. Regardless, President Obama has said he wants the bill on his desk by the Fourth of July.

WHIPPLE--Sally Johnson, 1921-2010. She danced with Martha Graham. She sang in William Schuman's Chorus. She chaired the Second District of Greenwich's Representative Town Meeting. She raised five children and nourished 12 grandchildren, three great-grandchildren, and two husbands. All in only 88 years. Sally Schilthuis Johnson Whipple, who died June 16 of complications of Alzheimer's, was the first of three formidable daughters of the late Willem and Sally Schilthuis. Born September 10, 1921, in New York City, she attended Friends Seminary, The Thomas School and Sarah Lawrence College. In 1943 she married Robert L. Johnson, Jr., who then was sent to the Pacific with the U.S. Navy for the duration of World War II. When Bob returned, they moved to Wynnewood, PA, where they raised their two sons and three daughters while Bob commuted to Philadelphia as an editor of The Saturday Evening Post. In 1962, when the Post transferred its editorial offices to New York City, Sally and family moved to Greenwich. Bob died in 1970, and Sally devoted her time to helping raise grandchildren, taking college courses, and volunteering for Greenwich charities. Surprised by a "Vote for Sally Johnson for the RTM" sign (posted by a friend), she was elected, and shortly was voted Chairman of the Second District. In 1994 she married widower A.B.C. Whipple, with whom she traveled from Nantucket to Virgin Gorda and Bermuda to Holland, where she kept in touch with her many Dutch cousins. Sally is survived by her sons Robert L. Johnson, III (and wife Patricia) of Houston, TX, Peter Johnson (and wife Connie) of Scottsdale, AZ, her daughters Linda Johnson Parker (and husband Richard) of Auburn, CA, Sally Johnson Wilkinson (and husband Geoffrey) of Milton, MA, and Carol Johnson Wynn (and husband Thomas) of Bristol, VT, plus her sister Pamela Rossbach (and husband Laurence) of North Haven, NY, those dozen grandchildren, three great-grandchildren, and her second husband, "Cal" Whipple, a former editor at LIFE Magazine, all of whom will never forget the grand and lovable lady who graced their lives. A celebration of her life will be held at St. Catherine of Sienna Church in Riverside at 11:00am on June 28th.

There was no red carpet. There were no borrowed designer dresses. There was no borrowed jewelry. And there were no high-end celebrities for the 100th anniversary of the Brooklyn Botanic Gardens on June 7. The stars of the evening were the gardens, including a new herb garden. The 450 guests wore their own clothes and their own jewelry -- unlike the extravagantly dressed guests at many of the high profile events, who migrate from Palm Beach to their summer homes in the Hamptons. The Brooklyn attendees reflected a very American style of dress for a major event. It reminded one of garden parties in Newport, R.I.; Rumson, N.J., and Philadelphia. Flower prints were a favorite, as was the occasional picture hat.

To the Sports Editor:

Let's face it, folks. The customer is not always right. In fact, some are just plain old abusive, cheap and crass. I say this not as a salesman but as a dyed-in-the-wool middle-class consumer. I'm waiting in line at a fast-food restaurant while a coupon fight goes on in front of me, delaying me from my sweet, sweet weekly communion with a Southern Style Chicken Biscuit. No, the coupon does not say that you are entitled to a free iced latte. You show it to me as if I'm your lawyer, and it states plainly, ''A free cup of coffee.'' And, no, they are not the same thing.

Al Kaline, a Hall of Fame outfielder for the Detroit Tigers, retired in 1974 with a career batting average of .297, 3,007 hits, 399 home runs and 1,583 runs batted in. Kaline, 75, now a special assistant to the Tigers' president, Dave Dombrowski, was in Manhattan in May. He accepted the Vin Scully Lifetime Achievement Award in Sports Broadcasting on behalf of Ernie Harwell, the longtime Tigers broadcaster who died just before the presentation. The award is sponsored by WFUV, Fordham University's radio station. Q. You never played in the minor leagues. Do you think other players are capable of making that jump?A. There's a financial issue today. You bring a player up too soon, he can play out his option and go someplace else just when he's becoming a star. He can leave the team that has groomed him and gave him money. When I played, you were owned outright by the club until a team traded you or released you.Q. Who was the toughest pitcher you faced?A. One pitcher who gave me a lot of trouble was Frank Sullivan with the Red Sox. He wasn't by any sense of imagination a great pitcher, but he was a big, tall sidearmer. I never got hits off him. When I was a real good player, Bob Lemon and Early Wynn were tough on me, too. Then when I got older, 38, 39, Nolan Ryan was tough.

Ever since 1962 when James Bond made his debut on the big screen in ''Dr. No,'' the public has had more than a passing interest in things Bond-related: Bond girls, Bond villains and certainly Bond cars. It bears clarification then as to what exactly qualifies as ''a Bond car.'' Simply put, the car has to have been officially issued to Bond by Q-Branch, the spy's official armorer.

JAFFE--Selma (Sandy), died on June 12. She was a caring, strong, vibrant wife, mother and registered nurse/state health facility inspector who protected the rights of nursing home residents, a native New Yorker and devoted bridge player, who savored the city's opera, ballet and museums, even after the loss of her husband of 56 years, Richard. She was quick to offer wisdom and wisecracks, never stopped learning, and always had an opinion. She inspired her daughter Susan to become a journalist and son Howard in his career as a musician. She was their champion, best critic and best example in life. Her children, family and friends will cherish all the good memories she leaves behind. Family visitation will be held at home July 18, 3-5pm.

PARIS -- Gen. Marcel Bigeard, one of France's most decorated veterans, who led troops in the French Resistance in World War II and in wars in Algeria and Indochina, died Friday in Toul, France, where he lived. He was 94. His death was confirmed by his wife, Gabrielle Grandemange. General Bigeard, who was wounded in battle five times and escaped from prisoner-of-war camps three times, achieved legendary status in France.

Q.I will be in London the first week in August with my granddaughter and daughter. Any suggestions for a very mature 8-year-old with a passion for acting -who is also fun-loving (true of all of us)? Beata Levine, MontrealA.Sarah Lyall wrote in her ''36 Hours in London'' (April 20, 2008) that ''there are many different Londons'' to satisfy every passion: opera, art, history and literature. But as the theater capital of the world, there is no better place to satisfy a passion for the stage. To take in the works of Shakespeare, head to the Globe Theater. The National Theater (nationaltheatre.org.uk) puts on performances from classic dramas to new plays, including musicals and children's shows. A good source for up-to-date information is the London Theater Guide Online (londontheatre.co.uk).

SCHWARTZ--William Bernstein, Jr.,died May 18, 2010, in Atlanta, where he was born November 14, 1921. U.S. Ambassador to the Bahamas 1977-1981; Naval officer in World War II; former President, Atlanta Chapter, American Jewish Committee; past Chairman, Emory University Board of Visitors; former Chairman, American Red Cross, Atlanta Chapter; President, Hebrew Benevolent Congregation (The Temple), 1958-1960; board member, National Service Industries, Inc., Balcor Energy, Phoenix Supply; President, Weine Investment Corporation; Chairman, The Chatham Valley Foundation; Vice Chairman, Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority. Survived by wife of 67 years, Sonia Weinberg Schwartz, and three sons: William Schwartz III (Nina), Arthur Jay Schwartz (Joyce), Robert Clay Schwartz (Terry); six grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

SKORY--Michael James. 20-May - 1954 to 16 - June - 2010. Beloved son of Frances and the late David Skory, and brother of John Skory, Carol Schwiebert, Sulaf Parker, Elizabeth North, and David Skory; Mike died suddenly of complications from Multiple Sclerosis.

Jenny Holzer's ''truisms'' have appeared on billboards, posters and LED displays. This month, her provocative pronouncements are competing for chest real estate in World Cup-obsessed South Africa. Instead of the ubiquitous green and yellow colors of Bafana Bafana, as the national soccer team is known, children from Johannesburg's inner-city schools and nearby Soweto have been spotted wearing white T-shirts printed with statements like, ''Abuse of power comes as no surprise,'' and, ''Remember you always have freedom of choice.''

WADING THROUGH FLOWERS IN LISSE, THE NETHERLANDS, MAY 6, 2010. Shailaja Sreenivas, 30, a homemaker from Bangalore, India, wheels a rented bike through the vast tulip fields of Keukenhof Gardens. ''My husband is working in Amsterdam for an IT company, so we came here together in January 2009, and we'll be here until October. I have a master's in computer education, but I really prefer doing creative things. For instance, most of the places we go are very scenic, beautiful places, and I love taking scenic pictures wherever we travel. Keukenhof is one of my favorite places I have ever been, a real feast for the eyes. I love flowers so much, when I first went into the garden -- it's so amazing, so beautiful, I actually shouted. In my childhood, I had dreamed of seeing a place like this. I'd never seen so many flowers in one place -- it took us almost 30 minutes to cover one or two gardens there. It looked like an ocean of flowers.'' As told to Austin Considine

An article last Sunday about ''Moby-Dick'' as a metaphor for the quest for petroleum and the recent spill misstated a word in an excerpt from Philip Hoare's ''The Whale: In Search of the Giants of the Sea.'' Mr. Hoare wrote, ''The whaler was a kind of pirate-miner -- an excavator of oceanic oil, stoking the furnace of the Industrial Revolution as much as any man digging coal out of the earth.'' He did not write ''pirate-minter.''
'He wouldn't or couldn't explain it.'

WATERFRONT COLONIAL $949,000

FRANKLIN--Norman, 93, of Southbury, CT, (Teaneck, NJ.) June 18. Teacher and advertising executive, co-writer-- music and lyrics--for "Thursdays Till 9", a pro-labor musical comedy. Memoirist and, at age 90, winner of national poetry award. Wise, witty, gracious and giving father of Paul and Dan, father-in-law of Adri and Nan, grandfather of Peter and Sara, revered uncle and friend. Remembrance to be held later in the summer.

9 P.M. (13, 49) AGATHA CHRISTIE'S MISS MARPLE, SERIES V: THE SECRET OF CHIMNEYS This second of three new ''Masterpiece Mystery!'' productions finds Miss Marple (Julia McKenzie) accompanying Lady Virginia Revel (Charlotte Salt) to a weekend party at Chimneys, her family home where her father, Lord Caterham (Edward Fox), is playing host to Count Ludwig von Stainach (Anthony Higgins) of Austria. But when the count goes missing, the search reveals a decades-old murder and a mysterious diamond heist. Adam Godley is George Lomax, the politician who suggested the gathering and who has proposed marriage to Virginia. Jonas Armstrong is Anthony Cade, another, more adventurous suitor, who has captured Virginia's eye. And Stephen Dillane, above, is Finch, the chief inspector from Scotland Yard who is going to help Miss Marple make sense of the chaos. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates discusses military progress in the Middle East and diplomatic relations with Iran.
RINGELHEIM--Myrna, died June 13. Beloved wife of the late Fen. Loving mother to Debra, David, Joy, grandson Dylan. We will love and miss you always.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the election for Cook County assessor misstated the deadline for independent candidates to collect 25,000 signatures to get on the ballot. It is this Monday -- not Monday, June 28.

''The world doesn't need more products, just better ones,'' says Chad Murawczyk, who opened MiN New York, an old-style apothecary, on one of SoHo's few remaining gritty stretches six months ago. To this end, Murawczyk has stocked the shop's dark-wood shelves with exclusive and hard-to-find fragrances like Linari's ''Notte Bianca'' (a favorite of David Bowie; $195) and Arabian Nights from Kilian Perfume as an Art ($395), as well as grooming products from Taylor of Old Bond Street and handmade straight razors from the French firm Thiers-Issard ($200-500). More a cabinet of curiosities than a drugstore, it's as if Zitomer had been transported to Savile Row. MiN New York, 117 Crosby Street; (212) 206-6366.

A picture caption last Sunday with an obituary about Vera Saeedpour, who started a library and museum dedicated to Kurds, misidentified the photographer. The picture of Ms. Saeedpour at her home in 1998 was taken by Aaron Fineman for The New York Times, not by Don Hogan Charles.

After a few calls to bike shops, it became clear: No one wanted to put the Flying Pigeon together. I bought the big black city bicycle, a classic from China imported via a shop in Los Angeles, as a gift for my wife's 30th birthday in early May. Yet as June loomed, it still sat unassembled in its rectangular box in my living room.

THOMASSON--Stan, noted New York architect, Professor of Design, sculptor and painter, died on June 12, in San Antonio, TX. He was 81. Mr. Thomasson passed away after a fall, surrounded by family. To view full obituary, go to: www.VisitmySA.com, Keyword: online obits

KADDEN--Ilse, died on June 17, 2010. Loving wife to Henry, mother to Harvey and Freddi, grandmother to Zachary, Joshua and Daniel, sister to Gus and Ruth, aunt to Evy, Lawrence, Howard, Steven and Bruce, and great-aunt. Remembering a truly caring and compassionate woman. Beloved by all who knew her. We will all miss you dearly and cherish your memory forever.

OSTERER--Beatrice Ruth. June 30, 1920, died June 7, 2010. Beloved wife to Maurice (d.), mother to Merle Zabusky (Byron, d.), and Carole Osterer (Bob Bellman), cherished grandmother to Marcia Z. Harwitz (David), Jonathan Zabusky (Leora) and Miles and Leah Bellman, adored great-grandmother, treasured aunt and friend. Bea embraced life with purpose, verve and an abiding commitment to hard work, Jewish tradition, and love for family and friends. Donations can be made to Orchard Cove, Canton MA, or New City Hadassah.

COHEN--Arthur, died peacefully in his sleep on June 15, 2010. Having recently celebrated his 80th birthday, he is survived by his wife Denise, his daughters Jill Cohen, Jackie Cohen (and her husband Eric Linden), and Alyssa Cohen Ben-Avi (and her husband Hanan Ben-Avi) and their mother Dale Tannen; his granddaughters Olivia Cohen Gay and Kaila Cohen Gay (and their father Eben Gay), and Julia Linden; his brother Howie (and his wife Chickie), his sister Pearl, numerous nieces and nephews and many dear friends. He had a wonderful life and, as he sang along with Frank Sinatra, "I lived a life that was full, I traveled each and ev'ry highway, and more, much more than this, I did it ...my way". He will live forever in our hearts.

The Mortgages column last Sunday, about a study on math skills and the likelihood of foreclosure, misstated the proportion of borrowers with poor math skills who went into foreclosure versus those with the best skills. Those borrowers were two times more likely to experience foreclosure, not three times more likely.

Do what hip-hop has done best -- transgress. Don't become the slightly more sensitive version of an already well-developed prototype. (Don't be a ''romantic comedy'' -- an easily deduced marketable contrivance). Real does recognize Real. Artists who are groomed for success won't transform anything beyond a calculated flux in the visible market trends. GAVIN BECKER of Brookline, Mass., responding to Jon Caramanica's article about the rapper Drake.

An article and a picture caption last Sunday about Alex Klein, who resigned from playing the oboe for the Chicago Symphony Orchestra because of a neurological disorder, gave outdated information for Mr. Klein's academic affiliation. He left his teaching position at Oberlin College in May.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Critics' Howls Won't Stop Vuvuzelas' Buzzing, Organizers Say,'' June 14: It is South Africa's party and if the vuvuzela is part of their soccer culture, then those attending, players and fans alike, just have to buck up and deal with it.

WEINSTEIN--Mildred. The staff of Weinstein Garlick Kirschenbaum of Brooklyn, NY and Weinstein Memorial Chapel of Yonkers, NY mourn the passing of our esteemed and beautiful co-founder, Mildred Weinstein. We extend our sincere condolence to her brothers, Seymour and Edward. Loved by all who knew her, we will miss her and cherish her memory forever.

A building dating from 1935 might not be the spot you'd expect for a ''green'' hotel, but that's exactly what you'll find at Mosaic House, opening tonight off Karlovo Namesti in the New Town area of Prague. A joint project between the local Bohemian Hostels chain and London-based Beds and Bars, the 94-room design hotel (Odboru 4; 420-246-008-324; mosaichouse.com), which was redesigned by the Czech architect Tereza Koucka, is also a hostel -- bunk beds fill a dorm-style room in the basement, and there are additional shared rooms elsewhere in the building.

WEINSTEIN--Mildred, beloved mother of the late Harvey. Devoted sister of Seymour, Eddie and the late Jack; loving sister-in-law of Helen; aunt of David, Amy, Suzin, Anne and Joan. She was a proud member of the Pythian Sisters of New York and Florida. Mildred was an owner, along with her brothers, of the Wienstein-Garlick-Kirsch-enbaum Chapels. Services: Monday, 1pm, Weinstein-Garlick-Kirschenbaum Chapels, 1153 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, NY.

KAN-SCHWARTZ--Diana, renowned artist, author, teacher and long-time Greenwich Village resident, died in her home on May 3, 2010 at the age of 84. Beloved wife of the late Paul Schwartz and mother of her late son Sing-Si Schwartz. Diana was a prominent member of the National Arts Club, Salmagundi Club, Lotos Club, the American Watercolor Society, the National Academy of Design, and fellow of the Royal Society of Arts in London, among others. Her annual watercolor and calligraphy workshops were attended by loyal students from around the world. Her works were represented by John Whitney Payson of the Midtown Payson Galleries of Hobe Sound, FL, L.J. Wender of Fine Chinese Paintings in New York, Dyansen Gallery in Boston, MA and Dennis Rae of Fine Arts in San Francisco, CA. A memorial service will be held at the National Arts Club, Wednesday, June 23 from 6-8pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to either American Watercolor Society or American Cancer Society.

CHRISTIE--Jean, of Madison, WI. Jean Christie, 98, long-time Great Neck resident living in Wisconsin since 2001, died at home on May 16, 2010. She was born in Manila (February 8, 1912). A graduate of George Washington (BA), the Fletcher School (MA), and Columbia (Ph.D.), she taught history at Fairleigh Dickinson until retirement in the 1980s. Her marriage to Robert Claus in 1938 lasted until his death in 2004. She is survived by her older son, Richard Claus, a grandson, and two granddaughters. A memorial will be held at Madison Friends Meetinghouse on August 8.

TENDLER--Karyn. June 15, 2010. New York Blood Center mourns the passing of Karyn Tendler, beloved daughter of David Tendler, our longtime Trustee and Vice Chairman. We extend our heartfelt condolences and support to David and his family during this difficult time. Howard P. Milstein, Chairman, Board of Trustees Christopher D. Hillyer, MD, President and CEO

Early each morning I deal myself a daily hand of pills: Wellbutrin (450 milligrams) and Zoloft (200 mg) to ply the capricious oceans of postcancer depression, Provigil (200 mg) to keep exhaustion at bay and a chewable orange baby aspirin (81 mg) as a sweet and modest hedge against a heart attack.

The term rookie doesn’t quite apply to Vito Schnabel. At 23, he may still live under his father’s roof — his magisterial living room in the Palazzo Chupi is studded with artwork by McDermott & McGough, Dan Colen, Ron Gorchov and Terence Koh — but as an art dealer, he is quickly fashioning himself more of an art-market prodigy than the prodigal son of the painter known as Julian Schnabel.

As Congress rushes this week to complete the most far-reaching financial reform plan in decades, the banking industry is mounting an 11th-hour end run, Eric Dash and Nelson D. Schwartz report in The New York Times.

BOSTON - When Victor Martinez took his place behind the plate for the Boston Red Sox on Saturday, something looked amiss. On his left hand was not a catcher's mitt, but a first baseman's glove.
The day’s action featured a lot of scoring, if only by Portugal, and plenty of physical play.
Jason Lee plays a cop with a passion for Elvis in a new crime drama beginning on Tuesday on TNT.

Dexter Filkins reports on a Congressional investigation that found that American taxpayers have inadvertently created a network of warlords across Afghanistan who are making millions of dollars escorting NATO convoys. These warlords operate outside the control of either the Afghan government or the American and NATO militaries.

TUESDAY'S PUZZLE - If you're one of those people who like word games ... Wait, you are. Right. Then you probably know all about the game in the center of the grid. To me, it's one of those rare games that is just as much fun if nobody bothers to keep score. Players take turns adding on to a growing sequence of letters. You lose if you complete a word or if you fail to create a new fragment that can begin a longer word. Look it up using your favorite Internet search engine if you'd like to find the details.

Peter R. Orszag will leave his job as the White House budget director in July, according to someone familiar with his plans, making him perhaps the first official to leave the Obama Cabinet and removing a major player from President Obama's economic team.

A number of responses to my column about the education I received at Classical High (a public school in Providence, RI) rehearsed a story of late-flowering gratitude after an earlier period of frustration and resentment. "I had a high school (or a college) experience like yours," the poster typically said, "and I hated it and complained all the time about the homework, the demands and the discipline; but now I am so pleased that I stayed the course and acquired skills that have served me well throughout my entire life."

In what has become his tradition within a tradition, President Obama for a third straight year seized on June's celebration of fathers to promote "a national conversation" about responsible fatherhood, infused with his own experiences as an abandoned son and now as a busy parent.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. - The Nets continued their search for a complementary big forward to center Brook Lopez on Monday by working out the college freshmen DeMarcus Cousins of Kentucky and Derrick Favors of Georgia Tech.
The new TNT procedural stars Jason Lee as a Memphis detective who sings on the side.

BP said Monday that it had so far spent about $2 billion in its response to the oil spill disaster in the Gulf of Mexico, including containment efforts, economic and environmental claims, and state and federal costs, The New York Times's Liz Robbins reports.
Intel has reached a legal cease-fire with the Federal Trade Commission.

As the debate over the financial regulatory bill nears an end in Congress, many on Wall Street are shifting their attention to Switzerland to see what new regulations will come out of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, the international banking watchdog.
Is the White House suddenly doubling down to try and keep President Obama's old United States Senate seat in Democratic hands?

One of the joys of Wimbledon is finding a match on the outer courts and settling in to watch. There's an intimacy to these matches, as you can sit in the first row and watch a match between two world class players who often battle through qualifying to earn a spot in the main draw.

In response to my column about big credit unions with loosey-goosey membership rules, one reader wrote in to chastise me for not offering more details on which credit unions specifically tended to have the best deals.
The Millburn Police Detective Bureau is investigating several recent burglaries in the township, including two more that occurred in the last week, department officials said today.

The Broadway productions "Memphis" and "Red" - the winners of the 2010 Tony Awards for best musical and best play, respectively - each enjoyed box-office bumps of about 20 percent last week in the immediate afterglow of the CBS telecast on June 13, according to Broadway box-office data released on Monday.

Because of international travel restrictions, the João Gilberto concert at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night as part of the CareFusion Jazz Festival has been canceled. George Wein, the producer of the festival, said in a statement: "I am heartbroken over this unfortunate situation. Joao Gilberto is one of the most important musical artists of our generation, and it has always been a privilege to present him at Carnegie Hall." Tickets will be refunded where they were purchased.
Following are responses from David Barstow, one of the reporters who examined the lax oversight of the oil rig's blowout preventer.

Booz Allen Hamilton, the consulting firm taken private less than two years ago by the Carlyle Group, is planning an initial public offering to raise as much as $300 million, Bloomberg News reports, providing another sign that the I.P.O. market appears to be thawing out from its chill earlier this year.

If it's Monday, Scorecard must be in Milan. Resort may have just wrapped for the ladies, but as our color-coded master fashion calendar reminds us, it's time to get up to speed on the spring 2011 men's-wear shows, which is why we've pulled double duty reading all the reviews so you don't have to. Between John Varvatos's 10th-anniversary rocker-chic redux and Dolce & Gabbana's 20th-anniversary Sicilian sartorial extravaganza, this weekend designers were taking a long look back. Yet it was Raf Simons's Koonsian pastiche for Jil Sander, which was actually shown in Florence last Thursday as part of Pitti Uomo, that blew everyone else out of the water, reminding us that granddad-like isn't necessarily chic. Celebration, indeed.

The amateur pantomime that is England's 2010 World Cup campaign took another theatrical turn on Monday, perhaps more entertaining in its way than the mercy flight of WAGs winging its way to South Africa in defiance of Coach Fabio Capello's ban on wives and girlfriends.
The five Democratic candidates vying to become New York's top prosecutor gathered together for the first time on Monday to make their cases.

Andrew J. Hall, the former Citigroup energy trader whose proposed $100 million bonus created an uproar about excessive Wall Street compensation, has raised $1.08 billion for an offshore version of his hedge fund, Bloomberg News reports.

Before Spain's 2-0 victory over Honduras on Monday moved it back into contention for a spot in the final 16, the nation's news media spilled a lot of ink, and pixels, defending the national team's captain and goalkeeper, Iker Casillas. As The Lede blog explained on Friday, last week Casillas was the victim of an apparently baseless rumor started by a report in The Times of London, which claimed that "many in Spain" said the team was in crisis because its keeper was too distracted by the beauty of his girlfriend, a sideline reporter for Spanish television, to do his job properly.
The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Gucci at Milan Fashion Week.

The new technologies from Microsoft, Nintendo and Sony provided the most important news from the Electronic Entertainment Expo last week, but there were plenty of exciting new games on display as well.

The new technologies from Microsoft, Nintendo and Sony provided the most important news from the Electronic Entertainment Expo in Los Angeles last week, but there were plenty of exciting new games on display as well. No one person is able to see anything close to everything at E3 - the show is just too big - but these are some of titles coming in the next year that appeared particularly interesting and impressive.

Hospital stays can be disorienting for any patient, but for some elderly patients the experience is particularly risky, triggering an unusual phenomenon called "hospital delirium.'' As New York Times reporter Pam Belluck explains, these frightening hallucinations can be triggered by medicine, infection, surgery or even simple medical procedures.
A bit late, but maybe worth the wait.

WIMBLEDON, England -- Taylor Dent of the United States serves, rushes the net, and volleys winners with the abandon of a 20th century player who doesn't realize the 21st century game of tennis favors duels from the baseline.

On Monday, a British court made public new charges against a man who had been convicted of killing a 2-year-old boy in 1993, when he was just 10 years old himself, and then released from prison in 2001 and given a new identity.

John Updike's papers may have gone to Harvard, but his typewriter could be yours. Christie's will auction off on Tuesday an Olympia "electric 65c" typewriter and metal typewriter cart that belonged to the late novelist. The estimate is $4,000-$6,000. The serial number indicates that Updike probably purchased the typewriter while his family lived in London, from 1968 to 1969, shortly after he wrote "Couples." He gave it to one of his daughters about 15 years before his death in 2009. A member of the writer's family is selling the typewriter now and will donate half the proceeds from the sale to the New York Public Library.

When did resort become a fully fledged season (like those divisions of the year, spring and fall, that actually represent a change in weather)? About that, we're not sure exactly. But as the fash pack has been busy since before Memorial Day taking in the 67 shows/presentations/European house reshowings/roving "street-sides," Scorecard has, as ever, kept tabs on all the critic talk for you. One thing's for certain: when reviewing collections intended expressly to lure the dollars of women who winter in the urban jungle, qualities like prettiness, wearableness and merchiness are suddenly very good things.

My column is on American gewürztraminer, a category that got me to wondering whether anybody drinks much gewürztraminer these days. I don't drink it too often myself, although I do love bringing a bottle of good gewürztraminer with me when I go to Phoenix Garden, one of my favorite places in New York for excellent Cantonese food.
The celebration of the summer solstice at Stonehenge was tempered by criticism of the British government's plan to cut financing for a visitors' center, The Guardian reported.

Just a quick note to say that since Nick's Thursday column, which proposed giant bomb-sniffing, Tuberculosis-detecting rats as alternatives to more traditional Father's Day gifts, Apopo, the organization behind the so-called HeroRATS, has received more than $150,000 in donations. And according to Mari Kuraishi, president of GlobalGiving.org, an online donations company that sponsors projects around the world like Apopo, an additional $30,000 went to non-rat-related enterprises.

The lawyer for City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook informed a federal judge on Monday that he might have a conflict of interest with a potential witness, which could further disrupt a case that has already been troubled by delays.

School's out, now what? That's the central question asked by this week's Critics' Pick, "Dazed and Confused," Richard Linklater's period look at high school life in 1976. Mr. Scott praises the film's soundtrack and Mr. Linklater's attention to authenticity when recreating the looks, clothes and mood of the era. He also makes note of the film's pacing, saying it "has a meandering, almost haphazard structure. You're not sure who you're going to run into next or where you're going to end up, which, of course, is what life is like when school is out." Have you seen "Dazed and Confused?" Please share your thoughts.
Two weeks ago, we wrote about Gary Lauder, a venture capitalist in California who had devised a new take on the stop sign, which he presented at a TED Talk in February.

At its board meeting on Tuesday, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is expected to approve an agreement under which it will be reimbursed by the city for the cost of building infrastructure below the planned performing arts center at ground zero. The construction of footings and foundations for the arts center has been estimated at $44 million. The authority, which owns the World Trade Center site, and the city have said that they are expecting that money to come from a $50 million fund controlled by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.
A winner has been selected in a contest sponsored by OgilvyOne Worldwide to find "the world's greatest salesperson" -- a person proficient enough in pitching to be able to sell a common brick.

WIMBLEDON, England -- A year ago, Stanislas Wawrinka of Switzerland fought Andy Murray of Scotland toe to toe in the first night match at Wimbledon, drawing cheers and shouts of approval as he was extending the British favorite to five sets under the new Center Court roof.

Back in 2004, when the Boston Red Sox were on their way to their first World Series in many years, I was going to be late to my one-on-one Portuguese class because the game was running long. I called my Portuguese teacher - now my friend -- Camila  and told her to meet me at the bar where I was watching.
The new issue of The New Yorker magazine might as well be called The Canadian. Yes, The Canadian.
As I have written here before, we have spent a lot of time cleaning out the garage and basement lately, a literal and psychic purging. (Remember that Dumpster I got for Mother's Day?)
In today's Personal Health column, Jane Brody explores whether repeated exposure to ultraviolet radiation through tanning has the potential to become addictive.
A. O. Scott looks back at Richard Linklater's film about the last day of school in 1976.
Several hundred yoga enthusiasts saluted the sun in Times Square Monday to mark the longest day of the year.
By some odd twist, oil gushers have come down in American cultural memory as a form of good news - evidence of riches found, like the popping of some geological champagne cork.
The New York Times announced on Monday that Arthur Brisbane, a longtime journalist, will become its new public editor. Here's an edited draft of the memo sent out by the company:
Win
Wednesday, June 16

In this week's edition of my column, The Appraisal, I go behind the camera with real estate photographers and learn the tricks of making apartments look great in listings. This is a big business: these photographs are the first images most buyers see of properties. Some apartments require subtle changes, like taking out clutter and slightly moving chairs. Others require photographers to completely clean out the apartments or to move all of the furniture. Then there are apartments that require nothing less than Photoshop to make them presentable.
Crunching on ice can be annoying to fellow diners. But now new research suggests it also may signal a health problem, writes Anahad O'Connor in today's "Really?" column.

Democrats in the House of Representatives said on Monday that they would agree to a Senate plan to make a proposed financial consumer watchdog part of the Federal Reserve, instead of an independent agency, Reuters reports.

On The New Old Age blog, writer Anne Underwood shares the story of her elderly father who left his retirement home to move in with his girlfriend. Her father called it "part of the adventure of life,'' but his daughter was worried about the toll the move might take on him physically and financially. She writes:

The odds remain slight that Congress will put a price on carbon across the whole economy. But there's still a chance that it may put a price on carbon for only power plants (but not for factories or transportation.)
Updated, 8:30 p.m. | Richard Epstein of the University of Chicago Law School takes on the positions of other panelists in this discussion. Scroll down to read his added comments.

Over drinks last week, a conservative journalist friend made a plausible case that Mike Huckabee - who was first out of the gate to criticize the Mitch Daniels "truce on social issues" trial balloon - should be considered the real front-runner for the Republican presidential nomination in 2012. Ariel Levy's profile of Huckabee, in this week's New Yorker, lines up plenty of reasons why this might be flat wrong, from Huckabee's proven inability to raise money or organize a ground game, to his perpetually-simmering war with the conservative establishment, to his tendency to self-pigeonhole (his protests to the contrary notwithstanding) as the candidate of Southern evangelicals and only Southern evangelicals. (There's also the fact that he might just be happier as a well-compensated entertainer than as a politician.) But Levy also captures many of the qualities that make Huckabee more formidable than many handicappers acknowledge: His immense charm and "relentless niceness," his intense bond with one of the G.O.P.'s largest constituencies, his high favorable numbers among Republican voters and his strength in early polls. And, of course, his ability to appear on any TV show, any time and anywhere, and charm the socks off the audience.

After my whimsical travels of the last week, it is good to come back to Numberplay (incidentally, we finally have this convenient URL that you can bookmark to get access to all Numberplay posts). In today's post, I will leave all whimsy aside, and show you that the universe we inhabit is stranger that our fictitious imaginings. Today we will explore a fundamental and almost unbelievable result of Quantum Mechanics (QM) through a set of simple puzzles. This famous result is "Bell's Interconnectedness Theorem" which was discovered by the physicist John Stewart Bell in 1964. Bell's theorem has been called by physicist Henry Stapp "the most profound discovery of Science." It is profound because it shows that the universe has the property of non-locality: two particles can be light years apart, yet they are linked to each other instantaneously. How instantaneously? Recent measurements have shown that this phenomenon occurs more than 10,000 times the speed of light! In order to show that the universe in non-local, Bell showed that a certain simple and obvious inequality - Bell's inequality - is violated. Amazingly, the only math that you need to understand this profound inequality is contained in the following simple problem.

The autocorrect feature in iPhones, Android phones and other smartphones go a long way toward erasing the inefficiency that comes from having no physical keyboard. You type a few letters of a word-or you mistype something-and the little autocorrect bubble appears, proposing a full completed (or corrected) alternative. On the iPhone, if you just keep typing, the suggestion replaces what you typed. (If the suggestion is wrong, you tap it to dismiss it.)

A 1,060-foot bridge over the Colorado River with a view of the Hoover Dam is set to open in November, Jennifer Steinhauer of The Times reports. In addition to offering a new vantage point, the bridge will allow drivers to bypass the "winding and often maddening journey along U.S. 93," the route that currently allows drivers to traverse the dam as well as the Nevada and Arizona border. "Tourists who forgo parking and taking an official tour instead opt for drive-by photography -- at times hanging out their car windows so they can get the best shot -- have always caused traffic snarls along the dam," Ms. Steinhauer writes. The bridge is to open in conjunction with the 75th anniversary of the dam, which drew 900,000 tourists last year.

The next season of "American Idol" isn't officially subtitled "The Search for the Next Justin Bieber," but one wonders if that teenage pop sensation had any influence on a newly announced adjustment to that reality contest's rules. On Monday the producers of "American Idol" announced that they will lower the minimum age of eligibility for the singing competition to 15, the "Idol" host Ryan Seacrest said on his official Web site. In previous years, the minimum age for "Idol" hopefuls had been 16, but now performers like Aaron Kelly and Haeley Vaughn (who were well shy of voting age when they appeared on the show's ninth season) will look like seasoned war horses compared to the 10th season's crop. Sorry, Larry Platt, but you still can't officially compete on the show: the maximum age remains 28.

O'BRIEN--Michael Charles, Jr.,MAI, SIOR, CRE 82, passed away on June 16, 2010. A Brooklyn native, he graduated from The College of the Holy Cross in 1949. He was a Lieutenant in the Navy's submarine service during the Korean War. After the Navy he joined M. C. O'Brien, Inc. and started a 60-year career back in Brooklyn. In addition to his wife, Ruth "Roostie" Finlen, of 54 years he is survived by his five children; Michael C. O'Brien, III of Floral Park, NY, Margaret Greason of New York, NY, Thomas J. O'Brien of Roxbury, NY, William P. O'Brien of Rockville Centre, NY and Ellen Bryceland of Bronxville, NY, 13 grandchildren and three sisters, Margaret Everett, Mary Lou Ortieg and Alice Ann Clifton. Visitation will take place at McGrath's Funeral Home, 20 Cedar Street, Bronxville, NY on Monday, June 21 at 2pm-4pm and 6pm-9pm. A Mass of Christian burial will take place on Tuesday, June 22 at 11am at Immaculate Conception Church, 8645 Edgerton Boulevard, Jamaica, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Brooklyn based non-profit, CAMBA, Inc. (www.camba.org)

Carlin. Friend to all, a kindergarten teacher at Donna Klein Jewish Academy, Boca Raton. Loved by all whose presence she graced. APPLBAUM--Rabbi Sidney, passed away on Friday afternoon, June 18, in New Brunswick, NJ. Born in Bentlyville, PA, Rabbi Applbaum grew up in Williamsburg, NY and was ordained at Yeshiva Chaim Berlin. He was appointed spiritual leader of Congregation Beth Judah in Brooklyn in 1947 and served there until his retirement in 1995. Rabbi Applbaum was instrumental in building the modern orthodox Jewish community both locally and nationally, establishing the Vaad Hakashruth of the Vaad HaRabanim of Flatbush in 1951, serving for 45 years, and founding the Tripartite Commission on Jewish Funeral Standards, of which he was chairman for 35 years. He served as Vice President of the Rabbinical Council of America for four terms. Rabbi Applbaum was predeceased by his first wife, the former Tovah Toporovsky. He is survived by his wife of 25 years, Carol Stone Applbaum, his four children, Yaakov Nisan, Alisa Weinrib, Isaac (Yitz) and Kalman, and ten grandchildren, his two stepsons, Elihu and Maurice Stone, and six step-grandchildren. Interment is Monday 3:30pm in Eretz Hachaim, Beit Shemesh, Israel. Shiva at 11 Mount Court, East Brunswick, NJ Tuesday through Saturday evening.

Services will be private.

KRISTOL--Pearl C.,of West Palm Beach, FL, and formerly of Wilmington, DE, died June 19, 2010, at age 98. She was active in the Jewish Federation of Delaware, Hadassah and Jewish Women International. Following the death of her beloved husband Abraham Kristol in 1990, she endowed The Kristol Center for Jewish Life, the Hillel Foundation at the University of Delaware, and continued to have an active interest in its progress. Mrs. Kristol is survived by her three sons and their wives, Daniel and Katherine, of Wilmington, Howard and Rochelle, of Wilmington and Boca Raton, FL, and David and Marjorie, of Summit, NJ; six grandchildren; and 12 great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at Congregation Beth Shalom, Wilmington, on Tuesday, June 22, at 12:30pm. In lieu of gifts of flowers, contributions in memory of Mrs. Kristol may be made to The Kristol Center for Jewish Life at the University of Delaware.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. - It was a Father's Day suitable for framing for Tom Watson, who played the course he first walked with his father for perhaps the last time on Sunday with his son, Michael, carrying his bag. ''It does complete the circle,'' said Watson, who received an exemption to the United States Open this year and is the only player to have competed in all five Opens held at Pebble Beach Golf Links. ''Winning here in '82 and calling my dad on Father's Day and then having my son caddy for me when I'm 60 years old. That's pretty special.''

REISMAN--Charles, 93, passed on June 19, 2010. Survived by wife, Gladys, three children, six grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Donations in lieu of flowers should be made to the Hadassah or the American Cancer Society.

SCHNUR--Bernard, age 96. Beloved husband of the late Miriam. Father of Wendy Kates (Howard), Myrna Kabnick (Michael) and the late Robert Schnur. Grandfather to Richard, Jill, Jamie and Michelle. Great-grandfather to Madeline and Marlee. You will be dearly missed.

Manute Bol, a towering Dinka tribesman who left southern Sudan to become one of the best shot blockers in the history of American basketball, then returned to his homeland to try to heal the wounds of a long, bloody civil war, died Saturday at the University of Virginia Medical Center in Charlottesville, according to Sally Jones, a spokeswoman for the hospital. He was 47 and lived in Olathe, Kan. The cause was severe kidney trouble and complications of a rare skin disorder known as Stevens-Johnson syndrome, said Tom Prichard, who runs Sudan Sunrise, a foundation that is building a school near Bol's birthplace in Turalei. Bol had been hospitalized since late May when he fell ill during a layover on a trip home from Sudan, Mr. Prichard said.

Survived by wife of 67 years, Sonia Weinberg Schwartz, and three sons: William Schwartz III (Nina), Arthur Jay Schwartz (Joyce), Robert Clay Schwartz (Terry); six grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

SLOAN--Lisa, dedicated mother to her young son, Charlie, and intelligent, passionate and loving daughter, sister, friend and colleague, passed away in her sleep early Saturday morning, June 12th. Lisa graduated from Bryn Mawr College and Columbia University School of Law. She was a Shareholder in the Corporate Group of the law firm, Greenberg Traurig, LLP. Lisa leaves behind a son, Charlie, her sister, Heather, her mother, Eleanor, and her brother, Joshua, his wife, Karen, and her nephews, Maxwell and Nathan and niece, Morgan. The funeral service for Lisa took place on Friday, June 18 at the Nickerson Funeral Home in Orleans, MA. There will also be a Memorial Service on Wednesday, June 23 in Philadelphia. In lieu of flowers, donations in her honor can be sent to the following: The Woodlynde School, 445 Upper Gulph Road, Strafford, PA 19087; Planned Parenthood of Southeastern Pennsylvania, 1144 Locust Street, Philadelphia, PA 19107; or The Women's Law Project, 125 South 9th Street, Suite 300, Philadelphia, PA 19107.

HARRIS--Ann Landau, passed away May 29, 2010. Everyone that you met loved and still loves you grandma! You were the best great-grandparent, grandparent, parent, wife, sister, aunt and friend. Everybody misses you but we know that you are in a better place. You had a youthful spirit and a kind and giving nature. You cared about everyone's needs before you cared about your own. You were always up to date with what was going on with your family, your community and the world at large. If everyone was like you, the world would definitely be a better place. You were so funny with the best stories to tell. You were the greatest and we hope you know that. Ephraim Poloner, On behalf of the Ann Harris Family

KAN-SCHWARTZ--Diana, renowned artist, author, teacher and long-time Greenwich Village resident, died in her home on May 3, 2010 at the age of 84. Beloved wife of the late Paul Schwartz and mother of her late son Sing-Si Schwartz. Diana was a prominent member of the National Arts Club, Salmagundi Club, Lotos Club, the American Watercolor Society, the National Academy of Design, and fellow of the Royal Society of Arts in London, among others. Her annual watercolor and calligraphy workshops were attended by loyal students from around the world. Her works were represented by John Whitney Payson of the Midtown Payson Galleries of Hobe Sound, FL, L.J. Wender of Fine Chinese Paintings in New York, Dyansen Gallery in Boston, MA and Dennis Rae of Fine Arts in San Francisco, CA. A memorial service will be held at the National Arts Club, Wednesday, June 23 from 6-8pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to either American Watercolor Society or American Cancer Society.
MILLER--Robert Douglas June 21,1970 - June 21, 1996 Remembered with love today and everyday. Mom, Dad and Rachel

SILVERMAN--Selma Bakst, died at age 83 on June 19, 2010. She was a most beloved wife, mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, sister, aunt, and friend. She brought beauty into the world and shared it with those around her. Born in Brooklyn, and a long-time resident of Roslyn and Sagaponack, she was an avid New Yorker who appreciated and relished the best the city had to offer. She was a woman of great style. She had a vibrant and keen intellect, was an avid reader, and was wonderfully articulate. An accomplished Life Master bridge player, a devotee of music, art, and books, an early and strong advocate for women's rights, civil rights, and social justice, she gave her deepest love to her family - her "proudest achievement." She is survived by her family who loved her deeply: her husband of 63 years, Alvin Silverman; her children, Barbara Berke, Andrew Silverman and his wife, Molly Paul, and Nancy Silverman and her husband, Benjamin Nathans; her sister Adelaide Wells and brother Allan Bakst and their families; and her eight grandchildren (Jessica, Sally, Jennifer, Nicholas, Will, Gabriel, Ilana and Dora) and two great-grandchildren (Caroline and Emily). We will all miss her greatly and will cherish her memory forever. Her memory can be honored by donations to two organizations she whole-heartedly supported: Emily's List (www.*emilyslist*.org) and Planned Parenthood of Nassau County (http://www.plannedparenthood.org/nassau-county/index.htm).

Two typewriters associated with famous writers, but not with their most famous works, sold for just above their low estimates at Christie's on Tuesday. Jack Kerouac's last typewriter, a Hermes 3000 manual that he used from 1966 until his death in 1969, brought $22,500 at the auction, having been estimated at $20,000-$30,000. Meanwhile, a typewriter that belonged to John Updike from the late 1960s until 15 years before his death sold for $4,375, having been estimated at $4,000-$6,000. (Updike produced several major novels in this period, but Christie's didn't determine whether he actually typed them on this machine.) Updike's typewriter was being sold by a member of his family; half the proceeds will go to the New York Public Library.

When the 41st Art Basel closed last Sunday, 62,500 people had passed through its doors in a week. That was a record number. They were artists, private collectors, consultants, artists, museum trustees and curators, historians and critics, and they looked at art in 300 galleries from 36 countries. These are the only solid statistics. No one tracks how much money changes hands at these assemblies of art and fraternity, but a conservative guess would be a few hundred million dollars. Considering how many people plunk down $35,000 for a couture handbag, taking home a more unique $2 million Paul McCarthy or a $15 million Picasso doesn't seem like such a stretch in Basel.

The conversion of unused office space into a gallery is nothing new in Berlin's Mitte district. But MADE, a new art center opened by three of the city's creative ringleaders (and sleekly designed by the architect Alexis Dornier), is aiming to do something out of the ordinary. A collaboration between Philip Gaedicke, Nico Zeh, Tadi Rock and Luise Biesalski, MADE provides free studio space to emerging artists, pays for their materials and then puts on a show of new work - and it will even throw in some publicity. The only catch is that they have to try something new. In other words, a photographer can't just take pictures and a painter can't just paint.

"[Early] rejections steeled Updike in his growing belief that American writers had grown infatuated with European modernists and should instead pay closer attention to their own time and place ...  'We do not need men like Proust and Joyce; men like this are a luxury, an added fillip that an abundant culture can produce only after the more basic literary need has been filled,' Updike wrote to his parents in 1951, when he was 19. 'This age needs rather men like Shakespeare, or Milton, or Pope; men who are filled with the strength of their cultures and do not transcend the limits of their age, but, working within the times, bring what is peculiar to the moment to glory. We need great artists who are willing to accept restrictions, and who love their environments with such vitality that they can produce an epic out of the Protestant ethic' - a prescient formulation of what he would later achieve in the Rabbit novels and his Pennsylvania short stories. 'Whatever the many failings of my work," he concluded, "let it stand as a manifesto of my love for the time in which I was born.'"

The deceptive marketing tactics used to sell equity-indexed annuities have been well documented. In case you haven't heard of these annuities, they're a complex financial product that promises a guaranteed return. Salesmen often make house calls, and they've been known to lure senior citizens to their so-called "educational" seminars by promising them a free meal. In many cases, elderly investors were sold products that were simply wrong for their circumstances, while the agent walked away with a hefty commission.

"If I were to put a dress on, I wouldn't look like a woman," says Sophie Hicks. "I'd look like a man in drag." The sternly chic British architect began wearing mannish suits as a fashion editor at glossies like Tatler and British Vogue. Then, in the late 1980s, she quit her editorial job and went to architecture school. Sure, high fashion frustrated her. (Madonna, at the very last moment, once bailed on a big photo shoot that Hicks had dreamed up with Azzedine Alaïa.) But Hicks's concerns about the industry went deeper. "I was only 26, and I started seeing fashion go in circles," she says, noting that the legends she worked alongside - like Grace Coddington - "must have seen the same things go around 12 dozen times." Hicks's biography has fabulous footnotes: She appeared in a Fellini film ("Intervista," in 1986), designed a Picasso exhibit for the Royal Academy of Arts, and made a perfume bottle for Paul Smith. Her most famous buildings are, perhaps predictably, fashion boutiques. She has designed shops for Yohji Yamamoto in Paris, Paul Smith in London and 100 or so Chloé stores, including flagships in Tokyo, New York and Hong Kong. Today, she's at work on a small home in South Kensington. For that building, she's invented a "geometric building block" with the British brick maker Ibstock. "It's a bit like mesh," she says of the partially translucent brick. "So you'll get little glimpses of what's going on outside."

Austerity -- it's moving to Europe, so you might as well get used to it. But aside from cuts and more cuts, what does it mean exactly? With an odd poetic justice, it's a word with Greek roots, meaning harsh and bitter, not far from the taste people will have in their mouths when the new budgets start kicking in. In the last century, it made the rounds with the wartime policies of the 40s, but this new rationing doesn't have a western front to justify it -- just yesterday's glut.

ENSLEY--Charles Stephen, President of Local 371 for 26 years, died on Friday afternoon, June 18, 2010, knowing that his wife, sister and nephew were at his side. Born in Birmingham, Alabama 69 years ago, Charles grew up amid the civil rights campaigns of the 1960s. Some of his principles came from his father, John, who in the 1950s led African-American workers against brutal opposition in a long battle for equal pay at the Birmingham News. Charles had unionism, equality and integrity in his DNA. Growing up in Birmingham as the youngest of four children, Charles learned the importance of individual goals and group goals as well. He graduated from Parker High, then the largest black high school in the country, and went on to attend Howard University in Washington, DC, where Stokely Carmichael was a fellow classmate and his instructors included some of the nation's top black professors such as E. Franklin Frazier, Bernard Fall, and Donald McHenry who went on to become the Ambassador to the UN under President Jimmy Carter. Charles Ensley and his wife Annette moved to New York in 1965. He became a caseworker in the Bureau of Child Welfare Bedford-Stuyvesant office and also worked on the side tutoring kids in Harlem and educating welfare rights groups. In 1982, after a hotly contested election, with more than 70% of the vote, he became President of Local 371 and began demanding more democracy and financial accountability in the union. Ensley was an innovative, independent leader with high integrity. He had an amazing sense of humor and a quick wit. He fought with vigor and intelligence and was proud of winning dignity and job protections for his members and never waivered in his steadfast determination to pursue a progressive agenda. He believed that diversity is a major source of the strength of the Union. Black, White and Latino, men and women - blue collar and professional the common ground is the union and defense of the rights of every single member. Under his leadership as a tough negotiator Local 371 became the "Mighty, Mighty Union" and membership grew from 9,000 to 17,000 members. He received numerous awards for his work, among them the prestigious Ellis Island Medal of Honor in 2001. He served on a number of Boards, including the AFSCME International Executive Board. Ensley who lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan enjoyed jazz, theatre, and reading that ranged from Russian literature to the French existentialists, with a particular interest in black history and the development of the black novel. He was a collector of black art and surrounded himself with some of the well known and lesser-known artists from around the world. Ensley is survived by his wife, Annette Ensley; his sister, Barbara Jean Ensley; his two nephews, Bradley Joel Funnye, Clarence Del Monte Funnye, a niece, Imani Austin; and cousins in Portland, Oregon, Denver, Colorado and Austin, Texas. His parents, John and Gladys Ensley, his sister, Mary Elizabeth Goldson and brother John Ensley preceded him in death. Ensley requested that there be no funeral or memorial services. He asked that everyone, particularly Local 371 members, use time, energy and resources in maintaining the Mighty, Mighty Union.

SILVERMAN--Selma Bakst, died at age 83 on June 19, 2010. She was a most beloved wife, mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, sister, aunt, and friend. She brought beauty into the world and shared it with those around her. Born in Brooklyn, and a long-time resident of Roslyn and Sagaponack, she was an avid New Yorker who appreciated and relished the best the city had to offer. She was a woman of great style. She had a vibrant and keen intellect, was an avid reader, and was wonderfully articulate. An accomplished Life Master bridge player, a devotee of music, art, and books, an early and strong advocate for women's rights, civil rights, and social justice, she gave her deepest love to her family - her "proudest achievement." She is survived by her family who loved her deeply: her husband of 63 years, Alvin Silverman; her children, Barbara Berke, Andrew Silverman and his wife, Molly Paul, and Nancy Silverman and her husband, Benjamin Nathans; her sister Adelaide Wells and brother Allan Bakst and their families; and her eight grandchildren (Jessica, Sally, Jennifer, Nicholas, Will, Gabriel, Ilana and Dora) and two great-grandchildren (Caroline and Emily). We will all miss her greatly and will cherish her memory forever. Her memory can be honored by donations to two organizations she whole-heartedly supported: Emily's List (www.*emilyslist*.org) and Planned Parenthood of Nassau County (http://www.plannedparenthood.org/nassau-county/index.htm).

Early each morning I deal myself a daily hand of pills: Wellbutrin (450 milligrams) and Zoloft (200 mg) to ply the capricious oceans of postcancer depression, Provigil (200 mg) to keep exhaustion at bay and a chewable orange baby aspirin (81 mg) as a sweet and modest hedge against a heart attack. As the pills clatter to the kitchen counter, the ghosts start to gather. They are the shades of the rugged and bitter men who helped shape me as a child - Great-Grandpa Ora and Grandpa Bub, Uncle Lloyd and Great-Uncle Billy, to name a few - and they're scowling. A real man, you see, isn't supposed to take pills to ease what ails him. Even aspirin was suspect when I grew up, in rural New Hampshire.

Many of us work in smoke-free offices, eat in smoke-free restaurants, even drink in smoke-free bars or outdoor cafes. But if we live in an apartment, should the whole building also be smoke free? In an essay this week in The New England Journal of Medicine, public health and legal experts call for banning smoking in all public housing complexes, even within individual units. They say there is no safe level of exposure to passive smoke, and that even if one person in the building smokes, others are exposed to secondhand smoke and to toxic gases and carcinogens from tobacco.

Monday, June 14 We time our activities in Vietnam to track those of the monkeys. Our usual pattern is to start to stir at 4 a.m., getting the fire going for breakfast (usually sticky rice or noodle soup). Several of us look over the maps and determine what areas to cover as well as which teams will go where. We try to be on our way early in the morning because our best chance of finding monkeys is when they are active. Doucs do not vocalize as frequently as other primates, so we rarely detect them by their calls. Generally, we hear leaves moving as animals jump from one branch to another; so if we are quiet, patient, and lucky enough to be nearby when they are moving, we are able to find groups.

10 P.M. (13, 49) WILLIAM KUNSTLER: DISTURBING THE UNIVERSE (2009) As children, Emily and Sarah Kunstler idolized their father, William, below, who had marched with Martin Luther King Jr. and defended the Chicago Seven and American Indians protesting at Wounded Knee, S.D. But as teenagers they grew increasingly disenchanted as he chose to represent terrorists and rapists and even embraced John Gotti in front of the courthouse press corps. ''P.O.V.'' begins its 23rd season with this documentary, in which the sisters try to reconcile their father's past with the wild-haired, media-hungry man -- who liked to compare himself to Michelangelo's statue of David -- they knew in their youth. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden called the film ''a refresher course on the history of American left-wing politics in the 1960s and '70s as well as an affectionate personal biography of Kunstler.'' He added, ''Although the film, with its home movies and family reminiscences, portrays him as a heroic crusader for justice, it is by no means a hagiography of a man who earned widespread contempt late in his career for defending pariahs.'' 8 P.M. (History) WHO REALLY DISCOVERED AMERICA? Nearly a dozen cultures --Chinese, Japanese, Polynesians, Norse, Welsh, Irish and Ancient Hebrews, among them -- have tales of discovering the New World woven into their histories. But few have appeared in American history books. In this special, researchers reconstruct ships, trace routes, test artifacts and analyze blood to answer the question of who was here first.

A picture caption on Saturday with the Shortcuts column, about the drawbacks of teenage popularity, misstated the findings of a survey described in the column. The survey, conducted by Joseph P. Allen, a psychology professor at the University of Virginia, found that the more popular teenagers were more likely get into trouble, including by substance abuse; he did not cite high-status teenagers like cheerleaders and football heroes. (He defined popularity by likability, not by social status.) The error was repeated in a capsule summary of the article.

The Times's Stephen Farrell checked in from Baghdad during the United States' World Cup match on Wednesday, where Iraqis found unity in backing a fellow Arab nation, Algeria. Battling the summer heat, blackouts and security scares, Iraqis watched the United States celebrate Landon Donovan's last-minute goal in silence, while the announcer consoled disappointed viewers, "Nevermind." With the Iraq national team having failed to reach the World Cup, most of the fans in Baghdad said they supported Algeria for sporting reasons and Arab solidarity, but others shared a different reasoning.

So, many of the questions asked of Wall, Cousins and Patterson concerned how the Wildcats managed not to win this year's N.C.A.A. title.
Around midnight last Friday the shoeless prisoner was roused from a nap and strapped into a chair. The guards put a patch over his heart, the firing squad's target from 25 feet. Any last words?

The Keys to the City art project, conceived by the Brooklyn artist Paul Ramírez Jonas, offers participants a key that grants access to generally off-limits parts of the city. One participant, Lauren Burke, is using her key to set up blind dates with guys at each location and blog about it.

9:54 p.m. | Updated Let's make it official: "Don't Stop Believin'," the 1981 Journey power ballad that has become a cultural touchstone -- for "The Sopranos," Hillary Rodham Clinton, "Glee," rainforest benefits, to name a few examples -- should be the anthem for the American soccer team and its fans. Maybe it's not as inspirational as Liverpool's "You'll Never Walk Alone," but it's all-American, cheesy, stadium rock at its best/worst and can't be ruined by spectators or bar patrons (drunk, optimistic or both).
No matter what Apple does to improve the iPhone, some people will continue to hate it.
Day 2 of the John Isner-Nicolas Mahut match was on ESPN2 on Wednesday when it switched to ESPNU at 2:26 p.m. Eastern, replaced by Australia's 2-1 win over Serbia in the World Cup.

Time's press office released the following statement on Josh Ozersky's column about having chefs cater his wedding, and on Mr. Ozersky's failure to tell readers that both the food and venue were free.

The architecture firm Polshek Partnership, which is responsible for the renovations of Carnegie Hall, the Brooklyn Museum, City Center and the Public Theater, will from now on call itself Ennead, the firm is to announce on Thursday. The name, a Greek term for a group of nine deities in Egyptian mythology, reflects the firm's reconfiguration as a collective of nine partners.
WIMBLEDON, England -- The electronic scoreboard went haywire at 47-47 but the humans stood up pretty well for the longest match in tennis history.

When Landon Donovan scored in stoppage time to rescue the national soccer team from elimination and sent the Americans to the Round of 16, it was just before noon on the East Coast, just before 9 a.m. on the West Coast, and just plain early in general across the United States. But Americans celebrated the same way, wherever they were.

Updated, June 24 | The longest day of the year has passed, but warm red and gold sunsets await. As the summer lights go down, the perfect ambiance for watching films on rooftops, grassy parks and piers is set.
Luscious roses like Rosanna, Aloha, Red Corsair and Amadeus are all on display.
A cottage in the Catskills that she renovated herself fulfills a dream for a woman who was once homeless.

The University of California, Berkeley on Wednesday announced the selection of the New York firm Diller Scofidio + Renfro to design a new Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive, the university's second attempt at the project. Last year, it abandoned plans for a $200 million, 140,000-square-foot museum designed by the Japanese architect Toyo Ito because it would have been too expensive; the budget for the new version is $95 million.
The story of how the hair veteran revolutionized hair styling.

GroundLink, which provides global transportation services, had been growing at an annual rate of 40 percent. It had 140 employees and expected annual revenues to hit $30 million. It borrowed $10 million to finance its growth. And then, in July 2008, corporate travel went off a cliff. With interest payments and vendor payments coming due, its chief executive, Alex Mashinsky, instituted what he calls "The Yes Campaign." Watch the video below to see how he turned the company around.
A game fraught with tension ended happily for the United States soccer team and its fans.

Embarking on a bit of a charm offensive, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change just released the names of more than 800 scientists selected to take part in writing its fifth assessment report on climate change, due out in 2014. The panel is charged with releasing periodic reports summarizing the state of knowledge about climate change as a guide to policy makers.

Gov. Christopher J. Christie appeared on the Fox Business Network with Neil Cavuto earlier today, where he discussed the state's budget, his relationship with teachers and why he is not interested in running for president -- among many other topics. The following is a transcript of that interview, provided by Fox Business Network. It's long, but is provided unedited, in the belief that it may be of interest to many Local readers.

Henrik Lundqvist, the New York Rangers goalie, has sold his 1,300-square-foot two-bedroom on West 83rd Street. The price was not available, but he was asking $1.75 million. Read more in Real Estate.

Mets pitcher Johan Santana was accused of sexual assault near his home in Fort Myers, Fla., in October. The police investigated but did not bring charges against him, citing lack of evidence.

There's something oddly exhilarating about baking a great loaf of bread. But unless you're a seasoned baker or a no-kneadist, it's not a feeling you get to experience that often. Thanks to the new "River Cottage Bread Handbook" from Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall and the River Cottage baker Daniel Stevens, I was quickly able to master that barely considered breakfast staple, the English muffin. Thomas, be afraid.
Tuesday, June 22

President Obama's removal of Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal as commander of American forces in Afghanistan injected new uncertainties into relations between the United States and the Afghan president, Hamid Karzai, who had urged American leaders to let General McChrystal remain in place. As Helene Cooper and Jack Healy report, General McChrystal had proved to be one of the few Western leaders who could work well with President Karzai.

Martha Clarke has won what is described as the largest yearly prize given to a modern dance choreographer, the $50,000 Scripps/ADF award, the American Dance Festival said Wednesday. Ms. Clarke, 66, is also a director, known for weaving together music, dance, visual art and texts. The festival on July 5 is presenting the premiere of her work "Angel Reapers," which is based on the life of Ann Lee, the founder of the Shaker movement.

Last year, my wife and I had a terrific Sunday lunch at our London friend Liz Murray's apartment (RvrVu of the Thames and all). Even though ten months or so have passed since we scoured our plates with bread, knife blades and fingers, I still think of an aromatic sweet-tart-spicy gooseberry relish she served with a pork roast. I'd extracted the recipe from her at the time, but since I couldn't immediately lay my hands on two of its ingredients - bottled elderflower cordial and the gooseberries themselves - I filed it away for future reference.

Not every creative director can be a Tom Ford, distilling two decades of sexy design into a cool cocktail of stylish cinematography, earning an Oscar nomination in the process. But that isn't stopping everyone from trying. In a time when the iPad has eclipsed the September issue, and editorial channels are growing while advertising page numbers are shrinking, luxury labels have to promote their collections somehow. The result? A fashion film movement, in full swing.

In Wednesday's paper, I wrote about Jean Hill, who persuaded her fellow voters in Concord, Mass., to ban sales of bottled water there. The town of about 17,000 people is more environmentally conscious than most - it is home to Walden Pond, after all - but many who support the ban in theory are calling it impractical.
Representative Joe L. Barton will keep his spot as the top Republican on the House Energy and Commerce Committee in spite of his apology to BP at a hearing last week.

For decades the Kentucky poet, critic, and farmer Wendell Berry has advocated personal activism on behalf of the environment. There should not be a "split between what we think and what we do," he has written. "Once our personal connection to what is wrong becomes clear, then we have to choose: we can go on as before, recognizing our dishonesty and living with it the best we can, or we can begin the effort to change the way we think and live."

With impressive sales of his debut album, the rapper Drake leads a wavelet of new releases on the Billboard album chart. Drake's "Thank Me Later" (Aspire/Young Money/Cash Money) sold 447,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It was the third biggest opening week of the year, after Sade (502,000) and Lady Antebellum (481,000).

Thanks to Jeroen Koolhaas and Dre Urhahn, one of Rio's bleakest neighborhoods now has a permanent rainbow. As part of their project "O Morro" (which literally translated means "the hill" but really signifies the presence of "the slum"), the Dutch artists have enlisted the community to transform the facades of 34 houses (about 7,000 square meters!) into a colorful community art project. Local residents who picked up a brush received a small salary (the painting took about a month) and an education in the production process. Koolhaas and Urhahn, who have been painting favelas for the past two years as part of a greater initiative to transform the hillside slums into places that residents are proud to live in, plan to return to Brazil to finish painting the entire hill.

House negotiators working to complete legislation to overhaul the nation's financial regulatory system have agreed to drop a proposal for a $150 billion fund that would be used to liquidate failing financial companies, The New York Times's David M. Herszenhorn reports from Washington.

Just when it looked like the United States team was headed home, Landon Donovan pounced, and the United States won. The United States won Group C and advanced to the Round of 16, where they will play Ghana on Saturday. It marks the first time the United States team won a World Cup group since 1930, the inaugural tournament, in Uruguay.

In May, I wrote about an endangered Kemp's Ridley sea turtle off the coast of Padre Island National Seashore in Texas, highlighting the danger that the gulf oil spill poses to these ancient endangered animals. Since then, hundreds of Kemp's Ridley and other sea turtles have been found stranded or dead, some of them covered in oil, although it is unclear whether the oil played a role in their deaths.

DC Comics, the home of Superman, announced two digital publishing and distribution initiatives on Wednesday. The company has teamed up with comiXology to produce a DC Comics App and store for the iPhone, iPod Touch and iPad devices. Digital versions of DC Comics will also be available on the Sony PlayStation Network and the Comics by comiXology app and Web site. The PlayStation platform opens with more than 80 comics and will add more than 50 issues per month, while comiXology begins with more than 100 titles and will add another 100 per month. Both platforms share a tiered pricing structure of 99 cents to $2.99 per issue. Newsarama.com has a list of the issues currently available, including two free comics that tell the origin stories of Superman and Batman.

According to a study published this spring in the journal Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise, people who exercise for more than about two hours at a time can benefit from sports drinks. Most of us know that, of course. The carbohydrates in the drinks provide immediate fuel, which allows our bodies to avoid dipping into its own energy stores, meaning that, theoretically, you can exercise longer or more intensively before running out of fuel. But few people, in practice, can or will drink enough calories during a long workout to benefit significantly, the study authors suggest. The volume of fluid needed is, to say the least, daunting. Achieving the ideal "carbohydrate-intake rates," the authors write, requires toting and stomaching about a half gallon of a typical sports drink every hour. Good luck with that.
