SILVERMAN--Selma Bakst, died at age 83 on June 19, 2010. She was a most beloved wife, mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, sister, aunt, and friend. She brought beauty into the world and shared it with those around her. Born in Brooklyn, and a long-time resident of Roslyn and Sagaponack, she was an avid New Yorker who appreciated and relished the best the city had to offer. She was a woman of great style. She had a vibrant and keen intellect, was an avid reader, and was wonderfully articulate. An accomplished Life Master bridge player, a devotee of music, art, and books, an early and strong advocate for women's rights, civil rights, and social justice, she gave her deepest love to her family - her "proudest achievement." She is survived by her family who loved her deeply: her husband of 63 years, Alvin Silverman; her children, Barbara Berke, Andrew Silverman and his wife, Molly Paul, and Nancy Silverman and her husband, Benjamin Nathans; her sister Adelaide Wells and brother Allan Bakst and their families; and her eight grandchildren (Jessica, Sally, Jennifer, Nicholas, Will, Gabriel, Ilana and Dora) and two great-grandchildren (Caroline and Emily). We will all miss her greatly and will cherish her memory forever. Her memory can be honored by donations to two organizations she whole-heartedly supported: Emily's List (www.*emilyslist*.org) and Planned Parenthood of Nassau County (http://www.plannedparenthood.org/nassau-county/index.htm).

7 P.M. (SNY) JERRY SEINFELD CALLS THE NEW YORK METS Mr. Seinfeld, below, will join the Mets announcers Gary Cohen and Keith Hernandez in the SNY broadcast booth for at least three innings as the team takes on the Detroit Tigers at Citi Field -- a Father's Day gift from Mr. Seinfeld's wife, Jessica, to fulfill her husband's longtime dream. It's a reunion, sort of. In 1992 Mr. Hernandez guest starred in a two-part ''Seinfeld'' episode called ''The Boyfriend,'' in which he asked Jerry to move the furniture while he wooed Elaine. In a subplot, when Kramer and Newman accused Mr. Hernandez of spitting on them after a Mets game, Jerry came to his hero's defense by devising a ''second-spitter'' theory. The role, which occurred after Mr. Hernandez's retirement from baseball, ''gave me a second shelf life, it's just incredible,'' he recently told Ken Belson of The New York Times. But he refuses to watch the episode ''because I thought I stunk.'' Now, he has a question for Mr. Seinfeld: What did you really think of my performance on the show? Tune in for the answer. 6 P.M. (Fox Business Network) CAVUTO Neil Cavuto interviews Gov. Christopher J. Christie of New Jersey about battling unions, his pledge to reduce state taxes and other topics.

A headline on Friday about adjustments that Israel announced to its blockade of Gaza referred imprecisely to the effect the revised policy would have on food entering the region. While Israel will indeed ''allow the entry of food,'' this will not be the first time it has done so during the three-year blockade. It has always allowed some types of food into Gaza; the latest change will lift restrictions that were in place on some foodstuffs.

CASSEROLES of all types tend to travel, freeze and reheat well, whether you are starting a co-op, cooking for a crowd or just using weekends to cook for the week. Examples include chilaquiles, enchiladas, spanakopita, gratins of all varieties, savory bread puddings, lasagna Bolognese and any number of other baked or stuffed pastas. Soups, stews and chili make sense in this format, as do braised meats, roast chicken, meatloaf or meatballs. Food served at room temperature, like poached chicken and salmon, work well, especially when accompanied by a spicy or creamy sauce.

ZAMANSKY--Arthur. The Workmen's Circle MultiCare Center mourns the loss of our Board member and Treasurer, Arthur Zamansky. BOND--Calvin G.,of Oswego, NY, Past Grand Master of Masons in New York State from 1984-1986, passed away June 19, 2010, after a long battle with cancer. He was 85 years old. Mr. Bond became a Freemason in Oswego Lodge (now Lake City Lodge) No. 127 in 1947, going on to serve as Master of the Lodge in 1954, and other Masonic offices in the district surrounding Oswego. Mr. Bond was also active in Masonic-related orders, including the Royal Arch Masons, in which he served as state-wide Grand High Priest in 1979; the Knights Templar, where he served as Commander of Ontario Commandery in 1975; and the Ancient and Accepted Scottish Rite, under whose jurisdiction Mr. Bond was awarded the 33rd degree in 1977. Following his tenure as Grand Master, Mr. Bond was appointed to the office of Grand Lecturer in 1988, an office which gave him the opportunity to travel to Masonic lodges across the state. Mr. Bond struck an imposing and impressive figure, as his height and his distinctive voice gave authority and drama to his educational presentations. He retired as Grand Lecturer in 1999. Mr. Bond was a graduate of State University College at Oswego, and worked as a controller and accountant at Cyclotherm Corporation and the Crane Company, in mid-state New York. He retired from Oswego Package Boiler Company in 1980, and became a private financial and management consultant, while devoting the bulk of his time to Masonic activities. He was active in his Episcopal church and a member of numerous civic and professional associations. Mr. Bond is survived by his loving wife of sixty years, Constance. Memorial Donations may be made to the Masonic Brotherhood Fund, 71 West 23rd Street, New York, NY 10010.

MAGRAM--Saul. The Lauder family and The Estee Lauder Companies are deeply saddened by the passing of our beloved former General Counsel, Saul Magram. Saul's unique intelligence, strategic thinking and warmth created a legacy of business success and enduring friendships during his 31 years at ELC. Saul passed away at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Florida after suffering a brief illness. Saul was a native New Yorker and a magna cum laude graduate of Harvard College and Harvard Law School. After law school, Saul was commissioned as an officer in the U.S. Navy. He joined The Estee Lauder Companies as Secretary, Corporate Counsel in 1968 and soon thereafter became its first General Counsel. Saul was integral to our growth, working closely with Mrs. Estee Lauder, Leonard Lauder and Ronald Lauder. He was instrumental in helping to take our Company public in 1995. Saul was equally passionate in supporting causes and organizations in the arts, education and nature. Saul was a valuable mentor, advisor, advocate, philanthropist and dear friend. Our thoughts are with his family and many friends. Saul had a genuine zest for life, a warm heart and generous soul. He will be remembered with deep love by his former colleagues.

Serious wine lovers would as soon pour a fine wine with artichokes as they would drink it from a paper cup. Artichokes contain cynarin, a compound with an oddly sweet aftertaste that can distort the flavor of wine, especially red. But during a tasting of American dry gewürztraminers, I thought about a superb artichoke dish I had recently at Nick & Toni's in East Hampton, N.Y. It was made with just the fleshy hearts and stems, roasted in a wood oven and slathered with garlic butter, cheese and bread crumbs.

HARRIS--Ann Landau, passed away May 29, 2010. Everyone that you met loved and still loves you grandma! You were the best great-grandparent, grandparent, parent, wife, sister, aunt and friend. JOHANNESBURG -- France exited in disgrace from the World Cup on Tuesday with no victories and little sympathy for a team that infamously used an intentional handball to get into the tournament and self-destructed on the way out. Les Bleus, as the French team is known, played the final 65-plus minutes a man short after midfielder Yoann Gourcuff was ejected for elbowing an opponent in the head.

Late goals from Martin Dimichelis and Martin Palermo preserved Argentina's perfect 3-0-0 record in Group B with a comfortable 2-0 win over Greece in Polokwane Tuesday night. Argentina won Group B with the maximum nine points and will face Mexico in the round of 16 on Sunday. Argentina needed only to avoid a heavy defeat to progress. Coach Diego Maradona made seven changes to the team that beat South Korea 4-1 last Saturday. He handed the captain's armband to Lionel Messi, who gave a commanding midfield performance alongside the veteran Juan Sebastian Veron.

Michael Max Fleming, a jazz bass violinist who has been teaching with the Jazzmobile organization for more than 20 years, practicing in his home in the Bronx, where he keeps the art objects, mostly African ritual totems, that he collects. Mr. Fleming, who was raised in Cincinnati, said he had wanted to be a bass singer, but his voice was too high. ''That's probably why I chose to play the bass violin,'' he said. His mother, Rebecca, played the piano, and his aunt Clara Harvey was a violinist. ''When she opened up the violin case,'' Mr. Fleming said, ''I smelled the rosin for the first time. That was a vivid memory.'' He began playing the bass violin in high school, and he came to New York in 1963. ''There was a time in New York when you could play six days a week,'' Mr. Fleming said. Now, he occasionally plays at the Kitano on Park Avenue, he said. Earlier pictures in the series are at nytimes.com/lens.

In a stirring match worthy of dredging tears from both sides by its conclusion, South Korea found its dream while Nigeria exited the World Cup with some fresh, near-miss nightmares. The Taeguk Warriors, solidifying the credentials they built with a brazen run to the semifinals in the 2002 World Cup in South Korea and Japan, reached their first knockout stage of a World Cup on foreign soil when they rebounded from a 1-0 deficit, took a 2-1 lead, watched Nigeria match them at 2-2 on a penalty in the 69th minute, then held on with heaving lungs. As Group B runners-up, they will meet Group A winners Uruguay in the round of 16 while Group B winners Argentina play Group A runners-up Mexico.

KAY--Stanley Martin Kaufman, 86, passed away peacefully in his home on June 21, 2010. In his 70 plus year career, Stanley enjoyed successes as a drummer, percussionist, artist manager, creative director, conductor, arranger and composer. After serving in the Marine Corps during World War II, Stanley rose to musical prominence in the mid 1940's as the back-up drummer and manager for the Buddy Rich Band. He was also drummer for such headline acts as Josephine Baker, Patty Paige and Frankie Lane. He was a creator, manager and conductor for the world-renowned "Hines, Hines & Dad," continuing to manage Maurice Hines as well as stars such as Michelle Lee and Paul Burke. In the decades to follow, Stanley became Entertainment Director of the New York Yankees, a position he served proudly throughout his life. In 1992 Stanley founded and was the creative force behind Sherrie Maricle & The DIVA Jazz Orchestra, a band that will carry on his extraordinary musical legacy. Stanley is survived by his sister, Sybil Goday, niece Mace Goday, grand niece Sybil Happy Goday, as well as the thousands of lives he touched with his extraordinary generosity, kindness, understanding and compassion. A memorial service will be held on Thursday June 24, 2010 at 11:45am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., New York City, 212-362-6600.

Vukosa, 2508 Gerald Way, San Jose, CA 95125 for St. Johns Church Stivan, Croatia.

The National Endowment for the Arts will present 18 lifetime achievement awards on Friday in the fields of opera, jazz, and folk and traditional arts. The honorees include the composer Philip Glass, for opera, and five members of the Marsalis family, for jazz. Each award comes with $25,000. Besides Branford, Delfeayo, Ellis, Jr., Jason, and Wynton Marsalis, the other 2010 Jazz Masters are Orrin Keepnews, a writer and record producer; Hubert Laws, a flutist; David Liebman, a saxophonist and flutist; and Johnny Mandel, a composer-arranger. The honorees in folk and traditional arts are Yacub Addy, a Ghanaian drummer; Jim "Texas Shorty" Chancellor, a fiddler; Gladys Kukana Grace, a Lauhala weaver; Mary Jackson, a sweetgrass basketweaver; Delano "Del" Floyd McCoury, a bluegrass guitarist and singer; Judith McCulloh, a folklorist and editor; Kamala Lakshmi Narayanan, a Bharatanatyam Indian dancer; Mike Rafferty, an Irish flute player; and Ezequiel Torres, an Afro-Cuban drummer and drum builder. The opera honorees, besides Mr. Glass, are Martina Arroyo, a soprano; David DiChiera, a composer and the general director of the Michigan Opera Theatre; and Eve Queler, the music director of Opera Orchestra of New York.

"In the longer term, the Army has to return to its tradition of getting rid of leaders who are failing ... Back in World War II, the Army had no qualms about letting officers go; at least 16 of the 155 generals who commanded divisions in combat during the war were relieved while in combat. George Marshall, the nation's top general, felt that a willingness to fire subordinates was a requirement of leadership. He once described Gen. Hap Arnold, chief of the Army Air Forces, as a fine man, but one who 'didn't have the nerve to get rid of men not worth a damn.' ... The tradition of swift relief provided two benefits that we have lost in today's Army: It punished failure and it gave an opportunity to younger, more energetic officers who were better equipped to adapt to the quickening pace of the war ... But that tradition was somehow lost in the Korean War and buried conclusively in Vietnam. Nowadays, dynamic young leaders can't emerge as quickly, because almost no one is fired. In a much-discussed 2007 article in Armed Forces Journal, Lt. Col. Paul Yingling wrote that "a private who loses a rifle suffers far greater consequences than a general who loses a war." ... Had Army officers been managed in the Afghan War as they were during World War II, we would be seeing a new generation of leaders emerge. Instead, a beleaguered president once again is sending David Petraeus to the rescue, making it appear as though he is the only competent general we have."

In a move that should come as a surprise to no one, Knicks center Eddy Curry has exercised his contract option for the 2010-11 season. It was late October when President Obama first called for measures to stabilize struggling small businesses. Then, in his State of the Union address in January, he emphasized the role small business would play in healing the nation's wounded economy. But it is only now, eight months after that speech, that Congress finally seems ready to act. And the House and Senate are so far apart that it is not clear that they will be able to agree on a bill that contains more than just a few of the president's ideas.

When I was starting out in science journalism in the early 1980s, a writer had three choices to begin reporting a story. You could go to your publication's wall of dusty encyclopedias of professional and scientific associations, phone directories and other reference tomes lining the walls (in my case, at Science Digest magazine). You could raid a more experienced colleague's Rolodex. Or you could call the Scientists Institute for Public Information, S.I.P.I, a nonprofit group founded in 1963 and mainly paid for by media companies and foundations to provide, in essence, directory assistance for journalists seeking scientists.

I recently had a chance to catch the Yves Saint Laurent retrospective in Paris, a tour through over 40 years and 300 creations from one of the 20th century's greatest designers. While certainly familiar with his groundbreaking "Le Smoking," an alternative to the little black dress based on a man's tuxedo, I was struck by how consistently he drew from the world of men's wear.

Christopher Coke, a reputed Jamaican drug lord, has waived his right to an extradition hearing and is expected to be flown to New York on Thursday to face federal charges. Efforts to track him down had set off violent clashes and a state of emergency in Kingston, Jamaica's capital. The balding Mr. Coke was captured Tuesday near Kingston after eluding the authorities for more than a month, in part by shaving his beard and wearing a lush black wig (see photo) and possibly a pink wig, too. There was a sweet moment early in the first set against the Williams sisters, when Julie Ditty huddled briefly with her partner Renata Yurocova. Down by 15-30, Ditty knew that an early break against the best doubles team in the world could spell disaster. She gathered herself, bounced the ball three times on the fresh grass at the baseline as part of her ritual, then hit a wicked lefty slice that Venus couldn't touch. Ace.

The Netherlands wrapped up Group E play with a 2-1 win over Cameroon in Cape Town this afternoon. The victory gave the Dutch maximum points from its three group games, and sets them up for a round of 16 clash with surprise qualifier Slovakia on Monday.

Today we're releasing our latest batch of subject headings to the Linked Data Cloud. We're especially excited about this release because it's the first to contain subject descriptors. Our previous releases contained only subject headings for people, places and organizations. While these subject headings are really useful, they only allow you to explore our archive in terms of "who" and "where." Our descriptors allow you to query the archive in terms of "what" - and that allows you to find articles based on the subject they discuss. Examples of descriptors include Law and Legislation, Dark Matter (Astronomy) and Ponzi Schemes.

If anybody doubted that President Obama's decision to fire Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal was a watershed moment -- not only in the war in Afghanistan, but in the history of that fundamental principle of the American republic, civil control of the military -- Times readers have given their own judgment, with a wave of responses that have come in to the paper's Web site over the past 24 hours.

If you happen to visit U.C.L.A.'s campus this summer, take a detour through the courtyard of Schoenberg Hall, which is home to the university's Herb Alpert School of Music. There, Ball-Nogues Studio, an enterprising young Los Angeles architecture practice, has created "Table Cloth," a site-specific installation that is on view through the summer. In a play on its name, "Table Cloth" doesn't cover a table, but rather is a cover that is made of tables. Hundreds of them.

The Opera Orchestra of New York, a small but beloved institution for fans of off-beat repertory and big voices, is staging something of a comeback. The company said Thursday it would end its financially induced hiatus and mount two concert productions next season: Meyerbeer's "L'Africaine,"and a double bill of Massenet's "La Navarraise" and Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana."

But two teams who are both desperate? This is the stuff of which salivating soccer dreams are made of. For live analysis of the Denmark-Japan match, continue reading.

That a German player named Mesut Özil scored the goal that sent his nation through to the second round of this year's World Cup is a sign that something fundamental has changed about what it means to be German. A country which, until quite recently, refused to give citizenship even to the German-born children of immigrants now finds itself represented by a squad of 23 players so ethnically diverse that 11 of them could have chosen to play instead for other nations.

Hunter Foster is hopping mad. The baby-faced, big-voiced Broadway performer currently appearing in "Million Dollar Quartet" has ignited a Facebook firestorm - well, started a Facebook page anyway - with a clarion call to scrub the Tony Awards free of the creeping mold of celebrity. Shortly after this year's unusually star-glutted and star-friendly awards telecast, Mr. Foster posted a page called "Give the Tonys Back to Broadway" on the social networking site. The group had more than 8,000 members at last count.

A company testing the fire suppression system at the NJ Transit offices at 180 Boyden Avenue in Maplewood accidentally released a small amount of halon, a chemical compound used for putting out fires, this morning. Employees were evacuated for a short time. According to Maplewood Deputy Fire Chief Mike Weber, there was no danger. Four days aboard the Dois Irmãos had left me with a healthy budget surplus of $72 for the rest of the week. And a quirk of geography gave me a tempting way to blow it all. I'd be crossing the Brazil-Bolivian border in the tiny town of Guajará-Mirim. There's not much there, but it is home to the Pakaás Palafitas Lodge, a legit jungle getaway like the kind you find all around tourist-clogged Manaus but without the clog of tourists. In other words, it has the three elements that make higher-end lodging affordable for even frugal travelers: lack of location, lack of location, and lack of location.

Monologue | Wednesday night on "The Tonight Show With Jay Leno" on NBC: General McChrystal was relieved of his duties because of derogatory comments he made about President Obama and other White House staffers. In fact, when he heard that, Joe Biden was shocked and said: "What? You can get fired for saying something stupid? What? When'd they start that? Is that new?"

Monologue | Wednesday night on "The Late Show With David Letterman" on CBS: You know about the big change in Afghanistan? General McChrystal did an interview in Rolling Stone and he was talking about how much he didn't like Joe Biden. He was talking about the administration. He was trashing everybody. So President Obama calls the guy home from Afghanistan, and they had, like, a sit-down in the White House, in the Oval Office, today. It was very, very intimate. It was the president, it was General McChrystal, the Salahis, and that's it.

Monologue | Wednesday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: Starting today, there is a huge rock festival in England. It is called Glastonbury. These days, every country has its own music festival. England has Glastonbury. Here, we have Lollapalooza and Coachella. In North Korea, they have the Kim Jong Ill-ith Fair.

Monologue | Wednesday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: Today, President Obama fired Gen. Stanley McChrystal, saying McChrystal showed poor judgment in his Rolling Stone interview. It turns out when it comes to criticizing the White House, the general's policy is "just ask, and I'll tell."

In the early '80s, a freelance war photographer named Ángel Franco decided to take breaks from chasing conflicts in Central and South America for a few years to cover the everyday drama of gunplay and arrest near where he grew up the 46th Precinct in the Bronx, a place so violent officers there named it the Alamo. Mr. Franco joined the Times as a staff photographer in 1985. Today, the Lens blog has a show of his early Bronx street work. Read more at Lens.

Forget about those foie gras and truffle burgers. A ham sandwich has stepped up to the plate, promising to indulge your appetite while wrecking your budget. And it could not be simpler. The single ingredient is that most elite of Spanish hams, jamòn Ibèrico de bellota, from black-footed pigs that rummage in the woods for acorns. At Jezalin's Gourmet Market, which recently opened in the Limelight Marketplace, at Sixth Avenue and West 20th Street, about a quarter-pound of the nearly mahogany slices, each well-marbled with creamy fat, come piled on a simple crusty baguette for a sandwich that the owner, Michael Tzetzailides, calls Conquistador and for which he charges $39.95. (This ham is priced anywhere from $150 to $250 a pound at various retail outlets.) And there is enough meat in the sandwich for two people to share.

On this week's New York Times Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein looks at a joint project of YouTube and the Guggenheim Museum to find and showcase the latest in video art. She talks to Nancy Spector, deputy director and chief curator of the Guggenheim Foundation, and Ed Sanders, senior marketing manager for YouTube, about how the project evolved and how it will work. Called "YouTube Play: A Biennial of Creative Video," it's open to anyone who submits a video by July 31. Up to 20 videos will be displayed at the Guggenheim Museum in New York on Oct. 21, with simultaneous showings at the museum's other venues, in Bilbao, Berlin and Venice.

Nineteen years old, rail thin, longhaired and topped with a beret, Dylan Meek was anything but. The intensity of his performance seemed to rattle petals off the roses planted beside the piano he played in front of St. Mark's Church in-the-Bowery, at Second Avenue and 10th Street.

Sustaining South American dominance in South Africa, Paraguay edged into the knockout round for the third time in the last four quadrenniums in a tepid, goalless affair in Polokwane that closed down New Zealand's daydream World Cup.

Slovakia bounced Italy out of the 2010 World Cup, by a 3-2 score, at Ellis Park in Johannesburg, the biggest shock of the tournament thus far. The Italians are the defending champions, and while it's difficult to repeat (only Italy in 1934 and 1938 and Brazil in 1958 and 1962 have done so), it's another thing to go out in the first round. It was a pulsating match, especially the second half. For Slovakia, which led 1-0 at halftime, Robert Vittek scored his second goal in the 73rd minute. The teams then traded goals in the 81st (Antonio DiNatale), 89th (Kamil Kopunek) and 92nd (Fabio Quagliarella). Paraguay and Slovakia qualify from Group F, and will meet their counterparts from Group G in the Round of 16. You can follow the Group E games, Denmark-Japan and Cameroon-Netherlands, here, at 2:30 p.m. Eastern time.

Just a quick thought. Round 9 of the Kings Tournament in Romania is underway and Magnus Carlsen of Norway has White against Liviu-Dieter Nisipeanu of Romania. The game, which is live, started 1 e4 e5 2 Nf3 Nc6 3 Bb5 and then Nisipeanu trotted out the Schliemann Defense with 3 ... f5. Now maybe Nisipeanu did not want to suffer several hours of the "Spanish Torture," the nickname for the Ruy Lopez. But playing the Schliemann, which is a bit unsound to begin with, against Carlsen seems a bit like committing harakiri. Maybe he figured he has a puncher's chance of winning if he just goes in and trades blows. Or maybe he is testing Carlsen's knowledge. We'll see.

DARST--Diane Elizabeth Wassman, Ph.D.,of Greenwich, CT, passed away gracefully surrounded by her adoring family on June 22, 2010. A true Renaissance Woman, Dr. Darst was a founder and director of Learning to Look, a nationally-known art education program for children that has been taught in numerous schools in the Connecticut and New York metropolitan areas. She authored two books, Western Civilization to 1648 and Learning to Look, A Complete Art History and Art Appreciation Program for Grades K-8. An active leader of numerous civic and cultural organizations, she served as Chairman of the Boards of the Greenwich Library, the United Way of Greenwich, and the Bruce Museum and as a member of the Boards of the Alliance for Cancer Gene Therapy (ACGT) and Greenwich Academy. She graduated first in her class, summa cum laude, and Phi Beta Kappa, from Connecticut College and was awarded a Ph.D. in European Cultural and Intellectual History from Columbia University under Jacques Barzun. She also danced professionally with the Zurich Opera Ballet Company. Diane was dearly beloved and most admired as daughter, sister, wife, and mother. She is survived by her husband, David M. Darst; her daughter Elizabeth M. Darst and son-in-law Charles S. Leykum; her son David M. Darst, Jr.; her brother E. Robert Wassman, M.D.; her sister Debra Wassman Lanman; and many loving cousins, nieces, and nephews. Her beautiful spirit, her strength of character, and her unending love will live on in all of us forever. Services will be held at 10am on Friday, June 25, 2010, at the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich. Donations may be made in her memory to the Bruce Museum, the Greenwich Library, or The United Way of Greenwich.

An article on Tuesday about the reaction of Gaza residents to news that Israel was easing its blockade misstated, in some editions, the year that Israel's military launched a war in Gaza in retaliation for rockets fired from there into Israel by Palestinian militants. The war, which lasted 22 days, began during the last week of December 2008. It was not in 2006.

PORTNOY--Hyman (Hal) Suddenly on June 19, 2010. Founder of Super Millwork, Inc., and founding member of Midway Jewish Center. Devoted husband of Elaine Sommer and the late Sylvia Portnoy. Dedicated father of Arlene Lavitt, Rochelle Lockwood, and the late Mark Portnoy. Cherished Poppy of Jason, Keith, Jared, and Matthew. Doting great-grandfather of Sam, Sarah, Molly, and Max. Survived by scores of adoring nieces, nephews, cousins, in-laws, and friends. He was an overflowing source of humor and patriotism, and always put others first. He truly lived, loved, and laughed. Arlene and her family will be sitting shiva at her Cove Neck home through Sunday evening, with the exception of Shabbat. Donations in Hal's memory can be made to the Anti-Defamation League at (561) 988-2919, attn: Linda Zisk.

SMOTRICH--David I.,76, of Chappaqua, died suddenly Sunday morning at his home. Mr. Smotrich, FAIA, graduated from Harvard College '55, and Harvard Graduate School of Design '60. Mr. Smotrich began his architectural career in Israel as part of the design team for the new city of Arad, Negev desert. After working for I.M. Pei, he established his own firm in New York City in 1965. He continued as principal of David Smotrich & Partners until his death. His work, which was nationally recognized, ranged broadly, from educational facilities and commercial projects to low-income and elderly housing. Mr. Smotrich is survived by his wife of 54 years, Bernice D. Smotrich, his children: Ross (Talma Nir), Maura and Hannah (Michael Barr), and nine loving grandchildren: Matthew, Amit, Alex, Shani, Ben, Avital, Dani, Joshua and Etai. He will be missed. Memorial donations may be sent to Block Island Conservancy.

SWARZMAN--Martin. Loving father of Steven and Howard, devoted father-in-law to Leah and Michelle, adored grandfather of Samantha, Danielle, Olivia, Julianna, Jack and Andrew, beloved brother of Phyllis and brother-in-law Harold, and cherished partner in life with Dora, sadly passed on June 22, 2010. Born in Brooklyn on May 16, 1931, Martin was a vibrant, charming and masterful real estate developer and entrepreneur. He was a principal of Glenwood Management for many years before retiring to Aventura, FL. In addition to being an honorary NYC Fire Commissioner, Martin was involved in charitable causes ranging from founding an orphanage in Peru to supporting the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America. We will always cherish his wit, intellect and warm and open personality. The Swarzman Family

BROWN--J. Dickson, of Musselburgh, Scotland and Bronxville, NY on June 21, 2010. Husband of Ann Brown, father of Anna, Cathy and Laura and friend to many. Memorial service at The Reformed Church of Bronxville on Saturday, June 26, at 11am.

A few years ago after learning of the death of a favorite teacher, a friend from surgical training and I began exchanging e-mail messages reminiscing about the man we once alternately referred to as ''the Silver Fox'' because of his dapper looks and ''Chuckles'' because of his easygoing manner. Dr. M was well known in the hospital for his elegant surgical technique and deep respect for patients as individuals. But what my friend, Dennis, and I, and the other doctors-in-training cherished most was his uncanny ability to recognize exactly how much we residents could and couldn't do. Or, perhaps more aptly, how much he should and shouldn't do when teaching us. When we were interns, fresh out of medical school, for example, Dr. M seemed to be everywhere at once, filling our lives with directives on patient management, directions on where to cut (''just a millimeter lower!'') and daily assurances that even the greatest of surgeons all started out struggling to remove grape-sized sebaceous cysts and egg-shaped benign fatty lumps and bumps.

SCHWARTZ--Sylvia. A beautiful light has gone out. From David Merrick to William Morris; from Broadway to globetrotting the world - Everyone Loved Sylvia. Chuck Prentiss & Family Wollensteins & Rosensons

Remember the Magic Slate? Mostly a kids' toy, it required a special stylus to write on a sheet of plastic; a wax sheet below the plastic adhered to the surface, making your marks visible. The magic part was when you lifted the plastic sheet, the wax backing moved away and voila! the sheet was empty again. Now, Kent Displays has come up with an electronic version, for $35. You can write on the Boogie Board's black surface with the included stylus, a comb or your fingernail, and green markings appear on the screen. To completely erase the screen, you push the erase button; the screen flashes and it's all fresh again.

Glen Gilbert, Chair.

WILLIAMS--Samuel Dunstan, 73, died Friday, June 18 after a six month battle with cancer. He was the devoted husband of Susan, and the adoring father of their autistic son Edward. He is also survived by two brothers Thomas of Inverness, CA and Resolvert Waldron Williams of Martha's Vineyard, MA, a nephew and many cousins. Sam grew up in Lawrence, Long Island. He was a long time New Yorker. He attended Lawrence Country Day School, graduated from Groton School '55, where he was a member of the crew and captain of the soccer team, and served as the class agent until his death. He also graduated from Harvard '59, where he was a member of the Freshman Crew and was the President of the Phoenix S.K. Club. He served in the U.S. Army as a member of the National Security Agency. Before beginning his long career in the investment business he worked at his family's company, the I.T. Williams Company, which imported hardwoods from the world over. At the time of his death he was a Senior Managing Director of Carret Asset Management, LLC. In the 1980's he was the Chair of the Building Capital Committee to finish the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York. Sam was a member of The Brook, and since 1966 of The Union Club where he served as a governor from 1971 to 1979. He also served on various committees including the Committee on Candidates of which he was Chair from 1976 to 1979, the House Committee, the Finance Committee, the Art Committee and the Entertainment Committee. He was also a member of The Pilgrims. He was a member of the Saint Nicholas Society of the City of New York for 40 years, and served as President from 2001 to 2004. On Long Island he was a long standing member of the Rockaway Hunting Club, the Lawrence Beach Club and the Cedarhurst Yacht Club. He was a member of The Mill Reef Club in Antigua. He served as the President of the Board of his cooperative apartment building from 2003 to 2010. He also served on the Board of AHRC / NYC Foundation, Inc. since it's inception in 1996. He was an ardent advocate for individuals with developmental disabilities because of his son, Edward. He was an avid sportsman who loved the ocean, sailing, deep powder skiing, squash and tennis. He was a brilliant, sensitive, consummate and elegant gentleman with extraordinary charm, poise and a great smile. He will be missed by many. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions in Sam's memory to The Saint Nicholas Society of the City of NY, 20 West 44th Street, Room 508, New York, NY 10036-6603 or to The Cedarhurst Yacht Club, c/o NMB Books, Inc., PO Box 631, Pomona, NY 10970. A memorial service will be held in September.

An article on June 12 about a dispute over a test for psychopathic traits referred incorrectly to the test, called the Psychopathy Checklist, Revised, or PCL-R. The test is one of a number of forensic psychology assessments that have received some scientific backing; it is not ''one of the few, if not the only, psychological measures in forensic science with any scientific backing.'' (The PCL-R has been more extensively researched and is in wider use than other such assessments.)

SHAPIRO--Sidney, born 1918 in Brooklyn, NY, died peacefully at home on June 21. He has joined his beloved and beautiful wife, Renate. Army vet of WWII. A leader in the home fashion industry for 50 years, known as Mr. Sid, member of Central Synagogue. Sid is remembered by his many friends and family for his magic and spontaneous humor. His wisdom and love will be a guide for his son, Darek (Noel), daughter-in-law, Nana and their children.

Viewing will take place at Mather-Hodge Funeral Home, Princeton, Friday, June 25, from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the Multiple Sclerosis Society.

The mobile phone, the Swiss Army knife of the digital generation, has already left a trail of lifeless gadgetry in its path. Many phone owners no longer carry around point-and-shoot cameras, video cameras, music players, notepads or their old sturdy Filofax. Instead, they choose a single-serving device: the smartphone. Now it looks as though the next inanimate object that could crumble may be the pocket mirror. And as it goes through its metamorphosis from analog to digital, the mirror could also get a bit of an upgrade.

KRANE--Steven C. The lawyers and staff of Proskauer Rose LLP mourn the sudden and untimely passing of our longtime partner, colleague, and friend, Steven C. Krane. Steve was one of the nation's foremost and widely recognized leaders in the field of legal ethics and professional responsibility. He was also a wise counselor and confidant, a dear friend, charming colleague and a truly kind and decent human being. The General Counsel of Proskauer, Steve also served as co-head of the firm's Law Firm Practice Group, where he represented law firms and individual lawyers in their most sensitive and important matters. But he will likely be best remembered for his integral leadership role in developing and interpreting the rules governing the professional conduct of lawyers. Steve was a member of the New York State Commission on Public Integrity and the former Chair of the American Bar Association's Standing Committee on Ethics and Professional Responsibility. For 14 years, Steve also led the New York State Bar Association committee responsible for formulating the ethics rules governing New York lawyers. In 2007, he was appointed by then-Chief Judge Judith Kaye as co-chair of the New York Judicial Institute on Professionalism in the Law. He also served as vice-chair of the NYSBA Special Committee on the Law Governing Firm Structure and Operation (the MacCrate Committee); chaired the NYSBA Special Committee on Multidisciplinary Practice; and was recently named vice-chair of the International Bar Association Committee on Multidisciplinary Practices. Steve was active in the development of law and policy relating to cross-border legal practice, serving as one of the principal negotiators for the ABA and NYSBA in their efforts to achieve agreements with foreign governments to liberalize restrictions on lawyers. He held numerous positions in this arena, including: chair-elect of the NYSBA Section on International Law and Practice; chair of the NYSBA Special Committee on Cross-Border Legal Practice; and advisor to the ABA Task Force on International Trade in Legal Services. He was recently appointed to the Policy Committee of the Bar Issues Commission of the International Bar Association. Steve also had a distinguished career as a bar leader outside of the field of legal ethics, most notably serving as president of the NYSBA in 2001-2002, the youngest person to hold that post, and as a member of the ABA's Board of Governors. He coordinated the efforts of the organized bar in responding to the terrorist attacks of September 11; successfully represented the ABA in its challenge to the Federal Trade Commission's "Red Flag Rules"; and created and chaired the Student Loan Assistance for the Public Interest program, which provides grants to lawyers in public interest jobs. Active in the community, he was a member of the Board of Directors of the Friends of the John Jay Homestead (Katonah, NY). He previously served as a clerk for Judge Kaye, with whom he maintained a longtime friendship, in the New York State Court of Appeals. In addition, he was a hearing panel member and the hearing panel chair of the Departmental Disciplinary Committee, First Judicial Department, in New York; served as a hearing panel chair for the Committee on Grievances of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York; and was a special referee for disciplinary cases in the Appellate Division, Second Judicial Department. Steve also wrote and lectured extensively on ethics issues, and taught professional responsibility for several years at the Columbia University School of Law. Apart from his extraordinary professional accomplishments, Steve was a remarkable human being: beloved by colleagues; a devoted mentor to numerous young lawyers; brilliant but humble; passionate about the profession; a man of boundless energy, impeccable integrity and filled with abundant cheer. He will be sorely missed and always remembered as a true lawyer's lawyer and a devoted colleague. Our thoughts are with his family. Allen I. Fagin Chairman, Proskauer Rose LLP

Silverstein is building at the World Trade Center site, according to city records and people familiar with the inquiry. The contractor, Regional Scaffolding and Hoisting Company, was issued a permit two weeks ago to install a construction elevator at 4 World Trade Center, according to documents filed with the city. The tower is rising at the southeastern corner of ground zero, across the Trade Center site from 1 World Trade Center, formerly known as the Freedom Tower.

8 P.M. (TCM) PRIME TIME FEATURE: 60TH ANNIVERSARY OF THE KOREAN WAR ''Men in War,'' Anthony Mann's 1957 masterpiece about two rival officers (Robert Ryan, above left, and Aldo Ray) who join forces to save their troops during a retreat from the North Koreans, kicks off this 15-film, 24-hour salute, which recalls the beginning of the Korean War on June 25, 1950. The tribute continues with John Ford's ''This Is Korea!'' (1951), which uses archival footage to document the North Korean aggression that started it all, at 10, and Samuel Fuller's ''Steel Helmet'' (1951), about a cynical sergeant (Gene Evans) and a South Korean orphan (William Chun) who join a ragtag group of American soldiers trapped behind enemy lines, at 11. Friday's schedule includes ''Time Limit'' (1957), directed by Karl Malden and starring Richard Basehart as an officer court-martialed under suspicion of collaborating with the North Koreans, at 2:30 p.m., and Arnold Laven's 1956 drama ''The Rack,'' with Paul Newman as a veteran accused of cracking under torture while a prisoner of war, at 4:30. 8 P.M. The Basics column on June 1, about the researcher J. Craig Venter's claim to have created the first ''synthetic cell,'' included an incorrect reference to Mycoplasma, the bacteria Dr. Venter's team used in its work. Unlike nearly all other types of bacteria, Mycoplasma lack cell walls; they do not have a ''stiffer bacterial wall.''

WIMBLEDON, England -- The tennis match that would not end did not. After two days and 163 games, including 118 on Wednesday alone, John Isner and Nicolas Mahut left Court 18 at Wimbledon with records for the longest match, in both time elapsed and number of games, in professional tennis history. And it still wasn't over.

On Tuesday evening, at just past 6, a few dozen people - tugboat captains, towing company owners, a maritime journalist or two - gathered on the rusting deck of the Mary A. Whalen, a retired oil tanker tied up in a berth at Pier 9B in Red Hook, Brooklyn. The sun was going down over Governors Island, and a bagpiper, in traditional cap and kilt, was playing Scottish tunes. A cheese plate had been set out on a table near a dozen rows of folding chairs. A container crane loomed in the distance. There were Heineken Lights on ice in a cooler near the bulkhead. Scotch was served in Dixie cups.

So, one general is out, another is back and President Obama says it's time to "persist and we persevere." Well, House and Senate Democrats seemed to take the message to heart, and after what The Times's Edward Wyatt called a "20-hour marathon by members of a House-Senate conference committee" on Thursday and Friday, the two chambers reconciled "competing versions of legislation that would transform financial regulation." An impressive bit of legislative perseverance from the Democratic leadership, to be sure, but will the end product truly "offer families the protections they deserve, help safeguard their financial security and give the businesses of America access to the credit they need to expand and innovate," as Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner promises? I suppose it depends on whom you ask.

One of the overlooked changes in the final financial regulatory bill was the removal of a proposed measure that would have made the Securities and Exchange Commission a self-financed agency, living off the fees it collects. Palestinian officials said on Friday that they had retrieved the bodies of two Palestinians killed after Israel bombed a weapons smuggling tunnel overnight on the Gaza-Egypt border, according to an Associated Press report. The Israeli military said the tunnel was targeted because Palestinians fired 12 rockets and mortars into Israel on Thursday. The border area between Egypt and the blockaded territory of Gaza is filled with smuggling tunnels.

Since last weekend, there has been an area of disturbed weather gradually making its way from the southern Windward Islands to its current location just north of Honduras. During the past 18 hours or so, it has gotten much better organized... the convection is stronger, more persistent, and more centrally located over the low-level circulation. Based on those indicators plus and an aircraft reconnaissance flight into it, it was upgraded to Tropical Depression 1 at 22Z today (6pm EDT). The intensity was found to be 30kts and 1004mb and on an upward trend.

In this World Cup, as with every other World Cup in history, wrong calls happen. Whether they are crucial and end a team's hopes or whether they are inconsequential, the calls are frustrating at the least and infuriating at the most. Naturally we focus our anger on the man on the field wearing a different color shirt. Yes, the referee gets most of the blame, or the whole refereeing team and occasionally a manipulative player who takes a dive to get a call.

When the intra-liberal e-mail round-robin known as JournoList first attracted attention early last year, it seemed significant primarily as a milestone in the emergence of a kind of "movement liberal" mentality among certain media personalities - a team-player spirit, you might say, that imitated what liberals have long perceived as one of the strengths of movement conservatism. I suspect that some of the journalists who participated in the e-mail list (I'm thinking of figures who write for mainstream outlets like Time and Newsweek and The New Yorker, in particular) would have never dreamed of joining a semi-secret liberal forum a decade ago: That would have seemed too partisan, too compromising, too biased. But now the world had changed, and they were happy to join a members-only political discussion group that deliberately excluded right-of-center writers and thinkers.

Surfer dudes can always load up on veggies and fruit at some Greenmarket before they jumped on the A Train to Rockaway Beach in Queens. But it's easier to do the shopping once they get there, at the new little market in the expanding, ramshackle complex anchored by Rockaway Taco. Elizabeth Gilchrist, a partner, said the produce was mainly local (much of it from Blooming Hill Farm in the Hudson Valley) and organic. Right now, greens, including callaloo, are in abundance, $3 a bag. There are also some tropical fruits because they are used by the smoothie stand that shares the premises. The market also sells bread from Roberta's in Bushwick, Brooklyn, and some locally handmade odds and ends like glasses made from Red Stripe beer bottles, $10 each.

When Henry James was 26, he took a trip to Italy, a place he described as "warm & living & palpable." Just two weeks after announcing its intention to do a summer's worth of programming there, Sunday Best, the weekly electronica party that tried to make a go of the outdoor space known as the Yard, will move on, its founders said. Though licensing for alcohol and other details were proceeding as planned, there were unforeseen complications with the space, Justin Carter, a founder of Sunday Best, said in a phone interview. Rather than leave fans wondering whether the party would go on each week, they are moving to the courtyard of Brooklyn Fireproof, a warehouse space and café in Bushwick, starting this Sunday, with Kenny Larkin, a Detroit D.J. on the decks, and no toxic odors in the air.

One of the quirks of the tennis scoring system is that a player can win more overall games but still lose the match. Mikhail Youzhny of Russia won one more game than Paul-Henri Mathieu of France, but the Frenchman prevailed in a fascinating five-set match on Court 18, 6-4, 2-6, 2-6, 6-3, 6-4. It was a match that each player seemed in control of, with Youzhny storming back from a first-set loss to dominate Mathieu. But he played more conservatively when he had the lead, allowing Mathieu to seize the initiative with bold, aggressive play.

The latest book from Stephen Hawking, the British theoretical physicist and author of the runaway bestseller, "A Brief History of Time," will be released Sept. 7, its publisher Bantam Dell said on Friday. The new book is called "The Grand Design," and is written with Leonard Mlodinow, a physicist at the California Institute of Technology. Mr. Hawking's book will address worldly questions - Why do we exist? Did the universe need a creator? - and consider whether there's a single unifying theory that can explain all the forces of nature.

The new Web site shortomatic.com lets you transfer any digital image onto a pair of board shorts. We cooked up these with the help of our art department, but you don't need to be a graphic designer to use the simple step-by-step service, which is a spinoff of the popular, punnier yogamatic.com (custom-designed yoga mats). At $99 (plus shipping), the shorts aren't cheap, but they're hand-sewn, made of super-soft polyester microfiber - and using your own image really does lend this summer staple some idiosyncratic pop. Only a men's style is available now, in sizes 24 through 38, but a shorter option for beach bunnies will go on sale next month.

SAN FRANCISCO -- It's tough to find a place less friendly to Republicans than San Francisco, where fewer than one in 10 voters are registered with the party and where the local chairman -- a former leader in the sanitary supply industry -- says his major goal for 2010 is to get ''more moderate'' members on the city's often un-moderate Board of Supervisors. But such hostile terrain did little to deter Michael Steele, the smiling chairman of the Republican National Committee, from making a brief landfall here on Thursday to rally the party faithful, or at least 100 or so members of the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce. ''We are going to be in play big time in California,'' Mr. Steele said. ''We're going to be here, we've got a lot of opportunity to work hard. And we've got great candidates.''

The United States' 1-0 win over Algeria on Wednesday, which put the Americans in the Round of 16, was seen by an average of 6.12 million viewers on ESPN, the most ever for a soccer game on the ESPN networks. Several days earlier, 5.2 million viewers tuned in for ESPN's broadcast of the United States-Slovenia game. Through Wednesday, an average of 2.6 million viewers per game were watching the World Cup on ESPN, ESPN2 and ABC, up from 1.8 million four years ago. The United States-England game June 12 drew 12.9 million viewers on ABC.

In 2009, the San Diego Padres had the second-smallest payroll in baseball and finished with a 75-87 record. Given the strength of their divisional opponents and the lack of changes the Padres made during the off-season, most experts viewed them as a likely fourth- or fifth-place finisher again this year. But the Padres have exceeded expectations and lead the National League West just a week before the season's halfway point. How have they managed this drastic turnaround?

KING--Nancy McLennan, born May 3, 1942 in Minneapolis, MN; died June 21, 2010 in Palo Alto, CA. Raised in San Francisco and a long term New York City resident, she was equally enamored of both the Bay Area and the streets of New York. Educated at Stanford University, including a junior year in Florence, she loved art and appreciated other cultures. Her nose was never far from a book or a copy of The New York Times. Her bright smile and generous spirit were contagious. Long time teacher and school administrator, she was widely admired and loved by her colleagues and students alike. Devoted mother of Gregory and Gavin, sister of Jim, Jane and Tom and grandmother to Caroline, Charlie and Marshall, Nancy always smiled at the end of her grandchildren's songs. In lieu of flowers, please donate gifts in her memory to the Dr. Charles E. McLennan Scholarship Fund at the Stanford University School of Medicine, PO Box 20466, Stanford, CA 94309.

ALCASABAS--Filemon B. It is with great sadness that the Board of Directors, the Administration, medical staff, employees and volunteers of Brookhaven Memorial Hospital Medical Center mourn the passing of our long time friend, and peer Filemon B. Alcasabas, M.D. Dr. Alcasabas was a devoted and compassionate health care provider, who dedicated over 35 years of service to our community. We extend our heart-felt condolences to his wife Leticia, and his children Aurene Alcasabas Pabalan M.D. and her husband Jerry, Arlene Sullivan and her husband Daniel, Robert Alcasabas and his wife Kathy and Allison Alcasabas and grandchildren Alyssa, Ariana, Daniel, Katherine, Sean, Amy and Robert.

KRANE--Steven C. The lawyers and staff of Proskauer Rose LLP mourn the sudden and untimely passing of our longtime partner, colleague, and friend, Steven C. Krane. Steve was one of the nation's foremost and widely recognized leaders in the field of legal ethics and professional responsibility. He was also a wise counselor and confidant, a dear friend, charming colleague and a truly kind and decent human being. The General Counsel of Proskauer, Steve also served as co-head of the firm's Law Firm Practice Group, where he represented law firms and individual lawyers in their most sensitive and important matters. But he will likely be best remembered for his integral leadership role in developing and interpreting the rules governing the professional conduct of lawyers. Steve was a member of the New York State Commission on Public Integrity and the former Chair of the American Bar Association's Standing Committee on Ethics and Professional Responsibility. For 14 years, Steve also led the New York State Bar Association committee responsible for formulating the ethics rules governing New York lawyers. In 2007, he was appointed by then-Chief Judge Judith Kaye as co-chair of the New York Judicial Institute on Professionalism in the Law. He also served as vice-chair of the NYSBA Special Committee on the Law Governing Firm Structure and Operation (the MacCrate Committee); chaired the NYSBA Special Committee on Multidisciplinary Practice; and was recently named vice-chair of the International Bar Association Committee on Multidisciplinary Practices. Steve was active in the development of law and policy relating to cross-border legal practice, serving as one of the principal negotiators for the ABA and NYSBA in their efforts to achieve agreements with foreign governments to liberalize restrictions on lawyers. He held numerous positions in this arena, including: chair-elect of the NYSBA Section on International Law and Practice; chair of the NYSBA Special Committee on Cross-Border Legal Practice; and advisor to the ABA Task Force on International Trade in Legal Services. He was recently appointed to the Policy Committee of the Bar Issues Commission of the International Bar Association. Steve also had a distinguished career as a bar leader outside of the field of legal ethics, most notably serving as president of the NYSBA in 2001-2002, the youngest person to hold that post, and as a member of the ABA's Board of Governors. He coordinated the efforts of the organized bar in responding to the terrorist attacks of September 11; successfully represented the ABA in its challenge to the Federal Trade Commission's "Red Flag Rules"; and created and chaired the Student Loan Assistance for the Public Interest program, which provides grants to lawyers in public interest jobs. Active in the community, he was a member of the Board of Directors of the Friends of the John Jay Homestead (Katonah, NY). He previously served as a clerk for Judge Kaye, with whom he maintained a longtime friendship, in the New York State Court of Appeals. In addition, he was a hearing panel member and the hearing panel chair of the Departmental Disciplinary Committee, First Judicial Department, in New York; served as a hearing panel chair for the Committee on Grievances of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York; and was a special referee for disciplinary cases in the Appellate Division, Second Judicial Department. Steve also wrote and lectured extensively on ethics issues, and taught professional responsibility for several years at the Columbia University School of Law. Apart from his extraordinary professional accomplishments, Steve was a remarkable human being: beloved by colleagues; a devoted mentor to numerous young lawyers; brilliant but humble; passionate about the profession; a man of boundless energy, impeccable integrity and filled with abundant cheer. He will be sorely missed and always remembered as a true lawyer's lawyer and a devoted colleague. Our thoughts are with his family. Funeral services will be held Monday June 28 at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, call: 212-288-3500 Allen I. Fagin Chairman, Proskauer Rose LLP

FRANTZ--Andrew G.,M.D. Columbia University Medical Center mourns the passing of Andrew G. Frantz, M.D., professor of medicine at Columbia, associate dean and chairman of admissions committee at the College of physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University, and former chief of the Endocrine Division. A native of New York, Dr. Frantz received his medical degree from the College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University in 1955. Dr. Frantz served two years as a lieutenant commander in the Navy at the U.S. Naval Hospital in Memphis, TN, and subsequently joined the faculty at Harvard Medical School. In 1966, he joined the faculty at Columbia. Dr. Frantz also known for his pioneering work on human prolactin. Gifts in Memory of Dr. Frantz can be made to the Andrew G. Frantz Scholarship Fund at Columbia University, College of Physicians and Surgeons, P&S Alumni Association, 630 West 168th Street, Suite 2-250, New York, NY 10032. We extend our sincerest condolences to his family. Lee Goldman, M.D. Executive Vice President for Health and Biomedical Sciences and Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine The P&S Alumni Association

CALCANTE--Elina T.,88 of Staten Island died June 23, 2010. She was the beloved wife of the late Raymond J. Neuberger Executive Assistant to four New York City Mayors. Elina retired from the City of NY Comptroller's Office and was currently Executive Assistant to Arthur Cheliotes, President of Local 1180 of the Communications Workers of America where she was employed for 35 years. Elina is survived by many nieces and nephews. Friends may call Monday, June 28th between 9am and 10am, at the Redgate - Hennessy Funeral Home, 4 Gorham Place, Trumbull, CT followed by a Mass of Christian Burial at 10:30am at Notre Dame Church, Morehouse Rd., Easton, CT. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Trumbull, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Leukemia and Lymphoma Society or American Lung Association.

DARST--Diane Elizabeth Wassman, Ph.D.,of Greenwich, CT, passed away gracefully surrounded by her adoring family on June 22, 2010. A true Renaissance Woman, Dr. Darst was a founder and director of Learning to Look, a nationally-known art education program for children that has been taught in numerous schools in the Connecticut and New York metropolitan areas. She authored two books, Western Civilization to 1648 and Learning to Look, A Complete Art History and Art Appreciation Program for Grades K-8. An active leader of numerous civic and cultural organizations, she served as Chairman of the Boards of the Greenwich Library, the United Way of Greenwich, and the Bruce Museum and as a member of the Boards of the Alliance for Cancer Gene Therapy (ACGT) and Greenwich Academy. She graduated first in her class, summa cum laude, and Phi Beta Kappa, from Connecticut College and was awarded a Ph.D. in European Cultural and Intellectual History from Columbia University under Jacques Barzun. She also danced professionally with the Zurich Opera Ballet Company. Diane was dearly beloved and most admired as daughter, sister, wife, and mother. She is survived by her husband, David M. Darst; her daughter Elizabeth M. Darst and son-in-law Charles S. Leykum; her son David M. Darst, Jr.; her brother E. Robert Wassman, M.D.; her sister Debra Wassman Lanman; and many loving cousins, nieces, and nephews. Her beautiful spirit, her strength of character, and her unending love will live on in all of us forever. Services will be held at 10am on Friday, June 25, 2010, at the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich. Donations may be made in her memory to the Bruce Museum, the Greenwich Library, or The United Way of Greenwich.

In 2000, when three Yale undergraduates founded an online financial services company called Higher One Holdings, they had visions of rapid growth and successively bigger rounds of financing from investors. With any luck, momentum would build toward the ultimate dot-com dream: a stock listing on a major public exchange. Along the way, though, market forces placed obstacles in their path. First there was the collapse of the Internet bubble, followed by a drought in private equity activity.

Services were held at Star of David Cemetery, North Lauderdale, FL, on June 23.

OSOFSKY--Aileen. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Chemotherapy Foundation mourn with deep sorrow the passing of Aileen Osofsky, Trustee and Honorary Trustee for the past 24 years, staunch benefactor and friend. She was a sophisticated ally with insight, conviction and tenacity - a pragmatist whose dedicated efforts were influential in advancing and expanding chemotherapy research and clinical science through innovative medical therapies. Her humanitarian concern, commitment and loving spirit will be remembered always with affection and gratitude. Franco M. Muggia, M.D. Chairman & Medical Director Barry Richter President Chemotherapy Foundation

The school year for Old First Nursery School in Park Slope, Brooklyn, wraps up on Friday. And for some parents, it will not be a moment too soon. At this, one of the city's oldest cooperative nursery schools, it was a year in which an increasingly rancorous debate over 4-year-old troublemakers resulted in a pile-up of events including - but certainly not limited to - external evaluations, a session with a mediator that opened with a banjo-toting parent offering a new school song, an attempt by a group of parents to implement a ''no-tolerance policy toward aggressive behavior.''

Russian natural gas resumed flowing through Belarus to Europe at normal levels on Thursday, as Belarus and Russia announced a tentative truce in their four-day energy dispute. Russia's government-owned gas company, Gazprom, said Belarus had settled its debt, but Belarus still contends that Russia owes it transit fees and says it will shut off gas shipments through its territory unless they are paid.

My heartfelt condolences to them and their families. Edward M. Berman, Singer Netter Dowd & Berman PLLC

An article on Wednesday about the elimination of France from the World Cup on Tuesday misstated part of the English translation of the name of European soccer's governing body, whose acronym is UEFA. It is the Union of European Football Associations, not the Union of European Soccer Federations.
