An obituary on Wednesday about the business reporter Chris Welles misspelled the given name of the dean of the Graduate School of Journalism at the City University of New York, who praised Mr. Welles's work. He is Stephen Shepard, not Steven.

An article on Saturday about BP's political connections described incorrectly the more than $77,000 in contributions that President Obama received in the 2008 election cycle from BP-related donors. All of the contributions came from BP employees; Mr. Obama did not receive any money from BP's political action committee in the presidential campaign. (He did receive $1,000 from the company's P.A.C. in his 2004 Senate campaign.)

An article on Thursday about the former lobbyist Jack Abramoff, who is working at a kosher pizzeria in Baltimore since his release from prison to a halfway house, described incorrectly the Washington restaurant Signatures, which was partly owned by Mr. Abramoff. It is not in fact a kosher restaurant. (Mr. Abramoff did open two other short-lived kosher dining places in Washington, Archives and Stacks.)

LOS ANGELES -- As recently as 2008, Locke High School here was one of the nation's worst failing schools, and drew national attention for its hallway beatings, bathroom rapes and rooftop parties held by gangs. For every student who graduated, four others dropped out. Now, two years after a charter school group took over, gang violence is sharply down, fewer students are dropping out, and test scores have inched upward. Newly planted olive trees in Locke's central plaza have helped transform the school's concrete quadrangle into a place where students congregate and do homework.

KINNEAR--Peter Ogden, 92, passed away on May 31, 2010. Peter was a gifted architect, a private, wise and graceful man, with a wonderful sense of humor. From boyhood to college, Peter spent summers at Camp Pasquaney in Hebron, NH. He said that it was here that he learned the values that he carried with him through his life. There began his love for the mountains of the Northeast, where he skied and fly fished well into his 80's. His love of fly fishing took him to his beloved Three Rivers Ranch in Idaho, where he and wife Emily fished the Snake River for almost 20 years. He graduated from Yale School of Architecture in 1941, and in the 1950s he started his own firm in Greenwich, CT. He designed and built over 250 homes, and a variety of other buildings from Art Galleries, to a Firehouse in Tarrytown, NY. For Peter, architecture was a pairing of simple, elegant design, with the needs of his clients. His brilliance at siting a building was nothing short of genius. His family and friends will miss this man who skied with grace, fished with ardor, designed with vision and had a good laugh along the way.

SAN FRANCISCO -- It's tough to find a place less friendly to Republicans than San Francisco, where fewer than one in 10 voters are registered with the party and where the local chairman -- a former leader in the sanitary supply industry -- says his major goal for 2010 is to get ''more moderate'' members on the city's often un-moderate Board of Supervisors. But such hostile terrain did little to deter Michael Steele, the smiling chairman of the Republican National Committee, from making a brief landfall here on Thursday to rally the party faithful, or at least 100 or so members of the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce. ''We are going to be in play big time in California,'' Mr. Steele said. ''We're going to be here, we've got a lot of opportunity to work hard. And we've got great candidates.''

KABUL, Afghanistan -- The business of running the war in Afghanistan went on seemingly as usual on Thursday, although many in the NATO command headquarters here were reeling over the rapid-fire events that culminated in their boss's dismissal, forcing many of them to polish their résumés. While no one said he was leaving, there was little doubt in anyone's mind that most of those closest to Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, who was fired on Wednesday by President Obama, would leave with him. That would be partly in a show of solidarity and partly because the new commander, Gen. David H. Petraeus, would not request their services.

WASHINGTON -- House and Senate negotiators were still trying to reconcile competing versions of a financial regulatory bill late Thursday. By 10:15 p.m., the members of a House and Senate conference committee had been officially meeting for almost 13 hours but had barely discussed the two most contested provisions: restrictions on trading by banks for their own account and the segregation of derivatives trading operations from a bank's other operations.

WINDMAN--Arnold L. Arnold Windman, a nationally known consulting engineer who designed the systems for some of New York City's and the nation's most iconic buildings and a loving husband and father of eight, died in Hilton Head, SC, last weekend at the age of 83. Over a forty-plus-year career, Arnold was a partner, president, vice chairman and chief engineer at Syska & Hennessy, New York City, one of the country's largest consulting engineering firms. During his tenure, the firm designed the systems for some of the country's most important buildings projects: the United Nation's Building; numerous state and private university projects; the expansion of Rockefeller Center; the New York State Office Building and Mall in Albany; major terminals at JFK and LAX; and Lincoln Center and the Kennedy Center. Arnold was lead-partner on The National Gallery in Washington, DC; The Jacob Javits Convention Center in NYC; major expansions of New York Hospital and Mount Sinai; The U.S. Air Force Academy in Colorado Springs and the American Hospital in Paris. He also oversaw the firm's expansion and growth from approximately 80 engineers in two offices to more than 600 in eight offices. Arnold was the national president of the American Council of Consulting Engineers (ACEC), the organization that represents 5,300 consulting engineering firm. He also led the formation of the American Tort Reform Association, Washington, DC, the only national organization dedicated exclusively to tort and liability reform through public education and the enactment of legislation. As an engineering student at the end of World War II, Arnold worked with a New York-based team of scientists that were part of the "Manhattan Project" which developed the atomic bomb. He graduated with honors in mechanical engineering from the City College of New York and was a member of the engineering honors society: Tau Beta Phi. After retiring, Pat and Arnold moved from Briarcliff Manor, NY, to Hilton Head, SC, where Arnold was an active member of the Sea Pines Board, the Sea Pines Forest Preserve and other planning groups. For several years, he was also active in the Democratic Party on Hilton Head. Arnold is survived by his wife, Pat, and seven children: Richard Windman; William Campbell, Marjorie Oxman, JoAnn Skolar, Sean Campbell, Colleen Campbell and Kevin Campbell; and grandchildren: Ian and Jay Oxman; Spencer Windman Campbell; Riley Campbell, Harper Campbell and Madison Campbell. A memorial service will be held Friday, June 25th at 4pm at the Island Funeral Home on Hilton Head Island. A second memorial service will be held in New York City later this summer.

An article on Thursday about the United States' 1-0 victory over Algeria in the World Cup on Wednesday misstated the reason the American team would have been eliminated had the game ended in a tie. It was because the team would have finished third in its group, not because of a ''complicated tie-breaker system.''

9 P.M. (NBC) MICHAEL JACKSON: A MOTHER'S STORY In her first televised interview since Jackson's death on June 25, 2009, his mother, Katherine, left, speaks with Sonia Lowe in this two-hour edition of ''Dateline NBC.'' On Ms. Jackson's mind: who she thinks is responsible for her son's death; his belief that people wanted him dead; how his three children are coping without their father, and her relationship with them; and how the Jackson family will be commemorating this day. She also responds to accusations that Mr. Jackson was a child molester and rumors that his former wife Debbie Rowe wants custody of the children. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE KING OF POP: ONE YEAR LATER This special installment of ''The Early Show'' features a performance of Michael Jackson's hit ''Man in the Mirror'' by James Morrison and remembrances from Christina Aguilera, Marc Anthony, L L Cool J, Smokey Robinson and John Landis, who directed the videos for ''Thriller'' and ''Black or White.'' ''Good Morning America,'' at 7 on ABC, also salutes Jackson; Alicia Keys performs.

GREER--Leonard, 71, on June 23, 2010. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Andrea and Joseph Silvia, Jessica and Richard Morris and Hilary Greer. Adored grandfather of Henry and Charlie. Service, Friday, June 25, 2010, 10am, Jewish Community Center of Harrison.

How do you make a stage musical from the story of the Shaggs, above, the vintage-1960s girl group whose artless compositions were so, shall we say, challenging that their debut album, ''Philosophy of the World,'' above, has been described as ''blessedly unrhythmic'' by The New York Times and the band itself deemed ''better than the Beatles'' by Frank Zappa? We'll see when ''The Shaggs: Philosophy of the World'' is presented as a joint production of Playwrights Horizons and New York Theater Workshop next year. Featuring a book and lyrics by Joy Gregory, and music and lyrics by Gunnar Madsen, ''The Shaggs'' chronicles the real-life story of the Wiggin sisters -- Dorothy, known as Dot (vocals and lead guitar); Betty (rhythm guitar); and Helen (drums) -- who had no musical experience when their father, Austin, pulled them out of school and set them on a very crooked path to artistic immortality. (An earlier version of the show was presented at the New York Musical Theater Festival in 2005.) The new production of ''The Shaggs: Philosophy of the World'' will be directed by John Langs and presented at Playwrights Horizons in spring 2011. Casting has not been announced.
GREER--Leonard. Our dear friend Len had an ongoing enthusiasm and zest for life. His positive attitude sustained him and all of us. It is hard to imagine the world without him. Janet and David Levine

DOWD--Hector G. The Louis Armstrong Educational Foundation, Inc. announces with profound sorrow the passing of its long-time friend and attorney who lent it his wisdom and good counsel, and who died on June 23, 2010 at age 90. We extend our condolences to his wife, Isabel, to his daughter and son-in-law, Isabel and Neil Christie, his son, Hector, and his five grandchildren. His memory will live on. Thanks to his advice and guidance Louis Armstrong's mission will continue to flourish. Stanley Crouch, President Phoebe Jacobs, Executive Vice President

GREER--Leonard. Our Len - one of a kind! He loved and lived life to the fullest. World traveler, theater and the arts patron, tournament poker player, golfer and adventurer. Always positive, never a complaint, even towards the end. He always said he felt "great". Your spirit will stay with us forever. Barbara and Nick Schiff

HARRIS--Vivian, on June 24, 2010. Past President and Founder of Ronald McDonald House of New York. She is survived by her children Ellyn and Jerry. Services Monday 2pm at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

STARK--Frederica, of Princeton, NJ, entrepreneur, passed away Tuesday, June 22. She was active in the Princeton Senior Center and was a stalwart member of the Knickerbocker Republican Club of New York City. She is survived by her son Jack and two sisters, Joan and Gloria. Viewing will take place at Mather-Hodge Funeral Home, Princeton, Friday, June 25, from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the Multiple Sclerosis Society.

OSOFSKY--Aileen, died June 22, aged 83. Chair of the American Contract Bridge League's National Goodwill Committee since 1985, Aileen broadly expanded the ACBL's goodwill efforts and improved the game for all players. In 2009, she was inducted into the ACBL Hall of Fame. Born in Brooklyn in 1926, Aileen skipped four grades as a student. In Junior H.S., she met Meyer Osofsky, who served in the U.S. Army Air Corps during WWII. They married in 1945. Meyer founded "Aileen," a popular women's sportswear line named for his wife. Since the 1970s, they split their time between New York City; Phoenix, AZ; and Shelter Island, NY. Aileen served on the boards of many secular and Jewish philanthropic organizations in New York and Phoenix. In 1991, Meyer and Aileen co-funded an airplane transfer of Russian Jewish refugees to Israel. Aileen is survived by her husband, Meyer; three siblings, Muriel, Albert, and Barbara; six children, Larry and Wailin, Randy and Stephen, and Alan and Deirdre; ten grandchildren, Anna and Alexander, Zachary and Leigh, LuLing, Judd, Dean and Juliana, Ryder, and Jarema; and three great-grandchildren, Lukas Meyer, Noah, and Josie. A memorial will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel in New York on Thursday, July 1, at 2:30pm. Aileen cared deeply about charity; donations in her memory should be made to the organization of your choice.
The American timetable for getting out makes it easier for Pakistan to play a more visible role. MAJ. GEN. ATHAR ABBAS, the spokesman for the Pakistani Army, on his nation's role in Afghanistan. [A4]

Nine Iraqi police officers were killed in attacks in Mosul and Baghdad late Wednesday and Thursday. In Mosul, three suicide bombers carried out separate attacks on Thursday, killing four police officers, the authorities said. The bombings came hours after three other police officers in the city were fatally shot at a checkpoint on Wednesday night. In Baghdad, a roadside bomb exploded Thursday as a police patrol passed, killing two officers.
ENSLEY--Charles S. Rest in Peace. I will always cherish your friendship, love, and support throughout the years. Nikki B.

KRANE--Steven C. The Justices of the New York State Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department mark with sadness the passing of a great friend of the court. As a valued member of the courts disciplinary committee, he served the Court with distinction for many years.

NEWMAN--Diane, passed away on June 23rd at her home in Florham Park, NJ. She was born September 9, 1939 in Los Angeles and grew up in San Francisco where she met and married her husband Paul on May 1st, 1960. They resided in Short Hills for over 20 years before moving to their current home in Florham Park. Diane leaves her husband Paul, daughter Amanda Damesek and husband Scott and her son Robert and his wife Kate. She has five grandchildren, Julia, Henry, Aaron, Elizabeth, and Andrew. Contributions may be made in her honor to Weill Cornell Medical College (Oncology), Attn: D. Brown in New York City or to the Children's Home Society of Trenton, NJ. There will be a memorial service for Diane at Temple B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, NJ on Friday morning at 10:30am.

BRIELOFF--Sherwood H.,of Plainview, NY passed away peacefully on June 24, 2010. His doting wife of 27 years, Linda, and a large extended family survives him. He will be missed by his Sister-In-Law and Brother-In-Law Rhoda and Richard Gould, niece Deb, her husband Scott Marcus and their children, Sarah and Ashley; nephew Bob Gould, his wife Jen, and their children Joseph, Jordyn and Jackson; Godson Sloan Anderson, Vicky Gagliardo, Caren Berk, his wonderful cousin Eunice Stiller and her daughter Shelly Herman. A former Grand Master of the Brooklyn Mason Lodge, University of Illinois graduate, and a WWII Veteran, Woody was offered and declined a purple heart so his parents would not have to know about his injuries. He enjoyed a correspondence relationship with Eleanor Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman. Services will be held at IJ Morris Funeral Home, 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, NY at 10 am on June 25, 2010. Donations may be made to the Diabetes Association or a charity of your choice.
RIPPS--David. June 25, 1967 We remember and miss David on his birthday and everyday with everlasting love. Mommy, Daddy, Van, Leah and Emily

KOUFAKIS--Steven M.,on June 21, 2010. Survived by Evie, loving father of Michael and Nikko, beloved son of Mary Koufakis, and cherished by all family members and friends. The Gay Pride parade was held this afternoon in Paris, and the streets and boulevards on the Left Bank on this beautiful June day were clogged. At Dior Homme, around 3 p.m., the audience looked sullen as it fanned away the heat in a former train depot, where the Dior crew had erected a blinding-white set with a center room curtained off with enough sheer drapery to close several Broadway productions. Rows of spotlights raised the temperature but they also created the desired effect as the models appeared as shadows behind the drapes.

I'm actually mildly optimistic that Congo is gaining traction on the international agenda, and that progress is possible after a pretty bad half century for Congo.

Nine weeks into the disaster in the Gulf of Mexico, there is more money in Bayou La Batre than there has been in decades, residents say. There are also more traffic accidents, more drug and alcohol use, more resentment, more rumors, more hunger and more worry.

OMAHA - As the last College World Series at venerable Rosenblatt Stadium nears its final days - the best-of-three championship series begins Monday night - one of the big unknowns is whether the wind and sun will be as tricky in the tournament's new home, TD Ameritrade Park.

SUNDAY'S PUZZLE - When I open up a big Sunday puzzle, my first problem is an ethical one. Should I read the title? Sometimes it doesn't matter. The title provides a clever joke about the puzzle but doesn't give anything away. Sometimes it's a spoiler: the theme can be discerned from the title alone, and I prefer to uncover it myself. Occasionally, the theme provides an essential clue.

It has been an eventful 12 months for Tom Watson, from his near victory at last year's British Open to his emotional exit at last week's United States Open. Now is a good time for Watson to give his fans a glimpse into his thinking, his technique and his golf wisdom, and that is the principal ambition of Watson's new, two-disc DVD, "Lessons of a Lifetime." Watson has stored up a lot of instructional advice over the decades, much of it culled from the golfing greats he has known. But this is no quick-fix highlight reel of golf tricks worth trying.

The conductor of the last W train, which took its final voyage on Friday evening, was a second-generation subway worker named Helen Carames, 32. Her mother still works at a station booth in Queens; her father retired as a car inspector after 35 years. Family legend has it that her great-grandmother sold tokens.

LOS ANGELES - It was almost possible to forget there was an actual baseball game Friday night at Dodger Stadium, where Joe Torre spent much of his time hugging and shaking hands with his former players and coaches on the Yankees. Not so for Alex Rodriguez, who apparently was so focused that he said he never saw Torre - even as Derek Jeter, Jorge Posada, Mariano Rivera and other teammates greeted Torre a few feet away from where Rodriguez was getting loose.
With the Yankees in Los Angeles this weekend, it is useful to remember that only the randomness of the calendar kept Rodriguez from starting his career with the Dodgers.

An article on Friday about the conclusion on Thursday of the longest tennis match ever -- John Isner's 6-4, 3-6, 6-7 (9), 7-6 (3), 70-68 victory at Wimbledon over Nicolas Mahut, which took 11 hours 5 minutes -- misstated the number of games played. It was 183, not 182.

When my aunt and uncle recently traveled to San Francisco, their flight arrived hours late and then had to wait nearly three hours at the airport for a rental car to be available. The rental company tried to appease them by offering a Toyota Prius hybrid as an extra perk. It was an upgrade, the agent told them. Turns out the agent was right. I recently did a quick search on Travelocity for green rental cars in San Francisco, and Toyota Prius models or similar green cars were generally priced at a large premium over equivalent rental cars. So how much more does a hybrid rental car cost, and why is the premium so high?

8 P.M. (HBO) FUNNY PEOPLE (2009) In this film from Judd Apatow, Adam Sandler, above, plays George Simmons, a stand-up comedian turned Hollywood star and jerk who discovers that he has a rare, potentially fatal blood disease. Seth Rogen is Ira, the fledgling comic George hires as an assistant, who for the time being seems only too content to accept his employer's scraps -- like the $1,000 he earns for writing jokes for George's appearance at a MySpace corporate event, while his boss pockets the $299,000 balance. And Mr. Apatow's wife, Leslie Mann, plays Laura, the love who got away from George, and the one he wants back now that he's dying. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said there was ''something irritatingly self-satisfied'' about the film, partly stemming from the autobiographical touches, including Mr. Apatow's use of his wife and his daughters, Maude and Iris, who portray Laura's children. ''Watching 'Funny People,' you get the sense that Mr. Apatow, one of the most successful filmmakers working in Hollywood, is very happy,'' she wrote. ''Bummer.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Lucky Severson investigates the ethical questions surrounding blood samples and other specimens sent to laboratories, some of which end up being used for medical research. Norman Fischer, a teacher of Zen Buddhism, explains why he believes that meditation is not in conflict with religion.

OSOFSKY--Aileen, died June 22, aged 83. Chair of the American Contract Bridge League's National Goodwill Committee since 1985, Aileen broadly expanded the ACBL's goodwill efforts and improved the game for all players. In 2009, she was inducted into the ACBL Hall of Fame. Born in Brooklyn in 1926, Aileen skipped four grades as a student. In Junior H.S., she met Meyer Osofsky, who served in the U.S. Army Air Corps during WWII. They married in 1945. Meyer founded "Aileen," a popular women's sportswear line named for his wife. Since the 1970s, they split their time between New York City; Phoenix, AZ; and Shelter Island, NY. Aileen served on the boards of many secular and Jewish philanthropic organizations in New York and Phoenix. In 1991, Meyer and Aileen co-funded an airplane transfer of Russian Jewish refugees to Israel. Aileen is survived by her husband, Meyer; three siblings, Muriel, Albert, and Barbara; six children, Larry and Wailin, Randy and Stephen, and Alan and Deirdre; ten grandchildren, Anna and Alexander, Zachary and Leigh, LuLing, Judd, Dean and Juliana, Ryder, and Jarema; and three great-grandchildren, Lukas Meyer, Noah, and Josie. A memorial will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel in New York on Thursday, July 1, at 2:30pm. Aileen cared deeply about charity; donations in her memory should be made to the organization of your choice.

An article in some editions on Friday about the Mets' 6-5 loss to the Detroit Tigers on Thursday referred incorrectly to the Mets' batting average with the bases loaded entering the game. While the average was .209, the ratio of hits to at-bats was 14 for 67, not 14 for 50. (Fifty is the number of runs the Mets have scored with the bases loaded this season.)

A music review on Thursday about a concert at the Nokia Theater on Tuesday night by the singer Adam Lambert referred incorrectly to kissing between Mr. Lambert and his bass player, Tommy Joe Ratliff. During the song ''Fever,'' they licked each other's lips; Mr. Ratliff did not merely give Mr. Lambert a quick peck on the shoulder. (He did that later in the show.)

A report in the In Transit column on Page 2 this weekend about Pierre Koffmann's new eponymous restaurant at the Berkeley Hotel in Knightsbridge, London, includes an erroneous date from a hotel publicist for the restaurant's opening. An article on Thursday about the European antitrust commissioner's leniency in assessing fines for price-fixing to avoid pushing companies into bankruptcy misstated the corporate status of Ideal Standard, a maker of bathroom fixtures that was found to be part of a cartel. Ideal Standard International is a private company based in Brussels; it is not owned by Wabco, an auto safety system supplier in the United States. (Wabco was spun off in 2007 from the American Standard Companies, now known as Trane Inc., which also sold its European bath and kitchen division to Ideal Standard that year. The European antitrust investigation was in progress at that time, and Wabco had agreed to pay any fine levied on Trane or Ideal Standard as a result of the investigation.)

WEISS--Lucille L. The Staff of Weiss Realty Co.,Inc. offer their heartfelt condolences to the family of Lucille L. Weiss of Long Beach, NY. Lucille was a very strong woman who enjoyed 97 years with her wonderful family and friends. Lucille will be missed by us all.

An article on Thursday about the hiring of a contractor that was a focus of a criminal investigation into a fatal fire at the former Deutsch Bank building to work on 4 World Trade Center referred imprecisely to the business affiliation of three men who were indicted on manslaughter charges in connection with the fire. While the John Galt Corporation and three supervisors were indeed indicted, only two of the supervisors worked for Galt. The third one worked for Bovis Lend Lease, which hired Galt and managed the demolition of the building. (All have pleaded not guilty.)

WILSON--Ann. The Nightingale-Bamford School expresses its profound sadness over the passing of Ann Wilson. Miss Wilson was a faithful alumna from the Class of 1949 and one of our longest-serving faculty members, devoting over 50 years of her life to our school. Her ability to capture the essence of girls was unparalleled, and the delight in reading and writing that she encouraged in her students inspired us all. Miss Wilson's legacy is in the lives of hundreds of Nightingale women whom she taught. A memorial service will be held at Nightingale in the fall. Nina Joukowsky Koprulu '79, Board President Dorothy A. Hutcheson, Head of School

Guests wore black tie, and some thwacked little white balls on Thursday night when SPiN, a stylish basement Ping-Pong parlor on East 23rd Street just off Park Avenue South pitted the sport's Olympians, national and world champions and others in a series of madcap exhibition games. The privilege to watch matches between table tennis celebrities like the Swedish doubles partners Jan-Ove Waldner and Mikael Appelgren (who between them have around half a dozen world championships and a smattering of Olympic medals), cost guests $75 to $200. The pair drank beers and ricocheted the balls between them, high, low, off the table and off the ceiling.

How I chose movers in the past isn't anything I'm proud of. The last time I picked a mover, I remember doing a quick search online and then signing up with the first mover I called. I naively agreed over the phone to pay the movers by the hour. The job, a move from one New York apartment to another, ended up taking at least 10 hours and costing my husband and me more than a thousand dollars, much more than the initial estimate.

Carl Richards is a certified financial planner and the founder of Prasada Capital. The only reason we invest in stocks is to earn more than we would get from cash or bonds. The amount you are supposed to earn by taking the additional risk of owning stocks is called the risk premium. If you don't get paid more for taking the risk, you should put your money in bonds.

7:43 p.m. | Updated There were a couple of days of breathless news stories playing up the threat to operations around the BP oil gusher posed by the brewing storm called Alex. But federal storm forecasters never saw much of a chance of this storm shifting northeast toward the region beset by slicks and oiled shores. As of Sunday night, the storm, still a tropical depression, had finished pummeling the Yucatan Peninsula and was projected to strengthen over warm Gulf of Mexico waters before making landfall on shores in the western gulf (although some models still calculate a possible risk to the oily east).

So we begin more or less with Tim Riggins's dream denied. Again! On last week's episode of "Friday Night Lights," there was a glimmer of hope for Riggins's -- real estate. (And that says it all, doesn't it?) He'd fallen in love with 25 gorgeous, unusually lush acres of tree-lined Texas property, and he could picture a nice life for himself on it. When he inquires about the land, he learns that it costs $85,000. He quite obviously doesn't have the money, and let's not even bother to discuss post-recession financing. Riggins puts on a suit to go meet the Realtor -- this is a grown-up appointment -- but adult life just doesn't suit Riggins (or it just doesn't like him). He starts pulling at his tie as if it's strangling him.

The American designer Thom Browne, having his Paris debut, invited everyone this evening to the French Communist Party headquarters, in a handsome Oscar Niemeyer building. After a bit of a wait, we were shown into a sloped meeting room with rows of long tables and little French and American flags at each place. Presently four identical-looking models entered the room dressed in crested blue blazers, shorts, white shirts and ties, and wearing chic wire sunglasses. They sat at the head table and addressed the assembly - first in English, then in French - with a comic gravity.

MONDAY'S PUZZLE - Today's puzzle will have you seeing double, with six "gaga"-like phrases making up the theme. The repeated syllables mostly all rhyme, with RARA AVIS being the biggest deviant (sounds sinister, doesn't it?). BABA WAWA finishes things up with a double dose of doubling.

In his "Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy," the science fiction writer Douglas Adams introduces Deep Thought - a computer the size of a small city, designed millions of years ago by a race of hyperintelligent pan-dimensional beings searching for the meaning of life. The super computer is described as a "so amazingly intelligent that even before the data banks had been connected up it had started from 'I think therefore I am' and got as far as the existence of rice pudding and income tax before anyone managed to turn it off ..."
Those in the ivory tower might think themselves enlightened; those on the ground find them irrelevant.- Mahmood, Richmond

MANDEL--Cecile, widow of Joseph David Mandel, beloved mother of Madeleine Mandel-Tiktin and Tom Mandel, grandmother of Juliette and Jade Mandel, and mother-in-law to Thomas Tiktin and Gail Topol, passed away in her home in New York City on June 25. A graduate of The New School for Social Research and Fordham University, she made a beautiful home for her family in Larchmont, and in her widowed years worked in real estate in the city, and continued her studies. She will be deeply missed by her family, and always remembered as an example of intelligence and strength. Service Monday 11:30am at the "Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

She worked in the financial services industry for over thirty years. She was preceded in death by her father Carl Hederich and sister Susan Lynne Rossi. In lieu of flowers, donation may be made to Mt. Olive Lutheran Church, 11500 E. Iliff Ave., Aurora, CO 80014, 303-755-9123.

HARRIS--Vivian S. The Board of Directors, Volunteers, and Staff of the Ronald McDonald House wish to express our sincere sympathy of the passing of our friend, advisor, co-founder of Ronald McDonald House New York, Vivian S. Harris. While our loss of this remarkable woman is deep and profound, we cannot imagine the loss to her daughter, Ellyn Harris and son, Jerry Harris. Vivian Harris served as President of the Board of Directors for her twenty-six years. In 1978, she helped form the foundation of Ronald McDonald House in New York City, creating our organization first known as The Childrens Oncology Society of New York, Inc. Through many obstacles and with great perseverance, Vivian expanded our services in 1993 when she built the largest Ronald McDonald House in the world with the support of The Tri-State McDonald's Owners/ Operators. In recognition of her many years of invaluable and outstanding service Vivian Harris was named President Emeritus. The organization further recognized her distinguished legacy in 2008 when she was awarded the Hope Award, the highest recognition our charity can bestow its volunteers, and established the Vivian Harris Society to honor her triumphant spirit. We are grateful for the extraordinary opportunity of counting Vivian Harris as part of our family and love and care she offered so freely to those she touched in life! Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn Chairman of the Board William T. Sullivan President and Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House New York

AUGER--Miss Diana J.,died at 94 at her Los Altos, California home in the early morning hours of June 10, 2010. A 1939 graduate of Northeastern University School of Law, Miss Auger practiced trademark law in Massachusetts, New York and California and retired from Syntex Corporation of Palo Alto, California in 1988. Her life was distinguished by her expertise in the law and by her memberships in and services to numerous professional and academic groups. She is survived by her brother Donald, his wife Ruth, their two daughters and the daughter of her late sister Barbara. Miss Auger, formerly of 60 Sutton Place South, will be buried with her parents in Everett, Massachusetts. Memorials in her name may be made to: The Diana J. Auger Scholarship, Northeastern University School of Law, Attn: Chris Nicholson, 400 Huntington Avenue, Boston, Massachusetts 02115.

LANDER--Dorothy (Schulein), born October 8, 1921 in New York City, died June 16, 2010 of a stroke. Daughter of Solomon and Edna (Rosenshine) Schulein, wife (50+ years) of (late) Hon. Benjamin Lander, Dorothy graduated from Ethical Culture and Duke University. Since 1968, she taught English to immigrants via English In Action. She attended Art Students League of New York and volunteered or contributed to many educational, environmental, artistic, social, and spiritual organizations. Loved by family and friends, she was an independent, intelligent, intuitive, empathic and vital woman, active until passing. An avid swimmer, she enjoyed theater, opera, concerts, museums, and poetry. She is survived by sister Joan Schulein Lipkin, Nancy (Robert) Schulein, 13 nieces and nephews, Kern family, and many friends. A gathering will be held July 11. Contributions in her name to The English-Speaking Union of the U.S. For more info, 212-818-1200 or EIA@ESUUS.Org.

An article last Sunday about the ways in which states are trying to control the cost of their pension plans described a pension cap in Illinois incorrectly. The cap applies to the annual salary upon which pensions will be based (for employees hired after Jan. 1, 2011, the cap is $106,800, indexed for inflation). The pension itself will not be capped at that amount.
'I got a little bit tired.' JOHN ISNER,

PORCINO--Vera, on June 19, 2010. Beloved wife of the late Santi Porcino; survived by her children Jill and Peter, daughter-in-law Susan, grandchildren Peter and Julia, brother Jack, sisters-in-law Jean and Natalie and many nieces, nephews and cousins. Vera was a modern dancer, but ballroom became her love and vocation. She taught thousands the beauty and intricacy of the fox trot, the cha cha, the rumba, the samba, the tango. Her grace, personal charm and resilience affected all. She will be missed. Donations can be made to Cavalry Hospice, Bronx, NY. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

CONRAD--Esther F. (Nollman), died Friday, May 14 in Ann Arbor MI. Married for 60 years to Bob Conrad ( August 14, 1919 - February 18, 2010). Esther was a beloved wife, mother, sister, aunt, and friend. She is survived by her son Fred and daughter-in-law Elizabeth Brooks (of Ann Arbor) and son Dan and daughter-in-law Sarah Wilcox (of San Francisco), grandchildren Allison and Jeffrey of Ann Arbor, and Paul and Ted of San Francisco. She is also survived by her sister-in-law, Mildred Nollman of Foxborough MA, eight nieces and nephews, and their families. Esther Nollman was born in Boston MA June 2, 1921. She was predeceased by her two older brothers Bernard and Harris, and sister-in-law Ruth. She was known throughout her life as "Red" because of her beautiful red hair. Esther graduated from Boston Latin School, and earned a bachelor's degree from Boston Teachers' College and certificate in retail from Simmons College in Boston. She began her professional life as a buyer for the Boston-based department store Filene's. She married Robert Conrad in 1950, and moved to New York City. Esther began a second career as a teacher of young children in the late 1950s, teaching for approximately 20 years at Downtown Community School and the Corlears School. For the next 15 years, she taught learning disabled adults at the Para-Educator Center at New York University where she derived great satisfaction from helping her students learn to live independently. She was much loved by her students and colleagues in both parts of her career. Esther loved music, theater, and travel, and the Boston Red Sox. She was devoted to her husband, her two sons, and their families. She will be remembered for her warm and lively dinner parties and especially the much-anticipated Thanksgiving dinners she and Bob hosted. She will also be remembered for her kindness. A long illness claimed Esther shortly after the death of Bob; she truly will be missed by everyone who knew her. Memorial contributions in Esther Conrad's name may be made to the Boston Symphony Orchestra's Youth and Education Fund, c/o Sabrina Karpe, Friends of the BSO, 301 Massachusetts Ave., Boston MA 02115.

''They don't call it Dead Horse Bay for nothing,'' said Jarad Astin, walking across the bottle-strewn beach in flip-flops with a seine net over his shoulder. We were there for BioBlitz , a 24-hour survey of Jamaica Bay on June 11 and 12 by scientists, professors, amateur naturalists and families. The goal of the field study, sponsored by Brooklyn College and the National Park Service, was to collect and identify as many species of animal, plant and marine life as possible. Our group, one of many working throughout the area, was attempting an accurate assessment of marine creatures, but at the beach of Dead Horse Bay, near Gerritsen Inlet, all we saw were discarded wine, juice and syrup bottles, mugs, film reels and other assorted trash.

City shorts have arrived as a fashion force for the young. And not just for weekends. That revives the question of appropriateness. Obviously they're not serious business dress. For young men, it's mainly the evenings, although a few brave guys wear them with jackets and ties, an idea that never took off in the mid-1950s. The return of the hot pants of 1970, worn with high heels, recalls '40s pin-up girls. They're now worn for day as well as for clubs. Wide-legged, knee-length shorts are seen as equivalent to short, above-the-knee skirts for the office. It'll take a couple of seasons to sort out how shorts fit in with all city lifestyles.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''In Soccer, When a Star Falls, It May Be a Great Acting Job,'' June 21: Many people question and theorize about the lack of interest in soccer in the United States. Look no further than this article.

STROMPF--Robert Herman. Died in Connecticut on June 20 at age 84. Adored husband of Jane Noveck Siegel Strompf. Beloved father of Richard (Inge) and Steven (Sharon) Strompf, and dear step-father of Andy (Robin) and Fred (Ilene) Siegel. Grandfather of Phillip and Rachel Strompf and Adam and Hayley Siegel. He was much loved and will be missed beyond measure. Donations can be made in Bob's memory to the Lustgarten Foundation.

WILSON--Ann. The Nightingale-Bamford School expresses its profound sadness over the passing of Ann Wilson. Miss Wilson was a faithful alumna from the Class of 1949 and one of our longest-serving faculty members, devoting over 50 years of her life to our school. Her ability to capture the essence of girls was unparalleled, and the delight in reading and writing that she encouraged in her students inspired us all. Miss Wilson's legacy is in the lives of hundreds of Nightingale women whom she taught. A memorial service will be held at Nightingale in the fall. Nina Joukowsky Koprulu '79, Board President Dorothy A. Hutcheson, Head of School

OGDEN--Peter Kinnear, 92, passed away on May 31, 2010. Peter was a gifted architect, a private, wise and graceful man, with a wonderful sense of humor. From boyhood to college, Peter spent summers at Camp Pasquaney in Hebron, NH. He said that it was here that he learned the values that he carried with him through his life. There began his love for the mountains of the Northeast, where he skied and fly fished well into his 80's. His love of fly fishing took him to his beloved Three Rivers Ranch in Idaho, where he and wife Emily fished the Snake River for almost 20 years. He graduated from Yale School of Architecture in 1941, and in the 1950s he started his own firm in Greenwich, CT. He designed and built over 250 homes, and a variety of other buildings from Art Galleries, to a Firehouse in Tarrytown, NY. For Peter, architecture was a pairing of simple, elegant design, with the needs of his clients. His brilliance at siting a building was nothing short of genius. His family and friends will miss this man who skied with grace, fished with ardor, designed with vision and had a good laugh along the way.
Art Randy Kennedy

Tunneling through Hallmundarhraun, Iceland, MAY 26, 2010 Therese Madden, third from left, in Viogelmir, a lava tube cave in Iceland. Ms. Madden, 37, a radio producer based in Philadelphia, was led there by Icelandic friends of her in-laws. Her in-laws chose Iceland because they had been in touch with an Icelandic exchange student they hosted in the early 1980s. That family returned the favor, acting as tour guides for this trip. ''We would never have found this cave. It was in a field of volcanic rocks. It got smaller and smaller as you walked down. It was cold and icy and just kept getting smaller and smaller. But it did feel pretty huge when you looked up.'' As told to Monica Drake.

BLOCK--Bernice Rocker, March 12, 1919 to June 17, 2010. Bernice Rocker Block, "Bonnie", 91, died peacefully in Oakland, CA after a stroke, surrounded by her family. Eldest daughter of Louis P Rocker and Matilda V Rocker. Married first to Manuel Stapen MD, and divorced in 1963. Married to Frederick H Block JD, until his death in 1994. Bonnie leaves her loving daughter Anita Stapen and son-in-law Richard Granberg, and loving grandchildren Rachel and David Granberg of Piedmont, CA, and Richard's son Leif Granberg of Oakland, CA; her late beloved daughter Nancy Stapen and son-in-law Ronald Lyberger and grandchildren Sarah and Julia Lyberger of Brookline, MA; loving step-children Elizabeth Block of London, UK and Fred Block (Carole Joffe), of Berkeley, CA and step-grandchildren Miriam and Judith Joffe-Block. She is also survived by her loving sister, Rhoda Rocker Dreifus of New Rochelle, NY, and late siblings Ruth Lloyd and Edwin Rocker, as well as nephews and a niece. Bonnie was a life-long New Yorker--a vivacious, elegant and charming woman. A graduate of the Fieldston School and Vassar College, she served in the Women's Auxiliary Army Core (WAAC) in WWII. She was an active volunteer in many organizations including the Child Study Association, the Ethical Culture Fieldston Schools, and the Jewish Foundation for the Education of Women (JFEW). Bonnie loved the opera, ballet, symphony, classical fine art, and literature. She was a wonderful hostess and cook, with a large circle of friends, especially the "Tuesday Lunch Girls". A year ago, she moved to CA to be near her daughter. She will be remembered by all who knew her as a strong, optimistic person who lived life to the fullest. She was loved by many and she will be missed. A private memorial is planned. Contact astapen@earthlink.net for more information. Donations may be made to JFEW, www.jfew.org, or Hadassah, www.hadassah.org.

Q.My husband and I would like to take five days to see Salzburg and Vienna this fall. We'd take in the Mozart component, but not just that. Any ideas? Estelle K. Kane,New YorkA.Salzburg, birthplace of Mozart, which sits on the banks of the Salzach River against a mountain backdrop, is known for its architectural grandeur. The city has palaces and castles, including the Hohensalzburg fortress, which offers great views of the Baroque Old Town and the surrounding Alps. Stroll around the pedestrian-only Old Town, a Unesco World Heritage site on the left bank of the river; its main street, Getreidegasse, is dotted with 17th- and 18th-century houses (Mozart was born at No. 9). Next, you can enjoy the outdoor cafes on Mozartplatz and the outdoor performances on Residenzplatz. Salzburg Panorama Tours (panoramatours.at) offers various excursions, including the city tour ''On the Traces of Mozart''; the four-hour ''Sound of Music'' tour to the Lake District and to places where that beloved film was shot; or the ''Eagle's Nest Tour,'' which takes you to Berchtesgaden and Obersalzberg in Bavaria, where Hitler and his inner circle had a vacation retreat.

An article last Sunday about the lawyer Gloria Allred referred incorrectly at one point to Thane Rosenbaum, a novelist and Fordham University law professor. It should have read ''Mr. Rosenbaum,'' not ''Mr. Thane.'' The article also misstated part of the name of the publication for which Emily Bazelon, a senior editor at Slate.com, was once an editor. It is the Yale Law Journal, not the Yale Law Review.

KING--Nancy McLennan, born May 3, 1942 in Minneapolis, MN; died June 21, 2010 in Palo Alto, CA. Raised in San Francisco and a long term New York City resident, she was equally enamored of both the Bay Area and the streets of New York. Educated at Stanford University, including a junior year in Florence, she loved art and appreciated other cultures. Her nose was never far from a book or a copy of The New York Times. Her bright smile and generous spirit were contagious. Long time teacher and school administrator, she was widely admired and loved by her colleagues and students alike. Devoted mother of Gregory and Gavin, sister of Jim, Jane and Tom and grandmother to Caroline, Charlie and Marshall, Nancy always smiled at the end of her grandchildren's songs. In lieu of flowers, please donate gifts in her memory to the Dr. Charles E. McLennan Scholarship Fund at the Stanford University School of Medicine, PO Box 20466, Stanford, CA 94309.

KASSEL--Terry Sonkin, 64, died June 12 at her home in Chapel Hill, North Carolina after a short illness. Terry was a pioneer in the field of Sports Marketing, having held the position of Senior Vice President at Major League Baseball for 16 years. Later, she formed her own marketing firm, Kassel Marketing, with MLB as one of her clients, in addition to the LPGA, the America's Cup, and the National Hockey League. She graduated from Walnut Hills High School in Cincinnati, Ohio, attended Syracuse University, and graduated from the University of Cincinnati. She is survived by her husband, Dr. Robert Silverman; her children: Beth Kassel, Coral Gables, FL; Matt and Caroline Kassel, Stamford, CT; and Patty and Dan Schwab, Harrisburg, PA; her brother and sister-in-law, Dr. David and Anna Sonkin; and her adoring grandchildren, Madison, Alexa, and Sammy Schwab and Benjamin and Sydney Kassel, who will lovingly remember her as "Bia."

Q.I am trying to plan a trip with my husband this fall to celebrate our five-year wedding anniversary. We are looking at about a week or so. Emily Silverthorn,PhiladelphiaA.To help narrow the infinite options available, ask yourself the following questions: What kind of experience do you want - do you want to explore a city, relax by the beach, experience nature, or a combination of the above?

WINDMAN--Arnold L. Arnold Windman, a nationally known consulting engineer who designed the systems for some of New York City's and the nation's most iconic buildings and a loving husband and father of eight, died in Hilton Head, SC, last weekend at the age of 83. Over a forty-plus-year career, Arnold was a partner, president, vice chairman and chief engineer at Syska & Hennessy, New York City, one of the country's largest consulting engineering firms. During his tenure, the firm designed the systems for some of the country's most important buildings projects: the United Nation's Building; numerous state and private university projects; the expansion of Rockefeller Center; the New York State Office Building and Mall in Albany; major terminals at JFK and LAX; and Lincoln Center and the Kennedy Center. Arnold was lead-partner on The National Gallery in Washington, DC; The Jacob Javits Convention Center in NYC; major expansions of New York Hospital and Mount Sinai; The U.S. Air Force Academy in Colorado Springs and the American Hospital in Paris. He also oversaw the firm's expansion and growth from approximately 80 engineers in two offices to more than 600 in eight offices. Arnold was the national president of the American Council of Consulting Engineers (ACEC), the organization that represents 5,300 consulting engineering firm. He also led the formation of the American Tort Reform Association, Washington, DC, the only national organization dedicated exclusively to tort and liability reform through public education and the enactment of legislation. As an engineering student at the end of World War II, Arnold worked with a New York-based team of scientists that were part of the "Manhattan Project" which developed the atomic bomb. He graduated with honors in mechanical engineering from the City College of New York and was a member of the engineering honors society: Tau Beta Phi. After retiring, Pat and Arnold moved from Briarcliff Manor, NY, to Hilton Head, SC, where Arnold was an active member of the Sea Pines Board, the Sea Pines Forest Preserve and other planning groups. For several years, he was also active in the Democratic Party on Hilton Head. Arnold is survived by his wife, Pat, and seven children: Richard Windman; William Campbell, Marjorie Oxman, JoAnn Skolar, Sean Campbell, Colleen Campbell and Kevin Campbell; and grandchildren: Ian and Jay Oxman; Spencer Windman Campbell; Riley Campbell, Harper Campbell and Madison Campbell. A memorial service will be held Friday, June 25th at 4pm at the Island Funeral Home on Hilton Head Island. A second memorial service will be held in New York City later this summer.

HARRIS--Vivian. Advocate for ill and disabled children. Vivian Harris, a prominent philanthropist and community leader who was a founder of Ronald McDonald House New York, and served as its President for 26 years, building it into the world's largest "home away from home" for children with cancer and their families, died June 23, 2010 at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. She died of natural causes following a long illness, said her daughter, Ellyn, who owns a music public relations firm. Born and raised in Manhattan, Ms. Harris was married to Victor Harris, whose family owned company, Bruno, NY, was the sole distributor of RCA & Whirlpool products in the tri-state area. Having earned a bachelor's degree in Child Psychology from New York University, she became known as one the city's most tireless advocates for sick and disabled children, and served on the boards of several prominent children's health organizations. In 1978, a friend asked Ms. Harris to help open a Ronald McDonald House then a fledgling operation with only one facility in Philadelphia in New York; she was initially reluctant, as she was already heavily involved with several other charities, including Handicapped Scouting Program of the Boy Scouts of America. Eventually, she agreed to volunteer on a very limited basis. What began as a temporary, part-time volunteer job soon turned into the driving force of Ms. Harris's life, and she became President of the House in 1979. The original New York City House was located on East 86th Street and had 24 guest rooms; Ms. Harris spearheaded the expansion of the House to its present location on East 73rd Street, which serves 84 families, and is now the largest Ronald McDonald House in the world. During her tenure, she expanded the Board of Directors to include some of the most influential and successful business leaders in New York, including investors Kenneth Langone and Stanley Shopkorn, and Randel Falco, former Chairman and CEO of America Online. In 1994, Ms. Harris launched "Skate with the Greats" an annual fundraising event with the New York Rangers, through which she befriended Rangers legend Rod Gilbert and his wife, Judy, who became avid supporters of the House. Mr. Gilbert said, "Vivian was a good friend and a very special lady. She made everybody Brian Leetch and I, and all the Rangers realize that we could help make a difference in these kids' lives. She had immense passion and tremendous grace. Judy and I will miss her very much, and our prayers are with her family." While Ms. Harris' role as a fundraiser and administrator helped the Ronald McDonald House of New York to expand and thrive, for the children and families who have stayed there, Ms. Harris will be remembered for how much she cared about their emotional well-being and happiness. Her mission was to make sure that the children were always treated, as she said, "as kids first, and kids with cancer second," which became the mantra of the House. Additionally, Ms. Harris was on the Board of Directors and Trustee of the Boy Scouts of America, where she was also Chair of Scouting for Children with Disabilities, a program that she expanded from 2,500 members to over 19,000. Her work on behalf of ill and disabled children earned Ms. Harris numerous awards and honors, including a Citation of Merit from Mayor Edward Koch for "Educating the Public About Handicapped Children" in 1980' Social Conscience Award from the Karen Horney Psychiatric Clinic, the organization's highest award, in 1976; Golden Torch Award from the National Boy Scout Committee in 1981; and a Silver Beaver Award from the Boy Scouts of America in 1980. She is survived by her brother, Robert Sloane, of Florida; her son, Jerry Harris, of Lloyd Harbor, New York; her daughter, Ellyn Harris Wallin, of Manhattan; and her grandson, Kevin Rudolf, of Los Angeles.

Because of an editing error, the 36 Hours column on June 13, about Brussels, referred imprecisely to the time it takes to travel between Brussels and Paris by train. It takes about an hour and 20 minutes, not just an hour. The column also misspelled the name of a Belgian cherry-flavored beer. It is kriek, not kreik.

Ford's 1976 presidential campaign before joining Xerox Corporation as a Sales Executive in Chicago and Washington, DC until her retirement. Karen is survived by two brothers: Terry P. Murphy of New York City and Michael F. Murphy of Idaho; a nephew Jacob "Jake" Murphy of Alaska along with cousins. We all will miss our dearly beloved Karen. In lieu of flowers, donations in her name can be made to the Humane Society at 2100 L St. NW, Washington, DC 20037.

Admirers of the chef Pierre Koffmann have been waiting since 2003, when his much-loved London restaurant La Tante Claire -- which once made its home in Chelsea, then moved to the Berkeley Hotel in Knightsbridge -- closed. They have been waiting for Mr. Koffmann to find a property and get back behind the stove. They've been waiting for him to stop teasing with consulting gigs and pop-up restaurants.

RICHARD AVEDON once told Ruth Ansel that if you did one good picture a year, that was enough. As an art director of Harper's Bazaar in the 1960s, The New York Times Magazine in the '70s and Vanity Fair in the '80s, she did far more than that. ''Hall of Femmes: Ruth Ansel,'' a new book by the Swedish design duo Hjarta Smarta, explores her extraordinary career as the first female art director in all three of those posts, and the iconic imagery she produced. Like the February 1965 cover of Bazaar (far left), which featured a close-up of Steve McQueen, his smiling face framed by the diamond bangles on a woman's arm. ''If we had used Cary Grant,'' she notes in the book, ''it would have been less of a surprise.'' Nowadays, Ms. Ansel runs her own design studio and has just completed a book on the photographer Jerry Schatzberg, which will be published by Rizzoli this fall. As for magazines, she has taken a ''timeout'' from looking at them. ''Back then we believed style and artistry, and originality made for good business,'' she said. ''We were all about surprises on the covers. Today, there is not enough time or money for that. What a great opportunity for someone willing to think out of the box. Hello, iPad!''
Film Neil Genzlinger

A Collecting article last Sunday about Alfa Romeo's centennial misidentified the 1938 event in which Alfa racecars finished first and second. It was the Mille Miglia in Italy, not the 24 Hours of Le Mans in France. The article also misidentified, in some copies, an organization headed by an expert on the cars and it misspelled his surname. Brewster Thackeray, not Thackery, is president of the Alfa Romeo Owners Club-U.S.A., not chairman of the Alfa Century 2010 convention.

It is called the European Grand Prix, but the race that takes place this weekend on the street circuit through the Juan Carlos I Marina in Valencia, on the Mediterranean coast of Spain, is actually another Spanish Grand Prix, the second of the year after the one in Barcelona on May 9. This is the one that is trying to cash in on the cachet of the most illustrious of them all, Monaco. It takes place in Spain's third-largest city -- where paella was invented, by the way -- with yachts, clean beaches and interesting cultural attractions like the City of Arts and Sciences.

HARRIS--Vivian S. We, children and families who were and are privileged to call Ronald McDonald House New York home while undergoing cancer therapy in New York City, are saddened to learn of the loss of our friend and inspirer of hope, Vivian Harris. She embodied the high ideals necessary for all to embrace when battling cancer: positivity, strength and commitment. Our sincere condolences are extended to her entire family. In Sympathy, The Families and Children of Ronald McDonald House New York

OLIVIA JUDSON Yeasts are fungi -- so they are related to mushrooms. And fungi are, strangely, quite close relations of ours. Or at least, they are more closely related to animals than they are to plants. Like animals, they digest their food -- though fungi do it not by swallowing, but by releasing chemicals into the environment. The chemicals break down the food -- like rotting wood -- into smaller molecules, and the fungus then imports these smaller molecules into its cells. Sometimes this takes on sinister dimensions. For example, if you are a nematode worm crawling through the soil, you may get stuck in a sticky web. But in this web there is no spider. The web itself is alive: it is not made of silk, but of the filaments of a fungus. The web itself will digest you. Other fungi set snares -- they produce rings of cells that swell up when a worm passes through, catching it round the middle. The fungus then digests the worm at its leisure.

If you think it is teenagers who are primarily guilty of sending text messages while driving, think again. According to a new poll from the Pew Internet and American Life Project, adults are more likely to have performed this behind-the-wheel juggling act, as well as talking on cellphones from the driver's seat.

HARRIS--Vivian. The Department of Pediatrics at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center deeply mourns the passing of Vivian Harris, former president of the Ronald McDonald House of New York City. Mrs. Harris was an extraordinary individual who devoted her life to the welfare of children. She served as President of this "home away from home" for children with cancer and their families for over 26 years, and in so doing, provided the means by which hundreds of children afflicted with a cancer diagnosis could achieve the best cancer care possible. As a partner with the Department of Pediatrics of MSKCC, she strove to provide the most appropriate and nurturing atmosphere possible to enable families to come through the cancer experience with minimal impact on the family unit. She was a strong advocate for the role of the family in the ultimate health and well-being of young patients. The "home" Vivian created, both in proximity and supportive services with our staff, allowed children and families to receive comprehensive cancer treatment they might otherwise have had to forego. Our robust program in ambulatory care, designed to significantly curtail the time children spend in hospital, was largely enabled by her drive to meet the needs of children and families in treatment. Mrs. Harris was beloved by the Board of Directors and staff of the Home, her colleagues at MSKCC, and the patients and families she served. Her personal style and good humor brought smiles and relief to the dozens in her care on a daily basis. Our condolences to her children, Jerry and Ellyn, her grandson Kevin Rudolf, and brother Robert Sloane. She will be deeply missed.

THE NEWS A federal law widely applied in white-collar criminal cases has been used by prosecutors in unconstitutionally vague ways, and only passes muster when aimed at bribes and kickbacks, the Supreme Court ruled. BEHIND THE NEWS The law made it a crime to deprive another of the intangible right of honest services. By reining in the law's scope, the decision threatens to unravel the convictions of Jeffrey K. Skilling of Enron infamy and the media mogul Conrad M. Black and could upend the political corruption case against former Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich of Illinois.

LANSNER--Fay, passed away peacefully at her home on Wednesday, June 23rd at the age of 89. Fay was a leading second generation abstract expressionist artist, and was a vibrant member of the New York City and Hamptons artworld for over 50 years. As co-founder of Women in the Arts in 1971, Fay also played a pivotal role in advancing the acceptance of women's art into the cultural mainstream. She is survived by her loving family: her daughters Gabrielle and Erica Lansner, her grandchildren Maya and Flora Villalobos, her step-granchild Nicholas Taucher, and her sons-in-law Dean Taucher and Eugene Villalobos. Her husband of 50 years, Kermit Lansner, former editor of Newsweek magazine, passed away in May 2000. Her warmth and gracious spirit and her love of color, art, and all things beautiful will stay with us forever. We will miss her dearly.

BETWEEN Chanel's French Riviera resort show and Rodarte's Godard-inspired T-shirts, there's a certain je ne sais quoi in the air. Now comes news that Opening Ceremony, which highlights the wares of a different country each year, has chosen France as its latest focus. To herald it, the shop has released a line of sandals designed in collaboration with the St.-Tropez shoemaker K. Jacques. The limited edition includes five traditional styles (three women's and two men's), reimagined in bright colors and an array of materials. ''We're good at teasing out the lightheartedness of these established brands,'' said Humberto Leon, an owner of Opening Ceremony.

FRUGAL TRAVELER Seth Kugel takes a four-day cruise from Manaus, Brazil, in the Amazon to Porto Velho near the Bolivian border. Seventeen dollars a day buys him breakfast, lunch and dinner, a place to hang his hammock and lots of people to talk to.

For residents of the blue-collar Bywater-Marigny area of New Orleans, access to the Mississippi River has been blocked for years by decaying industrial buildings. But it won't be much longer, thanks in part to R. Allen Eskew, an architect whose firm has been hired to turn a mile and a half of piers and wharves into a riverfront park to open in fall 2011, Step 1 in the nearly $300 million Reinventing the Crescent plan. The park is one of many projects, small and large, growing in the fertile soil around the Mississippi. Amid colorful shotgun houses, tucked away on streets named Piety, Desire and Independence, a wealth of cafes, boutiques and bars offer a calmer alternative to the excesses of the French Quarter, just upriver. HUGH RYAN

TripAdvisor has introduced a new feature that allows its readers to combine advice from their Facebook friends with the reader reviews that the site is known for. When users arrive at the site, they can click on a Facebook icon to create a TripAdvisor account that links with Facebook. Then, when researching a destination, hotel, attraction or restaurant users will now see a list of their friends who have also been to that location in the top, right-hand corner. In order for friends to show up, though, they also have to be users of the TripAdvisor Cities I've Visited application on Facebook. Then, the TripAdvisor Trip Friends feature allows users to message friends for travel advice.

That one resounding, gargantuan ''om'' in Central Park was apparently not enough to persuade the roiling dark clouds and persistent rain to back off. A few umbrellas snapped open as the chant grew louder and more pleading, and some people lifted a plaintive gaze to the sky. Come on, work with us.

WILLIAMS--Samuel Dunstan, 73, died Friday, June 18 after a six month battle with cancer. He was the devoted husband of Susan, and the adoring father of their autistic son Edward. He is also survived by two brothers Thomas of Inverness, CA and Resolvert Waldron Williams of Martha's Vineyard, MA, a nephew and many cousins. Sam grew up in Lawrence, Long Island. He was a long time New Yorker. He attended Lawrence Country Day School, graduated from Groton School '55, where he was a member of the crew and captain of the soccer team, and served as the class agent until his death. He also graduated from Harvard '59, where he was a member of the Freshman Crew and was the President of the Phoenix S.K. Club. He served in the U.S. Army as a member of the National Security Agency. Before beginning his long career in the investment business he worked at his family's company, the I.T. Williams Company, which imported hardwoods from the world over. At the time of his death he was a Senior Managing Director of Carret Asset Management, LLC. In the 1980's he was the Chair of the Building Capital Committee to finish the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York. Sam was a member of The Brook, and since 1966 of The Union Club where he served as a governor from 1971 to 1979. He also served on various committees including the Committee on Candidates of which he was Chair from 1976 to 1979, the House Committee, the Finance Committee, the Art Committee and the Entertainment Committee. He was also a member of The Pilgrims. He was a member of the Saint Nicholas Society of the City of New York for 40 years, and served as President from 2001 to 2004. On Long Island he was a long standing member of the Rockaway Hunting Club, the Lawrence Beach Club and the Cedarhurst Yacht Club. He was a member of The Mill Reef Club in Antigua. He served as the President of the Board of his cooperative apartment building from 2003 to 2010. He also served on the Board of AHRC / NYC Foundation, Inc. since it's inception in 1996. He was an ardent advocate for individuals with developmental disabilities because of his son, Edward. He was an avid sportsman who loved the ocean, sailing, deep powder skiing, squash and tennis. He was a brilliant, sensitive, consummate and elegant gentleman with extraordinary charm, poise and a great smile. He will be missed by many. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions in Sam's memory to The Saint Nicholas Society of the City of NY, 20 West 44th Street, Room 508, New York, NY 10036-6603 or to The Cedarhurst Yacht Club, c/o NMB Books, Inc., PO Box 631, Pomona, NY 10970. A memorial service will be held in September.

Oil making landfall from the leaking deepwater well in the Gulf of Mexico has ranged from scattered tarballs to heavy liquid washing ashore in Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama and Florida. LIGHT Tar balls, small patches of heavy oil or areas of light oiling. MODERATE 1 to 6 foot oil patches scattered along the beach. HEAVY 3 to 6 foot oil patches covering more than half the beach.

JUST as buzz is building around the release of ''Wall Street 2,'' big gold watches have come back into fashion, showing up on the wrists of quite a few editors and stylists. This time around, though, they are decidedly more fun than flash -- gold-plated stainless-steel versions that look like a million bucks with a tan, but are inexpensive enough to bang around all summer. Wear them with silk tops and Dries Van Noten trousers, as the fashion pack does, or a bikini and a Borsalino. Greed is not good. But a little cheap 'n' chic glam never hurts. Clockwise from right: Timex watch, $75 at timex.com; Michael Kors, $250 at Michael Kors; Emporio Armani, $445 at Emporio Armani.

Starting today, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will eliminate dozens of bus lines and cut service on many more as part of its effort to close a budget gap approaching $800 million. The service cuts elicited howls of protests from riders at public hearings, but the agency said it had little choice. Here is a roundup of route closings, and some vital statistics about the city's bus system, which carries more than two million riders a day, twice as many as any other American city. GLOVER--Jane Oughton, (nee Riley) formerly of Locust, NJ passed away surrounded by her family, on Friday, June 25th at the age of 87. She graduated from the School of the Holy Child, Suffern and attended Trinity College in Washington, DC. Jane was predeceased by her husband, William H. Glover, two brothers, James and Robert and a sister, Adelaide Murphy. She was the loving mother of W. Harvey (Marguerite), Jane (Roger) Foss, Peter A. (Claire), Mimi (David) Forer, Lisa G. (Reiner) Boehning, Alice G. (Paul) McKeon and Sara A. (Peter) Tucker; the adored grandmother of 21 grandchildren and thrilled great-grandmother of one great-granddaughter. She dedicated her life to her family, her dear friends and volunteered her time to many causes, from the PTA, to the transportation of troops during WW II. She gave her all to those she loved. Visitation will be held at the Thompson Memorial Home, 310 Broad St., Red Bank, NJ on Wednesday, June 30th, 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial on Thursday, July 1st, 10:00am at Holy Cross RC Church, 30 Ward Ave., Rumson. Interment will follow at Mt. Olivet Cemetery, Middletown. The family requests that memorial donations be made in her memory to The charity of your choice.

Full beards on men make us think of Karl Marx and Santa Claus. At least that's my bipolar reference. But full beards on men in fashion shows just make us giggle. We're so used to seeing smooth, chiseled baby faces on the runway - the Paris spring men's shows have just started - that we immediately wonder if there's a trend or a facial hair subculture that those clever designers are bringing to our attention. Of course, beards have a long history, and are associated with various religions and cultures, and it's really only been since the 1920s in western countries that men have generally preferred to be clean-shaven.

MILLER--Myron, died June 23, 2010 at age 91. Born in Bunker Hill, Kansas, raised in California, he served through World War II in the Pacific as a naval Chief Photographer's Mate. He came to New York in 1952, working as a magazine photographer, doing fashion, advertising, while learning to love life in Manhattan. He served as President of the ASMP, 1981-1982. He loved to ski and to sail, and for years raced an S-Boat on Long Island Sound, winning some silver. Myron had a wonderful enthusiasm for life. He is survived by his wife Effie, his son Roy, daughter-in-law Maureen and grandsons Ryan and Timothy. A memorial service will be held Thursday, July 1st, at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave. at 21st St., 11am-1pm.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending Saturday, June 12th 2010, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

An article last Sunday about the Asian-American pop group Legaci misstated the YouTube video on which the singer Cathy Nguyen declares, ''My nose itches.'' The music video is ''I'm Yours,'' not ''Lucky.''

If there's one rule any resident at 407 Central Park West knows, it's that no dogs are allowed. So when Donald W. Reilly, a former Marine, returned home from the Gulf Coast after Hurricane Katrina in 2005 with a beagle puppy, several of his neighbors were surprised. Several told their co-op board representative, who demanded that his landlord take action. Letters were exchanged, with Mr. Reilly explaining his situation, but nothing happened.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Federer and Nadal: The Best, and Better?'' June 20: There isn't or, rather, there shouldn't be any great mystery in how Roger Federer can be the best while Rafael Nadal is better than he is.

MAWBY--Sonia (Karasik), of New York City, died on Saturday, June 19, 2010 in Norwood, MA. She was predeceased by her longtime companion John Sebastian of Machias, Maine; Survivors include her daughter Marjorie Sonia Didriksson and her husband Jon of Norwood, MA; Former husband Geoffrey K. Mawby and sister Jacqueline Karasik. Funeral services are private.

WELLES--Christopher Jewett. In loving memory of Chris who died June 19, 2010. A resident of Brooklyn Heights, NY, Chris was a distinguished journalist whose work appeared in Life, Harper's, the Saturday Evening Post, New York, Institutional Investor, Corporate Finance, Esquire, [More], The Columbia Journalism Review, The Nation, The Los Angeles Times and Business Week. He also wrote five books including The Elusive Bonanza, The Last Days of the Club, and Conflicts of Interest: Nonprofit Institutions. His work won numerous awards, including several from the Journalism School at the University of Missouri-Columbia, an award for excellence from the John Hancock insurance company, a National Media Award from the American Psychological Association, the Gerald M. Loeb award, the National Magazine Award, and the distinguished achievement award of the Society of American Business Editors and Writers. After taking early retirement in the year 2000 because of incipient Alzheimer's, Chris pursued street photography and put on five shows at the Soho Photo Gallery, a photographer's cooperative. A memorial service will be held at 2pm on July 10th at the First Unitarian Church, 50 Monroe Place, Brooklyn, NY. Donations in lieu of flowers may be sent to the Alzheimer's Association-New York Chapter, 360 Lexington Ave. in New York.

Defining one's home and native land often includes drawing political boundaries, and can become a question of who settled there first. And the rise of Brooklyn from gritty to glamorous has caused natives and transplants alike to draw battle lines.

The West Virginia Secretary of State, Natalie E. Tennant, said Monday that she would not schedule a special election in November to replace Senator Robert C. Byrd, a decision that means Democrats do not have to worry about holding the seat - until 2012.

The Police Department has suspended a sergeant and an officer following the apparent suicide of a prisoner in their custody. Since my update on Friday afternoon, TD1 was upgraded to tropical storm Alex early the following day. It made first landfall on Belize City, Belize as a 50kt tropical storm, tracked northwest across the Yucatan Peninsula, and entered the southern Gulf of Mexico late Sunday night. Toward the end of the trip across the peninsula, it weakened slightly to a Depression, but almost immediately regained tropical storm strength upon entering the warm Gulf waters. At 15Z today, the intensity was 50kts and 989mb.

Many animals build shelters, some of them dazzlingly efficient and complex, but only humans design homes that thoroughly reflect the architecture of their lives, families, work - even their thoughts. The home has been central to human existence since the Paleolithic age: recent archaeological work in Israel has found evidence of domestic order - food preparation here, beds over there - dating from around 100,000 B.C.E.

The sweeping financial regulatory bill does have some benefits for parts of Wall Street. While the banks will face more restrictions, the exchanges potentially stand to win big as a result of new rules on the trading of certain derivative contracts, gaining possibly billions of dollars in new revenue.
An experimental treatment for multiple sclerosis is gaining interest on the Internet, inspiring hope among patients and scorn among skeptics, writes Denise Grady in today's Science Times.

Kaia Kanepi of Estonia, also known as the Tall One from Tallinn, beat Klara Zakopalova, 6-2, 6-4, to continue her great run on grass and advance to the quarterfinals. She won despite serving at only 52 percent, stepping up her return game to beat the Czech, who looked tentative on big points. Kanepi, by contrast, won six of nine break points in a match that was a huge opportunity for both players.

Noah Millman's critique of my column today makes reasonable points about the potential advantages of accepting failure in Afghanistan and simply picking up and leaving. I wish, though, that he'd reckoned a bit more with what I intended to be the thrust of the piece - namely, the fact that what many critics of counterinsurgency keep presenting as an exit strategy (drawing down troop levels and focusing on counterterrorism) might well turn out to be anything but.

Cynthia Rowley's new squid-ink colored Montauk shack, open for the season until October, is nestled between the $99-a-weeknight Memory Motel and Pizza Village. The store, which beckons with a small neon sign that says "shop," features Rowley's flirty summer frocks, brilliantly colored hammocks, books, candles and stylish home accessories. Out back in a second hut, Rowley is hosting a temporary store for Lauren Bush's Feed projects, which sells burlap bags, teddy bears and other items whose proceeds go toward ending global hunger.
