Elena Kagan strode into the Senate hearing on her nomination to the Supreme Court with a broad grin and a bounce in her step, The Associated Press reported. And then she planted herself, stone-faced, before the senators of the Judiciary Committee to hear a Republican rundown of everything that's wrong with her. That criticism was interspersed with praise from Democrats, for whom she could do no wrong.

In a stunning upset, Yen-Hsun Lu defeated Andy Roddick in a prizefight of a match, winning 9-7 in the fifth set. Lleyton Hewitt appeared to be climbing into the driver's seat midway through the fourth set against Novak Djokovic, but he let a few loose errors creep into his normally stingy game and allowed Djokovic to escape with a four-set win. The match was a breakthrough of sorts for Djokovic, who suffered a similar reversal of fortune at Roland Garros, when he let Jurgen Melzer back into the match after leading two-sets-to-love. Melzer won in five, and questions about the Serbian's conditioning, mental toughness, and will to win began to be heard.

ALBANY - Rick A. Lazio, the 52-year-old former congressman from Long Island, is the Republican designee for governor, but he's got an uphill battle in front of him. He is trailing far behind Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, the Democratic nominee, in the polls, and even further behind in fund-raising. And he still faces a challenge from Carl Paladino, a wealthy Buffalo developer who is undertaking a petition drive to get on the ballot. Mr. Lazio is on leave from J. P. Morgan, where he spent several years as a highly paid lobbyist.

Highlights from today's media coverage in The New York Times:

But what about the convicts in the Philippine prison who became viral sensations for their video re-creation of the zombie dance from "Thriller"?

There is a monetary cost to raising a child, as we discussed here last week. There are other costs, too, which we tend not to dwell on when deciding to have a child but which announce themselves starkly when we are deciding not to.

In this week's edition of the Appraisal, we visit some of the dozens of apartment buildings built during the prerecession  boom that are filled with amenities to attract tenants: everything from luxury fitness gyms to wine tastings to complimentary breakfasts. On the whole, many New Yorkers are soaking up these perks. The simplest ones seem to be the most popular - like free coffee and blueberry muffins. But some New Yorkers are working so hard to pay their hefty rents that they can't afford to use all of the amenities they originally anticipated.

Roger Federer played clean, simple tennis in routing Jurgen Melzer in straight sets. At 5-2 up in the first set, Federer had hit only one ball -- a backhand return -- into the net. This includes serves, which means that in seven games, every shot he hit cleared the net.
Congressional negotiators haggling over the fate of financial reform produced a bill that largely retained two Senate provisions likely to benefit small businesses.

Bechamel is a mainstay of French cuisine, often thought of as cream sauce. In fact, the authentic olive oil version is a surprisingly healthful addition to many vegetable dishes.

Last week we discussed spooky action at a distance in Quantum Mechanics. This week we consider a game in which action at a distance is commonplace: chess. Actually, this puzzle is long overdue - it suffered a spooky displacement in time. I had meant to run it in late April or early May during the World Chess Championship in Sofia, Bulgaria, when challenger Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria took on reigning champion Vishwanathan ("Vishy") Anand of India. Like boxing, the world chess championship is decided by a gladiatorial, head-to-head 12-round bout (over 18 days!) between the incumbent champion and a worthy challenger. Chess is a war-game after all!

5:40 p.m. | Updated As reader gonzo points out in Comment #46 below, a more accurate translation of Neuer's original quotation in German would be: "I only watched the shot from Lampard, grabbed the ball quickly and continued to play. If I had looked to the right and left, maybe the referee would have thought about it. Maybe because of that I contributed to the fact that he didn't give the goal." His actual remarks, therefore, suggest that he was not completely certain that the ball had crossed the line -- and only became convinced when he saw the replay in the doping control room after the match.

The search for a new editor for The New York Times Magazine is on. In a memo to the staff on Monday, Bill Keller, the paper's executive editor, announced that Gerry Marzorati will be taking on a new role overseeing new initiatives at The Times. Mr. Marzorati will continue to edit the magazine through the summer as the paper searches for his successor. Mr. Keller said he would consider both internal and external candidates for the position. His note to the staff is below.

A pilot project in graphic arts and a summer camp for teens on the autism spectrum is coming to Wyoming Church in Millburn in September. It will be run by Marcia Sherman, a Millburn resident. Ms. Sherman is married to John O'Neil, a New York Times editor, and they are the parents of James, 14, who has been diagnosed with autism. Mr. O'Neil has has penned lyrics for the album, "Songs of the Spectrum," the "home-grown autism awareness musical project," launched by Mr. O'Neil and other Millburn residents, and performed by the group, SingSOS!. Ms. Sherman's project will be partially funded by The Daniel Jordan Fiddle Foundation, and will follow a Spectra summer camp for autistic teens in Millburn this summer.

( VH1) BEHIND THE MUSIC In October 2008, not long after she became engaged to David Otunga and released her debut album, Jennifer Hudson, left, confronted tragedy when her mother and older brother were found dead inside the home where Ms. Hudson had grown up on the South Side of Chicago. Three days later her 7-year-old nephew was found shot to death in the back seat of an S.U.V. William Balfour, the estranged husband of Ms. Hudson's sister, Julia, was charged with the murders. The conductor of the last W train, which made its final voyage on Friday evening, was a woman named Helen Carames, 32, a second-generation subway worker. Her mother still works in a station booth in Queens; her father retired as a car inspector after 35 years. Family legend has it her great-grandmother sold tickets. Friday at midnight was Ms. Carames's fourth anniversary as a train driver, and she commemorated it by presiding over the death of a subway line she has captained every weekday for a year.

An article on Friday about indications of a revival in initial public offerings misstated the intentions of the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts regarding moving its listing to New York from Amsterdam. The company had set no timetable for that move; thus, it did not postpone it. The article also misstated the year that Sean Glass, one of the founders of Higher One Holdings, which recently held an I.P.O., first discussed the idea for the company with two friends. It was 1999, not 2000.

It has been an eventful 12 months for Tom Watson, from his near victory at last year's British Open to his emotional exit at last week's United States Open. Now is a good time for Watson to give his fans a glimpse into his thinking, his technique and his golf wisdom, and that is the principal ambition of Watson's new, two-disc DVD, ''Lessons of a Lifetime.'' Watson has stored up a lot of instructional advice over the decades, much of it culled from the golfing greats he has known. But this is no quick-fix highlight reel of golf tricks worth trying. That is obviously not Watson's way of doing things. His DVD starts with fundamentals like grip, setup and alignment and takes you through just about everything else you might encounter on the golf course, including a downhill buried lie in a bunker. Some of us might just throw up our hands and declare that ball unplayable, but that obviously is not Watson's way of doing things either.
When you're about to stroke a putt, do you stare down at the ball? Of course you do.
LEVY--Donald R. Missing you every day. Love, Cathy

MILLER--Myron, died June 23, 2010 at age 91. Born in Bunker Hill, Kansas, raised in California, he served through World War II in the Pacific as a naval Chief Photographer's Mate. He came to New York in 1952, working as a magazine photographer, doing fashion, advertising, while learning to love life in Manhattan. He served as President of the ASMP, 1981-1982. He loved to ski and to sail, and for years raced an S-Boat on Long Island Sound, winning some silver. Myron had a wonderful enthusiasm for life. He is survived by his wife Effie, his son Roy, daughter-in-law Maureen and grandsons Ryan and Timothy. A memorial service will be held Thursday, July 1st, at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave. at 21st St., 11am-1pm.

HIGGINS--Anne, 71, of North Scituate, RI, on June 22, 2010 in New York City. A graduate of Manhattanville College, an educator and management trainer, she will be greatly missed by her family and the many friends, colleagues, and students whose lives she touched with her vibrant energy, wide ranging interests, and unfailing generosity. A memorial service and burial will be held at Swan Point Cemetery in Providence, RI, at 12 noon on Friday, July 2.

Can a shuttered magazine find a new life on the iPad? That's what Conde Nast is hoping. On Tuesday, the company announced it would resurrect Gourmet magazine, the celebrated food and travel publication the company discontinued in October, as an iPad application called Gourmet Live.

FEIN--Arnold E.,83, died in Sarasota on June 25, 2010. Survived by his loving wife of 54 years, Shirley Polinsky Fein; children Joel Fein (Patricia Tobin); Tina Debra Fein Dinitz (Rick), and Mitchell Sue Cooper. Grandchildren: Meredith Cooper Mascolo (Matt); Andrew Cooper (Elizabeth); Nathan Pardes Fein Dinitz. Great-grandchild Cooper Gray Mascolo. Funeral service, June 28 1pm at Temple Beth Israel, Longboat Key, Florida.

DULLY--Peter Charles, Sr. died peacefully June 25, 2010 in Englewood, NJ, attended by his loving family including his wife of 45 years, Sidney and his sons Peter Jr. and Christopher. Mr. Dully was born in Englewood on November 25, 1941 and grew up in Tenafly, NJ. He attended Penn State University and was a proud and active member of Sigma Alpha Epsilon. Mr. Dully bought his seat on the New York Stock Exchange in 1966 and retired as a Managing Director at Bear Stearns in 2001, enjoying the competition and camaraderie of the floor throughout his career. He was an avid sportsman and a member of long standing of the Philadelphia Gun Club. Mr. Dully was active in numerous charities and organizations, including the Buttonwood Club of New York City. He was predeceased by his beloved parents Dorothy and Andrew of Tenafly, NJ. Visitation will be held at Barrett Funeral Home in Tenafly on Tuesday, June 29 from 6-9pm and from 9-11am on Wednesday, June 30, with a funeral service to follow. In lieu of flowers, the deceased asks that donations be made to The Reed Academy in Garfield, NJ.
International FAMILY OF ISRAELI SOLDIER

WAGNER--Allen, died peacefully at home on June 27th. Beloved husband of Judith. Devoted father of Maggie, Andrew and Emily. Cherished grandfather of Aria, Bo and AJ. Dear brother of Howard and the late Estelle Tucker. Adored father-in-law of Chelsea and Jay. Services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 12:30pm, Tuesday, June 29th.

HANNA--Archibald Jr.,93, in Hamden, retired Curator of the Western Americana Collection in the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library at Yale, died June 24, 2010. He joined the staff of the Yale University Library in 1949, and in 1952 was appointed Research Associate in the Yale History Department in 1960. He retired from the University in 1981. In 1952 he published his "Bibliography of John Buchan," in 1970 his "Brief History of the Thimble Islands,' and in 1985 "A Mirror for the Nation," a bibliography of early 20th century American Social Fiction. See online memorial at www.wsclancy.com
FELSEN--Esther. Missed, loved and remembered every day. Her loving family, including new great-grandson Oren, named in her memory.

Some people post videos to YouTube and Facebook with the hope that they will go viral. But for many others, the idea of the whole world viewing a personal video is a nightmare. VidMe, a new video site going live on Wednesday, is for the latter group. It lets people share videos privately with only a chosen group of friends; the videos cannot be forwarded or downloaded.

JABLONS--Beverly, died peacefully on June 26, 2010, aged 85, in New York City, surrounded by her family. Adoring mother of Joshua Jablons and Elissa Bernstein. Beloved mother-in-law of Cynthia Green and Matthew Bernstein, loving grandmother of Isabel, Zachary, Anna, Jonah, and Hannah, and cherished aunt of Cara, Stacie, and Daniel. Beverly went to work at 16 and during the 1940's and 50's she was a publicist with Harry Sobel, managing Perry Como, Julius La Rosa and chronicling the heyday of showbiz society in Manhattan. While working, she earned a degree from the State University of New York. An accomplished writer, Beverly published a novel, Dance Time. During a long career she published many articles and short stories, taught journal writing at Friends in Deed, and long served on the boards of Poets & Writers and the National Dance Institute. She was a treasured confidante and caring friend to all who came to know her. Beverly loved reading, dancing, talking, and, most of all, her family. She will be deeply missed by many. A funeral service will be held on Monday, June 28, 2010, at 1:30pm, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, in New York City. Donations in Beverly's memory may be made to the organizations above.

LOS ANGELES -- On the final night of the great reunion weekend, the Yankees recalled the glory years for Joe Torre. There was Derek Jeter at shortstop, Jorge Posada catching and Andy Pettitte on the mound, as special as ever. Mariano Rivera showed up, but his appearance was unexpected. The Yankees scored four runs off Jonathan Broxton in the ninth inning, then escaped with an 8-6 victory in 10 innings over Torre's Dodgers on Sunday when Robinson Cano blasted a two-run homer. It was the second time in four games that the Yankees tied the score in the ninth inning, went ahead in the 10th on a home run, then relied on two innings from Rivera. Rarely do managers bring in their closers in a tie game on the road, but Joe Girardi had Rivera, and with a day off Monday, he knew he could use him for two innings, if needed. Torre does not have the same luxury.

Oscar night belonged to a drama, ''The Hurt Locker,'' but the path to membership in the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences ran through the science fiction genre this year. Among the 135 film artists and executives invited to join, at least nine had credits on the 3-D science fiction epic ''Avatar,'' which was beaten by ''The Hurt Locker'' in the race for best picture.

TRENTON -- Stephen M. Sweeney, the president of the State Senate here, glowered with disgust as he described how one New Jersey town paid out nearly $1 million to four retiring police officers for their unused sick days and vacation time. Mr. Sweeney, a Democrat, also scowled about the estimated $46 billion New Jersey owes in pension contributions and its $58 billion in liabilities to finance retiree health coverage for government employees.

William S. Richardson, who as chief justice of the Hawaii Supreme Court for 16 years was a leading proponent of the rights of native Hawaiians, often relying on ancestral custom rather than Western common law in his decisions, died Monday in Honolulu. He was 90. He died of natural causes, according to a statement by the William S. Richardson School of Law at the University of Hawaii.

In early 2009, Igor and Marko Pusenjak, two brothers originally from Croatia, decided they wanted to build an application for the iPhone that would enable them to make extra money on the side. They set out to build a game that included a rabbit jumping up a screen trying to collect carrots. They soon realized that a collection of doodles they had sketched out to test the game were visually fun. And so Doodle Jump was born.

KRANE--Steven C. With great sadness, the New York State Bar Association mourns the passing of Steven C. Krane, the Association's 104th President. The entire legal profession has lost one of its greatest leaders and finest gentlemen. The consummate lawyer's lawyer, Steve was one of the nation's foremost and widely recognized leaders in the field of legal ethics and professional responsibility, and worked tirelessly throughout his career to promote legal reform. We always will remember Steve's lasting contributions and distinguished record of excellence in his service to the State Bar and to the legal profession.

BECK--Marion, May 24, 1921 to June 26, 2010. She is survived by her daughter, Jill Herman (Jose), her grandchildren Jody, Tracy, and Alexandra, and great-grandchildren, Max, Henri, Hana, and Dylan. Marion was a life long learner and educator. She was a gifted teacher who made learning interesting and challenging for all her students. She was an avid reader, loved music, going to museums, attending the ballet and knitting. Special thanks to Dr. Sara Bradley, Mt. Sinai Hospital, Mt. Sinai Visiting Doctors, and Visiting Nurse Service of NY, hospice care. Our family is grateful to Elaine who cared for Marion for over seven years. Private graveside services. Contributions in her memory can be made to Visiting Nurse Service of New York, Alzheimer's Association or any public school's library.
JABLONS--Beverly. Warm, loving, dear friend. We mourn the loss of our joyous companion whose talent, intelligence and independence have brightened our lives for five decades. Dan and Joanna Rose

To get to the city pool in Brooklyn's Gowanus neighborhood in the 1970s, a swimmer ran a gantlet. The pool sat amid factories and workshops, the streets around it crowded with trucks. Sex workers met clients near the gates, on Douglass Street. Still, clutching towels, local residents in need of a dip knew where to go, a block from the noxious canal, past the handball courts to the Douglass and DeGraw Pool, as it is officially known, in the shadow of a park where heroin addicts lounged.

The reaction was swift when Lavender Magazine, a biweekly for Minneapolis's gay and lesbian community, reported in its current issue that an outspokenly anti-homosexual local pastor attended a support group for people who want to remain chaste despite same-sex attraction. The pastor, Tom Brock, was put on leave from North Minneapolis' Hope Lutheran, pending an investigation. The magazine, meanwhile is embroiled in a journalism ethics debate for sending its reporter undercover into the confidential support group.
SEITTELMAN--Elizabeth. Thank you for your love and generosity. We miss you already. Minna and Mark Seitelman

I can't think of any two athletic achievements that have less in common than a hole in one and an Olympic gold medal. One takes seconds, is launched on a whim and involves some luck, while the other usually represents a lifetime of hard work realized in a superior triumph under unrelenting pressure. But maybe, somewhere in the back of my brain, I wondered if anyone had ever accomplished both in the same year. Until now.

SEITTELMAN--Elizabeth Edith. Devoted and loving daughter of the late Isidore and Jennie Seittelman. Loving sister of Estelle, many caring cousins and friends died June 26th, 2010. She graduated from Hunter College High School; Hunter College B.A. Cum Lauda, Phi Beta Kappa Eta Sigman Honors Society, the Earle prize in Greek; Fordham University M.A.; Ph.D. with two years as Department Assistant. Her honors include Professor Emerita York College; Hall of Fame Hunter College; Scholarship to Columbia University, listings in Who's Who in the East and Who's Who in America. She was a contributing editor to The Classical World for twenty five years. She had numerous publications including a series for the Bicentennial which appeared in The Principal 1976. She loved the theatre, travel and being with family and friends. Services will be held at "The Riverside" Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street at 12pm on Tuesday, June 29th.

LANGER--Saul, age 72, of Pound Ridge, NY and formerly of Katonah, NY died Saturday, June 26, 2010. He was predeceased by his loving wife, Sue. Saul is the loving father of Amy (Dawn) and Joan and devoted grandfather of Steven. He is also survived by Paul and Paula Morgenstein and Larry and Ginette Langer. Service will be graveside on Tuesday, June 29, 2010 at 10:30am at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Contributions in lieu of flowers to the children's charity of your choice

This week's review: Balaboosta, a charming, Middle Eastern trattoria that Einat Admony opened this spring, a full-grown offshoot of her popular West Village falafel joint, Taim. The restaurant is on Mulberry Street, just north of Spring, and sits behind wide glass windows. Trees on the sidewalk act as filters for the streetlight. If you squint, it might be Paris or Boston. It is emphatically New York.

Composition, color, pacing and variety - in addition to news value - are always factored into the choices for the dozen or more Pictures of the Day. And while some shows can't entirely escape the staccato impression left by each individual image, others seem to have an internal rhythm all their own, without respect to the widely varying contexts of the photography. In such shows, the viewer becomes aware of elements that unite the imagery rather than the circumstances that divide it. Try the exercise with the current show. What do you see when you don't quite know what you're looking at?

Tropical Storm Alex has gotten much better organized in the past 24 hours. The convection is becoming centralized and coalescing. Intensity as of 15Z today is 60kts and 982mb. It's very likely that by later today, Alex will become the season's first hurricane. Northern Mexico and the southern tip of Texas up to Baffin Bay are under a Hurricane Warning, and a Tropical Storm Warning extends from Baffin Bay to Port O'Connor.

The news that Chanel opened a pop-up store in St. Tropez last week came as no surprise, given that the French resort town seems to be Karl Lagerfeld's latest obsession. The designer recently showed his new Chanel resort collection there and used the town as the setting for his short film "Remember Now." The shop, in an 18th-century mansion near the Place des Lices, is awash in a Coco-esque palette of black, white, red and beige (along with gorgeously stenciled walls) that match the clothing and accessories for sale. Never mind that the store stocks only the fall ready-to-wear collection; the tile floors and exotic flora in the garden lend plenty of beachy vibes.Chanel in St. Tropez, 25 rue François Sibilli; open from June 23 to Oct. 3, 2010.

At age 102, the renowned Brazilian architect Oscar Niemeyer is still working - and still inspiring. Specifically, he inspired one of his countrymen - Roberto Stern, the president and creative director of the jeweler H. Stern - to bring out a collection of jewelry that was inspired by the maestro's sketches of buildings (including one of Brasilia, Niemeyer's masterpiece), flowers and even the female form. The H. Stern Collection by Oscar Niemeyer, which was created in collaboration with the architect, captures the sketches' light, flowing lines and their general joie de vivre. Niemeyer's sketch for the exuberantly-curved roof of a church in Pampulha, Belo Horizonte, for example, was translated into a pair of white gold and diamond earrings. An almost childlike drawing of a flower became a graceful, delicate bracelet made of what seems like a single, slender ribbon of yellow gold. The jeweler is known for its creative collaborations, like those with Diane von Furstenberg, the Campana brothers and even Disney (on the surreal-luxe "Alice in Wonderland" collection). But was Niemeyer surprised by Roberto Stern's request to turn his architectural sketches into rings and necklaces? Not at all. Stern recalled that the architect said simply, "I want to make beautiful things."

On our short list of people who would look cool taking us to run errands at the Piggly Wiggly, James Earl Jones would have to rank near the top - and Vanessa Redgrave wouldn't be a bad passenger to ride alongside, either. The producers of a coming Broadway production of "Driving Miss Daisy" evidently agree: they have cast Mr. Jones (a Tony Award-winner for "Fences" and "The Great White Hope") and Ms. Redgrave (a Tony winner for "Long Day's Journey Into Night") to star in a new production of Alfred Uhry's Pulitzer Prize-winning play about an Atlanta widow and her chauffeur, press representatives for the show said on Tuesday. The Broadway production of "Driving Miss Daisy" will be directed by David Esbjornson ("The Goat, or Who Is Sylvia?") and presented at the Golden Theater, with preview performances to begin on Oct. 7 and opening night set for Oct. 25. The play was originally presented off Broadway by Playwrights Horizons in a production that starred Dana Ivey and Morgan Freeman, leading to the Academy Award-winning 1989 film adaptation.

Nick Eanet, who joined the Juilliard String Quartet less than a year ago as first violinist, is resigning for health reasons, the group said on Tuesday. Mr. Eanet has "an acute digestive ailment" that makes it difficult for him to take part in the quartet's extensive touring, according to a statement. The condition is not life-threatening, it said. Mr. Eanet will spend next season with the quartet while a replacement is sought. Mr. Eanet had left a position as a concertmaster of the Metropolitan Opera to join the Juilliard, which was founded in 1946. He replaced Joel Smirnoff, who was named president of the Cleveland Institute of Music.

A Caravaggio painting considered to be the most valuable work of art in Ukraine was recovered in Germany, two years after it was stolen from a museum in Odessa, Reuters reported. The painting, called "The Taking of Christ" or "The Kiss of Judas," was made by Caravaggio in the early 17th century, and depicts Jesus and his apostles John and Judas as they are being separated by soldiers. It had belonged to a Russian ambassador to France and a Russian prince before it was turned over to the Odessa museum, where it was stolen in 2008. On Tuesday Anatoly Mogylyov, the interior minister of Ukraine, said in a briefing that the Ukrainian and German police had recovered the painting and detained members of a gang that focuses on high-value thefts who had tried to sell the work in Berlin. A version of the painting is also in the National Gallery of Ireland in Dublin.

There's a new poll out, from Vanity Fair and 60 Minutes, showing that 24 percent of Americans don't think that Barack Obama was born in the United States. On MSNBC last night, Chris Hayes asked me about it, and I tried to suggest that polls like this should be taken with a large grain of salt - both because Americans will happily express all kinds of outlandish opinions to a pollster without necessarily meaning much by them (does almost half the public really believe in U.F.O.s, at least in any serious way? I'm skeptical ...), and because public ignorance is vast and deep enough to account for a good-sized chunk of any apparently-scary fringe opinion. For instance, I suggested that a lot of respondents probably don't know that birthright citizenship is a requirement for the presidency, and that some respondents may not even be aware that Obama's birthplace, Hawaii, is actually one of the 50 states.

Working climate scientists are almost unanimous in their view that the earth is slowly warming up and that human activity, particularly the combustion of fossil fuels, is the primary cause. But beneath that surface unanimity, predictions vary about how much the planet will warm in the future because of rising greenhouse gases. Scientists' best guesses range from mild warming, to which the planet and its people might adapt easily, to temperature increases so extreme that life on earth would be radically altered.

After 120 minutes failed to produce a goal, Paraguay won a penalty shootout, 5-3, to eliminate Japan in Pretoria, South Africa, on Tuesday, and advanced to its first World Cup quarterfinal.It was a game in which the ball spent a lot of time in the penalty area, but paradoxically one with few great chances, as both team's strikers struggled.In the shootout, Paraguay converted all five kicks, but Japan defender Yuichi Komano hit the crossbar to send his team out.Paraguay dominated possession and outshot Japan, and was probably the worthier winner. But on the evidence of this match, the team is going to be a significant underdog to either Spain or Portugal in the next round.

Does your marriage need therapy? If you're like most people, the correct answer may well be yes, but your answer is probably no. In most marriages, one or both partners resist the idea of counseling. Some can't afford it, or find it inconvenient. And many view therapy as a last resort - something only desperate couples need. Only 19 percent of currently married couples have taken part in marriage counseling; a recent study of divorcing couples found that nearly two-thirds never sought counseling before deciding to end the relationship.

GOSS--Mary E. Weber Professor Emerita of the Department of Public Health at the Weill Cornell Medical Center, died unexpectedly at her home on June 23. A pioneering medical sociologist, her 1959 Ph.D. dissertation at Columbia University, under the direction of Professor Robert K. Merton, was an analysis of the organizational roles of physicians. Later published as Physicians in Bureaucracy, her early and influential work helped shape the emerging specialty of medical sociology. It was complemented by her contribution to the 1957 book The Student Physician that described innovative changes to the Comprehensive Care and Teaching Program for fourth-year medical students at Weill Cornell, such as introducing a public health focus on more advanced epidemiologic studies of diseases important to clinicians. As a medical sociologist, often in collaboration with Professor George G. Reader, MD, of Weill Cornell, she subsequently contributed to a wide range of studies on the delivery and effectiveness of medical care that led to her 1972 faculty appointment in the Weill Cornell Department of Public Health. She served a term as Book Review Editor of the American Journal of Sociology, and then was Editor of the Journal of Medical Sociology, now the Journal of Health and Social Behavior, from 1976 to 1978. Along with teaching and administrative responsibilities, her research interests continued until her retirement in 1992. For these and other contributions, she was honored in 2000 with the prestigious Leo G. Reeder Award from the Section of Medical Sociology of the American Sociological Association. Born in Chicago in 1926, she graduated in 1943 from the then Nazareth Academy for Women in LaGrange Park, IL. She then attended the University of Iowa, Iowa City, where in 1947 she received a department honored BA in sociology along with university honors and, in 1948, an MA, also in sociology. Married in 1945 to Albert E. Goss, in 1948 she and he began residency in Amherst, MA where she did fill-in teaching of sociology at Smith College and the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. In January 1951, she entered the Ph.D. program in sociology at Columbia University, in which she was a Gilder Fellow from 1952-1953, and began joint residence in New York City and Amherst. In 1966 she, her surviving husband and young son, Charles A. Goss, entered her long residency in Piscataway, NJ. Charles now resides in Chapel Hill, NC with his wife, Karen, and children Jessica and Derek. Her other immediate survivors comprise her sister, Dorothy Weber Inyard and nephew Gary Inyard of Chicago, brother C. Edward Weber and wife Suzanne, of Milwaukee, and nephews Paul Weber of Spencer, WI and Mark Weber of Eden Prairie MN, and their families. A memorial service will be announced later. Her ashes are consigned to the Weber family plot in the Bohemian National Cemetery in Chicago. Memorializing donations should be made to the Weill Cornell Medical College (please write "Dept. of Public Health in memory of Mary Goss" in the memo line of the check), Office of Development, 1300 York Avenue, Box 123, New York, NY 10065.

OBITUARIES An obituary last Tuesday about the Mexican writer and cultural critic Carlos Monsiváis included an incorrect translation of the title of one of his books. The title, ''Escenas de Pudor y Liviandad,'' means ''Scenes of Modesty and Frivolity'' or ''Scenes of Shame and Frivolity'' -- not ''Scenes of Power and Frivolity.'' (The book itself has not been translated into English.)

(He was in the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am in 2003, 2005 and 2006.)

10 P.M. (13) THE BEACHES OF AGNÈS (2009) In her latest documentary, presented by ''P.O.V.,'' the French filmmaker Agnès Varda, now 82, creates something of a sequel to ''The Gleaners and I.'' That film, which she shot on digital video, made a case for foraging as a way of life. In this film, which Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, called ''similarly glorious and generous,'' Ms. Varda, above, picks ''through the world, close to home and far afield, finding images that please her and give her pause, like her wrinkled hand, the one not holding the camera, that she scrutinizes with rue if no obvious regret.'' The result is an overview of her life, from her youth in Belgium to her association with the French New Wave, her marriage to the director Jacques Demy (''The Umbrellas of Cherbourg'') and the making of her movies. ''It's a remarkable history, rich in comedy and occasionally heartbreaking, filled with wise reflections and strange digressions about the wonders of life,'' Ms. Dargis added. ''It's a life she has come close to perfecting, I think, mostly by keeping her mind as blissfully and enduringly open as her round eyes.'' 8 P.M. (History) 10 WAYS TO KILL BIN LADEN C.I.A. agents, Special Forces soldiers and government officials elaborate on the boldest strategies used so far -- ambush and abduction plots, air strikes and ground assaults -- to try to capture or kill Osama bin Laden.

BRACKENRIDGE--A. Bruce, 79, died on June 27, 2010. He enjoyed a long and eventful career at JP Morgan. He traveled the world, lived for eight years in Europe and, as Head of Administration, oversaw the construction of four major office buildings, including 60 Wall Street. He was deeply involved in the creation of Euroclear. He served on numerous boards, including the Bayer Foreign Investment Corporation, the Parsons School of Design, the Lycee Francais of New York, the Board of Advisors of Doctors without Borders (USA), and the Board of Trustees of seven mutual funds at Merrill Lynch. After his retirement he focused on studying 18th Century history and the Enlightenment. A graduate of Williams College, he was an avid golfer, skier, cyclist and contrarian. His enthusiasm for these activities was passed on to his children and grandchildren. A superb husband and father, he is survived by his wife, Barbara; three children, Martha, Alec and Katie; seven grandchildren and two sisters. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in his name to f.a.c.e.s, a non-profit organization finding a cure for epilepsy and seizures, at 223 East 34th Street, New York, NY 10016 or http://nyufaces.org.

KLAUBER--John, 84, died on Sunday, June 27, 2010 in Connecticut. He is survived by his wife, Roberta, three daughters, Linda, Lisa and Laura, and seven grandchildren. John was a veteran of the U.S. Army and served in the Second Battalion of the 23rd Infantry during WWII. He fought in the "Battle of the Bulge." He received many commendations and was awarded the highest honors as a veteran of the Second World War. John was an avid skier, golfer and world traveler. He retired in 1986 after more than 30 years of working in the textile industry for Schuyer and Co. and Louis Dreyfus. John left an imprint on many people and he will be greatly missed. He was a tremendous personality who focused his life on education, positive energy and showering love on his family. The world lost a soul who added to everyone he met. Services are held today at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., at 12:45pm.

Welsh rarebit (aka Welsh rabbit) is basically a non-Swiss cheese fondue, generally enriched with egg, poured over toast and typically broiled until brown. There are dozens - hundreds - of recipes for Welsh rarebit kicking around, but here is how I made it a couple of weeks ago: two tablespoons each of flour and butter, made into a pale roux; just shy of 3/4 cup beer whisked in to form a sauce, which then simmered very gently for three or four minutes; six ounces roughly grated English cheddar (in this instance the so-called Borough Market cheddar from Whole Foods ); a tablespoon Dijon mustard; a teaspoon Worcestershire sauce; a scant 1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper; and finally a beaten egg, warmed with some of the sauce then returned to the pan to enrich and slightly thicken the dish. To me, that tastes just exactly right, though a lot will depend on your cheese and your beer, of course.

It's easy to forget - given the cold war that sprung up between France and America during the Iraq invasion and all those hundreds of bottles of sublime French wine that were poured down the drain - about the Treaty of Alliance. This was the pact signed in 1778 by Benjamin Franklin, among others, that swore eternal friendship between the two countries and brought France into the Revolutionary War. The American Friends of Versailles was partly founded on these brotherly principles: the president, Catherine Hamilton, is a sworn Francophile who started the group in 1999 after wandering through Versailles (she is a member of the board of Les Amis de Versailles) and finding the Trois Fontaines Bosquet in utter disarray. There, the inspiration to help restore Louis XIV's seat of political power - piece by piece - was born.

The McLaren Mercedes team has been on a campaign since the beginning of the season to show how its two drivers, Lewis Hamilton and Jenson Button, get along like brothers. This is the team, remember, where the greatest rivalry in Formula One history - I think - happened between Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost, in the late 1980s. Well, how things have changed , if we are to believe McLaren's PR department. And actually, there has been little to suggest that at the moment Hamilton and Button are at each other's throats. A couple of weeks ago the team released a video showing the two drivers trying to assemble a car, now they've put out one showing the two drivers looking around trying to find Senna's racing car. Allison Amend is the author of a story collection, "Things That Pass for Love," and a novel, "Stations West."Asking me to blog about music is like asking a parking meter about foreign policy: it may have an opinion, but it won't be worth much. You see, I don't listen to music. O.K., a little bit when jogging, but it's the same 10 songs in the same order that I've listened to on various machines (from yellow sports Walkman, to skipping CD-player, to minidisc player, to Zune - yes, Zune - to iPods) for years.  At the gym I watch reality television (like every  writer, I love "Hoarders"). At home, I listen to NPR.  So there's no way I can impress with obscure Laplandic bands or neologistic sub-genres. Instead, I'd like to share some songs I came across as I was doing research for "Stations West," my novel about Jewish immigrants in Oklahoma in the 19th century. One of the subplots surrounds the construction and subsequent development of the intercontinental railroad.  The railroad was the original information superhighway, bringing mail and newspapers, other cultures and foods to the remote West; railroad songs are the viral videos of the 19th century. Studying them  I learned about attitudes and motivations particular to that time and place. If history is written by the winners, then songs are written by the disenfranchised, and literature is mostly about the latter.

Several years ago, Dr. David Rowlands, a senior lecturer with the Institute of Food, Nutrition and Human Health at Massey University in New Zealand, set out to study the role of protein in recovery from hard exercise. He asked a group of male cyclists to ride intensely until their legs were aching and virtually all of their stored muscle fuel had been depleted. The cyclists then consumed bars and drinks that contained either mostly carbohydrates or both carbohydrates and protein. Then, over the next few days, they completed two sessions of hard intervals. One took place the following morning; the next, two days later.
